[h1]every abnormality has a weakness. the wise manager trains for what they will face.[/h1] lobotomy corporation takes places in a parapsychology research company responsible for supplying energy to a metropolis called the city. you are the manager of the aforementioned facility and your responsibility is the training of your agents and ensuring the production of energy. the energy denoted 'enkephalin/pe boxes' results from the interaction between your agents and eldritch creatures called abnormalities. each abnormality has a work preference and it is your job to discover their preferences to facilitate the efficient energy flow.  [h2]some may fall but their knowledge lives on.[/h2] one of the essential parts of the lobcorp is that your agents are disposable. your main progression comes from the gear you acquire from the abnormalities you work with and the missions you complete that are given to you from your subordinates. another part of the game comes from training your agents your agents gains stats depending on the danger level of the abnormality the damage they receive and how successful their work is(how many pe boxed they produce). you are going to be resetting a lot which also resets the stats of your agents so it takes less priority until you collect enough gear and complete the missions.  lobotomy corporation is a long-winded journey that rewards you with great lore that piques your interest including very memorable characters that are sure to leave a mark on you. it took me about 143 hours to completely finish the game in a blind playthrough and despite the hardships that i had to face i can say with the confidence that every single minute of my playtime was worth it.

a damn good game for people who like difficulty. this game is not easy and will not hold your hand. you simply have to jump in and figure things out (though the wiki is a lot of help :p). for some people the difficulty may be a bit much and that's part of the experience. all you'd have to do is restart from day 1 and you get all the info and gear from before. yes you'll restart however you get to choose safer and easier abnormalities to handle. that's what makes it fun to me. finding a new challenging abnormality and figuring out how it ticks. if it becomes a problem i simply restart and not choose it again. like i said this game is for those who like a challenge and it does not give you mercy. you only get mercy from trial and error and actually learning from it.

lobotomy corporation is an incredibly unique game:   i enjoyed every second of the game and is definitely worth your time. it can be very difficult but getting past those difficulties feel like a major victory. i didn't expect the game to be so captivating in it's gameplay music and story along with the many different abnormalities and problems the game throws at you. it truly is one of the best games i have played in a long time and will stay that way. the mechanics are unique in how you do work and when you suppress the abnormalities when they breach. the music is also very phenomenal!  i highly recommend this game if you like management + horror elements and have a good amount of patience and pain tolerance :d

lobotomy corporation is an anti-capitalist sci-fi horror rougelite + monster management sim. projectmoon calls out the cabin in the woods as a core inspiration and oh god it shows in such a fun way. the game places you in an underground facility where humans experiment on and extract energy from monsters known as ‚Äúabnormalities‚Äù. there‚Äôs over a hundred funky little freaks each with harrowing backstories and super interesting designs. each day you choose from 3 monsters to unlock and you have to figure out how to extract their energy without dying in the process.  the gameplay loop is real good for sure but i couldn‚Äôt actually beat the game. i put 20 hours in and saw that it would apparently take 100 hours to beat and i‚Äôm not that strong-willed lol. i‚Äôm not a speedrunner and i‚Äôm not the kind of guy who looks at really complex puzzles (like the extra stuff in the witness) and goes ‚Äúoh yeah i‚Äôll make 100%-ing that game my life for the next 4+ months‚Äù üòÇ  but despite the length i really did enjoy my time with it! i ended up watching the rest of the game on youtube because i haaaad to see how it ended!! the meta story of the game uses kabbalah and jewish mysticism in the same way neon genesis evangelion used christianity as a basis for its crazy apocalyptic world building. its so creative and engrossing and i wouldn‚Äôt shut up about it for at least a month

how to survive anything*/how to become the taliban (spoiler free)  before you send brave freedom fighters to glorious battle against the infidel (before you start a bad ordeal or open up the cage of a funny aleph or worse) purge the infidel from your own land (kill all clerks with execution bullets) if thou does not have the righteous tool of allah and the infidels gather strength from the blood pray to him (if you don't have execution bullets and a abnormality that escapes after deaths pray to god and hope you can take the domino flood like bigweld) send the weak and vulnerable to sanctum (send all low level employees into a single elevator) gather the mighty and zealous (gather all high level employees in a different elevator maybe with one or two scattered around abnos that are at risk of breaking out and would lead to domino flood) ensure that the infidel does not grow more powerful as you strike them down (make sure that they don't absorb/are immune to certain types of damage split em up into either a seperate strike team or just condemn them to the crying corner where the low levels are) send forth the righteous call for jihad (send one employee to open the door/start the event) engage in prayer to allah and he shall grant his protection to smite the foul agents of shaitan (bullets pierce your employees letting you grant a shield to all of them at once if they're stacked together in an elevator) ensue in glorious battle using all means for the glory of allah he has granted us the mighty caverns and mountains as our shield (use strike force as situation calls whether that be just slowly clearing the facility department by department hit and run or some cheese elevators let you move to dodge attacks the fastest) the weak and fragile should not be forgotten for they shall sow the seeds of allah for tomorrow (keep an eye on the weak/crying corner if they are at risk move up/down the elevator to dodge/run as needed) allah's mighty malƒÅk shall come to the aid of the faithful if they only call and serve allah (use mercenaries liberally farming energy is usually rather simple and safe) allah shall grant victory to those that eternally fight for his glory (lobotomy corp is a hard game and even with a good strategy it could take some tweaking/retries to get it all right. patience is required for many of them never fight face-face unless you have an overwhelming advantage)  *do not let the infidel sneak and lurk where he shall sow his seed of heresy (if the ordeal/abno teleports around and causes meltdowns you do have to split up and cast a wide net) **those who have not properly done the rites of allah shall find themselves broken and bleeding with his absence (actively train your employee's skills don't end the day as soon as you get the energy required. more boxes = more xp)

''what if we took the scp's and made a management game with it?'' from this sentence you can be sure that its gameplay is gonna be hell its controls are simple but managing each abnormality at once becomes so difficult you restart so much you learn to enjoy the pain. but is it really fun? fuck yeah.  its graphics/artstyle is really cute and simple and because its simple it doesnt tire you much you can play long time without your eyes tiring.  as for the story? this game is 50% visual novel and the story is also implemented in every part of the gameplay itself too so yeah its got a big story/lore  and its so well written you endure restarting like 5 in-game days 50+ times each my top retry day record is around 100 for a single day and i assure you im still enjoying this game.

this game took my perfectionism said fuck you ripped it apart ate it and i love this game for that.  you will fail. you will have major loss. this game will not pull punches and its up to you to not fuck it up.  you will reset at certain points in the game. i don't think you could even beat this game first try without looking up a guide. (and you have to reset to get the true ending) but even though it may force you to reset or you might fuck it up it doesnt insult you or say wow you're horrible. it just lets you go again. you will unlock things permanently as you go so when you reset you have them.  your employees will die. abnormalities will break out. shit will hit the fan. its inevitable. after all you must face the fear to build the future.

this game is great and all but this is the type of game where you are almost required to reset to do good in it. when you unlock gear from the abnormalities you work on (excluding e.g.o gifts) you can reset to day 1 with all that gear that you have as well as any permanent upgrades you get from facility upgrades and other particular events i wont mention due to spoilers. the true ending also requires you to fully research every abnormality that isn't made by a patreon backer (they have a circle instead of a square icon on them) which also adds to the difficulty of trying to 100% it. i heavily recommend getting some mods to help with the struggle such as gift chance boost special ego information hpbar stacking recustomization free customization and a few other quality of life mods that make the game way easier to understand as well as giving you more freedom in some of the things that dont impact gameplay. the story is the best part due to its deep world building present throughout the different games and comics/novels the game has.   difficulty: 7/10 replayability: 5/10 fun factor: 6/10 story: 9/10 lots of reading and no voices modability: 6/10 not too much in form of new content but there's tons of apperance and quality of life mods.

you the manager will face a gauntlet of horrors like you've never seen. you will fight you will fail and you will learn.  you will learn to stand up straight in the face of adversity. you'll learn to hold onto your rationality and make the right decisions when needed. you will fight to keep on living against the monsters of the world while striving to be a better person than you were the day before.  you'll step forth with the hope that tomorrow will be better. you'll recognize the loyalty of the faithful. and you'll muster up the courage to protect those who follow you.  you'll stand strong and embrace the past to build the future. you'll face your paralyzing fear to break the cycle that shackles you.  in the end with a smile you'll know that living this life of yours in the name of a fading dream was no mistake.  -a founder of lobotomy corporation

[b]this game will bully you with impossible situations.  restarting from day 1 is necessary.[/b]  a few things carry over each time: the names/details of abnormalities you've fully studied and core suppressions.  without spoilers core suppressions are 1 of 9 boss fights that you will challenge on certain in-game days and these will unlock permanent upgrades and protect a part of your facility from rng.  your strategy will be to in each run learn as much about different abnormalities as you can challenge a core suppression and restart.  the game will get easier and you'll get further into the story because when you're provided with a list of abnormalities to add to your facility each day you will know how to handle them and the lethal combinations the game will try to bait you into.   very good game and story but will drive you crazy.  if you are a perfectionist you will [b]suffer.[/b]   there is no such thing as a perfect run.  the employees you come to care for and raise will be slaughtered by situations you can't foresee or control.   like balancing a bunch of spinning dinner plates once one falls the rest can and will too. the game drills into you the sense of acceptable losses and how you can't save everyone and doing so otherwise is completely mad.  you will waste senseless amounts of time if you try to save everyone and you need to learn to swallow your pride and handle the losses you'll face and recognize when the game is telling you to restart or try a different approach.

this game is very stressful. but that's part of what makes it so good. and if you mess up its not fun. but thats not necessarily a bad thing.  its very much about management but not just numbers you have to memorize each abnormalities info to a t or else you're pretty much ****ed. and that's like 50 at a time.  its incredibly hard. but its also really rewarding once you know what you're doing.  the translation especially for the abnormality texts is really off. its charming but kind of hard to understand whats going on for quite a few of them or maybe i'm just illiterate.  and once the energy cap required for day end increases into the hundreds it can get pretty boring especially on repeat playthroughs which is needed for completion as its a soft-roguelike.  the art style is cute and simple but i kind of wish it was a bit more disturbing or less restrictive for the abnormalities in particular cause the horror isn't really there for most of them at least in my opinion.  the story is really interesting and engaging but it being locked behind tons of incredibly hard challenges is a bit annoying i can imagine its worse for people who aren't too used to management games or extreme difficulty in general.  its good especially for a studios first game. im pretty excited to play the next installment in the universe. but its a bit exhausting to put dozens of hours into a game like this but i realize that's my fault lol.

this game is mentally exhausting and that's fun  but in all seriousness you probably won't finish this game and that's okay. long story short lobotomy corp is an incredibly consistent yet frustrating game of simon says. do exactly this and that and you'll do great but if you deviate even a little forget something time to start over.   the game does a fantastic job of layering rule upon rule that you'll need to integrate into your workflow and it's a lot of fun to manage but it requires 100% of your attention at all times. the challenge is good but it's a pretty extreme challenge after a certain point and i personally decided to give it up around day 30 as i was getting to a point where it took me a dozen or more attempts to progress another day. plot's great characters are great absolutely recommend it if you're willing to put in the work.

i have no clue how to make a new review so i'm editing this one. despite putting over 70 hours into this game and making careful preparations for every day my dumb small brain cant seem to fucking remember fairy festival's fun little quirk. those green bastards have a higher kill count than every abnormality i have combined. 10/10 would forget again.   on a serious note i love this game through hell and back this game has taught me how expendable your little nuggets are and not to be attached even if they were your first nuggets. i myself would reset if even a single agent died but as days passed and time went on i ignored their deaths i did get very frustrated at myself but in the end i simply moved on with the day and replaced them quite instantly. the more departments you open you will inevitably gain more abnormalities and even more employees that means more things to keep track of and even more of your nuggets will die eventually from either a higher class abnormality breaking out or even from your own fuck ups. in the end everyone you see in the facility is expendable able to be replaced easily you may even find yourself in more frustration from losing the aleph gear the agent had. obviously this doesn't apply to every manager here including me but just because i said all this won't stop me from making sure to ensure the safety and longevity of my little nuggets and i hope my fellow managers will do the same. (except the clerks for some god forsaken reason they just looooovvvveee to pick a fight with anything and anyone including world-ending entities that are unable to be logically understood.)  and of course some of you might not want to read all this ***tl;dr - your little nuggets are the very reason you can sit in your office comfortably so treat them well but at the end of the day they are expendable and don't feel so down about losing a few of them. except clerks those guys hate everything and are also suicidal apparently.

this is an exceptional experience that dares to challenge you in ridiculous ways. it is both frustrating and rewarding to play blind. it will literally destroy your mental and physical health. i've left a positive review however i really would not recommend playing this game unless you're an experienced gamer without ahdh who is good at optimization and willing to whip out the wiki after a couple days in.  if you're trying to play this game to prepare for library of ruina but you're a casual gamer give it a whirl on sale for 10-20 in-game days but for your sake watch a story video on youtube for the rest or just read a synopsis. the true ending/epilogue is not possible to do for most gamers for these reasons: [spoiler] - there will be bosses that hard punish you for pausing the game which is a fundamental mechanic for not losing your mind keeping track of all the abnormalities you need to keep in check - you will randomly forget one of the 50 if you break this rule your agent simply dies abnormalities in your massive base - each day will get exponentially longer as you have more agents more facility levels more abnormalities and higher quotas to fulfill and there is no save state/quick save for the game so you could for example lose 2+ hours of work for a single day (multiple times) because of one random screw up you forgot about and have to start it all over with different rng - and all this aside the game is simply just hard. you have to optimize or else you will fall behind. you can start a new run with some things that you've earned but idk who has that kind of time (a complete run will take you 70-100 hours allegedly) [/spoiler]  tldr: wait for sale go in blind (but open up guides and wiki once you feel mentally stressed) and stop and watch youtube / read a synopsis after you hit a wall. unless you're a pro gamer without adhd with months to spare in which case go nuts. its a very interesting experience it just comes at a mental and physical cost irl!

in perseverance there is both agony and triumph. perseverance is the key to lobotomy corporation in both navigating its gameplay and fulfilling your role in its intricate story.  you've probably already learned this from the other reviews but to reiterate: this game is [b][u]hard[/u][/b]. while the first few days may seem like a cakewalk filled with repetitive gameplay you will soon find yourself entangled in a double-layered web of a quickly thickening plot and an ever-expanding facility containing deadlier monsters. the challenges ramp up significantly as you encounter story-relevant boss battles that can push you to the limits of adaptability. this game will slap your carefully planned routine out of your hands and laugh as your employees die horrible deaths as they scramble to suppress monsters that you [u]swear[/u] you were monitoring carefully but weren't. you will even come to find that certain basic game mechanics that you absolutely took for granted have turned out not to be a right but a [i]privilege[/i] (here's looking at you atziluth residents).  the experience can seem punishing and unforgiving. the roguelite mechanic is integral to progressing past seemingly impossible roadblocks. whether you activate the memory repository and rewind to the beginning of a week or restart completely from day 1 your facility and employees will be reverted/wiped but the gear you have bought and information you have learned will remain intact. sometimes the only way to overcome the game's challenges is to reset and return with more experience in mind and better armaments in hand.  personally what pushed me to power through all of the trials and tribulations the game has to offer was its intriguing story. with every cutscene you are left to piece together the past and ruminate on the future lying ahead for everyone involved with the corporation. there is a glimmer of hope hidden underneath all of the chilling depressing and forlorn moments in the plot. the way it ties into the gameplay at times does make you feel that you are facing the fear to build the future (ha ha). your own experiences managing the facility can also end up as entertaining anecdotes; you will certainly find several in other reviews.  lobotomy corporation is certainly not for everyone. it is a game of trial and error of accepting your failure and of persevering in search of the light at the end of the tunnel. those who are not fans of management games may find the basic gameplay loop to be boring. those who hate trial and error may find the virtually-necessary resetting to be tedious and overly grindy. those who dislike stories that are vague and metaphorical may find the plot to be overly convoluted drawn-out or outright confusing. and anyone can be a victim of the game's programming which can be... jank at times (memory leaks are a commonly reported issue). for what it's worth i was able to complete the game with almost no issues but your mileage may vary.  if you're someone who enjoys glory through struggle as well as management games then give lobotomy corporation a whirl (i recommend going in blind). you will likely quickly come to learn whether you love it or hate it.

lobotomy corporation is a game where you have to research and contain more than 100 entities called abnormalities for 50 days. sounds like hell right? don't worry as you have 11 helpers with unique traits and personalities! (they are all depressed). everyday you walk into your favorite office get your cup of coffee and start another day. first you hire new workers to whom you must not get attached in any way upgrade their skills and give them weapons if you have any. then your private managing hell begins. on day 1 you start with a sans undertale head on day 41 you try to stay alive by fighting magical girls. the difficulty  is rising in geometrical progression and it becomes harder and harder to keep everything under control. i would recommend this game to anyone with a healthy nervous system otherwise it will be difficult to stay sane. personally i enjoy this game. it taught me that birds can't be trusted fairy tales are scary and that express train is the fastest way to hell. 10/10

i got baited into playing this game because a friend thought i would love the world that project moon had built after seeing it through limbus company parading it as essential to understanding the basics of what is just korean scp. he was right i did like ip a lot better after this game but i will say full stop that if someone got you into this game cause the pm lore is amazing and you should get into it get off this steam page and go watch a story recap. this game is not worth only the story if you can't get through the gameplay.  the game is a management sim and some give it the title of roguelike because of the mechanic to restart to checkpoints or the whole game with your acquired information. you manage monsters with 4 types of work and occasionally they break out. this work is required because the game is divided into days that need an energy quota from that same work each day. progressively the quota and the risk of the monsters you handle increases. there's a small equipment system and that's it. that's the whole game.  this game at face value is all about information. if you look things up the experience will be spoiled drastically as the mystery of figuring out what you have to deal with be it monster or otherwise is an exhilarating feeling. however playing blind is also grueling because you end up throwing bodies to figure out exactly what you have to deal with or you get blindsided midday and have to reset 30 minutes of progress. people that moan about the difficulty of project moon games are exaggerating but this game isn't easy. the last few hurdles the game puts you through are challenging and many people get stumped at the last stretch. if you know everything that is contained in your facility by all means you have every right to handle anything that the game throws at you.  if you don't enjoy rts games or at least the kind of gameplay that comes with them don't play this game. if you don't want to spend hours upon hours retreading days of progress don't play this game. if you don't like problem solving or strategizing with the bullshit this game sends your way don't play this game. this game is only worth it if you want to personally earn and learn the lore of lobotomy corporation.  for that specific reason this game is definitely worth it or maybe consider it on sale. the few gripes i do have: replaying days is boring and a waste of time once you get far enough and reset it's just speedrunning to the end of each day without the action to action planning you might have done the first time around. the game isn't designed to be beaten in one go and you should know that before you play. things like [spoiler] whitenight and apocalypse bird [/spoiler] are completely optional and can be missed if a player is ignorant or simply skilled/lucky enough. no clue if there should have been things hinting at them or their consequences. [spoiler] the fucking idiots that designed the last two departments need to be fired. [/spoiler]

at 279 hours i have officially completed the game in its entirety.  is this game hard? yes. it is a game about trying essentially to trip up the player. it's a rube-goldberg machine of carefully calculated dick moves. there's an evergrowing list of rules with each abnormality you get: some very simple others frustratingly complicated but there is a list for each. for any rule there is an abnormality with the exact opposite rule: some will punish you on bad results others on bad or neutral. some will punish you on [i]only[/i] neutral some on good or bad results. the game will generously keep track of these rules as you discover them but you are drawn endlessly into the web. you will get comfortable with these rules in time but just as you get comfortable the game will begin to alter the deal and your prayers that it not be altered further will fall on deaf ears. is it hard? you know in being a korean game it reminds me a lot of starcraft and the korean fascination with that: starcraft is desperately hard but if you know what to do and can perfectly execute it it's easy. if you can't well you'll endure. restarting and resetting are major game mechanics without which the game cannot actually be completed (literally it is not possible to complete the game in one run without at least one memory reset).  is it interesting? [i]desperately.[/i] the story told by lobotomy corporation is one i very much enjoy and one that draws you the player in as the participate. there aren't choices to make though; rather the only choices are the ones you come up with to meet the challenges. for the game weaves the story and the difficulty together as you the manager of this strange facility desperately try to comprehend what it is that you are doing here and why.  you will come to love your agents you will suit them up in a variety of colorful equipment and you will send them to their horrible deaths over and over and over. decapitated eaten alive flattened like a pancake ripping off their own head dragged to hell digested by spiders turned *into* an interdimensional spider turning into a giant mushroom turned into a small slime turned into a large slime vaporized pulverized incinerated frozen ground into meat chunks killed by their fellow agents after they lost their minds and had to be put down executed with impunity by the manager... and this is not even nearly close to the many deaths you will see them suffer. you will reset and do it again. the charmingly horrible deaths are a balm of sorts: i remember a desperately frustrating death but watching the individual in question lower themselves into a bath full of blood and grimly deciding i needed to keep going with the day is part of the experience.  this game can be clunky it's not exceptionally polished there are infrequent graphical glitches and a few bugs that i had to go and install mods for (it's not necessary to do so but i wanted to). this game will not be an easy experience but if you are willing to face the fear and build the future you will enjoy it. i think that this game is [u]unrelenting[/u] and absolutely uncompromising but slowly bending it to your will until you stand at the end over a pile of corpses and regrets in bloody triumph is one hell of an experience and one i am so glad i decided to play.  [i]dedicated to hana architecture team captain alongside the other 11 agents killed on day 49. never forgotten.[/i] [i]also dedicated to dia the heretic. gave the ultimate sacrifice too many times.[/i]

one of the best management simulations with a rich story. if you like scp related games you'll love this game. lobotomy corp. also builds the foundation and atmosphere for projectmoon's other titles library of ruina and limbus company. projectmoon goes ham on the lore aspects and soundtrack of the game.  content advisory. this game touches on many dark themes and topics such as suicide/murder/drug use.  pros :   the world projectmoon has created with it's 3 games is nothing short of incredible. multiple story arcs and endings give lobotomy corporation good replay value. well worth the $8.50 usd sale price.  the ost for this game is an absolute banger. whether or not your little homies are getting eviscerated or you're watching a dialogue intermission about how one of your empathetic decisions caused the massacre of everyone in an entire sector the music does an amazing job at setting the tone.  create your little guys and try to keep them alive... i promise you you wont. but then again you can always restart the day... or turn back time... in a world where nothing is seemingly impossible due to monsters(abnormalities) born from the sins of mankind you're always within arm's length of a different possible outcome. however the price is almost always too great.  the monster management is fun and pretty unique. every abnormality has it's do's and don't's. one of them likes peeking out from a keyhole and is a little shy. if you watch him he'll breach and turn your employees into a bloody mist with his sawblades. but if you pan the camera away so he's off-screen he's completely docile. each new subject is rather fascinating in it's own unique way.  strategy is key with management and suppression tactics. the e.g.o equipment researched from abnormalities acts as sort-of a rock-paper-scissors mechanic to exploit weaknesses as well as protecting your little guys. more sectors opens up more perks for employees and containment cells for abnormalities. after later sectors open you'll have access to direct intervention via bullets you can shoot employees and abnormalities with which can buff heal or kill. then there's the rabbit protocol... for when the big f-u is neccesary.  check out the manga wonder lab which ties into the lore of lob corp. trust me they go hard on the lore and this manga is pretty damn good.  also check out the [ limbus company ] official promotion video. the ost track from mili - in hell we live lament feat. kihow from myth and roid goes hard.  oh yeah... the cons : you goan' die.  tldr : yes. 9.5/10

this is my favourite video game.   i love the story the characters and most importantly for a video game - the gameplay. despite its difficulty it's genuinely one of the most fun and addicting games i've played. i wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone that has an interest in challenging games and also in amazing story telling.

truly a masterpiece of a game and wonderful introduction to the project moon mythos. lobotomy corporation is an extremely challenging management simulator with very interesting and extremely addicting gameplay for a management sim there really isn‚Äôt a game like it. besides that however it also boasts a gripping storyline and the amazing world building project moon is known for. easily one of my favorite games ever made.  bonus points if you‚Äôre a fan of the scp foundation if you are their is like a 97% chance you‚Äôll love this game.

i will never bitch about smt 3's difficulty ever again.  lobotomy corp is the game to play when you have nothing going on in your life for a bit. unemployed? play it. friends out of town on your week off? play it. house sitting? wow free house. if you have anything going on your life is happy and you should continue to be without it.  never in a million years though should you feel guilty looking at a guide or wiki for a hint. this games difficulty is unapologetically unfair. i 100% the game myself had i not had someone who previously finished the game twice be willing to get me back to a certain point after losing over a weeks' worth of progress i would've put this game down and never looked back. there's plenty of cool things to experience throughout the game buts its difficulty being as it is i'd call it ultimately as being just short of a masterpiece. the amount of whats there being designed solely to waste your time and piss you off is genuinely unnecessary. i'll say it a million times as a quick side note for the devs going forward taking away the players ability to pause the game or adjust the game speed is not a challenge. its inconvenient more than anything.  some frustrating features aren't even based around playing the day to day game. when you mess up or want to try again you can hit a simple retry button and get all your stuff back you lost at no penalty should you do it. however theres also an option to go back in time a couple of days in case you really got stuck. for whatever reason using this option in order to try again will punish you but the normal retry wont. if you hit retry then on the prep screen proceed to go back in time a couple days anyways no punishment occurs. so i ask why does it matter what screen you hit memory deposit on? one punishes you but the other doesn't i'd like consistency.   occasionally too glitches occur. there's not many and most you'll encounter are simply visual hiccups that aren't too distracting such the game text switching to korean for a single very specific screen. the one's that are a bit a more irritating to get put you in bad situation. examples of this include: -characters being put to sleep but an entity known as void dream have a chance of just not being able to be interacted with. meaning because the character is still bearing the uncontrollable status ailment proceeding to the next day will count as them being killed. -end game bosses messing up when transitioning to their final phases and just being softlocked. taking no damage not moving you're just stuck at the final hurdle. -using skill points in increments of 60+ (yes you will do that in this games economy) occasionally have the tendency to just not give you the buffs after spending them   should you hit any of these pitfalls yourself and put the game down i do recommend at least looking up the story online. if theres anything this game absolutely crushes its the writing. sound design is a good second. i wouldn't say its worth stomaching the difficulty for alone but hey its by far the most entertaining thing here. there are completion rewards of course though anyone whose finished the game will tell you completion is practically the only way to really finish it.  final verdict: 6/10 tldr this game sucks but in a i'm finishing it because i'm not a bitch way.  still here? you've likely finished the game and are looking at reviews for the memes god bless you sir.  -the clerks don't have rights -gift this game to a friend you love to see getting annoyed -gebura is just a red haired version of 2b from neir. -beating this game has gotten me one step closer to playing limbus company and seeing the majesty that is don quixote and i couldn't be happier. -this game got my brother interested in reading classic literature. -i got a certain white themed abnormality to spawn at 2am right before going bed and wanted to slam my head into a wall -i was tricked into thinking this game gave you a stupid good job certificate when you beat it and i feel robbed.

lets start off by saying that this is a pretty niche game and is definitely not for everyone. if you want a casual game to play without too much worry this is definitely not it. this is one of those games where you get better at the game from failing over and over again and learning from the failures.  the best way i can describe this game is... do you remember that laboratory from stranger things? where they discover monsters ghosts and supernatural beings and then they experiment on them? yeah this is that. you play as a manager and you manage your employees by placing them in a cell with a supernatural being called anomalies. you place them in a cell and pray to god that the monster is in a good enough mood so they don't either rip your employees head from their shoulders make your employee kill themselves or make your employee kill others.   every monster has a catch or gimmick that you have to discover and then follow in order to keep your employees safe and make it to the next day (level). every day you get a new monster so the real trick is to juggle as many gimmicks as you can so you can make it to the next day without any casualties.   there is definitely a learning curve and it is true that the game gets easier the more runs you do. definitely pick it up if you like puzzles and don't mind a little cartoon horror

be prepared to be setback and to fail numerous times - perhaps even to be forced to restart in order to keep progressing. take what you've learnt and accomplished to aid you in order to reach the end.  only once you've reached the end you may see and feel as i now do.

lobotomy corporation is very unique in the fact that it can stress out frustrate and throw the player into despair in many different ways. however this game was an amazing experience in nearly every aspect for me. the many different abnormalities of the game at various different stages meant your facility was constantly changing to adapt to the newcomers as you progressed through the game as well as the missions you are given throughout each department plus the story. god the story of this game is phenomenal and keeps you going through the struggles of each day each restart and definitely rewards you throughout. in my opinion lobotomy corporation is 100% worth the money and your time.  tl:dr - great story great mechanics and i love gebura.

challenging game.  the controls are not the best story line is superb each element seems individualized and well thought out.  artwork/style is perfect for this kind of game at this price level.  the horror elements are horrifying while keeping game play non-punishing.  this game is based off of the scp/cabin in the woods/friday the 13th the series genre of horror.  each new in game day brings a different threat which must be handled while dealing with all previous threats... expect mass casualties all the time just like in the scp cartoon or beaker being blown up every sketch in the muppets.  you will get every one of your scientists killed and be hitting the redo button a lot but not in a way that impedes game play or fun.

disclaimer: i've installed a couple mods a bunch to iron out some issues i had and 2 to make it a little easier this game fucking rules it is meant for a pretty specific kind of person one who likes probing around in the dark with a flimsy stick while if you fuck up that stick bites your hand off crashes your game only doesn't bite when you stare directly at it makes you draw straws to see who gets sacrificed installs a waiting land mine *somewhere* that you have to shoot at or sometimes the easy answer of everyone dies and learning what is biting you doesn't make it better when your interests sometimes make you have to risk a chomp also the writing / story is great and the art for some of the monsters is downright ghoulish and terrifying with others being just a puppy :) this game definitely needs mods to a degree namely detailed info optimization as well as no annoying deaths if you're a coward like me (with a bunch of others that make it a bit less annoying) but it is truly an experience i've never seen in anything else i'm glad i stuck with it despite the initial complexity

what a good game. there's a lot of things i liked about this game. its soundtracks story game mechanics abnormalities and so on.  it was a difficult game that required a lot of trial and error and as someone who aspire to be a completionist i despise the thought of even a death occurring to one of my agents. something less than s rank is disgusting tho people can play with their own playstyle.  i definitely wouldn't recommend if you hate repetition because you need to repeat a day a lot. but if you know more it would be easier. it wasn't all good and sunshine because there were some days that made me suffer again and again and i made a grave mistake that needs me to restart all over again. thank goodness there are mods.   in short it was a game that made me learn true despair and insanity as you see victory within your grasp only for it to disappear over and over again.

if you're familiar with scp foundation then this is a different take on it. though here instead of escaping a compromised facility we're playing the manager and command agents around to perform work (end result being energy production for which we have meet the quota every day). as you can imagine this kind of operation can go horribly wrong in many ways...and oh boy it sure does. every single abnormality is dangerous in some way and it gets ever crazier with each new day as our department expands getting new additions. we can either go through trial end error to get necessary research on each subject to manage them properly or try to check the wiki online although that doesn't guarantee escaping dire consequences of sometimes merely having some abnormalities in the facility. to make things more tense we will be attacked by random abnormalities just entering the facility on daily basis so we will have to focus on more than our own containment chambers. i presume it's part of the appeal that we will face a lot of failure will have to restart a day or whole 5-day period to perhaps select more manageable abnormalities. i can tell we can either focus on our agents to keep them high level and well equipped or just keep hiring new lambs to slaughter in containment chamber as in the end produced energy is all that matters (or does it?). even though things roll out very slowly and consistently it will become overwhelming for someone not very into this idea of management sim and certainly feel grindy given we are always doing the same thing but more with extra strings and chances of things going apocalyptic attached each time.   i haven't made it that far myself given as it turned it's a bit too much for me but there is some truly deep lore in here. story is certainly a great focus in here and upon looking it up i have no doubts about it. between each day we have visual-novel style of dialogue with various ai's helping in the facility always keeping the creepy and uncertain tone of this entire operation. it sure is to keep the player on their toes at all times.  sadly i can't say more given it's not as for me as i thought but if it seems it might be for you i say go try it. i can totally see what it's going for and it's very much well done - a beautiful apocalyptic mess for a gameplay and grant mystery to unravel for a story. on perhaps a plus side there are no achievements so nothing to worry to be stressed over if it affects anyone.

i've never enjoyed a game that wants you to suffer so much until this came along. if you can get past the management + roguelite gameplay it is definitely worth the torture you get put through. can be a slow start but when you realise what's really happening it can be difficult to not invest time into. project moon makes great lore with the backstory of each character as well as the various abnormalities you face on a run to run basis. it doesn't get much better than picking one up that completely screws your facility as you just sit and watch hell unfold. i can't wait to finish this so i can move onto lor.  p.s. second warning is an absolute banger of a track why is this in a management sim?
this game made me religious

definitely in the top 10 for games to ruin your mental health with  this game offers a very particular gameplay experience that some people are going to love and some people are going to hate. you will need patience in spades if you hope to get far and you very likely won't clear the game in your very first run. i think the best advice i can offer is something i heard in a youtube review of the game; don't spoil yourself on any of the story but spoil yourself mechanically. learn as much as you can about potential additions to your facility & the incoming challenges so you don't get blindsided. seeing the story to its conclusion is worth every struggle

lob corp the game that sent me down the pm rabbit hole that ultimately made me pm's personal little bitch and further proved that a toxic relationship would be my undoing because i cannot peel myself away from this game as it infiltrates every passing thought i ever had. exposure to this game will corrode your very mind.  lobotomy corporation is a cute little management simulation made by a handful of students spare change and a dream. as it says on the tin you manage monsters keep them happy* and stop them from breaching. with every passing day you learn a little more about the world that project moon has beautifully expanded and its denizens every character and abnormality has a story to tell. just as you think you have it all figured out boom more story and possibly murder**  !!!  just a little warning to all future lob corp players  !!! 1. you cannot complete everything in your first run of the game but worry not resetting to day one keeps all your mission progress and collected items and research it took me many a day 1 reset to get what i needed done 2. daily resets are your best friend when it comes to learning with how to handle a new dangerous creature you sacrifice some people acquire knowledge scribble it down or commit it to memory and restart the day. you will lose research progress but you get your little lambs back and you have your actual knowledge to fill in those gaps. there are a lot of factors that can be taken into account with handling abnormalities so there is no shame in restarting the day 3. read project moon fans are well known for their inability to read i can confirm that this is true for i am illiterate. this game has a massive story*** and it's all very charming but reading the information presented to you will help you fulfill your duties as a manager. better get to exercising that brain of yours my friend it's your greatest weapon in this game.  misc. bongbong**** will reign supreme there is nothing there headpat malkuth it's mandatory  *warning not all monsters like being happy **murder is not the end ***story can easily be ignored but don't call the game bad if you're skipping all the dialogue ****name: bongbong | front hair style: 11 | back hair style: 11 0 red 0 green 255 blue | basic/panic/dead eyes: 31/4/1 | basic/combat/panic eyebrows: 7/7/5 | basic/combat mouth: 5/7

in lobotomy corporation you have the privilege of spending 100+ hours undergoing prolonged mental torture illegal in 87 countries in exchange for an introductory course on jewish kabbalah and also feeling like the biggest gamer in the world (because if you're playing project moon games you are). yesod is my babygirl

i played this game after i finished library of ruina. i think this is important to mention since after finishing lor as one of my favourite games i was coming into this one hella biased and you'll get bit of that in this review. i should also mention that in the time of writing this review i did not finish this game yet however after 90 hours i feel qualified to share my thoughts.   you play as a power plant manager. you probably heard about solar powerplants hydroelectric power plants nuclear power plants... well here you make power from monsters called abnormalities. you also get few very friendly and not weird at all ais to help you with your task. it's hard to not compare the story to lor so i'll compae it. i think i have issue here because i played lor 1st. i find it very sad that you only get a very little about anything that is happening outside the facility. i beleive this is only because i already knew how amazing the outside word is and maybe it wouldn't even cross my mind without that knowledge. while youi dont get much about the world you get to know all the ais working in lob corp quite well. all of them are very very lovable (especially my boy netzach i love him so much). i was already familiar all of them before playing this game however seeing ther story here brought them much more depth.  the gameplay is simple yet complacated. simple becuase all you do is pick an employee and assign them work. the complicated part comes from managing a large number of abnormalities at the tame time. it's easy to remember that you can't send employee to work with a specific abnormality since they don't have effectiove armor againts it's attacks however you might just overlook it if at the same time you must... oh i don't know pick up tickets every 2 minutes be carefull to not send this guy to work since he is sparkling a bit not hold that item for over 30 seconds find and shoot different abnormality since the work you assigned few minutes ago did not end up well checking how many of the random-ass npcs died so you can prepare for a meatball to murder your entire department and do all that while listening to that fucking fetus cry... ugh sorry got carried away a bit there. fortunetly the game does not throw all that at you at the same time your day norrmally starts with you choosing a new abnormality. this means the game gives you day to learn the quirks of the new abnormality so you are used to it the next day where you are learning about the new abnormality for that day. what i can complain about a bit is the tool days. the days where you find tool abnormality are basically just like the day before except you'll send one person to use do tool most likely die reset the day and do the same thing just without dying. after that i ended up not using 90% of the tools after getting the max research on them. but there is a thing that is more boring that tool days those are the days where you... don't get anything. you play the last day again without even the minimum of researching the tool you got. hoever you can normally do this quite fast and get back to researching new fun abnormalities. once in a while the game will throw some challenges called core supression at you and man... those are dufficult. i'm writing this after attempting binah core supression for a while and well it was so hard i decided to restart from day one. however even restarting from day 1 won't fully reset your progress since you keep all the ego (weapons and armor) as well as permanent upgrades and abnormality research. this means that even if you get stuck you don't have to feel bad if you need to reset to try and get to the same point with better gear (and knowledge).  in the end i don't think i can do anything else but reccomend this game. if you don't enjoy the managing simulatro gameplay you probably won't like it but if you do this is the peak.   also the music goes hard.

day 1: religion. day 12: [redacted] is cute! day 24: i take that back. day 29: there's nothing there to worry about. day 36: legs undertale? day 44: i am no longer a god. day 49: am i having a heart attack? day 50: *flips table*  i'm going to put this out front if you don't like grindy/monotonous games don't get this game. the 'retry day' button will be your best and closest friend right next to 'memory repository.' if you don't grind for the gear the levels and to complete missions you're going to have a rough time.   most of the tutorial is 'do this and only this' but it's good for people who don't have a clue as to what they're doing. all the extra information can be found in the manual alongside some sweet sweet lore. such as the reason the clerks carry a handgun of which they're told is for self defense but they'll learn it's use when the time comes. (;  however i encourage those who have friends who have played the game before teach them the basics outside of the tutorial levels. i have taught some new players over discord it's time efficient and less confusing.  the story is in my opinion the best part of this game. they have explanations for nearly everything including why everything looks cute and cartoony. the characters and their development is fantastic and satisfying as they talk about their backstory and you learn about their personalities. the fact that most of the abnormalities and the story itself is based off of various books and literature.  unbeknownst to many this game is for those who enjoy improvement through failure and the roller coaster of emotions that comes with. and trust me i mean it when i say that. one day in the game will be peaceful no abnormality breaches no agent deaths and man you got all the easy ordeals! then the next day you get a funny looking thing you can have your agents work with. it hasn't done anything all day and you decide well seems harmless. there's only 86 seconds left to fill out it's log so let's just get that out of the way while i train my agents. then your ai's are spamming you with reports all you can hear is wind and static and as you sit in your silly little manager's room everything on fire around you you check the last bit of the log that was just filled out... past 90 seconds of work the employee dies and all breach counters are reduced to 0. it is at this point you close the window and sit there as everything burns. an occasional hello? is heard in the vast reaches of your facility as you smile and sit in silence. the lights go out frames drop to 0 and your hot ai secretary comes in to tell you once again that you're a failure of a manager. yet for some ungodly reason you manage the strength to hit esc and then slap the 'retry day' button once again.   it is at this moment you will realize you love this game. all of it's horrible auto pathing the micromanaging of your agents in a fight the neutral music and gloriously anticipated moment second trumpet drops. you'll smile laugh cry and feel like you're having a heart attack on day 49 like all the other fans of the game. and maybe you'll find yourself repeating the process over and over again like me.  tldr; hot ai manager juicy lore/character development time travel frames drop to 0 lots of death da capo al fine.

really fun game. i heard people describe it a lot as being unfair unforgiving hating the player etc. and that stuff kind of made me think it sounded like it'd be unfun for the sake of being tough but actually... most things happen for reasons you can play around avoid or be on the lookout for and the ability to restart a day with what you've learned really makes it feel like learning the game rather than just being destroyed again and again for no reason.  plus there are a good handful of different things to motivate gameplay and interacting with things out of your comfort zone which i appreciate. abnormality gifts add some priority to try and get your workers interacting with more than just whoever's easy to access and deal with and the ability to train a worker's stats by using the related work method means there's incentive to have workers do things you know another would already be good at.  if you have any sliver of interest in this game i'd say pick it up and try it out. this is the type of game that makes me remember why i enjoy games. it's a good experience. i know i only have 10 hours and i haven't even reached the midgame but i've really enjoyed every moment spent with this game so far so i can easily say i recommend it.

[h1]what in the world did i just play and why did it work?[/h1] 82 hours to get the true ending in this roguelite management rng-fest (yes that's the summary you're gonna get). in short:  the good: story worldbuilding gameplay boss fights (in a management game hell yeah)  the neutral: music grind  the bad: rng  [b]story[/b]  without the story this game wouldn't be nearly as good as it is. but puzzling together what happened in a lab in the outskirts and why that relates to gaining energy from monstrous creatures called abnormalities while assisted by humanlike ai called sephirot (all with their own personality and problems) is very enjoyable. the story is given in bits and pieces out of chronological order and altogether vaguely which leads to a rather intriguing task of figuring out what went/is going on.  [b]gameplay[/b]  the gameplay sounds rather simple. you have employees who you can send to work with abnormalities to obtain energy to fill the daily quota. depending on the employee the abnormality the type of work and rng you will produce more or less energy and the abnormality will or will not get more unhappy. if an abnormality is fully unhappy bad things happen ranging from employee deaths due to abnormality breakout to... more deaths usually. the interesting part is that after working with a number of abnormalities a meltdown occurs. either it puts a qliphot meltdown on some random abnormalities which can be removed by working with them but makes them unhappy if left unattended or it spawns an ordeal in your facility forcing combat. combat due to ordeals or escaped abnormalities can go from simply sending in a blob of high-level employees to micromanaging to avoid attacks depending on the threat you're up against. all in all the gameplay loop is nicely put together.  [b]boss fights[/b]  there are no story spoilers here but i wanted to tag it anyways. [spoiler]boss fights also known as sephirot meltdowns introduce a gimmick for a day and reward you with a buff if you beat them. they are varied and a nice breakup of the regular gameplay loop and several of them are quite challenging (especially the final boss gauntlet).[/spoiler]   [b]music[/b]  although it's nothing special the music is fitting and doesn't disturb the other elements of the game.  [b]grind[/b]  yes it's one of those. you level up employees by working with abnormalities and in principle days are infinite. you almost have to level agents further than you would just by reaching the quota since later boss fights require a bunch of high level employees to deal with everything going on at the same time. furthermore to get true ending you need to have seen every abnormality and filled out their entire bio. this'll take at least two full runs likely three since rng isn't in your favour and your first run isn't likely to get all the way to the end if you're unprepared.  [b]rng[/b]  oh boy rng. the energy you get from working which abnormalities you get which ordeal you get where the ordeals spawn what abnormalities get a qliphot meltdown this game is jam-packed with rng and at several occasions good or bad rng is the difference between succeeding and having to retry the day (i'm looking at you queen of hatred!). especially bosses can be highly dependant on a role of the dice with a wrong role almost forfeiting the attempt.  [b]conclusion[/b]  story is good gameplay is good until you get to the third run and start to prepare/(grind) for the final boss gauntlet. it's rewarding to complete though and the story makes most of it worth it.

tl;dr: we love lobotomy corporation  this game is truly an experience. before i say anything else i just want to say this was a wild ride and i'm impressed with what i got vs. what i expected.  so this was my first micromanagement game and i really didn't know the suffering i was in for. this game really packs a punch with it's difficulty especially towards the end of the game. that being said the game simply presents itself as is and the player is left to adapt to it and by the time i had played the game a couple dozen hours i truly felt much more competent at the game.  i also really liked the idea of resetting being integral to gameplay because it really teaches you to appreciate the overall picture more. i wish that the game urged players to do this more because this is not a common feature amongst games. one of friends actually quit after getting all the way to day 47 because he had never really known why using the memory repostiroy feature was useful choosing to instead start from day 1 any time he wasn't satisfied with where he game was going.  that being saidi have a few qualms about gameplay with the main one being that 2x speed is the maximum setting for core gameplay. around 20hrs in i gave in to just getting a 5x speed mod so i could avoid grindy parts such as using the memory repository feature to discover new abnormalities. there are also some things in the game that irk me someone like a certain minion of an abnormality that likes to grab you and one-shot your employees when it revives every once in a while (you'll know it when you see it). or enemies having ridiculous attacks that are near-unavoidable. or a certain someone limiting your use of the speedup button..   regardless once you tough through it all you feel that much better about winning and that's what counts.  overall: 8/10

in short: story and lore of this game are amazing. not simple convoluted even i would say but great if you give it a thought. one of the best universes i dived into. gameplay though is extremely hard grindy controls and ui are also pretty bad. the overall expreience is weird since it's pretty unique and absolutely fantastic if you'll get engaged with the story but otherwise - is utterly terrible and seems like a torture. but for me as i've said before - it's one of the best universes i dived into.  now for the long story: as a person who likes story-rich games with lots of lore to get into this is one of the best games (series of games) i ever played. i love the story and characters a lot. you can even dive into philosophy and think about life society and developing as a person.  gameplay-wise it is pretty bad honestly. ui is pretty convoluted while game mechanics are very simple yet they require you to memorize a lot of stuff. control over the characters is disasterously inconvenient - you quite often need them to stay at an exact place but you can only tell them to go to the specific room not place. in some(many) cases this micro-control is very needed but unavailable. also the game is very-very grindy and no matter how much you grind it is still extremely difficult. like really over the top difficult. you will save-scam a lot and it is designed this way by the devs.  surprisingly though if you will manage to overcome all those difficulties and will do it all by yourself (i honestly didn't have the nerve) you will feel so much in character with the story and this is one of the coolest feelings i had with any game. this experience is very unique and makes you so engaged with the story. once you get past that point - you are a most likely a fan of the project moon universe.  the game is not for everyone though. the story is very difficult to understand and leaves you deep in thoughts a lot by the end of the game. if you like this type of experience: when you have to deserve your happy-ending and especially if you like to think about the story philosophy and lore a lot - you will like the game just give it some time to tell you major stuff. because at the start you don't really get much important info (you don't know enough to understand it in the beginning). if you just can't stand the gameplay you can drop the gameplay and just watch story videos on yt. i don't recommend doing it though because you will lose that specific and unique feeling of deserving you victory and being in-sync with the main protagonist. otherwise if you expect engaging gameplay with lots of action well-though strategy or a simple story - this game is not for you at all you will get disappointed.  p.s. if you liked this one you should look for it's sequel - library of ruina. there is also some small nice videos on pm official youtube channel and you can also find some official comics somewhere else.

finally the scp foundation game you were waiting for!  as a manager of an anomalies (monsters) containment site it is your job (actually your agents you command them) to study understand contain and... use them. if everything goes well you will complete your day with no worries... but things never go as smoothly as you expect.  sometimes those anomalies produce effects that you weren't expecting for... a safe anomaly suddenly had a darker side that just killed some of your best agents... or maybe that city-eating monster just escaped its chambers. it is your job to find ways to contain them manager!  story-wise the game is pretty good too. it is engaging enough so you keep going back for more about the corporation and the world it exists in.  if you want to play something different i strongly recommend it. just remember it is not easy! this game hates you and you will hate it too. but you will love it in the end.  (pro-tip: after playing some days i strongly recommend downloading the mod that shows how much exp each employee is receiving in their work. you can find it at nexus it is called  ‚Äúmore detailed info‚Äù.)

lobotomy corporation gives what i personally would call an accurate experience of managing an scp containment facility. whether that is a positive or negative really depends on your personal preference - it can be quite stressful especially when you have a lot of needy anomalies in your facility.  but since the game is a roguelite killing a run because you aren't having fun is a completely valid choice and is even rewarded since you retain all of the equipment you have earned so far as well as the information on anomalies you've already researched. you are also able to just rewind to the beginning of the day so that you can retry a section if you had too many losses or to the last checkpoint which you get every five days and let you keep all the research and new equipment that you earned.  the biggest con in my opinion is that the translations are somewhat lackluster at times and can feed you false information. (if you know any mods that can fix those translation errors feel free to tell me)
this game is incredible! well-crafted lore decent gameplay loop that has enough variety to keep you on your toes but not melt your brain with complexity and very high replay value.

ballbustingly hard and at times reminiscent of what must be the mental mindscape of a schizophrenic full-dosing lsd after spending a couple minutes staring at the wikipedia entry for the kabbalah this game is a chaotic and wild ass ride. however it's also a crucial hazing ritual that one must undertake in order to dive into psychotic world that project moon has cultivated in library of ruina and limbus company.  despite the constant complaints of (albeit justified) difficulty and jank levied against it lobotomy corporation was one of those very few titles that reminded me that video games can be more than derivative formula garbage. ironic because it runs like ass despite its looks even on the latest hardware a lot of the core mechanics are only sort of obliquely elaborated upon in the manager's manual and the spikes in difficulty are extremely sudden and seemingly impossibly vertical.  however if you man up and stick it through the rough spots you'll be rewarded with a genuinely unique and memorable experience. this game is the ultimate manifestation of the expression trial and error and as such if you're capable of inner monologue it'll lead you into a deep rabbit hole of experimentation laced with equal amounts of frustration balanced out by the inevitable elation you experience when you finally get a bead on keeping an aleph-level abormality content. it's invoked and kindled a sense of wonderment and curiosity that i genuinely haven't felt for a game since i was a child.  if you actually manage to make it through all the way 'til the end you'll also probably unironically have developed an increased sense of situational awareness multi-tasking and a renewed triumphant spirit to replace the despair-ridden husk that once inhabited your soul. the lessons learned from this unhinged and debauched journey will stick with you long after you've closed the game leaving you with a newfound appreciation for the resilience of the human spirit in the face of seemingly insurmountable challenges. it's a testament to the power of perseverance and the beauty of breaking through barriers despite the chaotic cacophony of suffering that might surround you. also a did nothing wrong.

lobotomy corp is a fantastic story wrapped in a game that tries very hard to apply its themes and logic to gameplay. many of the gameplay features are explained in-world over time and there's very few glaring issues with the plot (though you might need to do a little bit of digging to really piece it all together.)  unfortunately the gameplay is not very polished. the game is difficult but often this difficulty is through tedium and pestering rather than actual challenge which takes away from the experience. there are a lot of very poor design decisions interesting and neat concepts that were not refined into good gameplay and the nature of the game means that the majority of them will continue to be a problem throughout the very lengthy playtime.  regardless the story is good enough that i would recommend consuming it however you can stand. there's mods that take away some of the more tedious aspects of the game and unfortunately much of the exposition is backloaded so unless you have a wealth of patience consider mods or alternative methods to viewing the story over playing the game in its natural state.

gonna keep it blunt with you- this game is tough as balls. you have to micro manage so much to the point the game will crush yours balls and turn it into a smoothie if you forget about one thing. it's also incredibly repetitive to where it will get slightly harder and slightly more difficult each day out of the several you are forced to endure. i also kinda dropped playing it cause it requires a lot of time and it isn't summer yet.  okay so like why is this recommended? cause every other element of this game is amazing. above is the negative aspects of it. for some of the positive aspects:  + story and lore is easy highlight- you will find yourself enjoying reading a lot of it. along with that projectmoon (people who made the game) have two other games that expand on this. + you will find yourself eager to actually learn more about what everything does. more in the start of the game you will find yourself forced to learn the traits of each anomaly you hold but then you will find yourself wanting to instead of feeling forced + music is peak. even though you will 90% hear the same two tracks all the others are amazing such as the warnings. hell buy the soundtrack if you don't have a method of listening to them + art is pretty good and really goes over the top with the crazy shit that happens to your agents. don't be fooled by the fact the people you see in the screenshots above look like gacha characters.  + this game is incredibly unique taking inspiration (or i think so) from scp but takes a different approach to how it's world is built and how the mysterious creatures/objects are conjured origin wise  if you want to know if you should buy this i would say it's a game that takes a lot of dedication for it to shines it's best aspects. if you want a game that you can really get invested into story wise and have the time to do so (check other steam reviews of this game and gauge their amount of hours spent on the game i barely mid way into game) then this is an amazing game for you. if there is one thing this game requires of you it's patience. good game peace.

give it a try. you might not like it it's quite difficult you'll fail a lot and sometimes it's just stress management on steroids (its fun :d). but the narrative and the difficulty of the game kind of go hand in hand - there's something special about reaching the ending having reset 6 full times and losing 90% of all your nuggets xd  but the worldbuilding is really impeccable so if you like reading i highly recommend o7.

the lack of difficulty settings means that you have to play this game expecting that you will game over and need to restart. learning by error and slowly progressing or just having good luck with the entities you unlock. even so it's very fun and i'm a sucker for a good dystopian storyline.   there's a definite learning curve where the game pushes you to follow the logic and morals of this world rather than your own. the goal not being to keep as many people alive as possible but just to finish the day though more living employees will make your job the next day easier of course.   the visual style is cute and simplistic for the main game with beautiful art in occasional cutscenes that show the contrast of the game-like management position and the reality of the facility.   if you have some patience and a desire to unravel sinister secrets this game is definitely worth a try.
day 49.

lobotomy corporation if you like games then buckle up because as another steam review once said: it's a game with all the fun parts removed and god damnit i could not summarise it better.   i hope you like hearing the same 5 notes every single minute because that's what you'll be hearing for 80% of the game.  i hope you like restarting the day over and over because something went horribly wrong and trust me a lot can go wrong really quickly. i hope you like a complete disregard for any ballance whatsover in favour of making you cry and scream.  and above all else... i hope you can cope with the fact that this is somehow fun.  on a more serious note: this game is not for everyone. it's hard it's unfair but you can adapt and find a way through 95% of the time. the story is really nice really messed up too. the artstyle is cute... usually. the ost (except the fucking 5 notes) is really amazing.   being a masochist that played games like rimworld scp:containment breach dark souls and other rage inducing titles i definitely recommend.
