caution: maybe spoilers. i tried my best to avoid any major ones.  there are few games that properly evoke a variety of emotions of me and even fewer than can engross me so deeply that i start to obsess over the next session of play i so desperately wish to do. let me preface this by saying that this game is far from perfect and it has a lot of things that people will find annoying or downright frustrating. but for me that was part of the package of experience it offered and it all fit into place so damn well. for me this is a perfect game suited to my preferences. i was compelled to write this after having spent 142 hours to 100% the game and attain its true ending.  [b]gameplay[/b]: it's a management game but also much more than that. the game punishes tiny mistakes and poor choices of judgement in brutal fashion. the grind in the later parts of the game becomes arduous making each day feel like a marathon. those mishaps suddenly feel like soul-crushing events that make you feel either you have to make an immense sacrifice to proceed or restart the day and accept that you just wasted a bunch of your time. sometimes even rng factors in and decides that your destiny is to fail and there's little you can do but watch on as things spiral out of control. things like this break the will to play for many people and i wholly understand this. it's an unforgiving game. in terms of combat you literally are just a commander that sends units from point a to b. they handle everything else including any special abilities they may possess. you must simply guide them in the direction they need to go. it's a lot more work than it sounds like and at some points the game becomes heavily micro-intensive. rts players will feel at home.  however what this game does is reward you in dividends for keen observation patience and over-preparation. in strategy games i'm the turtle player. i overcompensate my lack of tactical finesse by developing a powerful base and producing a bunch of high quality units. this is what i did in this game. and this strategy was time-consuming and at times it was tedious. but it pays off. oh boy does it pay off. i went into this game 95% blind. i learned things through trial and error. this game while it does have a manual doesn't have an in-depth guide to every other intricacy it possesses. for some people the best option is to browse the web for guides and tips. this is perfectly valid considering the nature of this game. but i think part of what made the experience so memorable and important to me was being constantly beaten down by unknowns in the game only to rise up and conquer them after observing and learning from my mistakes. maybe i'm a bit of a masochist but the feeling of satisfaction you receive when the things you learn help prevail over a trial you struggled to bypass the euphoria is exquisite.  [b]narrative[/b]: this game has an interesting story that is provided through visual novel cutscenes between the days of play. you unlock new cutscenes via simple progression of days and also completing missions assigned to you. for people that dislike reading visual novels or reading in general the narrative will probably be a miss for you. there's a lot of reading to do. even for those that do enjoy those genres the story is a meticulously crafted one where everyone speaks in a certain way that feels like you're always on the verge of philosophising about existence itself. and most of the time that ends up being the case.  personally as a fan of other series that have similarly overtly complicated storytelling (such as girls frontline) this game felt like a natural fit for me. i became so engrossed with the world that they built through the dialogues and the story of the corporation you worked in. they drip-feed you these details that make you crave for more knowledge and some characters become unforgettable with the way they poetically speak about their story and how they are now. lobotomy corporation is very much a story of facing one's fears to build a future that you can walk into. yes the game's slogan is truly relevant at all times. amazing.  and when it all culminated into the ending sequence and the true ending... i shed tears. it was full of surprises. i was shocked but i was also relieved. i was given a victory lap. i was given a sheer spectacle that unfolded before my eyes in a way i didn't know the game was capable of presenting and i was in awe. a truly beautiful way to conclude a game. i pass my thanks onto the current english translators (i'm aware of the horror stories of the initial translators) for allowing me to experience this wonderful tale. and let's not get into the chills i got from those final lines...  [b]design[/b]: this game has a simple style that works pretty well and it even has an in-universe reason for the way it all looks. at first you will be overwhelmed by the ui and wondering what everything does. you slowly start to learn how everything works however and the important things the game will guide you through via the tutorial. you will likely discover new things about the ui as you proceed through the game and it can only help you. it is very much a game that once you become adjusted to the interface everything then becomes second nature to you.  mechanically the game doesn't have many complex base mechanics. you primarily manipulate time and you manipulate your agents. you order your agents to do work fight escaping monsters move to locations etc. this is the majority of your gameplay loop. the variables which change how these function are the abnormalities. every abnormality is unique and has its own set of conditions to take care of it. this changes what work you do when you do it who works on it etc. it's here that the game truly shines in how varied it can become and how many decisions you end up making. the game will tell you most things about the abnormalities as you work on them so you can trial and error before figuring out the correct method of caring for them.  as for the thematic design the game stands out. it has a unique artstyle that differentiates it from other games and every single of the abnormalities are carefully crafted to be exceptionally unique and interesting. every time i grabbed a new one i truly wondered what kind of atrocities it was capable of committing. some designs are unnervingly cute. some are absolute nightmare fuel. some are bizarre beyond our wildest dreams. it's a truly colorful roster of entities and that's not even speaking about the character cast itself. the sephirah each have their own distinct silhouettes and characters. many things in the game take heavy influences from cultures and mythologies such as fairy tales and kabbalah. those that enjoy seeing creative ideas and inspirations flourish eat your heart out.  [b]conclusion[/b]: i don't usually write reviews. i don't consider myself much of a critic (even though i'm probably qualified for it in some ways). everything i wrote here take it as a different perspective when approaching this game. keep it in mind and develop your own impressions. this is a game that resonates with a certain type of person heavily. it isn't for everyone but you can only really determine this by trying it out. and i truly believe the experience everyone else will have will be unique to them depending on their approach.  i felt compelled to write a review for this because it became one of my all-time favorite games. from start to finish and even beyond finishing it has captivated me and captured my heart. to the extent that i know that there will never ever be another lobotomy corporation. never another game that will be perfectly suited to my desires and that would deliver this amazing experience onto me. and that's perfectly fine because i already have it right here.  now time to hope library of ruina will also capture me so deeply.

the game is unfair the difficulty is artificial. you're expected to die to something you couldn't have possibly known beforehand restart and try again. it sounds bad but it's actually satisfying. dying over and over again learning and not repeating your mistakes is the core mechanic of the game. oh this guy does a ton of black damage i better have black resistant armor on whoever is working with him. oh this guy breaks out if i do x but calms down if i do y. that sort of thing.  the story is great i haven't come across anything like it before. i can't really explain any of it without spoiling but i'll just say that it's a wild ride. each of the horror creatures that you manage has their own backstory that slowly unlocks as you learn more about them.  a lot of the ui elements are clunky but you get used to it. you don't have control groups you can't easily see an overview of all of your agents & their status you can't chain commands like telling an agent to move somewhere then work on an abno etc. in order to customize your agent's name and appearance you have to spend an in-game resource (unless you mod that out).  it has some flaws but overall i'd say it's a unique intriguing experience that's worth your money and time.

[b]what worked well:[/b] [list] [*] fantastic world-building. [*] interesting and distinctive creature designs. [*] unique gameplay model that is fun for management fans. [/list]  [b]what could be improved:[/b] [list] [*] some questionable design choices such as requiring spending upgrade points for cosmetic changes. [*] ui can be clunky and unresponsive at times. [*] game starts having major framerate issues when you unlock the middle layer. [/list]  other notes: even after 400 hours i still absolutely love this game but it pretty much requires mods for major qol improvements (do a web search for lobotomy corporation streamer mod pack). for a first time playthrough if you want to experience it vanilla then i would recommend playing up to ~day 26 to experience most of how the game will play out but then install mods to make the experience much more enjoyable.

i recommend these following.  cheat engine for speed hacks.  basemod (prerequisite for the other mods) https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/2 more detailed info https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/47 permanent agents https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/79  cheat engine is a must due to the amount of absolute grind there is in this game on subsequent playthroughs it's not hard it's tedious it's awful and it can take you hours if you're not using cheat engine.  permanent agents i recommend for a similar reason however if you rush the missions you should be fine without it. i specifically recommend doing the dusk ordeal mission as soon as you get it if you choose to go without permanent agents. there is an entire other progression system unlocked by that mission that the game just doesn't tell you about.  lobotomy corporation is a fantastic game until it isn't. once you discover all the mysteries all that's left it to do the missions and progress days which will look like clicking between a few safe anomalies to grind power for 10-30 minutes. which is why you should do your best to progress mission objectives as fast as possible alongside your anomalies since not only do they give you story they give you buffs and once the anomalies are all studied there's not much fun to be found.  back to cheat engine look at my hours look at my hours. probably 20-30 hours of that have been without cheat engine. the rest you can multiply by 5-10. get cheat engine.  edit:  finally some in game help you can complete missions and anomalies and rewind time before it ever happened maintaining progress. meaning if for whatever reason you lost a bunch of people studying something or completing a mission you can rewind time to before it happened keep that progress and get back all those lost troops. the only cost being any stat increases on your guys along with new people you recruited.   the gameplay is needlessly time wasting as i've pointed out before. controlling characters is something you can adjust to but there's no denying it's god awful. likewise combat is terrible. story is great lore is great. can't get much further into it because this game could be ruined by spoilers since mystery is a central point (there is one exception).  a related issue is you could get so hard screwed by the game for just not knowing. to various degrees it's layers of bs to it. the lowest layer being that someone dies to anomaly and you get research this is a central gameplay mechanics you have to send sacrificial pawns. middle layer is someone dies to an anomaly and you get no research/not enough research. there's a couple i give a pass to because their clever but besides that that's just so uninteractive since a lot of the time these kinds of anomalies just insta wipe you.   top bs is the purple noon ordeal instantly killing characters in main rooms and you've been warned. how are you supposed to counter an instant kill for any non-endgame armored max health characters for this one specific event? the answer is you don't it happens to you once you restart the day and you never leave your characters in the main rooms when you see that ordeal coming up ever again.  now i may have been going on the negatives for awhile but that's because they're pretty bad and also specific.  otherwise the story is great. i love the writing for most of the lore in game. i think the progression system is extremely unique and good once you understand how it works.  the artwork is great and most the anomalies feel unique.  a lot of anomalies also have their own unique mechanics which makes the research side of the game really interesting and fun. every anomaly is its own puzzle.  the difficulty of the game mostly comes from the lack of understanding so once you've researched every it's naturally easier to progress even if you day 1 because you know what anomalies serve you best.  the biggest down there is how vague the game is with outcomes and rng which is part of why i recommend more detailed info. knowing the levels of your characters is also vital for stat farming and even some later objectives not base game you need more detailed info for that.   together i think lobotomy corporation is a very good but incredibly flawed game. for me i think it's worth it but for others maybe not. it's a cautious recommendation.  edit edit: i'm mad i was mostly positive about this game until day 46. all you need to know is due to in game mechanics i need to replay 45 days to get the true ending because rewind to the memory repository is an awful mechanic you should just be able to select previous days. i'd like to stress again this isn't a hard game it's a tedious one. so i've given up (again this isn't even taking into account my 5-10x speed multiplier).  if you want the game for the gameplay i can recommend it it should last a solid 20-30 hours.  if you want the game for its story look up the game's story on youtube i'd go as far as to say this game is openly disrespectful of your time spent with it. if you want to read up on the lore of the anomalies look at the wiki.  i mean this wholeheartedly that you should never play this game if you want any of the writing you shouldn't touch this game just view the writing. the only reason i've not changed to a negative review is because i recognize that the game is super fun before you learn every single anomaly.

lobotomy corp is the very embodiment of a test of patience and knowledge. i have beaten it 3 times with my 1st run needing to retry at day 1 twice and the rest only using memory repository for farming or when needed. at the beginning the game can be very difficult as you won't know what abnos gimmicks are as such you can make a very hellish facility that with one bad result would spiral out of control. however you do have the ability to rewind back to days ending in 1s or 6s which can allow you to reverse your decision though any abno you picked on those specific days are not reversible outside of a day 1 restart.   the main gameplay loop is learning the abno's mechanics getting it's gear completing any assigned mission and training your employees. some of the days can be quite calming with the song neutral becoming engraved into your brain while others can be a challenge that test's your understand of the mechanics and allowing you to hear it's good ost. there's also combat which essential ends with you sending all of your employees with good gear to beat down any enemy outside of their chamber. other factors can be considered like the abno's attack range and their animation which you can use to help make your employees doge attacks. though this also requires constant micro management but once you start pilling up with good weapons you can kill things very quickly so this might not become too tedious for some.  i won't talk about the story aside from it being in my opinion project's moon best narrative though there other products have better character writing. the story creates a good mystery for the company lobotomy corporation and unravels it quite nicely and it's writing for the setting is quite good and leaves it open ended enough that you can fill in the blanks with your imagination.   now before you start playing the game i strongly recommend getting the game's modding tool basemod and install the following mods optimisation mod and gift effects fix at the very least. the game is very unstable and some days can go for a very long time as such you don't want the game to crash and have you lose all your progress for factors outside of your control. also some things don't work properly which both basemod and gift fix help fix to a certain extent.  in the end this game is not for everyone and several parts of it can create genuine frustration however i hold it in a special place and in my opinion is project moon best work so far. not saying their other projects are bad but lobotomy corporation just captures something special that none of their current work has.

the first in a series of games by project moon all taking place in the same setting. it's easily become my favorite game series. project moon doesn't fuck around. they've built an amazing world and constantly challenge the player. each game is different and this one is probably the most unique of the three currently released games. most would probably consider this game the most tedious of the bunch i think as it tends to involve a lot of resetting and (what the player might think anyways) is lost progress. the beauty of it though is that if you can push through the challenge your struggles are perfectly integrated with the story which i think is done masterfully.  push yourself. meet the challenges. complete the seed of light. change the city forever. nothing will change if you can't keep going.

warining! warining! warining! manifestation of gameplay spoilers due to this being a retelling of the story from my experience. warning! warning! warning!  lobotomy corporation is a game that puts up a heavy facade. you take the role of x the newly appointed manager of the titular company lobotomy corporation. your role and goal is to extract energy from abnormalities which are monsters that range from sweet old ladies to skin stealers. to help you with this you're given an android assistant named angela.  the game goes along smoothly you meet department heads known as sephirot and by this point they all should seem decently friendly besides yesod. that is until the cognition filter breaks down giving you a small peek in to the true nature of the facility. right after that you get a call from a mysterious man named b who tells you that the company is not even half of what it seems sowing seeds of distrust in you and growing weeds of doubt weeds that angela wants to pluck.   now with your new sense of doubt you progress more through the game. by this point you should now see core suppression requirements on a bunch of the sephirot's mission pages. unless you know what you're doing you most likely will not see any core suppression until 60-100 hour in. i got lucky and realized dusk ordeals weren't nearly as much as they were made out to be. core suppressions are the boss fights of this game adding a new layer of difficulty on an otherwise normal day. and the more you beat the more you learn.   soon you learn about the man named a and the more you learn about him the more heartless he seems. you also learn of a woman named carmen who seemed to be the opposite of a in every way besides intelligence. you learn that carmen died somehow how she wanted to change the world for the better and how she wished to help every person in the city. you learn the sad tale of elijah a girl who died out of desperation for attention gabriel who was driven mad giovanni who was deceived michelle who was overwhelmed enoch and lisa who were taken in only for enoch to die at the well-meaning hands of carmen kali who died defending in vain daniel who betrayed garion who was just doing her job and benjamin who left a after carmen's death.  after learning all of this you begin thinking that a is the villain of the game. but he's the protagonist as angela finally reveals who a truly is and who she truly is. a is you and angela is an imperfect copy of carmen. a has put himself in to a time loop to get the perfect scenario for the seed of light a strange object which holds the power to accomplish carmen's dream and bring a well to everybody.   day 46-47 x meets abel another version of him representing a part of his mind that thinks nothing will ever change. abel tells a to either overcome what he has not or to stay with abel and accept defeat. x of course does not and perseveres through the day all 4 upper layer sephirot going in to meltdowns.   day 48 x meets his second counterpart abram who represents his guilt and grief for carmen. abram tells x that carmen is dead and gone to stop carrying on her legacy and to just let the facility crumble with his last moments being with carmen's extracted nervous system. x ignores him defeating the red mist a second time and advancing on almost ready to finish the seed of light.  day 49 x meets adam the version of himself that represents his god complex. adam is tired and wants to finish the seed of light project early. this wouldn't accomplish carmen's goal and instead would create an imperfect seed of light turning every single person in to abnormalities instead of allowing them to manifest their true selves. x goes through his hardest trial yet to deny adam but does succeed.  day 50 x meets ayin the true original a. ayin has a short conversation with x and then sends him off to finish the seed of light. after the day has passed the facility flips over to get the sephirot in their proper positions (keter being at the top and malkuth at the bottom) and a beam of light shoots from the facility after it breaks through the ground. this beam is the tree of light sprinkling it's seeds across the city bringing the perfect ending to the game which honestly made me cry. however angela has a different plan. (i won't say any more as it will spoil certain elements of the sequel library of ruina. i will say what's said in lobotomy corporation though.) angela filled with anger from the torment she's been put through due to the time loop wants to live a normal human life. she turns off the tree of light taking the light for herself and using it construct a library where she may accumulate knowledge of the world the city everything.   10/10 game and i don't give that out lightly. well at least i don't when i'm seriously reviewing something. it is a jankfest there are bugs at every corner but those are easy fixes with mods made to debug the game. play this game if you want to cry form happiness conclusion closure anger disappointment practically every emotion that can make you cry in this game will make you cry. after you're done play it's sequel it's somehow better than this.

this game is exciting in the elements that is a psychological horror. it's a setting where energy cannot meet the needs of the world anymore and they needed to find other ways. unique monsters (abnormalities or if you like scp anomalies) create energy based on how well the human you sent in works with them. there are different strength/danger categories just like scp. all the monsters have their own backstories and art made by different artist which is insanely respectable. i love seeing all the effort and love that was put into this game. there is a requirement for time travel in this game and the boss battles are sooooo difficult. it's my favorite management simulator i have ever played and the story between the days you do your work is so intriguing. i wish i could have more and more of this game so i started at the very beginning again just so i could experience it again. but nothing is like the first playthrough of discovering each abnormalities preferences through the scientific method of trial and error (aka death! :d more often than naught.) plus it's fun to get attached to your employees and watch them grow and mess up or do silly things or even die. i would recommend this game for everyone but it's simply a very long and arduous game so it can lose people's interest fast because it's novel-likeness and slow build up but it's completely worth it in my opinion.

listen: i first started playing years ago with zero knowledge of what was in store for me.  first few years i thought the game was about being a good manager and protecting my very killable employees. there was a lot to read and understand and i just jumped in no training or guidance. i suffered so much constantly in fear of each new abno and was bongbong-less. i made it to what i thought was the end of the game but it kept going o_o''' bruh there was more and that's when the story that i had forgotten existed popped off.  i was devastated and then i became obsessed. over time i started to learn the actual rules and how to play the game i was basically in the starter bubble before. this game is so heavily layered i'm afraid to say more and spoil the madness. i gotta say a no knowledge blind play through was the best way to play the game because the chaos was fresh every time screaming at my screen why did that happen?! how did you even do that?! or holy crap wtf is that?!  heh good times

lobotomy corporation is a very special type of game one whose narrative is so very closely interwoven with its gameplay that they may very well be one in the same.  it hates your very being. everything about you. it will beat you bloody. it will anger and frustrate you beyond what you think your limits are. you quit. you return to try again. you repeat the process.  it starts to change your perspective. you realize your employees are disposable to an extent. you lost half the department recontaining that abnormality but that's fine. you recontained it. you can continue. you hire new ones. you train them up. you lose them. you repeat the process.  you stop seeing the abnormalities as monsters. they're generators. you prioritize working the ones that give the most power. it's risky the higher the risk level the more power it gives. you work on the alephs they're the highest risk they'll end the day faster. if that aleph gets out you can't recontain it. it'll wipe your facility.  it does. everyone dies.  you repeat the process.   you aren't playing as a manager of this god-forsaken facility. you [i]are[/i] the manager.   ...but to be less eloquent and more succinct lobotomy corporation is the type of game where it not only expects you to fail (constantly) but weaves that failure to be part of the narrative it tells. it is a hard game it knows it's a hard game and it will force you to know it's a hard game. and that's the point! if it wasn't as hard as it is the narrative wouldn't hit as well as it does!  this does however introduce a problem; hard games can often become unfun games especially if you don't have the time for them. i do not fault anyone who can't put up with lobotomy corporation but i strongly recommend people at least try to. for those who [i]can[/i] put up with it the game is an experience that's rare to find outside of fromsoft (and i would argue that lobotomy corporation is [i]harder[/i] than fromsoft's soulsbornes!)

super great if you're a fan of rouge-like games where there's mounting pressure overtime.   great visuals great soundtrack great concept. game is simple to understand mechanically but becomes ridiculously punishingly hard to the point where you will likely not complete it unless you both know the game inside out and also get fairly lucky with the rng; speaking of lobotomy corporation gives you a choice of three options every handful of days or so which slowly become more and more pick the least miserable one. the longer the game goes on. as a plus it is also fairly easy to mod and it's super easy to customize your in-game agents with your own assets you drew yourself by simply dragging the images into your game files; agents only have one skin tone however which may pose challenges for certain types of custom made agents if that's a concern you have.  one thing i will say is that if you are into the game series for the story you will fucking struggle. lobotomy corporation will dump huge cut-scenes full of text dialogue in-between days (that are about 5 hours of footage all together! holy shit!) that in the moment you want to skip to immediately get to the game play and/or may not even unlock all of because the games so damn hard you never get to the text dumps at around day 40ish. made even worse by the fact that lobotomy corporation is /essential/ to understanding the plot of the two other games in the series (library of runia and limbus [?] company) so you have to either watch 5 hours of just text dump dialogue in a youtube comp or struggle through lobcorp in order to play runia and limbus.  great concept and great game on its own it just suffers from the fact that its sequel is much more lax; meaning people who play lobotomy corporation because they want to understand runia may walk away frustrated because the grueling rouge-like punishment is nothing like the other two games in the series.

going to append an asterisk to the above yes to also include with mods a lot of patience and the understanding that there may come a point where you decide to just go look up the remaining cutscenes on youtube.  i can break down the experience of lobcorp into two separate distinct stages: discovery and completion. during the discovery phase of playing the game each new abnormality mission and even new day is able to be approached with an abundance of caution and curiosity. you are after all still figuring out how stuff works‚Ñ¢ and the game is willing to allow you to fumble through messily enough with a bit of sass and a knowing grin - just don't mind the knife being held behind their back it's probably nothing. even when ultimately you come into a predicament that necessitates use of a day 1 reset: the seed of discovery keeps the player engaged and curious as to just what might come next. a good thing then that the answers can be more delightfully twisted than expectation may lead one to believe. it's compelling in a way that genuinely kept me playing long hours into the night past when i should've gone to bed.  the same cannot be said of the second stage: completion. this will come at different points for different folks in their own games - when the veil of mystery has been pulled back enough that all that remains is an intricate puzzle to be placed together over the course of an hours-long grind of known figures and punishing setbacks. here where the nervous tension of not knowing if your favorite agent might be speeding towards an early retirement is replaced with the dull monotony of watching progress bars fill and hoping that (maybe this time around) circumstances won't end up in disaster is where lobcorp truly becomes a test of will (and navigating sometimes-fiddly controls). maybe perhaps you'll eek out a win and then rewind the ol' repository so as to not lose quite so much progress as the end of day screen dutifully reports. by the fourth or fifth time you're doing this: the aforementioned possibility of just looking up the damned story becomes that much more enticing.  i enjoyed lobcorp but it's definitely not a game i would be surprised to hear someone tell me that they gave up on mid-way through. my own file ended up utilizing a few quality-of-life mods to make the tedious climb back to the final chapter something that i could complete before my interest in the game truly snuffed out from sheer burnout. at time of completion i was happy to resign the game to fond memories and hope that the sequel has a bit less tedium and just as much unique creativity.  to end this review i'll share with you what originally sold me on giving this game a chance: there is boss fights. how the hell do you do that in a management sim game? the answer may surprise you! (it sure as hell surprised me.)

such an amazing game. truly underappreciated in the sense that more people should know of it.   it's a scp-esque management game where you don't have to build the base but manage it and it's inhabitants. you learn about each new anomaly as you work with it and it's a discovery process full of fun and chaos. you hire agents and decide who works where which stats to level on which characters... do you buy the stats at a cost outright or use the skill until a levelup? and what if some anomalies require (for a relatively reliable result) a specific value range for a stat? what if the guy previously in charge of managing it overleveled the stat naturally...   play it!

very fun and interesting game! not as hard as it looks either.  edit: one thing that needs to be mentioned is that there's a bug that will cause the game to crash after about 1 hour of playing the same level. it gives an 'access violation' in memory which is caused by a programming error that makes the game use up more and more resources until your ram is all filled up which crashes the game. to fix this i installed the 'optimization mod' from nexusmods.com.   in terms of gameplay i absolutely recommend buying this game. in terms of the overall product it irritates me that this bug (which actually prevents you from finishing the campaign since the levels get longer as you go) has been around for years and the devs have refused to fix it despite numerous reports. so buyer beware i guess...

[h1]three things to understand about this game (no spoilers):[/h1]  [b]1. go in blind![/b] don't do any research if you can help it.  a majority of the joy of this game is learning it and exploring it.  [b]2. this is a korean game.[/b] if you don't have experience to know what this means it is incredibly difficult and you will grind it a lot.  you'll spend a lot of the time doing the same thing over and over hoping for improvement and defeat will be brutal.  go in expecting the worst and have fun with it.  (i mean really this sort of difficulty and grinding should be expected by the theme.)  [b]3. this is a roguelite game[/b] this is something i didn't really consider at first.  roguelites require you to fail fail fail and as you progress you'll get to keep a little bit of something for the next try.  don't be afraid to rewind back.  yeah it sucks having to grind through the same stuff again but you'll have more stuff a better idea of the game and the opportunity to make new choices.  getting attached to what you built and sticking with it when you hit a wall and can't progress is only a recipe for depression.

despite the difficulties and frustration this game can cause lobotomy corporation has easily become one of if not my favorite game. somehow it's able to make you extremely attached to workers meant to be disposable. it's magic. all of the characters in the game are great and i've gotten very attached to them. the gameplay when not frustrating which it usually isn't is very fun and i absolutely love it. and despite how difficult the game may be it's also forgiving. every 5 days you reach a memory repository day and you can rewind to it at any time keeping any gear you obtained. this can be heavily abused to obtain high level gear i would know i've done it before and with no regret whatsoever. one thing that does pain me about the game however is having to force myself to get desensitized to agent deaths. every time a death message pops up i'm very tempted to press the retry day button though i force myself to go on. that is unless the death is one of my department captains my little scrunkly wunklies. the abnormalities are very interesting too. i haven't seen a single design i dislike and for the most part any deaths caused by abnormalities are due to your error. for the most part. there are a few rng parts and unfair mechanics. i also love laetitia. and der freisch√ºtz. all in all i would say that the game is amazing. it's story is /very/ intriguing and i find myself extremely eager to learn more and more about the lore. easily my favorite game.

so i went into this game solely because i wanted to experience the sequel library of ruina to it's fullest extent. lore implications and the possibility of characters crossing over is not something i wanted to miss out on.  from what i can tell there's a lot of people who are dissuaded from trying this game because of the genre. i've never really had any urge to play a management sim game but i figured what the hell let's give it a shot and i'm so glad i did. lobotomy corporation's gameplay is very true to the story through all the time lost to mistakes or oversights you come to appreciate the manager's position and how painful the journey actually is. somehow after all the frustrating resets and losses i came out the other end feeling truly satisfied. i guarantee you'll love to hate it. big cope.

[b]item #[/b]: scp-8008 - game critic  [b]object class:[/b] euclid  [b]special containmnet procedures:[/b] scp-8008 is contained within a standard secure humanoid containment cell in [data redacted]. this cell must contain access to a controlled network with strict whitelist protocols. watchmojo domains are not to be included in the whitelist under any circumstance.  [b]description:[/b] scp-8008 is a humanoid creature with little muscle mass suggesting a sedentary lifestyle. security personnel describe the aroma of scp-8008's containment cell as anime cons before the girls started showing up.  scp-8008 is normally docile and mutters to itself without need for sleep or sustenance. these mutters are incomprehensible without high frequency audio recordings which decipher them to be endless top 10 lists. interactions with class-d personnel reveal that scp-8008 will provide coherent statements when asked its opinion on games during which its normally humanoid face will grotesquely twist into exaggerated expressions resembling emoji pictographs.  [b]audio log #****: interview with scp-8008[/b] [b]class d#******[/b]: so it says here i'm supposed to ask you what do you think of [data redacted] [b]scp-8008[/b]: i think it's wonderfully creative with its varied abnormalities quirky art style and off-kilter narrative but it's held back by a clunky ui and monotonous gameplay once the mystery behind it has been solved. i recommend it to anyone who gets the meta of this review or anyone fascinated by creepypastas in general but for the money i'd sooner pitch don't starve cultist simulator or any of the sunless game. this is a very difficult game.  i have over a hundred hours in it currently and still have not gotten to an ending that isn't the default bad ending which all but forces you to reset to day 1. thankfully restarting from day 1 is merciful and keeps all of your encyclopedia entries and ego gear. resetting even one day over and over is essentially part of the gameplay loop. you're expected to learn from trial and error and it rewards you for paying attention to the lore and entries.  i personally recommend going in blind but if you're ever uncertain about an abnormality crossreferencing the wiki will save you a lot of grief. i'm gonna keep trying to go for the 100% ending so i'll probably update this review when i do.

lobotomy corporation is a difficult game but one i enjoy immensely.  it's a good game to play if you enjoy challenge and have the time to sink into it.  it's also good for those who enjoy fantasy management scp as well as watching your little nuggets grow and become the ugliest and strongest possible <3 there is no more joy than watching them grow extra eyes on their cheek maybe where a literal face mask... yuck! but aw!  the game play is engaging and feels rewarding. while it definitely has a bit of a problem where if you don't know what you're doing the first time around you may have to restart the whole cycle (which can take a while depending on how you play and it often requires a bit of grinding) it has the tools to let you explore try again and slowly figure out what each abnormality can do. as you figure out what each one does you're rewarded with an increases in stats information story and even weapons/accessories depending on the abnormality. when i see the little ugly nuggets smack their silly pink goo and feather bullets(?!) at each abnormality and destroy them you can't help but feel a bit of pride.  as a reward for progressing and surviving you get to learn the stories of each character and if you play your cards right you can learn so much more about them.  also there's customization want to get attached to any of your employees that may die at any moment? go right ahead! this will not backfire i'm not sad shut u

this game is not for everyone. it will beat you senseless through repetition trial and error and the sheer horror contained within it. it is a game that asks the player whether they truly think it is worth it to simply continue to see an ideal through until the very end no matter the pain and suffering that is along the way. if you feel like you can withstand a plunge of over a hundred hours into such a task and be rewarded for your trials only at the very end then the game is worth looking into for you. this game is as close to human suffering condensed into a product as you can get you can start off likening your employees to humans in your head seeing your nuggets complete each day and trying your hardest to keep them alive. eventually something will snap in you and they change from individual to expendable. a way of putting this game simply is that it is training for middle management.  so basically this game is mainly for those who see suffering as the path to growth and if you can accept that this game will be great for you. now finally after having spent almost five years in my off and on run i can continue onwards into the library.

first management-type game i've ever played and i have to say that this game is definitely worth playing. the more i learned about the abnormalities the easier it became to contain them. it's pretty fun learning about them too. forgetting about one little thing in this game however could lead to one or multiple of your agents dying it's definitely unforgiving. one thing that was really relieving is that if your first run that you sunk hours into goes to hell you can keep playing the game and not feel like everything is over. the knowledge and equipment you earned from from your last run is saved into your next playthrough and you can improve on the mistakes that you made before with each run-through. definitely a game that you can sink tens or maybe even hundreds of hours into and still enjoy playing it.

the gameplay is fairly simple to grasp. you have an abnormality who is sitting in a nice little containment cell. you have an agent who needs to gather energy from it. you chose what type of work to perform and that's it. you watch the little guy go and hope for the best. if you're a good manager this game will become routine almost tedious in its design. if everything is performing as intended all you do is schedule your little guys to do their little works and once you've got enough energy you move on to the next day to continue the story. but not everything goes as you want it to.  every single abnormality has its own list of rules that must be obeyed. this abnormality kills you if your work time takes too long. this one gives you a gift but if you work on another abnormality while carrying its gift you die and turn into a horrible monster. this one doesn't like repression work. that one hates employees with high temperance. these are all rules you'll have to tuck away into your subconscious as you play the game. forget any one rule and you're likely to have an employee die. i once had spent a few hours on a single day trying to grind my employee's stats to maximum for upcoming challenges. i had one employee work with a safe abnormality who gives a little healing orb for doing work. it's not an abnormality that's good at training stats however so i sent that employee to work with another to finish off her stats. to my dismay i forgot that anyone carrying the orb is likely to die if they work on any other abnormality. not only that but any employees who got the orb throughout the day also die when that happens causing 5 deaths in my facility of 20 employees.  but this is where the game really starts to shine in my opinion. you can retry at almost any time. those 5 employees are back under my care as though nothing had ever happened. i was a bit aggravated to lose my employees but it was my fault. fundamentally lobotomy corp does not present the player with impossible tasks. there is never a case where an employees death is a requirement to progress. some challenges can be made easier by throwing a few corpses at it. one of the hardest challenges in the entire game can be made trivial if you're willing to commit to sacrificing a single employee but it's never a requirement to progress. a deathless run is more than doable. everything comes down to player knowledge. in that way this game is a little bit like outer wilds. your own knowledge is one of the strongest weapons at your disposal.  but then it gets even better. every 5 days the game saves to something called the memory repository. any gear you've unlocked quests completed research gained and upgrades acquired persist when returning to the memory repository. that one sacrifice to cheese one of the hardest encounters in the game? that employee too can come back. the challenge will still be cleared. and you will have new resources available further challenges even easier. you can go through a week farm a bunch of high level gear and return to the start of the week with everyone alive and now decked out in the high level gear you just earned.  and so eventually we return to the status quo. my entire facility is now flooded with level v agents with maxed out stats and ego gifts. my facility is so powerful we can set dangerous aleph class abnormalities free for fun and easily suppress them without a single lost employee. and so the game has returned to that tedium i mentioned before. if you're a good manager nothing will go wrong. if nothing is going wrong then all you're really doing is farming energy and moving along. the game has two ways of co this fatigue. ordeals and missions.  missions are challenges set forth by the other characters in the game. most of these are pretty easy but some can be quite challenging. one of them is suppress 3 different aleph class abnormalities in a single day. for someone like me with a small army of super units decked out in the best gear thanks to judicious use of time travel this is fairly trivial. but for most players this is a wall that will be nearly insurmountable. they also reward you with permanent upgrades.  the second mechanic is ordeals. these are essentially uncontained abnormalities that appear randomly throughout the day. the game gives you a warning before they spawn and the player themselves must trigger the event by performing work. the first time you encounter an ordeal it will likely be a nightmare. you won't understand what these clowns are. you won't be in position to stop them and you won't understand why der freishutz just shot a bullet down a hallway and killed half your employees. eventually you'll learn that the clowns spawn in random hallways but only one per department. you'll learn that their goal is to either breach or trigger the special ability of an abnormality in their hallway and you'll learn that you can easily hard counter them by placing one employee per hallway ahead of time. and that's only  crimson dawn one of the easiest ordeals to handle. thankfully though every single ordeal save one is just like this. they have a very obvious counterplay and once you understand it you won't lose an employee to it ever again. except for violet midnight. if you see violet midnight just hit that retry button i guess. it ain't worth it.  and thus we once again return to the norm. you've completed the missions you know how to handle ordeals your abnormalities are safe. and then the game starts throwing something else at you that pushes you to the brink. suddenly you get a challenge where all your work orders are scrambled. your employee stats are lowered. healing is disabled. a skilled player will not be used to putting out fires. they'll prevent the fires from happening in the first place through diligent management. and then the game sets off an inferno and tells you adapt or die. these are some of the most fun challenges the game has to offer but also the most difficult. these moments are stressful tense and you'll probably have to retry some of them several times before you clear the challenge but at the same time the catharsis once you do is one of the best. and remember all of the above is still in play during these challenges. abnormalities still need work.  i could honestly say as much about the story as i've said about the gameplay. i found the characters endearing and charming. the abnormalities are as much a character as anything else in this game and most of them are lovely. my personal favorite is probably censored. an abnormality that pokes fun at all those childishly written scp articles where they try to add mystique and danger by just spamming [redacted] all over the page. the abnormality itself is a giant censor bar because it's so horrifying to look at that even you the manager would die just seeing it. top class stuff. despite its arguably horror roots and shocking violent content the game isn't afraid to be a bit cheeky and playful with it all. the game's setting is one that will sneak up on you. the true nature of the city and the world they all live in is fairly compelling anti-capitalist stuff. one of my favorite abnormalities is a blind birth with a crooked scales of justice hanging on its neck. the bird cannot tell that the scales are crooked because it is blind. absolutely flawless symbolism.  the music is also great. there's only like 10 tracks total but they're all wonderful and never get grating despite looping constantly. the graphics are clumsy and the game is a bit poorly programmed and janky in spots but everything else fantastic.  tldr: lobotomy corporation is a tough but ultimately fair game with lots of replay value wrapped in a great story with sometimes tedious gameplay. surprisingly well balanced in spite of what others have said about vertical difficulty spikes or impossible challenges. 9/10 i could have gone on but i ran out of space. oops.

it took too many years to clear this game i dropped out once and after 3 or 4 years i tried once more. last 46~49th days were brutal for me in the end i lost 96% of my employees. a challenging game is not a bad game but it needs too much of luck sometime to break through the ordeals. also without mods the game was frequently laggy. it might be my system but the lag added another problem on the top of uncomfortable control. it is a definitely forcing to  use a micro-control to avoid certain enemies but it does not even have a basic functions such as a group set for specific agents (like an attack team for monsters or something). the art style and atmosphere of the game is excellent. the story was hard to digest for me though. i understood the storyline but some details are a bit obscure. i had loved some characters but the temporal blank to clear the game made me lost almost all the memory of characters in the game which affected my experience definitely especially the glorious ending scenes...  overall if you want to experience the sorrows of a middle manager who stuck in the unlimited number of the time-loop i can recommend to buy it. however you should finish it without too much time-span like me. also for me it is not a replayable game after the ending. fortunately it is not a full-price game so it is acceptable.

[h1]summary[/h1] a superb blend of the visual novel management and roguelelike genres!  [h1]story[/h1] i loved the story setup and gradual unraveling alongside the events happening in the factory itself. the characters lore and general worldbuilding were all intriguing and left many open questions that i hope are even further explored in the sequel (library of ruina). that is not to say the story was completely open-ended. i thought there was a concrete conclusion to this game itself which i thoroughly enjoyed even as it set up the sequel in the epilogue.  the story is short relative to the amount of gameplay time necessary to get the true ending. so if you discover you do not enjoy the gameplay it is absolutely not worth the amount of gameplay required to see the full story unfold.  [h1]gameplay[/h1] i thought the combination of management with roguelike mechanics and some permanence (you keep a few things such as abnormality information and equipment across resets) made for a really fun experience. the retry/reset mechanisms also provided a ton of room for freely experimenting. the boss and mini-boss fights were all unique and provided some clever uses of all the game mechanics which could really require you to change up your strategy and adapt.  i do not typically play management games. i actually discovered this one due to finding out it was the prequel to ruina. i have not yet played ruina since i decided to play them in order. however i do at least know the gameplay is completely different (card-based vs. management).   [h1]soundtrack[/h1] the ost seemed quite small but it blended really well into the ambiance considering it is on loop throughout most of the playthrough as you navigate each day. i never felt distracted or annoyed by any song despite hearing them countless times.  [h1]graphics[/h1] the graphics can look outright silly and goofy at times especially considering the dark events going on. there is an in-story explanation for why things look the way they do and you even get glimpses of what things really look like as you progress.  that said i thought the general graphics and designs were fine in the grand scheme of things. the more artistic pieces littered throughout which depicted the true gritty reality looked phenomenal!  [h1]cons[/h1] there was one big con which i thought was worth mentioning: some of the ui can be [i]too[/i] vague or lacking in certain information. here is a non-exhaustive list of examples off the top of my head:   1. the success percentage for each type of work does not show up anywhere in the in-game ui. i had to always look it up on the wiki if i wanted to know.  2. the game gives no indication of how many hits a weapon does per attack. a seemingly weak weapon might actually be really strong despite it showing low damage values because of a high number of hits per attack. the game only shows attack speed which is separate from number of hits per attack. i only discovered this one late into the game when i started checking the wiki.  3. there is no dashboard to easily check each agent's status including shields. you can partially work around this one by selecting any unit and shuffling through the departments that way although that view is lacking shield info or the ability to select an agent (as in the view you get when you click them).  i know some of the information limitations (especially agent statuses) may have been intentional and are part of the handicaps you get at times. still i wish they were more clearly visible when they were not intentionally being hidden as part of a challenge since information is a core part of the gameplay. the bright side is that the wiki is rich in information and makes it possible to get a lot of the missing in-game information easily.

one of the greatest games i'll probably ever play. difficulty curve is probably nearly perfect in the sense that you're always completing some feat you imagined would be impossible 6 hours previous and then doing so trivially another 6 hours after that.   the only flaw this game has imho is the (sometimes) finicky real time combat controls - you are not able to direct which side of a room your 'units'(nuggets) should move to and you must instead do so by directing them to an adjacent room and then canceling the move via another attack command so that they walk through an enemy then attack again. this is generally fine but there are some rooms that do not have an adjacent room to the left which makes things kinda annoying.

welcome to the corporation manager. here you manage your team. generate energy for the world. simple. things can go wrong will go wrong but nothing is too difficult for you to handle. remember your ultimate goal is to reach energy quota. employee are expendable.  it is true this game suffer a case of micromanagement especially the difficult combat sequence. employee are expendable holds true except the contradiction here is that you need a high level employee to get the job done wether its for combat or day to day work. which led to a grind that most managers will catch on quickly.   art direction is superb everything goes together. i absolutely love this and the game itself isn't afraid showing the gruesome part of it. sound is also great it complements the art style. music ... oh boy another contradictory its like the game wants you the manager to mess up and get the situation under control instead of taking an easy way out.  gameplay has some learning curve but once understand it turns into a fight against the user interface. micromanagement is there but macro is also present as some combat scenario discourage the use of big angry agent mob. feeling left out? the game will give you a tool to directly interact on your employee later as the game progress.  minor spoiler tips. it is unrealistic to go through the whole game on the first playthrough. holds very true on day 46-50.  the game gives 4 ways for the manager to reset their progress 3 of which continue your progression.  a daily reset. after everyday 5 reset. all the way back to day 1. use these to your advantage.  last but not least the forsaken reset. back to square one everything you've done gone. this is probably my favorite game of all time. if you're new lemme tell ya this is popular for a reason. this game is a prequel to library of ruina. i've been following it's development all the way back when this game was in legacy it's come a long way since then.   the gameplay loop is simple you have a team of employees (we call them nuggets) and you have to work on abnormalities in order to generate energy. each abnormality has special requirements that your employee has to meet in order to work on them. you'll probably die a lot figuring out how to contain these creatures but that's alright- the game intends for you to die and restart frequently. knowledge is carried on from previous restarts and the game provides many methods of restarting from a simple day retry to going back in time 5 days to restarting the run entirely. the name of the game is to fail learn from these failures and push forward towards success.   as well as knowledge carrying over [spoiler]you also keep all perks gained during boss battles and won't have to do those battles again unless you do a full game restart. this makes future runs easier the harder the battle the more worthwhile the perk you'll get out of it is.[/spoiler] you can also continue to grind the day after you've collected enough energy in order to improve your nugget's stats.   also these abnormality designs? [i]mwah![/i] i got into the game because i absolutely love monsters. the game goes into a lot of detail about how they function and has stories connected to each one of them. i love their mechanics and how some are interconnected to each other both story-wise and mechanically. if you're looking into this game for the monsters i would also highly recommend reading the company's comic wonderlab. it takes place during the same time as this game and also focuses heavily on the monsters.  now this game isn't without flaws. truth be told it's a bit spaghetti coded this was the company's first game after all. it does have a memory leak problem but this can be circumvented by just closing the game and reopening it after 3 hours. there are also a few bugs but nothing too game breaking. the most game breaking bug is [spoiler]the different abnormality on first day glitch which can be accidentally triggered and could be an instant restart if you're unprepared for the chosen abnormality.[/spoiler] however one really funny thing about it being like this is that you can easily access the game's files including [b]every single text file in the game.[/b] i have personally renamed all the abnormalities and a few of the ui texts.  all in all if constant grinding and failure isn't your thing it's best not to get the game. if you wanna know the lore for library of ruina without playing there's a playlist of the entire story on youtube you could watch. but if you're alright with failing and getting back up again to push forward this game will be a wonderful and thrilling experience for you and is definitely worthwhile to play.

i have mixed feelings about this game. wish there was a neutral review option.  the story and writing is great. lots of abnormalities each with their own little stories. the sound design and music is good too.  gameplay is terrible though.  you will need to restart in-game days and even entire playthroughs a lot especially if going in blind. in the first few runs you will not have much information to work with and will have to resort to trial error and lots of failure to figure out the best way to manage what you've got. restarting is major part of the core gameplay loop and is encouraged; it's even relevant to the plot. rewinding to a recent checkpoint or even the start of a playthrough lets you keep the equipment upgrades and most importantly the information gained from the previous runs.  the pacing is quite slow. most of the game is spent sending your agents to work with abnormalities waiting for them to reach the containment unit waiting for them to finish their work waiting for them to return back to their department's main room and then waiting for them to heal before sending them out to work again. even with 2x speed this feels like a drag.  the worst part is that the optimal strategy involves grinding by having your agents continue to work long after the workday is over to farm experience or gifts. this is further exacerbated by the fact that agents are not permanent (they can die and be lost forever or lost when you start a new playthrough) and the fact that you can't check your leveling progress (only by ending the day can you see the stat increases). all that grinding for a run that may or may not end in utter failure does get tedious.  the game isn't very accessible either. much of the text containing important information like the stat requirements to equip an item or the notifications that inform you that yet another employee has died are too small to read comfortably with no option to change the font size.  there's also quite a few bugs caused by simple typo errors in the code which to this day have yet to be officially fixed and need to be fixed by unofficial mods.  the only reason i still think this game is worth playing despite all its flaws apart from the story is the mods. while the game does not have steam workshop support there are numerous mods from various other sites adding quite a bit of content and quality of life features.  honestly though their next game library of ruina is much much better and i recommend playing that instead before deciding if you want to get this. if you still want to play this though for the sake of your irl sanity points i suggest at least getting a few qol/bugfix mods such as the automatic work macro mod and once you're familiar enough with the game a game speed increasing mod.

a very interesting concept for a management game.  your task is to train your employees and use them to study and extract energy from a bunch of monsters. each monster has its own particularities about how it should be handled that if not respected will lead to a bunch of also particular penalties. this complexity is i think the point that makes this game stand out from others in its genre the most. apart from this the setting and characters are quite exceptional and the story is pretty good. while most of the game is actually rather easy it also provides some very hard challenges here and there so overall i'd say the difficulty is satisfying.  in terms of defaults i guess the worst point is how it doesn't manage to fully use its mechanical complexity. ok every monster is very particular. but in truth most of the time the game will allow you to ignore nearly all monsters to focus on the few most convenient ones which in my opinion kind of defeats the point of implementing all those monsters and behaviors in the first place. i also can't help but wonder if being able to easily unlock the full explanation of how individual monsters work was a good idea or not. perhaps letting the player study them themselves would have been a better idea? maybe not. i don't know. it is also somewhat buggy though not overly so. in my entire playtime i had a single crash and a few other minor problems. throughout the game there are lots of downtime between the actual challenges meant purely for grinding. this time investment is meant to make you more engaged and tense during difficulties as every mistake will come with the risk of permanently losing the resources you've grinded for. i'll admit this might be a necessary evil when done in moderation but i honestly think this game goes a bit too far into wasting your time.  thankfully there are a few mods out there that can help you tailor the experience to your liking. i would definitely recommend checking them out 10~20 hours into the game to see if there are any that could fix whatever problem you might have with the game at that point.  overall i loved the game so i definitely recommend it though i expect that it will not appeal to everyone.

i don't know how to put into words how much i like this game. not saying its my favorite game ever as if i cannot understate that but i know i loved this game and it's hard to explain...  to start this game has multiple different layers of gameplay. at lobotomy corporation's core it's a monster management type of game (i don't actually know of any other monster management types of games but they probably exist?). the main gameplay experience is encountering new types of monsters or anomalous items (abnormalities) working with them to find out their unique abilities and behaviors and stopping them from slaughtering everything they come into contact with.   as everyone has already said think scp management game.   as the game progresses you will encounter new abnormalities and have to respond to them accordingly while accounting for all of the ones you already have in your facility and any potential ways they can interact with each other. one abnormality may seem completely normal and passive but then working with a different one may trigger something to happen with or because of the first abnormality for example. it can get complex and quite difficult with the correct collection of abnormalities.   while dealing with the abnormalities themselves you will also have to take care of ordeals which are scheduled events of enemies invading the facility in ascending difficulty; as well as complete bonus objectives relating to the story's npcs (the sephirot/sephirah). completing these bonus objectives unlocks optional [spoiler](but required for the true ending)[/spoiler]  challenges to complete as well which will reward you with minor and or major boons for the rest of the playthrough if they are overcome. some of them are extremely difficult though and will only get harder as you complete more.   in summary you have to research new abnormalities deal with existing ones overcome the ordeals and complete the sephirah challenges. well to be fair all you have to do is generate enough energy each day by working with any and all non-tool abnormalities but that's not the real experience of the game of course.   that's putting it plainly though. you will be tested and challenged and quite possibly be put into situations where you cannot realistically win. good thing though - you can restart from day one and keep most of your progress including abnormality dissolution and e.g.o. equipment (weapons and armor). the game is hard possibly the hardest i've played and 100% completed taking me 171.5 hours and there's only 50 days/levels in the game.   the abnormality design is really good. i simultaneously was excited for and dreaded each new one all the way until the last. there are sentient and non-sentient (tool) abnormalities extremely dangerous and mostly passive abnormalities as well as helpful ones too.   the story was fine. i didn't pay close enough attention though because it took me 171.5 hours and about 3 and a half playthroughs (quotes because they were basically mandatory for 100% completion and not full playthroughs like most games) but from what i gathered it's about a nearly apocalyptic and chaotic world where power and influence seem to mean everything and no line is too far to be crossed.   the game can get buggy at times and the ui can be difficult to work with but not to a point where it can make things too hard to deal with just uncomfortable. the game will also get lower and lower fps as the days go on which will make it harder to control things but it wasn't unmanageable.   soundtrack was good really good at times but for the majority i had my own music playing (as you tend to do after so much time).   difficulty is optional if you don't really care about 100% completion or the story that much. if you don't care it's pretty normal. if you care about the story it can be quite difficult. if you want 100% completion be prepared to spend nearly an hour on each level near the end and have to retry a good amount of things dozens of times. i played pretty much completely blind and without guides so that was just my experience. i honestly wouldn't discredit people if they needed some help coming up with a strategy for some of the challenges in the game and looked some things up though brute force actually came through for me some times.  easily one of my favorite games definitely top 10. could never have imagined how long it would take or how difficult some of the challenges were going to be 171.5 hours ago.  upon reading more reviews i should mention that the game's this game is weird and punishing but god i love it a lot.  it has some pretty bad sudden difficulty humps but the writing is top notch the art is great the music is great and the gameplay is really fun and addictive.  it's not the kind of game i'd recommend to everyone. it can definitely get frustrating at times. you can end up in unwinnable scenarios or scenarios that are just so difficult to juggle that you don't even want to try and will have to rewind over. if you're okay with the concept of restarting your run a few times due to either your own screwups or wanting to play more optimally and you're the kind of person who likes to micromanage the crap out of everything play lobcorp. it's a very unique cool game.  i recommend you consider using mods - i used one for showing more exact stats personally.

day seven: i have this figured out after a week of managing this trainwreck. sometimes an interaction with a new monster kills someone unexpectedly so i re-do the day and have no fatalities the second time around probably completing a research project while i'm at it. employees level up slowly but if i'm wise about it i can keep my top brass alive and productive. challenging at times surely but i'm looking forward to seeing the story unfold. this game is pretty all right.  day twenty-one: i have spent hours in real time replaying one day in the hopes that even a single employee lives though i know if i lose one of my senior hires i'm not sure what kind of hope i have to contain many of my research subjects. by the time i've met half of my energy quota i have a maneating mecha-dog white noise that makes you insane a bunch of buzzsaw robots some kind of opium poppy pleasure god a bulletproof shapeshifting meat golem and some psycho with a hand cannon and a scythe loose in the hallways. people are screaming and being blown to bloody pulps by the dozens. a magical girl teleports into a hallway full of fleeing employees to help killing many instantly before becoming a hysterical snake chimera as a giant aggressive swan-man materializes on the floor below. the company hasn't even opened all of its wings yet undoubtedly full of further horrors. there are four unfinished research projects i can't hope to complete a single one of today without great luck let alone two. only the dead can know peace from this evil. this game rules.  in all seriousness: >>>if there were translation issues they have since been resolved- beyond the occasional weird grammar choice the english language version is very comprehensible. >>>there is the occasional visual glitch. masks slide a bit off of a character's model people listed as dead in the ui are just standing in the cell where they supposedly expired. the numerical level of the temperance stat is cut off in the weapon/armor selection menus so i'll have to back up to identify that bit. it's not really an issue- but what is is the glitch that seems to make moving and zooming into the map impossible if you open the manager's guide from the pause menu which pretty much forces you to restart the day. other than that i haven't run into anything egregious bug-wise yet. >>>sound and most of the art design is great in this. every anomaly has its own encyclopedia portrait character model (sometimes multiple...) and  suite of sound effects/ambient noise that will become louder or more distant depending on your proximity to the cell and if it is contained or not. there's a musical track for every situation from choosing your next monster to watching everything go up in flames in various increments. >>>ui does leave something to be desired. when a lot of stuff is happening in a hallway it can be hard to select or even identify individual employees since they're all often stacked on top of each other during combat. it's easier to get the hang of the clunky selection situation when everything isn't going wrong but obviously things go wrong. a lot. all at once. i end up using the click-and-drag mass selection to just move entire departments to handle stuff a lot which probably isn't a sound strat by now but i don't enjoy fiddling with finding and selecting individual employees. they're basically all just the same silhouette with different hair expressions and outfits unable to be distinguished by department unless you select them or can see the tiny colored armband which can get even more confusing when the random npc drones (same character silhouette) milling about get mixed up in the crowd and start littering the halls as corpses.  this game is hard. it has a surprising amount of depth but there is also an element of randomness that can make or break the periods between memory repository saves that happen every week or so. whenever you acquire new research subjects you pick from three mystery choices identified only by some cryptic phrase and a number and frequently end up accidentally killing people or setting monsters loose as you attempt to research how to handle them properly. the discovery of new details for every unique anomaly is part of the fun but you will fucking suffer for it by the time you've fully expanded the first of the facility's three levels. it's similar to darkest dungeon in that you will hire a lot of cannon fodder and hope to christ that your favorite senior hires make it through the grinder but even more punishing. the importance of having experienced people to handle the more dangerous stuff and the steep price of new hires paid from the same pool of points that will improve your extant employees' training makes losing someone a tragedy despite how inevitable it is.  [tl;dr] this isn't so much a management simulator as it is an exercise in disaster mitigation framed by an explorative story and roguelite gameplay. it'll stress you out and stretch your brain thinner and thinner as the departments start piling on though the goals of your daily routine don't change much. still the depth of story is as weirdly entrancing as the scp foundation content that inspired it. haven't even finished it yet but i'm prepared to keep smashing my head against this wall until i uncover the full narrative behind the drywall. if that's up your alley lobcorp is worth the price of admission especially for the hours of horrible terrible no-good fun you'll get out of it for 25 bucks. you'll get your money's worth by the time you rage quit.
