lobotomy corporation is a game where pale twinks in suits form friendships with floating skulls to generate electricity and then everyone dies somehow.  you play as the manager that bizarre mythological figure always invoked by angry customers despite never being summoned. you have been tasked with running the eponymous lobotomy corporation an ever-expanding underground power plant that harnesses energy from a collection of objects and entities known collectively as abnormalities in order to feed the world's insatiable need for power. in the meantime you discover that the dangers of managing these unstable abnormalities is only slightly less than the real existential danger that is our current crippling dependence on fossil fuels.  confusion can be said to be lc's primary gameplay mechanic. nothing in the game is ever truly explained to you and what you don't know can very much hurt you. what [i]are[/i] the abnormalities? what do each of the four kinds of work you can do with them actually entail? how does this generate electricity? why does electricity come in boxes? what is a qliphoth generator and why does nobody seem at all concerned about the fact that it seems to melt down every single day? what was it exactly that killed literally every employee in my base at the exact same time?  making matters worse is that the writing deliberately goes out of its way to make this more difficult. unlike say the scp foundation (who uses clear unambiguous language and hides information with trade talk and redaction) lc filters everything through the sort of floaty high-minded not-at-all-how-normal-people-talk sort of speech that you tend to find in works whose authors [i]really[/i] want you to know that they read books sometimes. my ai director who's supposed to be answering my questions can't even give me directions to the bathroom without launching into a 40 minute tirade about the philosophy of striving for the future interspersing a dozen pell-mell references to judeo-christian mysticism and asking me for the hundredth time if i believe i have somehow grown spiritually from taking on this job.  the result of all of this is an environment that is 100% hostile to you as a player. it's designed to make you fail repeatedly until you finally manage to piece together what the hell your job even [i]is[/i] and whether or not you should make friends with the spooky audio recording you keep locked in a cell. make no mistake: i mean that last sentence in possibly the most positive way. the penalties for failure aren't really that severe; you just get sent back to the start of the next day with your own personal knowledge of the situation more or less intact. once you manage to piece together the lingo you can start to get a sense of how the game wants you to proceed. every new piece of info you unlock reinforces or refutes guesses you were already forming through trial and error. and every new abnormality under your care becomes a new knife to juggle increasing the danger while also making the resulting ballet of agent actions all the more impressive to behold.  in short lc is a good game with a competent premise encouraging experimentation and discovery and being just the right amount of tense. i would definitely recommend avoiding wikis and walkthroughs wherever possible and really enjoy the sense of desperate helplessness the game seeks to instill in you. i give this game an ergo proxy is my favorite anime you guys let me tell you all about it out of 10.

most games have mindless grinding but imagine one where you can't do that and everything gives you anxiety. i have not even reached day 30 in this game but i may take this game slower because doing it in one session has lead to the main music that plays to haunt my brain. this game is really fun and entertaining when you get new abnormalities and get to see what they do. that however is also the worst part of the game. this game was made for you to grind and suffer but the story and different scenarios you deal with have kept my interest up high.  would recommend this game to anyone into horror/scp type related stuff. it's a management simulator that keeps you on your toes with a unique story and charming art style. this game is really hard even when you think you're prepared for more powerful situations it still may not be enough. finding different strategies with how to deal with things is part of the fun but i understand that there will be many who grow frustrated with this type of game easily. you just have to keep in mind that there is a sluggish pacing to the game play if you choose to be more cautious.   some days in this game have taken me up to an hour of just getting employees stats up to prepare for more horrors.

this is a good game. and if you have the knowledge for it you can see that interestingly this game is filled with occult references. mainly pulling from the kabbalistic philosophy of life. the upgrading of your corporation is essentially a backwards journey from malkuth to kether on the tree of life. you are 'taming' qliphoth energy which is essentially the 'evil'  or dualistic version of the tree of life. this gives the game a very interesting premise and adds to it's mystery.   if you want a better understanding of just what the hell is going on in this game i highly suggest looking into the kabbalah. it adds to the lore of the game 100x and is one of the main reasons this game has me now sucked into it. i love mystery and esoteric concepts and this game does not disappoint in that regard.  it also helps if you love management games and brutal difficulty. this game really makes you think both philosophically and logically in making your next move. this is a very unique and hidden gem of a game.

i'm enjoying it so far.   lots of western occult stuff in it. plays like oxygen not included but not as sim/survival. content is like neon genesis evangelion but instead of kaiju battles it's scp foundation stuff.   so far i've gotten to day 4 enjoy looking at the flavor text of the stuff i'm studying and feeling dread every step of the way of something terrible happening.   you can repeat days if you like. i am not sure of the implications of doing so. there are choices to be made and i'm not sure how that affects the story but it feels enjoyable to explore it.  some things that need fixing: -sound effect slider: hell there's space right there for it! sometimes the screaming can be a bit grating so being able to turn that down would be nice. -some of the songs hit a limiter or something and crackles whatever. -feels very indie and a little rough around the edges. worth it at a lower price than normal i feel though. -beginning is front heavy and odd how much the girl character talks about how cute she looks and how much you might think so too. not too bad though -slow down the flavor text! i wanna read some of it! the working flavor text also covers too much of what's going on and is a little distracting.  good things: -some of the music really slaps -basically play your way through a custom themed scp foundation database while playing a simpler version of oxygen not included (like an ant farm!) -inventory system based on research points so anomalies have a function to keep around and continue researching -mix of chibi/cute style anime with the occult is oddly foreboding -if you know occult stuff it's real fun although may or may not be accurate in it (like they'll have the sephirot and talk about it but it ain't gonna be like a wikipedia page on the actual subject or accurate lore surrounding it). we'll see though i'll have to play more.  conclusion: get it on sale or try it out if you like these sorts of games. it's pretty fun!

the people who tell you to skip this and go play ruina or limbus first are denying you from an amazing experience. it's not a perfect game or the most optimized game ever but lobcorp is a game that delivers an amazing story with a lot of charm and fun. lobcorp is one of those games that actually made me feel emotions while playing it and it even snuck its way into my dreams and made me wake up in a cold sweat due to how impactful it's music and gameplay can be. the game is hard but it doesn't manage to drive me away since the payoff is immaculate in the story telling and you just can't bring yourself to drop it if you're invested. the later days have super tough bosses and abnormalities but you'll be rewarded with one of the best end sequences i've experienced in a video game.  it's a management game unlike ruina and limbus and although a lot harder for newcomers to grasp and understand it's a super fun and charming experience. the characters are amazing you'll see them in ruina too obviously but to really understand them you have to play this game. they're super lovable and have very realistic and relatable problems. the game just has an immense amount of charm with the death animations for employees or the animations on all the abnormalities that'll make you really happy to see even though they're all pretty messed up. the amount of charm on each abnormality is insane there isn't a single abnormality i hate (but there are some abnormalities added by backers which aren't the best i'll say). it's got a super isolated feeling ruina and limbus can't replicate but it make sense since it's a prequel to both games.   please please please do not listen to people who tell you to skip it it's basically the most important game to understand the lore of the universe and the story is just amazingly enjoyable on its own. ruina is a great game to understand the world but you won't understand the role of abnormalities and distortions all to well without it. it really is the game that made me fall in love with project moon and it's the first one i played all their games are really good and fun and while different than the other 2 games as of now lobotomy corporation is an amazing first look at what this world is all about.

this game is a game that's hard to recommend because of how much you need time you need to sink into it but i really do recommend it because it's truly a special game.  it's hard and will definitely test your patience but when you finally get it down you become efficient at it and you will be able to overcome basically everything else the game throws at you especially since majority of it is just building upon what you learned earlier.  it's definitely daunting at first and even at times i felt like i wanted to give up or that i wanted to take a break from it but the difficulty slowly trains you to watch out for specific things and it's so good at doing that so if you feel like giving up i would just suggest push on for a little longer.  story wise it's really good and has such a good message and the cast is really good and it definitely ties into the main gameplay in a thematic way really well. i also don't think any other project moon game was able to capture the feeling of loneliness that this games story has (which is fair as i think it's the only game by them where that feeling would make sense) and that feeling really heightens the experience.  i feel like one of the best attributes the game has however is that it's obvious that project moon had a really fun time making it stuff like the really charming sound design & abnormality encyclopedia portraits along with the crudely drawn abnormalities makes it obvious they just wanted to make a game that they wanted to make and not what others wanted from them.  at most the negatives would be obviously the jank (the bullet upgrades from chesed don't function at all) the memory leak (probably the biggest issue it can cause drastic fps drops and possibly crashing depending on the scale) along with the encyclopedia making some abnormalities unclear on how they work at first but there's no negative in the game that actively ruins the gameplay and the latter negative applies to a very small few.  overall lobotomy corporation is just a really charming & special game with a really good story that i recommend definitely in my top 3 games  [table]     [tr]         [th]specific part[/th]         [th]rank[/th]     [/tr]     [tr]         [td]gameplay[/td]         [td]85[/td]     [/tr]     [tr]         [td]story[/td]         [td]90[/td]     [/tr]     [tr]         [td]charm[/td]         [td]absolutely a truck load you know it baby[/td]     [/tr]

i'll get to the point. the game is probably the hardest game i've every played. seriously.  just to explain the game the game is about harnessing energy from monsters. the more dangerous the monster is the more energy produced. the monsters can escape and kill your employees either by escaping and attacking them or using special abilities they have. they escape if the little number located out their containment cell goes to 0. some monsters have no number and just has a cross.   enough of the explanation several factors make this game really hard.  first reason: the gameplay is original so you can't use knowledge or skills from other games. this means that even a heavy gamer's skill in this game will be as close to a light gamer.  second reason: rng. i just hate rng. no. just no. all games do have a bit of rng no matter what but this game oh this game. i fucking hate this game's rng. there are things called ordeals and these things are based off of rng. the midnight ordeals will make you suffer and cry if you are a little noob like me and if you played this game it probably is safe to say that the green one is the easiest ordeal. last reason: overall time consuming. this is probably the biggest one. you would have to reset the day if an employee with really good armour dies.
play this game if you think being mentally drained is fun. its a good game.
im a masochist

i got this game about three months ago. 372 hours later i've finished it. overall it's the best 'bad' game i've ever played. i say it's 'bad' in more of an objective sense with questionable design choices bugs and that famous memory leak making the end of the game a struggle against the game's performance. but it's the best one i've played due to everything else. the main gameplay loop of 'pick up new eldritch horror find out what it does use it as another cog in your endless production cycle' doesn't tend to feel stale outside of really long days and learning about each different abnormality is a very interesting experience. the game's 'event' beats also work very well from the higher level of ordeals to the aleph-level threats and the special department events that i won't go into detail with due to spoilers. disciplinary overall was my favourite but each was individual and unique enough that i enjoyed them all (except probably central command's).  the story and writing of this game are also of course phenomenal. each abnormality has its story some better than others and they're a bit less scp than they are just general stories. but they're beautifully written and each feel distinct. the main plot and sephirah stories were also incredible but even better is the game's worldbuilding. the nests the outskirts the backstreets the ruins - all of these locations are brought up and all of them sound enticing. the ruins in particular are never elaborated on adding to this. i feel like this is already long and rambling so i want to cut it short. lobotomy corporation is a very particular game and you'll either enjoy it or not. i can't really say what it is that decides where you fall into though i found my biggest player motivations in the story and the mystery/adaptation elements of working out how to handle each abnormality. this game is incredible and i legitimately can't wait to start playing the sequel - i just hope it can give me as much fun as lob did.  and side note the ending of the game (370 hours later) is the best ending i've experienced in a game.

i'll admit that the gameplay is not the best unless you enjoy watching your agents managing abnormalities and having the facility run smoothly (until something goes wrong of course) but while the gameplay is a bit subpar the story is straight amazing. every character feels like a actual person and you slowly understand them as the days go by. so gameplay: 7/10 (i do like managing the abnormalities okay >_>) story: 10/10

[h1]overview[/h1] this game is a cute but sometimes scary base management game but you're managing scp like monsters. the game ui evolved tremendously than the last time i played it much awhile ago. and the story of the game seems to be have endings now. but if you come from oxygen not included or sheltered like game maybe you found some inconveniences or lack of mechanics that can be fixed by mods. well mods isnt that many lol. [h1]pros:[/h1] - the graphics now chibi like characters compared to older that like doodle lol - we can customize our agent but with lob points (i thinks its annoying we must pay for it lol) - every anomalies is uniques and we must using try and fail methods to understand how to handle one anomalies - the story seems clearer than past updates now we maybe can get some fanart/fanfictions here lol - the gameplay is simple but solid upgrades can be obtained if you complete the side missions in each days [h1]cons:[/h1] - well this game lacks many 2d base management have such as easier to choose which characters you want to focus with autonomy anomaly room/lobby/corridor placement (this one is annoying since i liked everything next to each other to make it easier to manage but the game place it randomly and scrolling up and down is tiring especially there is huge breakout) - if you face the chicken cloud anomaly there is a chance agent inside other anomalies room sleeping there and theres no way to wake them up if you not wake them up they counted as death. unfair i think - also same anomalies as above the game not telling you you can wake some agents with rapid click around their feet lacks of informations popup to what we can do or not. - the selecting certain agents rts style sometimes good but sometimes bad agent move too often to pick the right one we want to move and one to stay. - the rmd of moving agents to room sometimes hit and miss especially to opress one anomaly - theres no indicator of who is opressing who. sometimes get you feel annoyed to supress two anomaly in one division. making harder to split team to opress - the clerk (uncontrolled npc agent) sometimes can help fights or just being feeder dirtying the rooms. annoying. - lack of other things to do there should be barracks where weapons to agents to supress anomalies theraphy room to make agents calmer medic to heal agents pantry to feed agents small healing and stamina recovery toilets/wc to reduce stress and recover stamina for agent turrets or automated locking wall protocol to prevent anomalies going further to surface etc. this game just repetitive after 3 hours of playing. almost no variant - the upgrades above is there in game but came as sop that you must choose between days. - days in game should progressive not we need to end it things. anomalies also added if we added room for anomalies thing also more deep about making room for anomalies that if suitable to them they less likely to breach adn easier to cooperate. add maintenance to room also. [h1]conclusion[/h1] yes as i mention above the game is really simple and hard lol. so quickly finish gathering anomalies energy and end the day is the best way to play the game we can't really enjoy seeing the anomalies and managing agents and how the facility works. the game felt like tower defense than base management honestly. if the dev still want to add new mechanics considering adding those i mentioned above. it could make the facility management more fun and not felt like rushing.

i finally decided to try attempting a mission i've had since like the second day i've owned this game where i need to go through with a day to a certain point until some big bads spawn in the facility that i need to kill. i get all the way through the day with no hiccups even got a few rare items for my employees... feeling pretty good.   i get to the point where the boss enemies spawn and i start dealing with them surprisingly efficiently. game is going wonderfully right now. i notice one of my best employees is a little low on health and i decide to have them drink a special healing juice scp to restore their health for the rest of the fight. she drinks it we kill the bosses we're about to be in the clear and- she fucking explodes.   i check the wiki to see why she exploded because i was so angry and completely befuddled at the sight of her dying from an item anomaly i'd used a hundred times before with no bad things happening. turns out because i had exactly one completely different person drink the healing juice halfway through the day she had a 15% chance to explode. fifteen. percent. and of course out of all of my employees that could have died from it it was one of my best ones with a really good armor set i couldn't reacquire and a good weapon i also couldn't reacquire because of how the game's roguelite system works. the amount of bad luck that had to have accrued to reach those tremendously unlikely odds is astounding. i am livid.  so yeah. play this game but only if you [b]really[/b] hate yourself. :)

came for the gameplay stayed for the difficulty and astounding story. the game as with many games that are extremely difficult is naturally not for everyone.  if you don't cope well with multitasking at times being on a pretty hardcore timer where the punishment is instant loss for falling behind along with no checkpoints in levels meaning a failure is potentially 40 minutes to an hour of wasted effort you likely will stop enjoying the game about halfway - endgame.  the first 25-34 or so days are comparable to the calm and then it rapidly ramps up in difficulty from there.   the gameplay loop is relatively straightforward there are 50 days each day you get a new thing to manage all of the abnormalities as they're called have a different gimmick and a different threat level based off of how destructive they are when something goes wrong. you gradually uncover more of the build and learn more to its purpose with the help of the ai assistant angela and meet what amounts to the departmental leaders of each portion of the building as you go. the main progression (restarting only loses days.) is by completing tasks set out by each department which can range from you will end up completing this on your own to hell on earth. the tasks culminate in this games version of bossfights which slight spoiler: despite technically being optional in that you can opt not to do them it is impossible to complete the game without finishing them and you do have a limit to how long you can wait before completing them and otherwise have to reset back to day 1 if you dont finish them. the endgame is brutal more so than the rest of the game.  along the way a very intricate plot gets unwraveled as you play and you can pick up more clues to it by reading the stories of the abnormalities.  while the game technically has 4 main endings and 1 true ending the first 3 endings are more the failure screens as they are only unlocked after a. beating the game. b. failing at certain portions of the last 3 or so days. the character writing in the game is astounding especially given that i personally wasnt expecting it. and the plot can get very emotional (and also very fucking dark be warned.) at points and will make you feel a fair amount of genuine sympathy for most of the characters.  for the true ending without spoiling it you may also have already guessed this: the true ending is unlocked by 100%ing the game. sits firmly in the echelon of best games ive ever played as it sits in the echelon of hardest games ive ever played. if you can get past the difficulty the game is absolutely beautiful in its storytelling has some of the more creative enemy designs ive seen in a game and in general is fucking great. the game has a sequel library of ruina. its important to note that the true ending of this game does make the plot for ruina make more sense.  i rate the game as is obvious a 10/10.  (last note: this game will give you an irrational fear of train horns.)

i went into this game already knowing all of the story due to having discovered it on youtube and management games weren't really my thing i thought at the time. one of my friends decided to try the game out for themselves however and watching them play through it on stream made me want to get the game for myself. now i have went through 3 runs and beat the game with every abnormality dissolved.  this game is great if your into management types of games albeit it can get frustrating at times. there is quite a lot of stuff based on rng and there is multiple parts (notably day 49) that are not explained well enough in game for them to be fair however i had scoured the wiki a ton so i didn't have as much of an issue. another thing is i already had a vague concept of what each abnormality did going in and i thought it would ruin the experience for me but i soon noticed that it really didn't matter as it doesn't take long to unlock all of an abnormalities info.  overall this was a great game and worth the money for me. i can see how it wouldn't be a game for everyone however as a lot of the stuff can feel like bullshit and in some cases it's honestly better to scour the wiki for information on how stuff works. stuff like day 49 can be quite frustrating too so if you get frustrated easily this game isn't for you. however if you are patient and like management games and have a ton of time to dump (seriously work days take about 30 minutes on average) i'd recommend checking it out!

frustrating but brilliant! lobotomy inc is a well crafted game with a story that meshes very well into the mechanics. while it can be overall frustrating and there is a chance to lose hours of progress with a misplay that sort of 'is' the point of lobotomy. you learn the quirks of each creature and how they interact you learn to avoid some abnormailites while others that you 'feared' and dreaded actually had a bit of an exploitable quirk. yes adding more and more causes the puzzle to become a bit of a frustrating reset spiral but thats the beauty if things are not going your way you can go back a few days. if the mistake came towards the start you can restart the game... and keep all the equipment (unless you made a big oops and saved after your entire facility was murderized) and perks you unlocked in the process. it has a level of 'korean time sink frustration' with chance of drops its a good feeling when you plan out your day according to your facility and then say yeah in the next facility we are not going to select the llama but the sinister pulsating black hole is a suprisingly viable energy source so long as we only have our chads research it!?

rough on lower end pc's that the game constantly tries to shit itself after anything significant for example after completing the hellish day known as 47 and treated to interesting lore the game froze this game is definitely not for everyone and i don't mean that by age rating.  hard stressful management type games are hardly anyone's cup of tea especially when they can be as brutal as lobotomy corporation.  however if you decide to go through it you will find a beautiful and satisfying experience with a solid build up to a great theme and emotional message.  i will always encourage you to try but there's no shame if you can't bare with the game.

i may be in this boat late but lobotomy corporation is anything but a normal game. sure the game thrives off its story but the mystery of the unique world juxtaposed between figuring out how to keep your precious workers from meeting a tragic demise kept me coming back for more (this game has heavy religious undertones especially judaic).   the game is pretty simple to understand but as you progress the game can quickly ramp up in difficulty if you are not prepared. expect trial and error as you manage your facility and don't be dismayed if you have to start over.  the use of music is best defined as minimalist. when nothing important is happening you will be listening to the same track on repeat but when needed most the music more then pulls its weight. the songs are amazing and fit with each different severity.  i could keep going on with this but here is my opinion: -if your interested in the game i highly suggest waiting until it is on sale as the game can easily be something you love or hate.  -come in curious as most of the satisfaction of lobotomy comes from figuring out how to manage abnormalities. searching things up ruins the experience. -don't get too worked up over failure my greatest breakthroughs came after coming back the next day.  most importantly there are so many great reviews for this game. don't take mine as the only one as there are so many different things that can relate to you. i had so much fun playing this game and i wish you only the best.

[b]my score:[/b] 9/10  [h1]prologue[/h1] welcome to lobotomy corporation the leading company in the production of energy through the innovative process of containment and observation of beings known as anomalies creatures that appear in this world with the most varied forms and powers and we would like to congratulate you for being accepted in our staff as the new manager responsible for taking care of the team that will have to come into direct contact with these anomalies to obtain energy we expect great results from you new manager. note the company is not responsible for any bad decision made by the manager that may result in the employees in things such as but not limited to injuries madness phobias deaths of the most varied forms end of the world among many others. ^^  and so begins the work of our protagonist the newest manager of the lobotomy corporation with the arduous and as will soon discover not an easy task of having every day without a single day off fullfil an ever-increasing quota of energy requested while trying to keep employees safe from the anomalies which are both an excellent source of energy but also overwhelmingly capable of killing anyone who comes into contact with them or at least leaving really unpleasant memories. and as a bonus every day a new anomaly arrives at the facility and it's up to the manager to find out information about they before they gets angry manages to break free and real chaos ensues. but don't worry because in your new role you will have the help of the peculiar if i may call it that managers of each of the departments in addition to your assistant the always well informed and cold ai angela. ^^  [b]pros:[/b] + a game with a very different and interesting story where from our first day of work we are presented not only with the most diverse and deadly anomalies but also with other company employees responsible for managing their departments each with their own personality quirks and secrets which little by little reveal more about the present and the very dark past of the company. + huge cast of anomalies with a little more than eighty with the most varied appearances powers that they used if they free themselves some even don't even need to free themselves to bring chaos rules of what they like and don't like history and equipment that can be produced from knowledge about them. + the first game that takes place in the dark and sinister universe created by the studio with the other games taking place in the same universe. it's not mandatory to play this one to play the others but it's interesting to know how it all started. + very unique art style combining the cute with the dark in a well balanced way but be careful because sooner or later you will discover that not everything is what it seems to be in this universe. + soundtrack with songs that match very well with the game and its universe in addition to great sound effects especially for anomalies after all some even use sounds.  [b]cons:[/b] - prepare your patience because many and many times your patience will be tested as it will take a long time to learn all the rules of the anomalies and for that it is necessary that the employees have contact with them without knowing the rules in the first times so mistakes will be made a considerable number of times but nothing that patience cannot solve.  [h1] game mechanics[/h1] thus begins the journey of our protagonist a new manager where we have every day that manages a group of employees with up to five members for each of the departments sending them to the dangerous task of contacting the anomalies and making them happy  thus producing energy. each of the employees has four attributes fortitude prudence temperance and justice these attributes can be improved with points between days or by repeating jobs that have the same color as the attribute you want to improve. these attributes are vital as many anomalies need a minimum value to accept the employee's presence without killing them outright. ^^  which brings us to one of the main points the anomalies beings or objects that present one or several powers of supernatural origin being classified in five levels according to the risk being them from the safest to the most dangerous zayin teth he  waw and aleph with the first level being the easiest but as the level progresses they start to have more complicated rules requiring for example minimum levels or in some cases even that a certain attribute is not above a certain value if no the anomaly becomes very interested in the employee's life for reasons that are nothing pleasant. ^^  [h1] art and sound[/h1] at this point i must start by congratulating the people responsible for the art of the south korean studio projectmoon for having made an art that i think perfectly matched the theme of the game as it is an art that combines the cute and the shady and at the same time it's interesting and well made whether it's the different departments the equipment made from the anomalies the anomalies themselves and the many unique ways that each anomaly can kill. another congratulations to the soundtrack part i liked it and i think the songs are very pleasant as well as i think they made good choices regarding the sound effects. ^^  [h1] conclusion[/h1] lobotomy corporation was a surprise to me when i saw it for the first time i remember that it was at a very early stage of development and that i bought it when it was more advanced and i was really satisfied with what i saw still in development until the completion of the process creating the game we have today. undoubtedly it is a game that i strongly recommend for anyone looking for a very different management experience with a dark and at the same time very interesting story very charismatic characters with their quirks beautiful arts and the large cast of anomalies created by the studio no it's an easy game and patience will be tested but i guarantee the final experience will pay off. ^^

this game is unique. this game has a lot of flaws. the music is excellent. the mechanic to go back to a prior save is in-canon and part of expected gameplay.  the idea going into this is that you do not have the resources or the knowledge to do your job properly. not just on the abnormalities you are working with. you have to unlock *health bars*.  however all research is permanent progression. yes folks this management sim is also a rogue-lite.  you cannot 100% this game in one run. there will be abnormalities leftover and the final cutscene unlocks after you fill out the codex. you also can't do all of the challenges without a little rewinding. (it's a management game of course there's a scheduling conflict.)  rng is capable of making a day fail. a major part of the game is managing risk not just disaster management. preventative measures... once you know what you're trying to prevent and how.  time is weird in this game. some things care about its passage normally but most of the game every task advances a counter between events. if you don't have anything that cares about time you can deal with one problem at a time and have your minions heal up in the main rooms. or you can rush and make things more hectic for yourself. in a way that's very responsive to the way you like to play... until you install something that makes you play differently to survive.  personally i played until i picked something my facility could not handle looked for a guide found a let's play and spent a week reading it. some of the late-game challenges just don't seem like things i can handle because they mess with your pause button and while yes forcing the game into real-time management is a fair challenge... my adhd makes that not great. i do need to refresh my memory now and then and stress makes it worse.
its the best game i've ever played while not wanting to play it at all. purchase if you enjoy suffering

alright with having completed the game at this point i have a few grievances.  this is a good game. it's story is wonderful the art is so nice its very fun to play. *however* getting the true ending of the game is not fun. at first it will start out pretty fun the loop of researching abnormalities getting new gear resetting with that stronger gear and upgrades you've gotten is fun.  the first few of the required missions as i'll call them for lack of spoilers are actually very fun and provide some unique challenge to management. but then the difficulty of them will just skyrocket. expect to spend upwards of a day just to finish one of these missions if that.   i highly recommend the game but... just be aware you are getting into a major difficulty spike towards the late game and it will be punishing and infuriating.   if you dont want to experience that dont get the game and/or mod the game and use the console to skip the problematic parts. it's really up[ to if you like that kind of punishing challenge.

a power plant simulator heavily inspired by shows like 'cabin in the woods' and 'black mirror'.   one of the most unique games that i've ever played and i'm really glad that i got to experience it.  i would seriously pay to forget all about it so i could play it again for the first time.    as much as i loved the experience there are a couple of drawbacks: - there are a couple of really steep difficulty spikes.  i like difficult games.  it feels great when you get past these spikes but yeah there are some difficult days. -  98% of the game is realtime w/ pause... as thematic as that other 2% is i found it frustrating. -  i had almost no problems with bugs until the final big fight... its a crazy difficult scenario and then to have a bug make the boss unbeatable.... grrr.   there are ways to cheat past to see the ending but yeah that sucked.    all that said these are things that annoyed me only because i _loved_ the rest of the game.  i certainly recommend it but be prepared for some bumps along the way.

[b]lobotomy corporation[/b] ~ artificial samsara difficulty: gets increasingly difficult as you progress. length: it took me 130+ hours to get the true ending + secret ending. enjoyable?: lobotomy corporation isn't just a game about managing monsters it's a story of redemption a tale of overcoming the [i]samsara[/i]. my frustrations with the game mechanics became somewhat alleviated upon realizing how greatly intertwined they are with the story. i won't spoil too much.  the premise is basically this: >on the surface lobotomy corporation an energy producing company >energy is extracted from working with abnormalities.  >many abnormalities are harmful. >some can breach containment if mishandled or right conditions are met.  depending on which abnormalities you select you can make the game exponentially harder for yourself. thankfully the game gives you options to make it easier for yourself:     1. unlimited day resets.      2. roll back to a checkpoint day.      3. if things are [i]really bad[/i] you could always roll back to day 1.  for the last two options any abnormality information department upgrades and ego equipment you have at the time will be saved.   you will start off with one department and will unlock more departments as you progress through the game. each department has missions. completing these missions gives you permanent upgrades and pieces of the story. if you're aiming for the true ending + secret ending it requires completing all missions + 100% abnormality dissolution (full observation level of all abnormalities exception of a few).  good luck!

warning: if you are a perfectionist this anomaly of a game is a cognito-hazard. it could potentially be harmful to your mental health. beware.  if you are not a perfectionist and you're willing to continue the game even though your best characters have died even though you're given the option to go back in time and redo everything every single day and you're willing to have a sub-par ending it can be a blast. but if you let too many of your best people die you won't have them later down the line when you have the most dangerous anomalies kicking about and you may need to start the entire game over. in order to gain what you don't have you must sacrifice what you don't have. in this sense this game cannibalizes on itself and is a paradox.  this game should be a permadeath/ironman game where you cannot load saves but in order to do so it would need some extensive quality of life modifications. in order to beat the game as is you must embrace insanity. in doing so you might just arise from the ashes a better person refined by the refiner's fire. but if you fail you may be haunted by eldritch nightmares forevermore.  did i make it through unscathed? no. i was too much of a perfectionist afterall. after playing the game as if it was permadeath in the third deepest department (i think) i realized it was physically impossible for me to suppress all cores to get what i could only assume was the good ending. perhaps one day when i am a stronger person i will come back to this. or perhaps make my own anomaly containment game. only time can tell.  the best part about the game is slowly learning about the lore of all of your individual anomalies. ironically the game's lore itself was the most disappointing part for me. i'd recommend you skip all of it though that is not the popular opinion. again this game is a paradox.  i give this an apocalypse slime girl/10. thank you for the insanity.

lobotomy corporation is one of the best games i've played yet it's a struggle to recommend. although the gameplay may seem like a basic management simulation on the surface it gets quite deep and challenging having to control and maintain the facility. every new abnormality you obtain is an experience as you won't know what it'll do how deadly it is or even how dangerous it is until you work with it at least once. the game is best experienced blind because of this and i would advise against using a guide or wiki unless necessary (don't feel bad looking up strategies for some of the end days). on top of the deep and enjoyable gameplay this game has a fantastic plot to unravel and understand. i thoroughly enjoyed the story and would put it up there with some of the best.  now why do i say it's a hard game to recommend? the game has a very steep difficulty curve. the tutorial gives you just enough to get started and you will fail and lose your employees many times. thankfully you can restart the day as many times as you want and the game even has a separate checkpoint system on every 5 days that you can rewind to at any time. rewinding to these checkpoints or restarting the game from day 1 keeps all your upgrades research and equipment and you are encouraged to restart in the game if things get too difficult to manage. i know this would be a big turnoff to some people but the game has enough variety and it makes sense in a story context that i think it's both a good thing and done well regardless of my opinion on it i do think it makes the game quite difficult to recommend. if you enjoy or don't mind a difficult experience i would absolutely implore you to play this game. it is too good to be passed on. it is a good game sure. the managing aspect can be fun and it has some story which as you complete missions/objectives with the respective department you get story and upgrades. however this is where i have my biggest grip with this: while having upgrades tied to the missions it provides incentives sure thats great but among the few first you get very basic stuff which should already be a feature inside the game from the day 1. specially considering that some are as basic as being able to see the health and sanity bars of your agents increase the passage of time up to x2 and recall the entire department to the staff room so they recover. at first i didnt know about that i was searching like crazy a way to get the bars on top of the agents cause i could never know when they were about to die or their state when an emergency happened the game tells you nothing about this and is very frustrating. once you are past the first few missions it seems that it focuses on providing actual value with the researches stuff like; rooms heal much faster/better or they dont stop when an anomaly steps inside so your agents get healed while fighting. all is good and dandy with these ones but to hide away hud features that are needed is not a good idea. the other thing i have a big grip about it is that the font is soooo f*cking small like legit it has me getting closer to the monitor every now and then to read stuff or whats worse sometimes even when they are already small the space any words were given is tiny so most of the time you will not know what level you agent has a certain skill (each one has 4 they can be up to level 5 these play an important role in the game) the game is from south korea so i can only imagine that with much fewer signs they convey words much more easily hence they dont need so much space. coupling with this the options menu is very very lacking is almost sad audio is only master volume and music volume and sometimes i feel some noises are too loud but it doesnt help much. one of the pros is that it has a big vareity of languages so likely you find yours.  again great game is pretty nice and has some very clever jokes but at times some of these things coupled with a challenging gameplay can at times cut my time with it a bit short even when i would love to keep playing it for longer

i will say i still haven't beaten it plan to finish a campaign this time stopped last time do to old computer issues. but suffice to say there's a lot of potential gameplay in here and arguably a lot of replay value as well.  the most important thing is the atmosphere and story the feel and question of what the hell is going on and this game nails that side really well. the atmosphere is great the music is limited but good for what it needs to convey and feel like. the entities you'll be trying to contain and work with are highly varied and some are things you can basically ignore or easily work with not risks... while others threaten to tear their way out and devour all the staff in your entire base if you don't carefully manage them constantly. the game starts simple and fairly easy... but as time goes on will get really hard as many of these entities might start stacking onto others in some really dangerous ways. overall an excelent and unique type of game that i can highly recommend.  the art is pretty good the aesthetic and atmosphere are great. the audio is also pretty good once again on the atmosphere it works especially great. the gameplay is interesting varied and different from almost any other games you'll have played. the story is very much worth playing for and i say that not having even finished it yet but it hits harder than many so far and leaves a lasting memory.  overall i can solidly recommend this one. do note it does take some time to finish though and if you just want an idle clicker base management game... this wont be for you. it'll start like that most likely... but as time goes on you'll be frantically going around trying to handle issues all over depending on the entitites you end up with on your run.

this is a great combination of management strategy and horror/fantasy. the imagination behind it and the creatures (and how they are selected) is superb plus the concept is amusing and interesting. there's a decent amount of gameplay hours here but oh boy does it become a grind after a while.  the goal is: you manage a facility with the help of some totally-not-at-all-sinister ai assistants and no knowledge of what happened to your predecessors. you head up teams of scientists/workers/fodder who have some basic stats that govern what level they can work to and you send them in to work with the monsters you approve to be housed in the facility. working with them successfully gets you energy. working with them unsuccessfully gets you murdered. heck sometimes working with them successfully also gets you murdered depending on who you've sent into the cage and herein lies the frustration and joy of trial and error research. more work with a monster uncovers more of their secrets and less chance of your prized worker being reduced to a set of bones. it's pretty forgiving though you can restart the day to glue your friend back together.  the day ends when you collect the prescribed amount of energy the goal amount increasing each day. but the gameplay concept stays generally the same throughout so it does become a grind after a while especially when some of the monsters are so damn needy with how often you have to check on them. but the range of beasts is worth playing on i got to day 27 until it flipped from this is fun to this feels like being at work.  so that's the overview but no write-up does the game justice. go play it. if you like management/strategy/horror it's recommended plus it's one of those games you have to tell people about until they tell you to shut up.  and if a doctor comes knocking don't. let. the. clock. strike. twelve. seriously. just don't.

the game's pretty great! the management of the abnormalities (scp's with a different name) is fun and keeps you on your toes as to not send employees to their deaths. the story (from where i am in the game) is pretty cool so far if initially a bit bizarrely presented. the basic gameplay loop consists of choosing an abnormality to add to your facility watching two visual-novel-like cutscenes preparing your workers by upgrading their stats and equipping them with weapons and armor and then managing the facility for the day while trying to get enough energy points to complete the level.   if anything i'd say the game is as much of a roguelike as a management game. when you begin a day you are given a choice between three abnormalities to add to the facility but their names effects and appearance are completely obscured with the only information given being a vague quote from their backstory. but if you uncover knowledge about them during the levels the information gained is now locked in forever. so when you need to use the five day checkpoint system (and trust me you will) or even start from day 1 again you can now see the specific abnormality's name if it shows up in the choices. this allows a pretty interesting dynamic where you can plan which abnormalities to choose as to not have conflicting requirements with other abnormalities. plus all equipment and upgrades gained when resetting to the checkpoint or day 1 also stays.  the only real complaints i have are that the text in the ui is way too small the tutorial is pretty terrible at teaching you how to actually play the game and that the game can get a bit grindy when trying to increase employee's stats. overall though lobotomy corporation is unlike any game i've ever played and though it can be a bit tough to get into the game is still very good.

fair warning this game is a little janky and has a nasty memory leak that makes late-game play really dip in terms of framerate. there are mods to fix this among other longstanding bugs which i highly recommend looking into to smoothen the experience.  but that aside lobotomy corporation is something i could only describe as enticingly hostile. this game is hostile rude sometimes just unfair to you but when you push through its quirks its fangs look past the jaws of every monster looking to make you reset again and again by god it's such a good game.  the lore the setting the way every monster fits in somehow in this messed up world the satisfaction of finally taking down a massive threat with only moderate casualties it's all so so good. if you're a fan of simulation games don't mind a deep dive into a game that tries to make you fail every step of the way give this a go. and when you're done with it either you've beaten it or given up go give the sequel a try.  it's all worth it in the end.

where to even start. lobotomy corp is an scp-esque management where you manage and learn various abnormalities and inevitably fail and get your loved employees murdered by them when you make the wrong call. entangled in this chaos is a rather fascinating little story that plays between each day where you learn just what is the purpose of the facility you manage instead of what you are told at the beginning. it has this very uncanny feeling to it.  but let's not spoil the story first thing first gameplay this game has a very steep difficulty curve. i would say it's not even a curve it's more of a cliff and even after you master it its endgame is in the words of the game itself absolutely brutal. the biggest part of your time will be spent trying to make it through each respective day managing monsters each with their little quirks some simple some difficult some... well apocalyptic let's just say that. most days you will have to add at least one more to your collection and eventually each day will turn into this grand puzzle where you have to keep 80000000 things on your mind in order for everything not to go to hell... and even then it still might because of various ordeals you will have to deal with which are essentially events that happen as you work your way through the day that introduce yet another element of chaos and in essence to keep the cycle from becoming stale as every day will be slightly different and keep you in this wonderful state of constant stress where you are never sure if you make it through the day without getting half of your department turned into red jelly.  the art style is fairly simple the story even clarifies that what you see are not in fact what your employees look like rather it is a filter that makes them look like dolls to prevent you the manager from losing your marbles. and still it manages to be extremely grim and filled with gore your employees can get their heads bitten off they can be possessed and have to be subsequently murdered they can be charmed cocooned eaten mauled frozen burnt shot(by you mostly) turned into trees turned into apostles axed melted go insane explode commit suicide... you get the point. it's great.  i won't spoil the story because i believe it should be experienced first hand if you are the slightest bit interested but what i will say is that it tackles several of very serious topics such as depression ptsd and suicide and delivers a very strong message on the matter if you choose to go for the true ending.  i've owned this little gem since around 2019 and just now decided to give it a shot and after 90ish hours and 100% completion i can say i was blown away and i tip my proverbial hat to project moon for this wonderful game.   p.s.: on the topic of performance the game does suffer from fps drops to such a degree it became a joke within the community even your frames get murdered in this game. it's not crippling but it is definitely there.

from what i briefly played lobotomy corporation comes right out of the gates with a steep learning curve. the game becomes less difficult as time goes on. the art style and general atmosphere of the game are what really sold me. i don't care about graphics that much but this game is so stylistically pleasing that i had to point it out.

this game and i have a funky relationship. the exploratory components of the gameplay the writing the music it is all absolutely stellar. there is so much to rave about it. the thing which irks me the most about this game however is probably the user-hostile experience. i have not had such a user-hostile experience playing a video game before. insufficient tutorial aside there are a lot of weird aspects to the game which seem needlessly punishing. for example e.g.o. loss upon employee death is quite brutal on your second+ playthrough and it adds a needless amount of risk to giving out your most powerful e.g.o. to employees when the criteria for equipping high-level e.g.o. is already so high. in addition the consequences of return to memory repository are quite hard to read into at first. while employees who died after memory imprint come back to life e.g.o. is still lost.  the most punishing aspect of the game is easily the grindy aspect. to end most days you need to reach a certain power output level and this makes replays incredibly tedious. what's more without spoiling some special days instead require you to play through days up to a certain point. some of these days get incredibly long and having someone in your team die with good weaponry/armor during the end of one of these long days is incredibly brutal and demoralizing.  some of the abnormalities seem to be implemented specifically to make you vigilant (or suffer) as opposed to giving you a fun time. of course i can't get into these without spoiling the game but some abnormalities are incredibly high-maintenance high-risk for sometimes little to no reward. the only reason i managed to play this game well was because i had watched streams beforehand and knew about some of the worst abnormalities and how to deal with them as minimally as possible.  there is a modding community for this game and near the end of my playthrough i had to download a few mods because the gameplay was becoming exceedingly disproportionately punishing. i would heavily recommend downloading mods for this game because it is to be frank unfair. there is one abnormality which if you encounter it on a run that isn't your first will potentially wipe e.g.o. from other runs. there is a special day which require you to work for 30 minutes before doing something incredibly challenging and losing on that day requires you to redo those 30 minutes. this game asks for a tremendous amount of patience from players and i do not blame anyone for saying no to that demand via mods.  however the incredible amount of charm and the overall experience was something truly magical. the story made me feel an array of emotions several upon several unscripted moments in the gameplay were fun and memorable and oh my god the music. i cannot speak for whether or not the variable difficulty spikes and punishments are going to be worth it at all to you but if you think you have the patience for this game i would say that i would recommend this game.

there's way too much to do at a ridiculous difficulty too much is up to chance it's endlessly demoralizing... and it's awesome. would strongly recommend using some mods to make things less impossible though the balance is tricky; the mortality rate is part of the whole 'thing.' play at your own risk it absorbed our life for a bit there. got obsessed with one of the randomly generated disposable dough boys who'd survived a long time... had to get the persistent employees mod to keep him forever. just had to. the monsters come in a good variety though there's certainly some clear motifs some of which are unfortunate but overall it works. figuring each abomination's deal is a real good time though it gets repetitive and menial once you've got them. that's kind of the point so mad respect for the vision. the story is dark and intriguing and we still haven't finished it but every time we get a tiny bit more is a victory and a celebration of sadness and despair and hot robots. stupid sexy perception filters. like we want to clear this robot cause they're our favourite but the reward is they're gone from the narrative and lose at least like 10% hotness. once again the game shows itself a demoralizing experience a pure and perfect vision of pointless suffering in all aspects. beautiful. in the end you should play it because we need more people to obsessively talk about it with.

this game hates you.  no really. it hates you. it hates your guts it hates your attempts it will chew you up because you decided to take in a new abnormality (totally not scp) send one of your agents in and 30 seconds later wonder why it mutated into a middle-tier slime that's currently infecting others and cascading into your 5th reset of the hour.  and when the hooks are in deep enough? you shrug it off. you reset. you start seeing your agents as disposable beings that are just there to survive until the next bit. you get to the next day with 3 dead. this is a good thing. 3 dead is easily replaceable. dead people are replacable.  you watch someone grow for 10 days. level 4. researching the higher tier monsters. you screw up. you see them immediately die because the roulette hated them enough that they were chosen for a sacrifice to an abnormality that hits way above your paygrade. you wonder if you can save them. you decide not to. you hit a wall. no matter what this next part is impossible. reset upon reset. a memory imprint a few days back; something's stopping you're not lucky enough the list goes on.  that's fine. day 1 reset. you keep the knowledge of the abnormalities you researched. certain meta tidbits are preserved. you go again. try a few new ones. fall back on the ones that you know won't screw you over. repeat. and again.   the game is jank. the game has questionable elements. the game has a few missing staircase things and abnormalities that deliberately kick you in the nuts while you're down. the game's translation could stand to have stronger character voices a clearer emphasis on how you're supposed to take this game a combat system micro that isn't so finicky on and on and on. it's the product of a failed kickstarter that somehow made it to the light of day in all its flawed glory.  and it works. the brainworms hit me. even when every later day ended with a sense of dread at what's coming next what the plot wishes to give what the characters want to do even when it'd be better to close it and relax...the agents get prepped. the abnormalities are extracted. and the days go on.  what it gets right is the feeling. it has an atmosphere in mind something intertwining directly back to the setting the plot the reason you're in l corp in the first place doing all this while an ai directs you again and again and again. it's the ludonarrative aspect that's the true king here and your enjoyment of this is entirely predicated on understanding what the game wants you to feel and how much you buy into it. the gameplay and stress work so well with the plot that leaving it out for a plot video is a disservice.   it's hard to emphasize how much this game gets right in terms of gameplay and plot working together without spoiling stuff. the barest knowledge is that you're there for a reason. there's a reason why the protagonist doesn't up and quit.  if it's too hard mod it. zero shame. the game is tough as nails. get stuff from nexus mods. super agents (it will not save you). infinite points. learn when your own wellbeing is better than cracking against this wall of a game and break it down with the mods to experience the gameplay interplay with the story at hand. the mods will not make this a 100% cakewalk but it'll lessen some of the more demanding aspects...and not all of it.   tldr drakengard of management sims mod it once you've hit your own personal wall and get the true ending watch the 100% true ending on youtube afterwards unless you want to go and roll for every abnormality and learn about them all  everyone is disposable

since i've finished this game after many many hours of cbt i can finally write a review about it.  first off this (hard as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•) game is a madhouse simulator. you're basically trying to farm energy from a bunch of psychotic monsters called abnormalities (like scps) that are about as stable as my last relationship and just like exes - unpredictable and dangerous. all abno's can ruin your life if you don't pay attention each of them having their own risk level and a set of (initially hidden) rules or guidelines that you are asked to follow to make sure they don't escape and/or kill your personnel. later on any 'accidents' in your facility can lead to a chain reaction of death and decay which will force you to restart the day (sometimes causing you to waste 20-40 minutes :d). btw for the true ending you'll have to restart your entire run once or more since it requires you to have researched all abnormalities! also rng can be a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.  this game is a real ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• excercise in patience and frankly i would not recommend anyone play it. but if you do decide to go through all the pain and hardship... you'll find yourself strangely rewarded. the story is great and is surprisingly deep and intricate. every abnormality feels unique and seeing your facility grow in size and complexity over time feels like you're always progressing. the music goes mega hard. there are mods out there that either fix bugs add some qol new abnormalities and armour/weapons etc.  in the end lc isn't just about surviving through all the days; it's about embracing the insanity that goes with it. it's a rollercoaster ride through a nightmare that you (eventually) can't help but enjoy. it's stressful it's overwhelming but damn it's satisfying.  although i'm sad that it ended it was worth it.

talking about lobotomy corp without spoiling anything is tough so i made a list of positives and negatives to quickly sum up if you should get the game.  get the game if you: -like a solid management-sim game with an scp-like theme. -simple but stylized art that sets the game apart from others. -a soundtrack that highlights a working day's progress (including horrible mistakes). -a story that has a cast of really memorable characters actually explains several core gameplay mechanics and continually gut-punches your emotions as the plot develops.  don't get the game if you: -are easily stressed in sim games and are not looking to change that; the game can feel [b]very[/b] overwhelming to 1st timers in management sims by the halfway point. -are turned-off by unorthodox art and ui styles; the visuals and menu systems are far from perfect so i can see how some people can get frustrated from just looking at the game.  thank you for making an amazing experience project moon!

lobotomy corporation is a management game based around a legal scp facility masquerading as an energy company to power a post-geneva convention world ravaged by wars; where everything not under government jurisdiction has degraded into a ruined future detroit populated entirely by cannibals and starving children (not much has changed really).  you play as the manager of this godforsaken company where with the help of anime waifus/husbandos with various interesting personalities (such as hyperactive tomboy clinically depressed drug addict and oddly feminine man [all of them]) you must harvest energy from lovecraftian abominations normal furniture and children.   with the divine power granted to you by an ai literally designed to cause neuron activation you must task your 'willing' employees to perform well-informed and ethical experiments on 'abnormalities' in order to reach the daily quota of energy boxes.   employees are squishy adorable completely mentally stable nuggets whose lives should be valued and cherished which is why there is a designated button for killing them. feel free to murder them lest they contract eldritch herpes become possessed by shoe demons go insane or just for because you feel like it.  abnormalities require experimentation to gain any information about them whatsoever including which works will cause immediate death or breach. their names range from utterly incomprehensible to suspiciously literal to outright lies which is why you should treat 'nothing there' with utmost caution.  if that wasn't enough each experiment you perform will add one to the 'qliphoth counter' which will eventually result in a 'qliphoth meltdown' which causes a set number of random abnormalities to gain a 60-second timer that will result in immediate breach if you don't work on them before the timer is up.  sprinkled throughout these meltdown levels are 'ordeals' which come in four varieties: dawn noon dusk and instant death (midnight). depending on what colour and variety you get citizens of detroit meatballs or irradiated maggots will spawn all over your facility. this is completely unavoidable and your only option is to try to kill all of them before they explode or eat your employees.  finally there are boss fights scattered throughout the game that i can't tell you about rest assured you get spoiled. however i can say that i wholeheartedly enjoyed getting eye cancer and watching every one of my employees become subject to set's stand ability from jojo's bizarre adventure: stardust crusaders and only lost a small piece of my soul.  overall this game is very fun and i would recommend it to anyone who enjoys games made for people who desire suffering like anime girls or have heard of scp in any way. 10/10 would watch helplessly as my resident waifus attempt drug overdose while god's aborted fetus destroys my facility again.

amazing game but tough to widely recommend. i will try my best to write about what i consider the features that this game shines best and might interest others.  the story its characters and the world they live in its an amazing experience exploring aspects of humanity as honest as it can be. this is the harder aspect to recommend avoiding spoilers but also the most satisfying in my experience. the game builds up slowly and gives no sign of being anything out of the ordinary for a good bunch of scenes and suddenly it just all connects and there is no stop to wanting to know what is going on and how it will end.  (if its any clue that the writers are into something day 1 [spoiler] they throw at you the terms sephira and malkuth and there is an obvious graph resembling an inverted tree of life on the department. [/spoiler])  the world building within itself is great and its later further developed by the direct sequel library of ruina and the side story comics released.   its genre is very niche a facility management game as the core gameplay. depending on experience and certain abnormalities currently on the facility this aspect of the game can be overwhelming or very simple.   a big challenge from this game is figuring out how abnormalities work derived from how they look the obscure lore they come with or other strange patterns they might show. as many would claim that the abnormalities are what make the game reach ridiculous levels of difficulty its not a reason to fear picking it up due to the memory repository system which lets you weed out abnormalities you do not wish to work on your current run serving also as check point every 5 days ingame reducing the difficulty by a whole lot if handled properly.  the game rewards restarting from day 1 you keep research levels observations on abnormalities and certain events that happen during the story. had a bad time? shake it off learn from the experience and get ready to go back in next time.

what this game did that really stood out for me is meshing the gameplay with the story and setting for an incredible storytelling experience. a non spoilery example of this would be that the game frequently brings up how employees are constantly being killed in the facility and as the game progresses you will pretty much inevitably become more and more comfortable sacrificing your employees lives for minimal gain. this type of stuff about the game really helps add weight to the story in a way only games can and i wish more games made this part of the core of their design philosophy.   however i find it hard to recommend this game in general due to the fact that this game is not only incredibly long but also in my experience the first ~10 hours or so of the game were not all that engaging. the game can be very slow and the appeal of the gameplay (which is essentially figuring out the rules of how to contain/deal with these spooky/funny monsters) is not immediately obvious. my best shot at explaining why i and so many people like the gameplay comes down to the really creative designs of the abnormalities (in terms of not only gameplay but visuals and lore) which can make obtaining information about them quite fun and also once you start getting to the mid game you will have abnormalities that can interact with each other in interesting (or infuriating) ways which really forces you to evolve your strategies as the game progresses.   another interesting point about this is game is that while the early game is easy and peaceful this game quickly starts putting larger and larger obstacles in front of the player to the point where it can feel daunting or even overwhelming. i actually really love this about this game because the difficulty is so unique these obstacles are less often a numbers or rng contest and more so a change in how you have to play the game and its so incredibly refreshing. this makes the obstacles all feel fair and unique not to mention super satisfying to overcome.   personally this game is an easy 10/10 and def worth the money but for some it will just not be worth the time

this game is super unique calling it korean anime scp management would be an understatement. its community is wonderful filled with talented artists shitposting meme creators to people calling one of the characters emo it's just a funny community.   the gameplay is interesting it's really hard to explain what is important in this screenshot because everything is important at this point i want to introduce you to your best friend the manual now it's not like an old nintendo game where you got a physical manual or like fallout new vegas where you get a digital manual or team fortress 2 where you get a joke manual on the dispenser its a digital manual accessible at any time (there is only one time where you can't get it open and you get told that thee shall not open an instruction booklet for jezus crust is here it explains everything in a useful and short way.  now the third part i will talk about is lore. now imagine playing minecraft and you decide to break obsidian with your hands with mining fatigue 3.  that is how thick the lore is! here are some needed words to know: fixer sweeper claw wings feathers districts (lobotomy corp is district 12) arbiters.  now for a little interesting thing. take a look at the sephirah (your ai npc characters you will grow to know and love) and their map of the facility. then google up the jewish tree of life. you will start to see something neat.  tldr: play the game read the manual look up the entire lore look up the jewish tree of life embrace bong bong (a running gag in the community) and of course:  face the fear build the future

what can i say about lobotomy corporation that hasn't already been said? it's probably one of my favorite games. it perfectly scratches that itch in my brain - the one that loves management simulators and the one that loves brutal difficulty. i've spent countless hours perfecting facilities getting equipment and crashing and burning horribly due to my own inadequacy. i hate this game. i love this game. tales of woe paint the walls of this place.  if you love learning by bashing your skull against the wall this game will capture your heart. it will capture it too hard. it will crush you in its iron jaws and you will smile.  i had recently acquired a new beast whom i quickly was able to deduce became irritated as the overload counter increased. it inevitably escaped and though quite tough i could recontain it with my well-equipped staff. she however on her way out did kill several lackeys and thus irritated another entity and it breached as well. this one harder to deal with but not insurmountable. once the first was dealt with the second was dispatched as well. alas! the third act of this story led with it another abnormality who raised hell when things escaped. this one not so quickly dispatched. it was a beautiful falling domino of my own creation.  on the other end of the spectrum however was frank. frank was a boring low-grade agent whom i hired for the fate of certain death against something i didn't understand. frank however did not die. he lived against that thing through luck. and through madness through nightmarish events through it all frank lived on wearing nothing but a suit and wielding nothing but a baton. he got himself a nice promotion fantastic gear and retired to the upper levels for an easy career beating down weak anomalies.  fortune favors the bold and the foolhardy alike. if you don't know anything about this game and you've played management simulators and gotten bored from the ease of it or if maybe you like darkest dungeon give this a try. it might stick. it might not. either way project moon is a very interesting studio that i'm happy to follow in their future endeavors.

does not respect your time. is this game interesting? satisfying? enriching? do i still think about it months later? did i endure this experience for almost a year? did i fall even deeper into it as i got an injury that restricted the selection of games i could play? did it become my white whale my dark soul? yes.  i would advise against playing this if you value your time at all. this is a game that really does deserve the abandon all hope all ye who enter sign i am writing for it. in one way i respect how the pain and suffering this game generates artfully intertwines with it's story. in another way i feel like the design of this game is lazy and leans into some shadowy corners that are better left untread.  i understand that difficulty is very enticing to a certain type of person but if my tale of woe has enticed you listen to this. in most games the difficulty lies in the *skill of execution* or *mental analysis*. lobotomy corp's difficulty mostly lies in *tenacity* and *a resistance to despair* with a sprinkling of *exploration of un-signposted systems* along the way. this is not a place of honour.
