this game is so goddamn good. i am not typically a fan of management style games but this one really knocks it out the park and has managed to keep me hooked.   if you find scps and their backstories interesting you'll love lobotomy corporation as it has similar creatures (dubbed abnormalities that you must work with and manage them in appropriate ways or pay the price.   this game is also really harsh if you do not want any employees to die - a perfect no mistake play through of this game is nigh impossible but that's exactly what makes it so interesting. along with this you also get to learn the captivating stories behind some abnormalities and their origin.   my friend gave me this game ages ago but i never saw it interesting enough to play but sure enough after giving it ago i was wonderfully surprised. even though i got it for free i would buy it regardless. literally going to buy library of ruina (the next game set in the same world) just because this game is so goddamn good.

this is the gateway drug for project moon games and each characteristic of this game that you love is expanded upon in their series in this universe. the mystery only grows as more is revealed in lor and trailers for lc (limbus company) the gameplay becomes less random and more complex the music (and i know this sounds nuts) gets better. this game is like trying to get water from a cactus and while that can be painful at times; it's an amazing feeling to drink from the fruits of your labors. if you ever truly get stuck there's no shame in looking at the wiki but only ever do it if you've tried to figure something out at least a few times.   if you even remotely think this game is fun get through the malding and you'll have a key to one of the best crafted universes i have ever experienced.

now to say that this game's rating is complicated is a bit of an understatement.  the game's story is phenomenal and truly builds up incredibly to it's sucessor library of ruina. however the game itself is *very* rough around the edges. it is poorly optimized and does have a few glitches here and there. the gameplay loop is also definitely not for everyone but that couldn't be more false for the bossfights; as tension builds up and you're in a mad scramble trying to get everything together until finally the day finished window pops up and you take a sigh of relief as you take the next few days to collect some more e.g.o. before the next bossfight.  i recommend this games mostly for it's highs as it is a game of incredible highs and pitiful lows unfortunately. if you're not much into story and moreso like braindead gameplay you should try ruina instead then. but this game has quite a bit to offer. i'd recommend modding it with basemod and getting optimization mod and whatever quality of life mods you may prefer after playing it a bit since apparently there's an on-going trend of amazing unity games being horribly optimized. (looking at you valheim)  overall i'd give this game a solid 8.8; the story is fantastically jaw-dropping and had me going what the f*ck and holy sh*t at least 17 times with it's several twists and turns and i personally enjoyed the gameplay even if it's not for everyone but the downsides of poor optimization and lack of polish at times is a bit too detrimental to the game itself at times.  if you think this game seems like your type don't be too bothered by my warnings and definitely go for it. it's quite an experience. but if it doesn't look like it then try picking it up on a sale.

i'll break this down into positive and negative categories.firstly the pros the story is nice and engaging ordeals prevent the game  from becoming to stale in a run. the soundtrack is nice and i never found myself getting annoyed by it for the entire time i was playing the game. the tutorial at least for my explained everything i needed to know nicely so when i was in the game nothing was too confusing. some of the abnormalities have quite interesting mechanics and trying to see what works and what doesn't is part of the fun of the game!  secondly the cons this type of game certainly isn't for everyone it can be quite grindy at times and in some cases you may even have to restart all over to day 1 because certain challenges are exponentially harder in certain conditions. in my run of the game i've also experienced a few bugs such as an abnormality going invisible an abnormality deciding to up and teleport when they should have no ability to do so and an abnormality not going back into its containment after killing it and just staying there to list a few. another thing to note is that this game tends to lag when certain events occur my computer rarely ever lags for anything even games like valorant apex and overwatch on high fps yet this game dropped frames quite quickly but asking some people there is supposedly a mod to assist in dealing with the lag.  the game can also be quite repetitive at times.  whether this game is for you or not leads to one major question: how much are you willing to fail redoing things countless times to the point of lunacy do you enjoy a type of game where all your progress can simply be gone by a fingers snap? if you like the challenge the game shouldn't be too bad for ya.

scp foundation ft. hot anime girls demonic abominations religion god and more.  edit #1: after 55+ hours of slaving away at days i'm back at day 1. don't expect to beat this game on your first run and never give up keep grinding don't let the game beat you.  edit #2: after 75+ hours of playing this game i've realized chesed is a bitchass motherfucker hoooooly shit who invented his 0 iq speedrun missions???  edit #3: 80+ hours in i'm back to day 1. don't touch me almost made me quit the game. don't buy this garbage.  edit #4: 85+ hours in the third and final world reset. third time's a charm baby no more resets from here on out straight to day 46.   edit #5: 120+ hours in. never get queen of hatred clouded monk big bird smiling bodies and some others. these abnormalities want nothing but to make you miserable. fuck this game. also midnight ordeals i hate 'em.  edit #6: 135+ hours gebura's core suppression forced me to come to this. for the last time the fourth reset. the ultimate finale.   edit #7: at 160 hours i've come to realize that binah is a fuckass bitch. who the fuck conceptualized her degenerate mechanics!? i know one thing is for sure whoever did must've realized that gebura was just too easy because her ass was handicapped to a fucking room! binah's stride alone causes qliphoth meltdowns how?! this bitch has the audacity to have my employees running around the damn facility just for them all to be killed by a pillar flying at light speed dealing infinite pale damage huuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuh!?!?!?!?!?!?! actual retarded game please give me a refund and never consider buying this (edit of edit #7: i can't believe binah is this easy.)  edit #8: at 167 hours i re-enter the endgame. it's been a while day 46.  edit #9: 180 hours. day 49 is the bane of my existence i might have a mental breakdown because of it. (edit of edit #9: backward clock is the holiest abnormality in this game.) [edit of edit of edit #9: all my employees dies in day 49 your sacrifices weren't in vain control team we've made it. but i'll resurrect you one last time the original five to complete the last day together and my last day as manager. it's been fun.)  the true review of the game:  after 184 hours of playing this game it has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time. the above was just a joke review for my entertainment but i think this game deserves something heartfelt. there are three things that i think this game does a great job at and that make it worthwhile.  symbolism: this game is so much more than it is at a surface level. the story is quite understandable i'm sure if you went back and watched every cutscene you could put two and two together. but take a step back and try searching up the etymology of some of the words the sefirot the names of the sefirot the seed of life the names of a the names of the abnormalities what do they actually mean? this game is very symbolic and the message it delivers is so much more profound when you know where its inspirations come from.  mechanics don't grow old: if there's one thing to complain about in games with many mechanics is that the way you play the game becomes obsolete once reaching the endgame. mechanics that you would once use in the beginning of the game are replaced by overpowered endgame gear or abilities that leave those tutorial mechanics without purpose. this game does it different if anything it makes you consider more mechanics and expands on mechanics the more you play the game. things like the stat level of your employees when working on certain abnormalities the time it takes if they're hurt or not how many employees die in the facility i mean what do you think the point of the sephirah meltdowns were? completing each one added onto your mechanics and benefited you. i mean control team's mission reward literally establishes the mechanics you use to play the game for the rest of the game. that is being able to see your employee hp/sp speeding up the game and having the ability to send employees to work in other departments.  the gameplay compliments the story: this one is awesome. i can't say if project moon made the gameplay compliment the story or the story compliment the gameplay but it goes both ways. the cognition filter gives the developers to make the game look cartoony and friendly and it misleads you you later grow to understand that this is a very fucked place. even abnormalities like censored take the cognition filter to a next level. the reason you're able to retry days and go back to a memory repository is all a part of the lore as well it's very interesting when a game does that.  ultimately hats off to project moon my journey with this game was a fun one and i recommend it to anyone. though this is just one chapter of my journey not the end of my story. so i must turn to the next title library of ruina; this was one hell of a game.

you might be intimidated by the managerial nature of this game. you might be intimidated by the hardcore aspects of the learning curve. you might even think it's just scp but anime.  you're wrong and i want you to try this game out. just try it. it's amazing. a story and world of unique proportions. it's not just scp anime but monsters inc. - you use these weird things called abnormalities to produce energy but with employee fatality rates most readily compared to the early days of the industrial revolution. and you have a time machine to try again if you fuck up too badly. anyone can win this game and 100% it it's not about skill or your ability to fulfill your goals; it's about decision making and perseverance. whether you choose to continue and learn or stop and start over with the knowledge you gained committing time crimes.  oh and library of ruina is waiting for you once you decide you've had enough of this. and go read the other things from the developer project moon. they even have webcomics and other media related to this series and it's all amazing. wonderful even.

im an avid enjoyer of project moons shenanigans and this was one of the first games ive encountered that they made. tbh ive heard about the second game a lot too (do check library of ruina out very cool) and people were telling me that you cant really understand the second game if you havent played lobotomy corp.  in a basic form this game is has pretty complicated lore and difficult gameplay (if you arent really into trial and error and arent very patient) you get to manage abnormalities with your employees and collect energy from the monsters as you work with them and most of them (if not all) have some sort of adverse effect behind them. the game gives you information on the the more you work and if you dont unlock that information and mess up with an abnormality youll risk something in some way. every abnormality is unique and has varying threats from no risk at all to lovecraftian horror. you also have an advanced artificial intelligence guiding you named angela and you get to meet other people along your journey as a manager. you expand on your department and unlock new skills this game really encourages progress and its really worth it if you push through. its really unmotivating if you fail but extremely relieving and rewarding when you succeed.  unfortunately this game is quite buggy at times and laggy sometimes an employee will die for no reason whatsoever and can only leave you to assume said employee simply spited the world and leave you hanging. this game isnt originally english either sometimes the translation can be quite confusing and theres gonna be some tidbits of korean left over in the game. theres also depictions of gore and some horror but everything is in a cartoonish style so its not too horrible you are dealing with the unknown after all. the soundtrack is absolute fire love when the facility is falling apart and a dj party is going on i recommend this game strongly and its given me plenty of fun times and pain project moon really did it with this one. through all the polishing and fixes this game went through its pretty nice to see it where it is right now

this is the game that starts you in the world that projectmoon wants you to be in. it will be full of difficulty and suffering. things will go wrong. they will go wrong in the worst way possible. if you don't see it happening it means bad stuff is happening somewhere. after a short time playing it i admit i cannot go much further without having a real breakdown. it was certainly fun but i suffered more. if you are like me you will reset the day a hundred a thousand times over before reaching a perfect ending that i did not reach. i feel all people should at least try this game before moving to its much better and slightly more fair sequel. will you suffer with me for the story the world building the characters and of course the music that haunts you after repeating so many times. to me it was worth it.

great game and story!   it's like 1990s simtower except all your residents want to suck out your brains and transform them into self-aware fuzzy pink slippers or well just eat you.  that said please be aware that this game can get extremely grindy - levels last a long time by the end and one simple lapse in attention can lead to a failure cascade and losing half the experienced staff that you've painstakingly leveled up (or pressing the restart button).  this also means there is plenty of content to sink your time into though which will be a plus for some.  'combat' can also be difficult to manage with some monsters/bosses requiring you to maneuver your agents precisely to avoid instant death - which the controls definitely don't lend themselves to.  the last few levels in particular are an extraordinary challenge and i somewhat doubt most gamers will have patience to see the true ending.  however even if you can't quite make it to the end (like me!) it's still worth it to go as far as you're willing and able before resorting to watching the cutscenes elsewhere.  the game's excellent worldbuilding leads nicely into the studio's well-done sequel library of ruina which manages to feel enjoyably similar even with an entirely different genre and style of play.  overall this is a fantastic game that you can sink plenty of hours into and one i may replay someday when i have the time and patience to try and beat the last few levels on my own.

the gameplay loop of collect energy got repetitive really quickly but the puzzles and boss fights for lack of better terms were incredibly rewarding to figure out as well as figuring out how to properly use a dangerous abnormality. the story was incredible the abnormalities are cool and creative (for the most part) and recognizing the less obvious fairytale abnormalities from the source material and the jewish-mysticism religious themes that the game so heavily draws from made me feel educated and intelligent (as opposed to feeling like i knew a bunch of useless trivia).  a fantastic game i don't regret a single hour spent on the main flaws being that once you 100% know what you're doing and don't have an immediate progression goal to work toward the gameplay loop gets boring (meaning that it in my opinion has little replay value once you've 100%ed it) and the game is horribly optimized; once you get your middle layer departments the game starts lagging like hell even on a machine that was high-end when it came out which is mostly just annoying although it becomes a serious issue near the endgame particularly during [spoiler]a boss fight that involves a lot of multitasking on a very tight timer while unable to pause.[/spoiler]  overall amazing game with the caveat that it's super not for everyone and its particular brand of difficulty can be extremely frustrating if you're not very patient.
the women are the scariest in this game

lobotomy corporation (or lobocorp) is a monster management game with similar themes to scp. you manage a facility full of these abnormalities and research them extracting energy from them in the process. as time goes on you get more and more with their own rules. some of them are very deadly! some are very helpful. sometimes they will escape and try to wreak havoc and as such you will need to have your employees re-contain them.  the game can definitely be difficult at times but it is very worth it for the games thoroughly engaging plot and interesting world. there is also a comic that released after it taking place during the events of the game‚Äî wonderlab which i recommend reading! (although it's not required by any means.)  overall a lot of this game is best experienced blind. the game features some rogue elements like how resetting back to day 1 keeps the research and gear you owned. i will be honest and say the game requires some willpower but that's part of the experience.   good luck manager!

the game is very challenging for beginners and can take a while to beat your first completion. however the game does reward the player when they take risk. the story itself is enjoyable and has enough lore to keep you interested.   overall good game i highly recommend it if you are up for the challenge.

washing machines live longer with calgon  (its very good but very hard and if you aren't into trial and error it probably isn't for you. there's a lot of bugs that do not appear as though they are going to be fixed and while none of them are game breaking and many seasoned players may find it adds to the charm it is very noticeable and occasionally frustrating. the game suffers from performance issues and crashing when played for extended periods of time and you can't save during a day so i would recommend closing and reopening the game between days if you intend to play for a long session. you will not be given information about the mechanics or preferences of the abnormalities or other threats you will deal with throughout the game and must figure it out for yourself through simply trying things and paying attention to the results - this is intentional and by design. despite all of this if you enjoy management games don't mind trial and error or loss of progress and can tolerate cartoon violence and gore lobotomy corporation is a hard recommend. the game's story holds a special place in my heart but even if you are not too interested in story the cutscenes are usually not very long and the gameplay stands well on its own.)

mountain of smiling bodies sucks

the game is rather rough around the edges - the music doesn't transition very well the ui is a bit of a pain to deal with many of the game's systems are needlessly complicated or overexplained controlling employees is annoying as they can be randomly deselected and it times overlap each other making selecting a specific one difficult text is not in a consistent font size or alignment which bothers the hell out of me as someone in publishing and even post-patch there are still some translation issues though i suspect this is not nearly as bad as before.  having said that the game is so compelling that it is easy to look past all of these issues.  the scp foundation is one of the most interesting creative writing projects on the internet so playing a game where you're effectively managing a scp foundation facility and trying to discover how to exploit and contain dangerous objects and entities is very interesting. from what i can tell these are all original entities not copies from the scp foundation though they are just as interesting. this is great if you've read tonnes of scp write ups already and are worried you'll have an 'unfair advantage' going in.  the game describes itself as a roguelite and while that's sort-of true in reality you can play it how you like. you can play until you accidentally choose an entity you cannot handle or figure out or which kills all your staff and start over where you retain the gear you manufactured and the entity information you uncovered allowing you to more quickly catch up to where you were. if you don't want to go back to the beginning you can rewind to before you selected an entity or simply retry the level. this flexibility makes it easier the play the game the way you want without being tempted to look up spoilers which you really shouldn't do.  as you get further into the game it gets increasingly complicated with you needing to handle more and more entities at the same time. you'll need to take notes and pause regularly to handle it.  overall very interesting game and a great scp foundation simulator which could use a little polish.

at first it seemed like a mediocre management game it turns out it has a very nice story 9/10 game do buy it   gameplay is slightly repetitive because of the rouge-like elements which help a lot probably necessary for getting the endings and/or the true ending  notable cons: for some abnormalities (basically scps) you'd have to spend ages to figure out how to research them without instantly having them escape so checking the wiki was needed to not make it a pain in the butt  surprising pros: there's a lot of unique death animations

this is an overall good review/thesis but there is some criticism. everything involving the story is great but gameplay has two flaws which not everyone will experience equally. the first is that the game provides little to no advice on when or even why to restart which left me and likely many other players futilely trying to progress when we should have cut our losses. in roguelites which is what lob corp advertises itself as you are forced to restart (by dying) after a relatively short amount of time due to a lack of skill/upgrades. but in this game you get no clear indication on when to restart or how it will even benefit you. it's more akin to an idle game where you intentionally trade in your whole run for special upgrades but in those cases it's very clear what benefit you receive and when progress has slowed down. you also invest a lot of time in your first few runs in lob corp which makes it doubly difficult to throw it all away. the end of my first run around day 37 was definitely the most frustrating and terrible experience i had with the game which i wouldn't have eventually resolved if i wasn't interested in the story. if loading the game or starting a new day fills you with a combination of apathy dread anxiety or stress to the point which playing becomes unenjoyable just restart or rewind. pushing forward will not help you and upgrades will eventually come which drastically speed up the early game for future runs. the game should have better emphasized the importance of restarting and completing missions by actually showing to you what it is you stand to gain or at the very least not locking it behind a difficulty spike. after i came to this realization the rest of the game was substantially more enjoyable and progress felt satisfying.  the second flaw is that combat is wonky and information within the game is sparse on how certain things work. this can be seen as a good thing because it somewhat simplifies combat and emphasizes broad decision making over precise strategy but the system is very finicky and feels very unnatural when facing tougher foes. it can feel like you're trying to grapple with the game and even cheese it but it's truly the intended way for it to work. sometimes the game expects certain specific responses from the player which are not easily supported by the movement system which can lead to irritating struggles that only feel difficult because you can't move agents precisely. admittedly this problem is much less severe and can be circumvented with proper preparation or luck but this preparation can be deceptively difficult due to the other information that the game hides such as the mechanics behind work success rate and work xp. i suggest that toward the end of your playtime that you consult a wiki or guide for info or even use an info mod like i did but this is quite late into the game and you can probably decide for yourself. it's definitely possible to enjoy most of the game blind which i recommend. no matter what the game is repetitive and rewards grinding but the atmosphere keeps it from feeling monotonous.

had a hard time getting into it to which ended up getting so into it i accidentally stayed up all night playing.  great story very challenging and fun gameplay that will test your memory. am i forgetting something? nah it can't be that important -> choo choo third trumpet time the game is brutally difficult but it is designed with that in mind. don't worry too much about losing when you hit a wall you can rewind back to a previous day but you keep all your progress (abno research/missions/core supression bonusses) so when things get too tough you can essentially redo while keeping your progess.  in essence losing and rewinding is part of the progression don't spend an eternity banging your head against the wall retrying the day and roll with the losses if they aren't too severe and rewind when you hit a wall  my biggest gripe with it however is that it's pretty rough around the edges when it comes to micro managing your agents.  especially so when you are blobbing and can't see health bars underneath eachother makes it difficult deciding when to fire health/shield bullets.  a lot of mechanics later in the game punish you for blobbing like this but that isn't until later a lot of problems in the mid game can be solved by bumrushing it with pointy sticks and guns

i got lobotomy corporation because i was really interested in playing projectmoon's newer game library of ruina when i first saw it for sale (i might still) and i heard there were tie-ins and callbacks to this game in lor and some of the players were saying you won't get the full experience in lor unless you play lc first. ok that's all well and good i love a good bit of worldbuilding and lore.   however from what i have played of lc so far i can tell it is not the game for me and that it is going to be a huge time investment time i do not have to play a game i am not fully enjoying. it's not the difficulty i love difficult games. it's not the management genre i play my fair share and i love games like crusader kings and the old tycoon games and have nothing but respect for the greats of the genre (which many of them like this game aren't my thing).   if you love management games and you love challenging games this is worth your time to at least look into. the story and the gameplay mechanics unfold beautifully like a flower each day more difficult than the last. i can't tell yet if the game is satirical or self-serious regarding management and the corporate mindset. the decisions you make are cartoonishly sociopathic but it's also totally in line with how a powerful large corporation operates. either way i was able to set aside my contempt for this mindset irl and laugh at this goofy power fantasy video game. as you progress each day more characters are introduced and management gets more complicated as you have to hire more employees train them delegate tasks and deal with new abnormalities and their weird behaviors. it gets real sweaty.  the abnormalities (monsters you harvest energy from) are varied and interesting and sometimes funny. the ones you get are picked from 3 random boxes at the end of the day with cryptic flavor text that hints at what is inside. death is inevitable replaying days is inevitable. if you love fiddly little numbers and boxes and systems in your games this is gonna give you the biggest hard-on. the soundtrack is nothing but bangers which is great because you're going to be staring at this thing for 100 hours at least from what i hear.   so do i recommend it? yes but with the caveat that you really look into it and see if it is for you first because this is about as niche as it gets. i'll end this by saying i have nothing but respect for projectmoon and what they have done here. i feel like i gave lobotomy corporation a good old fashioned try but i'm going to set it aside. thanks for reading.

a friend said it's a good game but hard to recommend and that sums it up  lobotomy corporation perfectly.   for context most of the games bought and played on steam aren't actually finished as a matter of fact i can tell just by looking at the review playtimes that the vast majority of people haven't finished the game. if lobotomy corporation had achievements to track how many people actually finished the game i would not be surprised if the completion rate was less then 3%.  why is this relevant? because if you want a fun and kind of addicting simulation/management game for the first 10-30 hours then this game is good! you definitely get value out of it for the 10 or so dollars it goes on sale for. the story is amazing i almost cried several times throughout the game the music is great as well but...  if you want to actually finish the game then be prepared for agony it takes around 100-130+ hours to actually finish it and that's not because the story is that long as a matter of fact all of the dialogue can be read back to back in around 30 minutes or less. the reason the game takes so long to beat is that the endgame is absolutely brutal and will require at least 2-3 repeat runs and by the time you're on the third one the game definitely becomes a slog. i was going mad i thought several times about quitting the game and leaving a bad review because it was getting really hard and i couldn't stand the thought of resetting it again or trying for another day. nevertheless with some help i pulled through.  and it's worth it. the pay off is worth it not gonna say much obviously but do not be afraid to get help or tips during the last ordeals if you're at your limit because you should see this game to the end if you've made to that far anyways.   so yes if you do want to get this game just understand that the late game  is absolutely brutal and will require at minimum 100 hours to finish.   it's not for everyone but in order to build the future you have to face the fear and the ordeals that come with it and only then will your core meltdowns be suppressed with enough time.

a solid challenging experience of trying to figure out what measures must be taken for the proper containment of otherworldly abnormalities. these abnormalities start out relatively harmless and simple but as the game progresses and you expand deeper into the facility more dangerous and complicated beings inhabit the halls. truly enjoyable experience experimenting on each abnormality and watching my workers die as i inevitably send them to their deaths.  i wonder if i do this he'll get eaten? yup he got eaten.  a word of warning however- this game if you wish to complete it is mercilessly grindy. you'll be restarting your run often as you as a manager obtain new skills and abilities after certain points and each time it'll be a long journey back to where you came from. near the end after defeating a certain black haired boss i had to convince myself to play through the multiple weeks to get back towards the end replaying content with the now-familiar abnormalities. as a first time player you're not going to know which box contains which horror meaning that you can just get screwed from the outset if you're unfortunate enough. watching friends play and seeing they got some particularly tough combinations from the start sucked.  still if you're up to the challenge i'd recommend lobotomy corporation. i had a genuine good time feverishly scrambling and being surprised whenever something escaped containment and turned my people into bees or whatever. the story is told at a slow drip pace but is intriguing enough to keep you coming back until the very end.   the cuter the abnormality the higher likelihood its a nightmare to deal with lmaoooooo

lobotomy corporation is a game i do not think i will ever forget. there are several moments in this game that hit such a legitimate harmony of music and emotional investment that they live in my head rent free and will most likely do so for many years. that being said the game is what i like to refer to as a korean autism management simulation in that the concept of repetition is so core to the gameplay loop that it has direct plot relevance. the game is easy to learn and gets gradually more insane with one of the most rewarding skill and power curves i can remember in gaming.  the game is extremely frustrating this is a game where 100% completion is not optional as there is no way to properly beat the game otherwise. i can guarantee you it will take you a minimum of 100/125 hours. do not use wikipedia for this game do not research strategies. experimentation and discovery is beyond core to the intended experience of the game.   this review may not be the best one or even a necessarily appetizing one but in all honesty i love this game with all of my heart. i will never do a playthrough of this game again and i do not even recommend it to many of my friends. it's amazing please buy it.  also if you skip this game to play library of ruina i will tear your soul from your body and i promise you will be fundamentally unable to understand several characters

i can't play this game for too long periods of time because of the sheer number of casualties and body count  of my employees that seems to accumulate over time. their screams and mangled bodies weigh heavy on my mind. however lobotomy corporation is an absolutely fascinating game! a management/roguelike(lite)/horror game that consistently manages to stress and astonish. a cute and somewhat basic art style for the grunts clerks and agents at your disposal and hundreds of intricate well-made portraits and designed abnormalities causes a delightful contrast for the mediocre and macabre. every time something goes right in this game you are wrong. look elsewhere in your facility.  no annoying notification noises for when something bad is happening a bona-fide s-tier soundtrack and many distinct sound cues between the abnormalities give massive credit to the team for their sound design. surprisingly deep customization for those same previously mentioned grunts and only hints and a choice to decide what abnormality is coming soon to your facility not only keep you yourself as the manager on your toes but provide many options to pick and choose favorites both normalities and abnormals alike. along with a surprisingly lenient learning curve a handful of rng elements a challenge mode and the ability to skip dialogue lends an intense amount of replayability between saves and accepted defeats.  the game has also received many an update from the legacy version to the more updated and refined version that is defaulted when you purchase the game.  this game is a 10/10 at its best and at its unfathomable worst it is only an 8/10 perhaps 7/10 if management sims or roguelikes(lites) aren't your thing.  a genuine steal on sale but still worth a purchase if any of the above interests you. (no this is not an scp game but it's in a similar vein.) also the default language is south korean and i must recommend changing it from the settings. there is also a wikia for general tips or outright strategy.

easily one of my favourite games of all time now. bought it on a whim after seeing some fan characters and i liked the looks of some of the main cast. i don't normally enjoy management sims but this was totally different.  it's a hard game. i still haven't beaten it. but doing my best to get through the later days and the challenges is such a thrill and incredibly rewarding. the soundtrack is wonderful (if drum and base is something you enjoy although there are some very nice piano and jazzy tracks). there are subtle details that really add to the tone of the game (the shift in oh no things are going wrong in the 2nd warning theme versus the its all over now 3rd warning theme? masterful.)   the story is a lot more than i expected. i was anticipating scp clone just do it because we can. instead it's this story about grief regret and what does it take to forgive someone if you even can? all wrapped up in a cute exterior (which has a lore explanation too!!! get to day 10.) i love scp but i feel i actually care about the world this game is set in. and so much of the lore is hidden in dialogue or monster files (as you learn more about a creature you can access it's story files. they are just as fun to read as playing the game!) it took putting the pieces together from multiple character dialogues to finally learn what a sweeper is in the lore. everything has a reason here.   watching the gameplay does not help to get a sense of the enjoyment it really is one of those games you have to physically try and feel the stress for yourself. although that one video on youtube of the full qligoth meltdown does give a taste of the monsters ahead the number of deaths expected and the three theme songs you will likely hear many many times.  i cannot stress enough how much i enjoyed this game. no it is not for everyone. it's a strange style of game that does have it's hiccups (and certain very detested monsters. fuck you plague tree.) however it is a rich interesting world with fun mechanics great soundtrack and hours of enjoyable stress. you will love your employees and try to keep your faves alive. additionally there is a sequel game (library of ruina) a webcomic (wonderlab by project moon. it can be read standalone but many concepts will make more sense playing the game) light novels (distortion detective) and soon an app game (limbus company.)  the many shells cried out manager. want to see? welcome to lobotomy corporation.

this game is pain yet i can never stop coming back. lobotomy corporation is a tough as nails management game but has an extremely satisfying feeling of progression. you start off with relatively harmless abnormalities to contain but over time you'll find yourself dealing with objects with terrifying god like powers.   you'll find yourself failing again and again as you learn the ins and outs of each abnormality in your facility. abnormalities that may have seemed impossible to deal with first will eventually just become a simple part of your daily managerial routine as they go from overrunning your entire facility to eventually just becoming a minor bother. nothing really beats that feeling of overcoming the creature that wiped your strongest units 10 times over.   do be warned though lobotomy corp will still continue to throw everything at you as you develop your facility even further. you will fail a lot often by things you couldn't even foresee. if trial and error isn't your cup of tea you may want to give this game a pass.  however if you love the idea of uncovering the powers and backstories of incredibly fascinating abnormalities i do suggest picking this game up and going in completely blind. this game definitely benefits from having you not know a single thing about what you have to contain.

really entertaining game for masochists!   ---> many negative reviews concerning the game's translations should be disregarded that issue has been looong gone. i do agree that this game will not be kind with your time though which makes the game difficult to recommend to others  the game's nature of constant trial and error (which can be very time consuming) may make this game frustrating for some. the lengthy tutorial does offer a lot of information for you to digest and i understood most of the game's mechanics by experiencing it but i'd still argue that going through the tutorial is absolutely vital. if anyone's worried about the game eating up a lot of your time there are a few quality of life mods on nexus that can be installed including macros and boosted chances of obtaining gifts which i highly urge you to use in late game.  restarting/resetting the game seems to be encouraged and will make each run easier because of the accumulated gear and rewards from missions you've completed. the fact that you are able to pick which abnormalities you can introduce into your facility solely from a quote in their origin is a big part of the fun or your demise....... the story (which is really great by the way) is slowly unfolded through each day you complete and you are expected to piece it together. please play lobotomy corporation before ruina  finished game at 142 hours 1.29.22 :d

this game is really fun! it's a combination of management game roguelike and even rt strategy. the gameplay is really good for my taste - there is a lot of things to uncover and do and all of the elements work well with each other. if you enjoy first hours of game you'd enjoy the rest.  the interface is hard to wrap your head around initially but you get how to play surprisingly quickly so after initial frustration it works pretty well.  the anomalies is my favorite part of the game. some people cheat by reading wiki but i personally enjoy uncovering features of every anomaly on my own. it's really nice and interesting there are a lot of passion and unique ideas in every anomaly and you never know when you're going to pick one that will genocide your entire staff. it's even quite scary at times despite graphics being so cute because you never know what to expect and sometimes everything can be destroyed and get really bloody and gruesome from a single wrong decision.   can't say much about plot yet since my progression through the game is really slow since i keep trying and erroring (i find it quite fun and satisfying!) but it looks really promising and the lore of the game is really interesting to get into too! seems like it's going to be deeper than it seems so far!

lobotomy corp is a game about researching monsters for energy for the betterment of humanity.  as a whole this is a game i can strongly recommend to anybody to go and try. however i can also get that while most people will have fun in trying it it can be a bit overwhelming or even cruel to people who want to beat it (especially 100%).  each day you get a new abnormality you have 0 information about ones you had before and as such you must send employees to research it. chances are often times you'll have employees die in the process but that's part of the process. once you get what makes monsters tick you can reliably farm them for green energy.  the fun part comes from the fact that each monster has it's own things that make it tick. while the game starts off with a really simple premise it takes advantage of every single thing you could possibly do in this game and as such keeps you on your toes. and i do mean everything. there are some that react to simply your management skills all the way to what one might assume to be a bit more benign such as where the camera is.  as days go on more and more abnormalities exist in your facility and in turn more and more opportunities for things to cascade into bigger and bigger problems. for example one abnormality might break out killing a few employees causing another abnormality to panic and break free and since stuff is breaking out another abnormality might jump out of their cage in response causing other abnormalities to escape. one or 2 small mistakes can easily cause a range of issues if you aren't prepared. and that is the fun meat of the game.  if i have any issues about this game it's that the tutorial could explain things a bit better. it very loosely explains how even core mechanics such as exp on employees work or how bullets work or how the reset to day 1 actually works (it's more than just 'reset all progress')  overall a fun game that can be brutal at times especially when things go wrong but that's the fun of it. not a game every person will be likely to beat but a game most people can at least sit down and enjoy for whatever time they do with 0 regrets. a unique take on a genre that is fun to simply experience at least once.

lobotomy corporation is as the game's own summary says a monster management game with heavy horror undertones and very much inspired by the scp foundation series. you take command as the leader of a research facility that's here to extract energy and apparently to learn about these monsters. there's a lot of fun to be found when reading the descriptions of these abnormalities (as the game calls them) and the story sections slowly clue you in very well on how things are going [spoiler] unless you skip them for some reason >:( [/spoiler]  the game has been said to be frustratingly hard and this is especially off putting (other than it being a different genre of game) to folks who were told to play this game first then library of ruina simply because of the lore and story impacts. personally barely a few hours into my playthrough i realised that i would definitely quit if i kept going for a 100% blind playthrough so i just looked up not-plot relevant spoilers on how to deal with (some of) the abnormalities when i became hardstuck. now that i'm currently 70% into my playthrough i feel like this is the right decision however the game is still really hard asf lmao as in you will be retrying multiple times and this is by design. you're supposed to be discouraged and frustrated but that makes success all the more sweeter.  some people say discovering the quirks of each monster is part of the fun but i can't really relate when it takes so long and there's so many monsters to figure out and time is precious to me. of course some other folks don't like the minefield-esque system of discovery while also not liking having to look things up when they hit a wall because people say blind playthroughs are more fun. that aside there's also people who recommend you to simply just look up the story on youtube. personally i still find the management and expanding the facility addicting even though i ruin the fun part for myself and the story bits still feel deserved and more enjoyable when i worked for it.  overall i recommend the game part of this game for people who like management games and completionists who want to experience this (soon to be trilogy) series by the books instead of just watching the story on youtube (which is also fine. people have different amounts of free time available to invest in things they're not 100% sure are worth it). might edit this review later once i'm done with the game or leave it as is.  p.s: [spoiler] child of the galaxy is the best abnormality also don't hesitate to sacrifice your employees despite how cutesy the game makes them look. [/spoiler]  ------------------------- after a few more hours -------------------------  i'd like to admit to being an absolute coward. [spoiler] gebura [/spoiler] made me a little too frustrated and [spoiler] binah [/spoiler] finally really broke me. i read that the later days are even worse so i simply just gave up and watched the rest of the story on youtube. seeing how insane they got made me a little regretful but at the same time glad that i didn't have to deal with that shit lmao. that said...  i'd like to preface by saying that when people say the artstyle/music is good they're obviously being subjective and there's no need to say that its their own opinion. but it is amazing and i enjoyed enough of the soundtrack organically that i can appreciate a lot of the music tracks outside the game way more (even though on youtube/soundcloud you'll find that there's literal tens of them there's a lot). the characters are very stylish and the whole hebrew naming scheme in a lot of the game's lore is something i've never seen before so it was a very fresh and cool experience to the usual anime stuff i've consumed lately.  i can't wait to hop on to library of ruina now which i hear is easier needing less reaction time and management skills (which isn't my forte). it being a card game is a big bonus since i like theorycrafting in those. knowing nothing about lor i still think i enjoyed a majority of my time spent with this game. if you like a well written story and expansive lore world building (both distinct things) you'll have a good time.

it's like miitopia but instead of giving your sprinkles to a mii you shoot your employees.  around day 21 is where it starts to get good and hectic especially when you complete the requirements for the mysterious core suppression you keep seeing. monsters that were once harmless suddenly release other deadlier monsters. and you might accidentally teach some of your employees that letting monsters out of their enclosures is noble. and you start to figure out each tiny monster type (ordeals) needs to be dealt with in a specific way - some of the weakest dawn class ordeals become serious threats if you don't place kill teams in anticipation of them and the second threat level - noon - can outright wipe entire departments in under three seconds even if all your dudes have max stats. i am not exaggerating it will happen in less than three seconds even against those weaklings.  other than that it's got the usual relaxing and addictive management sim vibes. but also the heart-pounding nature of roguelikes and rtss.  [b]edit after 40 hours:[/b] all my clerks are going to die anyways so i now spend several minutes a day activating their kill chips so they don't leave bodies as helpful as those would be for my cannibalistic agents.

rewrote this review because i've played a lot more!!!  - - - lobotomy corporation is one of my favourite games of all time.  everything about this game keeps me wanting to know more about (insert character) or what is the story for (insert abnormality). it keeps my tiny attention span fixed on the game and the incentive to keep playing which i find difficult for some games to do. just overall big fan of the lore   the music throughout the whole game is so good. from the menu music and when the worst thing ever happens and trumpet 2 goes off. mmmmmmmmmmmm ear blessing  i could go on for days but for now im just gonna say i love this game so much. chefs kiss

this is a game that is designed to not necessarily be won but be played. if you decide to get into it you will play it a lot because it is that kind of game. other than the most basic of tutorials the game is an exercise in failure. you will fail you will fail a lot. at 100+ hours into the game i can't even begin to remember the number of times i have failed restarted days rewound weeks started over from day one. and that is the point. you don't lose everything when you restart from the beginning with each run you learn more about the creatures the events the rules that govern the game. with each run you should be able to progress further and further and learn more and more about the facility you run the world around you and exactly what you are doing in this ungodly hell where sneezing at the wrong time can get half of your employees ruthlessly massacred by all manner of horrific contrivances.  this kind of game is not for everyone if you are not willing to fail to reach a dead end and to start again don't pick up this game. if you're willing to take the time the game asks of you however you can find a surprisingly deep involved and fun experience.

i can't stress enough how much i love this game it quickly became one of my all time favourites. that being said it's not a game that will click with everyone. the gameplay can be clunky and grindy at times.  it starts out slow as well and takes a bit until it really gets into interesting parts. and it is also hard as hell.   if you can overcome these things and get used to how the game works it is a blast though. the music is great the story is interesting and the character and monster design is amazing in my opinion. it was always a thrill to discover a new abnormality and see how it works and what it can do. i had exciting battles aganist apocalyptic creatures forcing me to figure out strategies to finally beat them. after about 90h i finally reached the end and wished it never ended and i could just keep playing the game.   one thing to note is that it is advertised as a rouge like but i don't think it fits that category. it does scratch the itch of a hard and replayable game. but it is lacking permadeath and procedural level generation. if you come in looking for those this will not be the game for you.

lobotomy corporation is a litmus test for how much a person weighs innovation against their own toleration for jank. there is little derision in this sentiment i truly think this game is creative enough to be worth a persons time. but compromises are going to need to be made to run the final gauntlet and reach the ending of this expansive and mystifying odyssey through a unique take on the dystopia genre.   i don't want to say too much about the game as its best to go in blind (although there is an issue with this in that the tutorial is godawful ill expand on this later) but the gist is that you are the new manager of an underground megacorp who extracts energy by sending in employees to interact with a variety of monsters most of which fit into the new weird classification rather than your frankensteins and draculas of old. this is purely a management game which is not a genre i am well versed in at all but despite this i found myself falling into the groove of things fairly easily. most of your time will be spent trying to mitigate complete disaster usually at the cost of your miserable employees lives who only put up with the grueling task of being thrown into rooms with nightmare machines  because its somehow even worse on the surface.. this might sound stressful and in a way it is but whats compelling is learning more about the monsters themselves as the more you learn the easier they become to manage and each monster also provides unique armor and weapons to give to your employees if you work with them enough (there's also upwards of 80 of them)  despite being fresh and unique down to its bones i do not consider lobotomy corp to be a timeless game. the hope is that someone will one day take the ideas in this game and present it in a format that both respects the players time and has a better player onboarding process. that game would be timeless. my 175 hours of playtime spanned the course of 3 years which included completely walking away from the game several times over. by the end of my final run getting 100% and seeing the epilogue i felt satisfied emotional and wanting to see more of this world. but every time i think of that number 175 hours i think about how the bulk of that time was spent grinding my employees resetting the week; resetting the entire game and i cant help but feel that there is a way to deliver the meat of what makes this game special in less than half of the time it currently demands.  i'd like to add here that not all people will take this long to beat the game but i trudged through without the use of guides or wikis and i honestly believe that's the best way to compliment the games mechanics. going into every day having to manage  a new monster you know nothing about one that could potentially throw your ever growing ecosystem of monsters into a cascading nightmare of violence and horror is at the core of facing the fear so to speak. the highs are extremely high in this game and its slow and creeping dread cultivates some of the most organic holy s*** oh god no moments i've ever seen in the medium.   the other issue (that unfortunately this game's also fantastic sequel suffers from) is its absolutely abysmal learning curve right out the gate. just read the damn manual! withstanding  a bunch of still shot images hamfistedly explaining the myriad of this games systems is worsened by using an esoteric vocabulary for pretty much everything. within the first 10 minutes mechanics with monikers such as e.g.o enkaphlanktyn quiploth counter and p.e boxes are thrown at you as if you are already extremely well versed in jewish mysticism. i imagine more than 70% of the people willing to try this game will be put off by how overwhelming this all is. combine that with the fact that its best to look up as little as possible to truly immerse yourself in the game's mystery and you've got yourself a deadly dichotomy at least as far as player retention goes.  this issue comes back to that phrase i used earlier jank. there's more than a handful of places where the mechanical flow and quality of life of this game could be greatly improved upon. even down to just naming conventions for example the 4 employee stats are named fortitude prudence temperance and justice which are all improved by doing the equivalent work types on monsters: instinct insight attachment and repression.  there's no reason for these stats and works to have different names besides flavor. don't get me wrong i'm all about going to flavor town but not when it comes at the cost of unnecessary obfuscation. some things also just straight out aren't explained and i didn't even find out until over 100 hours in that you could highlight an employee and then right click on a monster to send just that employee to go work on it despite that employee not being in the same department. its also never explained that the more damage from a monsters matching attack type the more you will gain exp of that specific stat.   in the end it comes down to what you're willing to put up with for the payoff. this game is hard and attempts to put you in the fetal position every chance it gets. there's a few things you can do to help iron out the kinks such as the more information mod which gives you actual percentage values for everything in the game instead of  generalized phrases suggesting your work chance success. and while i didn't use it myself (and now wish i had) there's a mod that increases your chance of getting ego gifts (unique cosmetic perks given at extremely low odds like 1%) which i think would balance out the games absolutely brutal difficulty for a lot of people.   this game will probably always be niche all of project moons games might be unless they figure out how to teach their players their games. but if you can trudge through it all and take the time to learn the game inside and out upon reaching the end you'll look back upon one of the most unique and memorable experiences the medium currently offers.   its a weird position for me to be in because on paper i would never just recommend this game to anyone casually. but if you're the kind of person willing to make the dive face the fear and build the future then definitely try it out. i think you'll know in the first 2 hours if its something you'll enjoy.

i give this game a yes because i like the concept but i dislike the execution. not that this is a bad game. i am sure that there are many people that like this game and will like this game but it is not for me. this game requires that you be alright with repeatedly starting over because you don't know what your doing. you will be dealing with supernatural entities of which you start out knowing nothing and have to figure out how not to get everyone dead on your own. it was fun at first but i slowly realized that i hated not knowing how to deal with every new entity.   this is a game about repeatedly experimenting with what works frequent restarts and slow but eventual success. know that before you buy.

i learned the kabbalah took a philosophy class took a psychology class and read an entire book of the bible in one incredibly manic night. the real joy of this game is in piecing together the story and then looking deeper to uncover what it's actually about. i don't like most video essays but this game is probably one of the few where looking into it to that extreme is warranted and one of the few pieces of media where it enhances the experience of playing it. i would recommend playing the first few days and then looking up the game's article on wikipedia it has no spoilers but will point out one of the game's most obvious references and the one it commits the most to. the game's actual story is pretty good to but there's nothing like the feeling of falling down a rabbit hole this deep.

this game was made for a very specific type of person and that person is me. despite the grind despite the jank and despite the slow start to the story this game has managed to soar right to the top of my all-time favorite games because despite all its flaws it manages to create a unique experience that literally no other game can provide. gameplay: it boils down to this: get a new scp-like entity every day; send little men to research them and gain their essence; turn this essence into unique weapons and armor that helps you survive stronger entities all while collecting daily energy quotas. sprinkle in some combat avoid containment breaches and generally try to avoid casualties. story: the story is great when you actually understand what's going on but the game presents information to you in a confusing almost backwards way often stating things without explaining them until much later. what i will say is this: first off the writing starts out pretty 'eh' but slowly gets better over the course of the game until things get pretty crazy. secondly unless you're paying very close attention the whole time i would recommend rereading the latter half of the game's dialogue after you've beaten the game- not necessary but it's really easy to miss important stuff. the grind: this game's grinding isn't that bad but it is there so you ought to know about it. there are 4 color-coded stats 4 color-coded work types and 4-color coded damage types. if one of your little men does red work for example their red stat would go up at the end of the day. it's really just a matter swapping people around who need training in different areas though at the end of each day you also get a number of points you can use to instantly level people up. difficulty: this game can seem really intimidating for new player from all the information on-screen but you only need to pay attention to a few things at a time and it quickly becomes second-nature. unit control during combat can be pretty unintuitive and while microing is very possible it can be a little tricky to learn for the first time. the game mostly expects you to set up squads beforehand that are resistant to the damage type of your enemy and retreat if things get too hairy. the game itself starts out pretty relaxing honestly but slowly becomes more and more stressful as the days progress. as for actually *completing* the game let's just say it will be time consuming and brutal... extremely brutal. [spoiler] day 49 took me 24 hours over the course of 4 days to beat. that's what i get for trying to do it without any casualties. [/spoiler] that being said if you're willing to play through the game several times and do a lot of stat grinding along the way then keep at it relentlessly until you succeed. so yeah if this game sounds interesting to you i would highly recommend you give it a shot. it's a long game: it took me about 300 hours to beat but i played so much of it because i thoroughly enjoyed (almost) every second of it. you could also totally beat the game way faster than i did as i wasted a ton of time. the sequel to this game library of ruina is another legendary game that is also worth checking out even if you're not into the gameplay of this one. this game goes on sale for $10 every once in a while so keep an eye out during the next big steam sale.

this game feels very unique in its design. best way i can describe it is creepypasta spc management simulator rpg. the overall goal of each 'day' in the game is to interact with objects or creatures brought to your corporation to harvest energy to power the world. each of these creatures behave differently depending on both how your employees at the corporation interact with them and outlying factors and events in the corporation overall. as you progress through days the managers of each department slowly become unlocked and they all have challenges for you to overcome before a small 'bosslike' battle with them is unlocked. it is a trial and error roguelike gameplay style where it is expected you will fail and inevitably have to reset your overall run to start again with previously gained knowledges.  overall i have loved the game for a long time and recommend it to anyone looking for a different gameplay experience that i myself have been unable to exactly find anywhere else.

i am going to preface this review with my opinion upfront; i do not like this game neither the story nor the way the game explores game mechanics.  this does not mean it is a bad game and that is why despise me disliking the game personally i still recommend it.  for those looking for an scp style game this isn't it. it comes close though. allow me to explain a bit.  you start off as a manager of lobotomy corporation; a company trying to solve the world's energy crisis by utilizing abnormalities. in order to collect energy you must study the abnormalities collect information personalize each one's containment cell and so on. you collect abnormalities by selecting from 3 unknown (boxes? look like movie projectors but i'll keep going) each one with a clue or a quote to hint towards the abnormalities nature.   i personally dislike picking from a set of boxes and would prefer to actually try to contain the abnormalities firsthand but this is a minor gripe and nothing not easily overlooked. besides; it must not be your department to try to contain them but another department entirely.   and then that brings up the biggest issue one that started small but slowly grew; you are a company first. containment is merely the byproduct of needing the energy from the abnormalities. enforcing quotas over study and research and so on. this slowly irked me until i could no longer enjoy the game itself as the company aspect and feel grew only stronger from there.   if you want to play a soulless company that happens to study abnormalities contain them but whose primary focus is draining them of all their juice this game will be for you and worth the price.   one note i will add here is that you don't get to decide how your base is laid out. i feel like this was a massive wasted opportunity as deciding where rooms are what corridors go where and so on would play a wonderful strategic role when focusing on containment and defense against breaches and other groups of interest.

a very unique experience. this game seems to be a simple management game at the surface but it has a large amount of depth. the story is very interesting and the drip feed as you progress through the game kept me invested wanting to progress. there is a lot of trial and error and the game is very unforgiving but it does make for a very rewarding experience whenever you finally do overcome the obstacle in your path. it is clear that this game was made with a lot of passion and while it isn't perfect i thoroughly enjoyed my time with it. its sequel library of ruina is without a doubt the best game i've ever played and it is made so much better if you've played this game first. project moon is easily my favorite game developer.

i've finally beaten this game for the first time and decided to write a review. to preface this review most of the issues pointed by the negative reviews are no longer relevant. the translation issues have been fixed. optimization is still not the best but there are no more memory leaks in my experience.  [b]warning! this game is not for the faint of heart or people that lack patience. the game can become more difficult the longer you play and you will have a better experience if you treat it like a roguelike as the game expects you to restart and there is a specific mechanic in the game that allows you to rewind time while keeping some of your progress.[/b]   [b]overview[/b]  pros : - the only scp-like management game that you'll ever find - story rich game in a cyberpunk dystopian setting with fantasy elements - roleplaying elements - unique monster mechanics and interesting lores - the game will throw surprises at you - character customization for employees - hard game  cons : - ui is a little bit clunky - fps drops sometimes - gameplay can be a bit repetitive - training employees can be grindy - hard game  [b]full review[/b]  lobotomy corporation is a monster management game where you manage creatures called abnormalities in a very scp like fashion. you play as a manager overseeing abnormalities by assigning your employees to work on the abnormalities. each of the abnormalities has its own set of rules to determine how to best deal with it. these rules are hidden at first so you must do a little experimentation before you can unlock them.  each day that you complete a level you have to pick one of three abnormalities that are offered. as you progress more the threat level for abnormalities that you encounter will increase. you will also discover that not only you have to manage these abnormalities on their own some of them can also interact with other abnormality. this is what i will call a combo. some combos can be helpful to you but a lot of them are really deadly. this is where most of the difficulty comes in.   as i mentioned earlier the game can be really brutal and if you find yourself stuck on a day or level because you can't manage these abnormalities it will be better to use a feature called memory repository to go back in time. it will allow you to repick abnormalities. worst case scenario you will have to reset to day 1 but don't worry as you will keep your abnormalities informations and equipments. you will also find yourself progress the day a lot more quicker than before. the negative is the game can become a bit repetitive after a while especially after you unlocked a lot of the informations and equipments but the game will throw surprises at you and it was enough to keep me interested.  as for the story i personally really like it. without spoiling anything the story takes place in a cyberpunk dystopian setting with a lot of fantasy elements thrown in which i don't see that many of. it is presented in a style that is similar to a visual novel. this game also has a sequel called library of ruina so if you are interested in the story and world of lobotomy corporation you might want to check that game out as well.

the game constantly trains you to not give a shit about your employees' mental health and/or wellbeing with this we can conclude this must be jeff bezos's favorite game. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- initializing system                                        accelerating energy convection                                    running sephirot protocol  i wrote the jeff bezos joke 164 hours ago just when i was starting lobotomy corp. after finally finishing the game and thinking about the experience i feel the best way to describe lobotomy corp is a blood diamond.   overall i disliked most of the time i spent playing the game.  the game itself isn't very fun it's a very micro-managing heavy game with not a lot of options to actually make the game entertaining; you unlock some options thought the game but most of them are options that you should've had from the very start.   the difficulty ramps up constantly and the random anomalies make your choice almost worthless since when you first start the game you won't know the monster that gives you a nice hp boost from the one that fucks everyone and everything up and you have no way to appease it because you need an aleph(highest level) armor to even try to without your employee ripping his eyes out. so yeah go back to your last checkpoint- oh that was today? too bad don't pick a fucking aleph next time dipshit.  as i said there's a lot of blood covering up this diamond. but underneath all this gunk the diamond shines like a sun.  the story is captivating and is the main reason you're going to want to finish the day for those sweet sweet 30 seconds of juicy l o r e. every new concept that is introduced is more interesting and intriguing than the last some revelations can sound very abstract at first but as the story goes on they become more concrete. the characters are also a huge highlight as they are all an absolute delight even minor ones that don't show up very often(looking at you myo). the world project moon has created is fascinating and it's no wonder the sequel takes place in this same derelict wonderland.  which makes it even more tragic that the game that accompanies this world is not as grand. at the end of the day i wholeheartedly recommend lobotomy corp but only up to day 45(do the core supressions if you want) or hell until you get tired of it; then go watch all the endings in youtube. with lobotomy corp i feel i experienced a 12 hour game in 170 hours. i'm glad i played it though
