sometimes an experience comes around that is in many ways kind of bad but still pretty good. the gameplay might be frustrating or the design isn't fully coherent but underneath all that grime and rough shell is an experience that is interesting unique or fascinating unto itself. i haven't played something like this in a while but after almost reaching the end of [i]lobotomy corporation[/i] i can firmly state it belongs in this category.   the basic gameplay structure of [i]lobotomy corporation[/i] is simple. it's a management/rts hybrid where you control a series of little doll-workers called agents in a massive underground laboratory. what's being researched here? all manner of eldritch abominations godless horrors screaming masses of flesh and the odd what if this fairy tale was fucked up creature here and there all collected under the umbrella term abnormality. after selecting an abnormality for the day you take your agents and select one of four works to perform on the abnormalities such as instinct work to feed them or insight work to learn how they work which produce e-boxes that fill a daily quota that rises slowly with each new day. once enough e-boxes have been collected the day ends and you're granted a score that allows you to hire new employees or improve the stats of older ones. following this you're allowed to expand the departments where the abnormalities are kept and given research tasks by the a.i's who manage them to help gain an edge and the next day begins.  however working with the beasts and ghouls that are imprisoned within the facility is far from easy- if the monsters aren't trying to break free from their bondage then they're doing some kind of horrible other thing to your workers. each abnormality is completely unique in their containment measures and much of the learning process of the game is figuring out how to keep each critter under lockdown lest they bust out. these containment procedures can be anything from don't do this specific type of work to don't work on this abnormality if you have an agent level lower than v to working with this abnormality after working with this specific other abnormality will cause the former to breach which makes each terror wonderfully unique and memorable. as you work on abnormalities more and more you unlock greater details of their containment from their true name their disposition towards certain kinds of work to hints on how to keep them contained. even better once you fill out the managerial guide for taking care of an abnormality you can cash in the points you earn from working with them to craft e.g.o. armor sets and weapons or receive powerful stat-boosting gifts. these look bad-ass plain and simple and it feels excellent to finally master an abnormality long enough to make a devastating new weapon or effective suit for your agents to wear. watching your employee force go from barely-equipped bozos who can't even handle a single attack robot to a mob of freaks ripping apart anything that moves feels awesome and rewarding. the loop of getting a new abnormality mastering its containment and then reaping the rewards of keeping it in your facility feels very rewarding though it does become very tedious after a while.   you might be wondering if the entire game is about learning how to manage the abnormalities what happens when you learn how each one works? the answer is that the game becomes rote and tiresome as you go through the motions of assigning work and watching a bar fill up with little in the way of stimulation. there's little risk for each abno breaking out if you're diligent with your work which makes for a management experience that is pretty darn tedious. combat fares no better- while your agents can fight against the escaping abnormalities and the occasional invading force the microgame of controlling your units mostly consists of left-click dragging your entire force right clicking on an enemy and waiting until their hp drops to zero. if the enemy is particularly dangerous then you have to learn to highlight said allied force click a room away to force your guys to move out of the way while the enemy attacks and then left click them all again and move them back into place. it's like playing [i]dark souls[/i] in the form of an rts and it sucks. even worse are the lack of assisting features. there's no way to select your troops and create groups (which would be very useful since many difficult lategame encounters involve splitting up your attacking force into different damage types) no way to automate the work process with each abnormality and nothing to do but watch your employees hit stuff until it dies while ordering them out of the way if things get spicy. combat thus becomes more tedious than fun which means the management and the combat aspects of the gameplay are both pretty boring. combine this with a game design that emphasises grinding for hours on end and a difficulty scale that could be charitably called schizophrenic and you have a recipe for a game that loses its luster very quickly. the sheer tediousness with which the basic gameplay of lobcorp conducts itself is a major turnoff for me and makes it hard to play the game for long period of time when meaningful progress is my objective for the day.   speaking of difficulty lets get back to that subject. lobcorp is hard. like a high-tier abnormality breached? restart the day tier hard. i have no problem with a game being tough but i do have a problem with how often lobcorp sets up undoing progress as a means to punish failure. there's nothing quite as soul-suckingly frustrating as completing a day only for a single high-tier abnormality to breach and either wipe out half your facility trying to contain it or force you to sacrifice a huge chunk of your upgrade points in order to suppress it. a single mistake is often all it takes to either instantly end your day with a restart which can be very disheartening when days last thirty minutes or more and this problem is exacerbated when trying to learn how the abnormalities work. while the game is built with restarting from day one in mind (as you keep your e.g.o. and abnormality logs and can thus avoid ones you don't want for your current facility) it is no less frustrating to go all the way back to day one after putting so much effort into making it further than you did before.  tedious gameplay a grindy design and all over the place difficulty that uses the erasure of progress as a means of punishing failure are the signs of an game that lacks polish. lobcorp is truly jank but underneath that jank is an experience that is fascinating and engaging. learning about abnormalities and then mastering their containment always feels great while learning about the world and the story of the facility and the damned souls who run it make for a story that is nothing short of enthralling. i haven't even spoken about how the game integrates story elements into the gameplay which are so absolutely genius that i cannot even speak about them here for fear of ruining their impact in-game.   i've chosen to be very upfront with lobcorp's problems in this review because i feel that anyone who wants to get into this game should know about them but i think it speaks volumes for how compelling the good elements of lobcorp are that i've sunken more than fourty hours into the damn thing despite my eminent bitching. even with all it does wrong you can just tell that this game was the work of a team that really wanted to make something [i]interesting[/i] despite their lack of game design skill which shines through in the compelling elements it succeeds in. i will commit to beating lobcorp in spite of it's flaws because being the manager of this fucked up little slice of hell is too compelling to put down unfinished.

it's hard. it's unforgiving. it is at times unfair.  but it's worth it. the story is pretty damn amazing and gameplay is challenging but in a fun way - it's like a puzzle that becomes more complex with every passing day. at the start you only have to worry about 2 or 3 things but before you know it you will be juggling dozens of different issues each one with its own mechanic. just one word of advice - get yourself cheat engine and speedhack this game. if you want to play it safely it's not uncommon for a day to last around an hour. speedhacking can make it more bearable if like me you don't have that much free time to play games.  finally - you will probably swear like a sailor more than once because of this game. but as i said at the start keep at it - for the sake of the story. and because you owe it to everyone down there.

very stress inducing game. if you are here because of library of ruina and played it before imo skip it since the ending will be less of a twist. but if you want to try it out anyway enjoy of the many torments you will suffer here.  it is a management sim that has horror and rougelike mix in together. surprisingly it works out just fine.  it is one of those games where death is a common thing to expect so having a 0 death run is pretty much impossible on your first run without having to google who does what. so pray that your favorite employee comes out alive.  the best way to experience this game is to go 100% blind imo but there are certain abnormalities that can literally can end your run depending if you have the gear if for whatever reason if it escapes. google will be your best friend. sure it will might ruin the surprise but it will also save many head aces and potential run ender. just remember to not chicken out and pick only the easy ones since they are usually tie to gear rank (i.e the harder they are the better gear they will drop)  the story is okay and the casts are pretty good. each being unique to their roles and how they view of their job their co-workers and their employees. it isn't amazing as lor but it is decent.  the game does suffer frame issue in the late game unless you have some godlike processor because of how many things are on the screen at ones and movement may be clunky at times and could cause your group to get killed because of how targeting works.  combat system can be hard and confusing at first but they are easy to understand and to master ones you get the hang of it.  but overall it is a great game and it will make you feel like you are the scp director of the site. if you enjoy the story of lc and want more then library of ruina will add more story into it.

changing my review since i have more hours on the game.  lobotomy corporation is a ruthless gruesome yet cutesy scp-inspired roguelite. similar artstyle to that of the mobile fallout shelter game with a hint of anime. your goal is to manage and generate power by working on abnormalities in your expanding facility. abnormalities are essentially creatures/objects that all behave differently. they require you to figure out how to handle them effectively yourself by unlocking information on it this is done by completing work with them usually with trial and error. the game progressively gets more interesting and difficult when you're managing more complicated and dangerous abnormalities that can escape or cause absolute chaos in your facility.  lobotomy corporation is a fun and casual experience until late game where the difficulty spikes up drastically. late game you will run into some story-based objectives that feel borderline impossible at the start. this is when you realize where the rogue-lite aspect comes in the game expects you to restart. essentially a new game+ where you keep things from your previous playthrough to get more knowledge more skill and better equipment and unlocks to help you progress and beat the game. this adds a lot of replay value and since each playthrough you will be dealing with different abnormalities it will keep the gameplay fresh.  the artstyle and soundtrack is very well made even if at times it feels unpolished. the story is not terrible it doesn't particularly grasp me personally but it's a nice touch to the game and adds some depth into the experience.  as far as complaints go with the game the game can become annoying and unfair at times. i've gotten to a point i expect the worst possible scenario when i jump into new content in the game because lobotomy corporation actually has zero chill and is willing to make your experience frustrating and ruthlessly difficult. this isn't a bad thing but it can get very stressful and time consuming just to make progress. my second complaint is combat can occasionally get annoying when you want to manage multiple agents that are stacked on top of eachother being unable to see their hp/sp bars without checking the suppression interface or knowing who has the shield you just gave.  my last complaint is the game does have some bugs that will make you have to restart the day that you spent an hour on. as one can imagine that is very frustrating but since i enjoy the game so much i still continue it anyway. the bugs are also not frequent enough to be a dealbreaker or gamebreaking but they do appear occasionally and depending the scenario it can be extremely annoying.  tldr; this game is fantastic and i highly recommend this game if you enjoy management games and/or if you like games that are willing to be gruesome and make you want to tear your hair out. melting love is cute and if you use repression on her you're just being mean.

things you will see in your time as lobotomy corp's new manager:  -cute girls -cute girls who want to kill you -a lot of clowns  -birds of all shapes and sizes -nuggets (and basically everything in the facility is hungry) -a concerning number of children involved in this mess -puppies (all of them can murder) -retry the day six consecutive times in a row -cactus  ...seriously though i genuinely adore this game if the time i've spent playing it hasn't made that clear enough. even though there are improvements that could be made i overall find it charming and intriguing.  the gameplay is difficult and stressful. it's also punishing for careless mistakes and not paying attention to what specific abnormalities mean. however  the mechanics are rather easy to learn and understand and you are rewarded for making the most of situations and planning accordingly. knowing when to restart how to effectively use your employees and the gimmicks of abnormalities will be your key to victory.  the main draw for me personally is the story. the store page doesn't really delve into the characters you meet and the lore of the world but trust me when i say that it's deeper and more interesting than it seems. i don't want to risk spoiling anything so all i will say is that the backstory for the corporation as well as the gameplay itself make it clear that a player character isn't necessarily a good person just because they're the protagonist.  of course the game could be improved. by mid to late-game restarting runs began to feel tedious since there isn't much to do in early sections and some parts literally don't work (that one welfare research...). while these weren't enough to dissuade me from liking this game they still stuck out to me.   overall though i love this game a lot. recommended for people who are into stressing themselves out over nuggets.  (also if you were turned away by the jank translation you'll probably be happy to know that the revamped version (which was released in 2020) is much much better!)

lobotomy corporation was a game that i bought years ago under the pretense of supporting an indie with a good idea with very little expectation. thankfully the game ended up being pretty good and project moon is now one of my favorite developers period though i admit this has more to do with library of ruina their recent release and direct chronological sequel to lobotomy corporation. but we're here to talk about lobotomy corporation so let's do that for now.  lobotomy corporation describes itself as an scp sim and while that isn't a bad or unhelpful description i think if you go into this game exclusively expecting scp you might end up a bit disappointed. monsters ultimately are very simple (for the best) with all of them being able to be worked in one of four ways instinct insight attachment and repression with additional conditions being used to make them more or less difficult to manage.   they additionally have a qliploth counter which reduces as you mess up or occasionally succeed; some monsters are prone to breaking out and managing the breakout is a part of managing the monster. some common examples of wrinkles are having certain stat thresholds (employees must be below/above 3 of a particular stat for instance) or wanting the work success to be good neutral or bad specifically. some monsters cause radial effects after some trigger is set off some monsters just break out some monsters heal people when you do a good job some monsters aren't monsters at all and are rather static artifacts that generally won't bug you if you don't bug them.  however if you think you can avoid combat forever you are sorely mistaken. there are also ordeals which pop up after a certain number of monster interactions which create sort've combat trials for your employees through the day and serve as a soft timer to how long a day can run in early game and as a challenge to be overcome in late game. additionally the game has ways of forcing interactions with certain monsters tied into this mechanic meaning that for a while every monster is a risk even if you never intend to touch them.  employees are also a mechanic and to keep it short they have four stats corresponding with the work types and gear which you synthesize from monster energy which you get from working monsters. gear has four elements also roughly corresponding with the work types and armor as a result has four resistances. this part at least should be fairly simple to understand. combat takes place in an almost sort've 2d rts style with you shuffling your little nuggets around the facility to engage and pulling them back if the thing you're fighting is about to do something nasty. you are going to do a lot of room to room dances.  if all that sounds like a lot to take in mechanically it is. it is a difficult game and you will absolutely lose employees to forgetting to do a certain thing or act a certain way around a certain monster and it's a part of the design. at some point you're just going to have too many plates to spin and too many variables to consider and you're going to slip. eventually these slips will overcome you and you'll have to reset the timeline. literally. there's a mechanic in the game where you start from the beginning of your run with all the information that you've gathered on monsters up to that point recorded and all the gear you have. except you're back at day one the plot has reset you have no monsters and one employee.  you will have to do this a lot. i think i reset too much on my first run but you will absolutely have to reset at least a handful of times and you shouldn't burn yourself trying to avoid it because due to the plot and requirements that show up later in the game you will have to. your eventual goal is to fully record every abnormality and get to the final day day 50. without spoiling the plot which is excellent presented in a visual novel format and unfortunately only mostly starts making any sense in the latter half of the game the final five days is... brutal. you don't have enough context to understand why. if you get that far you will and that will become a part of the difficulty. i have to admit nobody makes a challenge that makes me feel like i am completely and totally overwhelmed and incapable of beating something like project moon and lobotomy corp is no exception. i can't say i didn't enjoy the ride though!  tl;dr: very mechanically dense game due to sheer variety of variables a game where perfect runs are very difficult a very difficult game in general some employee management and very light rts elements mostly in micro/macro being helpful terms to describe how you maneuver your employees. don't buy this game for the rts elements i stress it's mostly a terminology thing. 50 days gets brutally difficult near the end you will have to soft reset the game using an in game mechanic for the plot if you don't like playing similar content repeatedly i'd skip this one you'll be doing a lot of it. i enjoyed the plot it worked for what it was trying to do though it kicks in too late for it to be something i'd suggest as a primarily purchase decision.  if you want a sort've rough around the edges resource management game you could do much worse and you'll get a nice plot and some good monster design to go with it.

lobotomy corporation is essentially a new take on the scp styled horror or stories. while most of the scp related games tend to be based almost solely on escaping usually as a low-to lowest ranking lobotomy puts you in the shoes of the manager of the site. it shines an amazing light into a role many forget exists; the one that has to make the big calls around the facility.  what it did good: + fun sweet cartoonistic designs keep the game lighthearted while still having the disturbance of scp natures. + the soundtrack although fairly repetitive is fitting throughout the game and is well handled. + rogue-like elements that encourage the user to adapt as they go along while also taking risks. + customization of agents that [strike] causes you to reset 200 times so your look-alike lives [/strike] + a balanced sense of resource management with risks/deaths  what it could do better: - weapon choices felt fairly lack-luster certain types had only few notable and some types had no player usability at all - small aleph pool [spoiler] some even fake being other risk levels [/spoiler] - as stated earlier depending on playstyles music could get very repetitive - [spoiler] unavoidable deaths because the plague doctor thinks the 12th guy needed drowned [/spoiler]  in the end i say it's one of my favorite games and it even has mods albeit few and many aren't english and the modding scene isn't the most supported by the game.

you play as an iteration of an overburdened and broken man the manager who is tasked to meet energy quotas provide therapy sessions to spiteful personalities trapped in tin cans take care of said tin cans throwing a fit towards you fend off creatures calamities balding and the rapture. all while trying to keep your little nuggets - employees alive so you can move on to the next day. lobcorp initially pulls you in with the opportunity to explore and learn about its abnormalities but this curiosity evolves into sort of a responsibility to carry out and see the finale of a staged play. the world building lore and motifs in this game are great. the art style is appealing. music fits the setting in-game. the gameplay doesn't require you to be a good multitasker or rts savant. the game can be completed by memorising all your failures and learned countermeasures(you are expected to fail a lot).  the game is unpolished in some areas such as bad performance on the later days clerks bugging out sometimes employee e.g.o. visuals defaulting the savefile can have corruptions and the art can be not-so-hd under a magnifying lens. but that is really it for the flaws. difficulty in lobcorp is justified simple as.   don't trust any bl**dfiends. have faith in the plan. do it all for an ai's sincere smile.

i adore this game the brutality and dark aspects of some parts of it are just a couple of the aspects of this game that have lead me to love it. i'm a definite fan of how some abnormalities places that classic lobot brutal spin on fairytales and just how great some of the other lore is in general the way in which it doesn't fully explain how some of these things came to be retains a sense of mystery around them.  later on in the game it still is able to retain a stressful yet somewhat calm atmosphere (at least until people start dying). i love the idea of ordeals and their different tiers.   there are only a few issues i'd be able to highlight with the game: the first is a lack of easy modding support it'd be great to see what the community could come up with through steam workshop if given the chance (which could also lengthen the life of the game as a whole). the second is simply the lack of replayability with 216 hours in the game i've seen and suffered at the hands of all the game's anomalies and i would love to see some more anomalies be added into the game at some point (though this is likely just wishful thinking as i know the devs are preoccupied with other games). my final issue is with customisation i would definitely enjoy more customisation options to be added as well as the rgb for hair to be working better.  to conclude i would definitely recommend this game to those who would enjoy its dark aspects such as those who like the scp foundation.

this is a game with overflowing levels of thought.  perhaps an odd dichotomy for a game with lobotomy in the title but i stand by it.  project moon has a great talent for incorporating story concepts seamlessly through gameplay and lobotomy corporation is an experience i would recommend to anyone who can face the fear.  preamble aside lobotomy corporation is a management game of sorts the basic gist is that you are managing the day to day of a lobotomy corporation facility and that involves telling people how to make monsters produce green energy while also having those monster handling people sometimes survive this process.  a large draw to this game is the cadence you get while one learning what each monster does and simultaneously improving your own detective work for future monsters  so that you can more quickly figure out how to efficiently make batteries of them.  this cadence lasts for most of the game and is later overtaken by various side challenges that drive the main plot of the game.    once you reach that mid game and you'll know it the game will slowly but steadily ramp up the challenge and the pressure until it culminates in one of the most satisfying endgames i've ever experienced maybe even the most satisfying.  if this sounds like a fun time to you then i recommend this game wholeheartedly.  but i do understand this isn't a game everyone would enjoy but anyone who would enjoy this game will really enjoy this game.   so i do recommend this game but i'll give a warning: this game is not easy this game is long(~100 hours and then some) and some of the abnormalities are tedious and stressful to work with and there are many easy ways to ruin minutes of effort in a few mistaken seconds but even so i found it worthwhile as it is and would change nothing about it.    also includes character customization so that you can grow attached to your employees before the game makes you choose between their lives and your convenience.  at the very least you can make sure your employee will look cute before they are killed/lobotomized/sent to at least three different forms of hell/converted to watts/change careers to go to the fishing industry/or worse.  also soundtrack is top tier.  10/10 gud game to get gud.

want to hurt? want to live in pain? dive into a pool only to find yourself in the middle of the ocean during a storm? or well take care of monsters because that's cool and interesting... then this is the game for you.  the importance of trial and error rings true within this game. you won't understand these abnormalities at first toiling around as you either get dealt a wave of destruction or minor annoyance to your facility. managing these abnormalities to just pass another day. the gameplay of each day can range from 10 - 20 minutes to an hour or so of managing abnormalities making sure nobody explodes into gorefests or the facility getting completely destroyed. your employees (besides the clerks) items you acquire and power you gained can be completely lost if you don't suppress and manage the problems that occur throughout your sessions.   each and every day ending and beginning with a new set of challenges and a story being told overtime of your past with the department heads around you. uncovering a dark but hopeful story underneath it all for an epic climax and ending near the final days of the game. there will be hard obstacles in the way though world-ending scenarios impeding your progress  and large scale events that could ruin everything; however in the essence of it all you need to overcome them. you have to endure the onslaught of pain. you got to keep moving and fight back. you must face the fear and build the future.

i respect how mean this game is. the ways your poor agents will die are vast and unavoidable. it's a pretty unique experience that'd i recommend even if i don't like playing it.  lobotomy corp is a scp management sim. with a heavy focus on the management part. the objective is to work on various monstrosities to meet a daily energy quota through 4 different works your agents preform on scps. working unlocks scp specific equipment(needed for survival and suppression) and also the guidelines and weaknesses for dealing with said scp. after a successful day you can replace fallen agents level-up and generally prepare for whatever is added on the next day.   and that‚Äôs essentially it. the actual playing of the game is pretty straightforward. it‚Äôs mostly pausing assigning agents work and then speeding up until they‚Äôre either done or dead. with some supression hear and there. a real less is more approach to its mechanics.   most of the fun comes from managing various murderous and unusual quirks. and by managing i mean actual management. who can do what when where and with what equipment. sometimes it‚Äôs as simple as a being stat is too high or low (or both). but often its hoping that the claire assigned to the giant fetus doesn‚Äôt make it cry because that causes the meat lantern to escape and you have to find that one manually to suppress with ranged red damage of course but then river in safety just dropped dead for something you probably did and also someone else put on the red shoes while you weren‚Äôt paying attention. you'll be restarting a lot in this game. it‚Äôs fun frustrating and a bit tedious.   there are other things like ordeals (enemy invasions) meltdown levels (scps require immediate care) optional objectives grinding works to level agents and other stuff i didn‚Äôt get to. these too are all part of the managerial puzzle. i find it vaguely exhausting and but couldn‚Äôt stop thinking about it. it's a lot to keep track of and it doesn‚Äôt get easier.   the ui exacerbates this. keeping track of everything means frequent pausing and scrolling. selecting agents stacked on top of each other is annoying. text is sometimes too small or too quick. little issues like these are sprinkled throughout this game. easily ignorable if you like the game or gently grating depending on how much you're enjoying yourself  now the story and writing i like but the difficulty of the game made it feel almost tangential. the actual scp writing didn't wow me but it‚Äôs fun to read when you have actual firsthand experience. the visual novel portion is interesting but there is no way in hell i'm seeing the end of this. i only got to day 22 out of 50. and that‚Äôs probably the biggest shame about this game. despite its cool premise and interesting story it still wasn't enough for me to push through. neat game though recommend for people who like the dark sorta cheesy scp horror stuff. or for people with extreme amounts of patience.

good game good soundtrack good story.  the video showcased is a little old though the most notable feature that has been changed is that the elevators are instant now and the game was retranslated recently.  if you like facility management games you'll like this one if you like a good story you'll like this one or even if you like scp-like games this is also good for that.  if you liked the story the most i would recommend their second game library of ruina which continues this one but it throws away the facility management also.  but this game gets really hard as you get into the further days. this isn't meant to be a shorter game this game wants you to restart to get an advantage the early abnormalities are pretty easy but late game it gets to when a hard abnormality escapes you have to instantly restart the day. to combat this i recommend restarting to day 1 or restarting to a few days in the past. when you restart everything but your characters stay meaning you can keep all the info you gathered about abnormalities items you've gained from them and quests you might have done making it easier to focus on other abnormalities and quests to get them out of the way.  a lot of the older reviews about translation are not true to today where it was retranslated there was also a big update regarding mechanics after it wasn't early access which divided the game between legacy and normal which changed art ui all kinds of stuff so watch out for those reviews too.  to sum it all up this is a hard facility management scp-like story game that can get repetitive at times but you can always restart to make your run easier and better. this game takes a lot of learning so be ready if you do buy this.

here is my spoiler free review of the game. lobotomy corporation is a management sim/visual novel with an engaging story and somewhat addictive play loop. the game takes place over the course of a certain amount of days during which you have to gather boxes from these things called abnormalities. if you've read anything on the scp wiki it's like that. between each management day you get at least one cut-scene that gives the game the visual novel identity with more cut-scenes happening the more objectives you complete. before each day starts you get one new abnormality the danger level of which ranges from literally harmless to just reset now it'll save you a half hour of anguish. lobotomy corporation is best enjoyed completely blind. if you enjoy scp management sims and a sense of mystery throughout the entire game i highly recommend. that being said prepare for a bit of grinding. stats are a very important aspect and grinding for high stats will always be a good idea. also be prepared to reset; it's nearly impossible to get everything on your first run in fact it's literally impossible to get everything on your first run. there's not enough days to get all the abnormalities fully understood. my advice is to reset whenever you start to feel stumped and take what you learned and apply it to your next run. this game is a rogue-lite after all like hades. 8/10 would recommend.  the following is a spoiler based review addition. venture at your own risk: [spoiler] there are five levels of danger in lobotomy corporation. zayin: baby's first abnormality teth: friendly hello hi? he: doable but god am i scared waw: getting spicy and aleph: oh got why is everything on fire? use this to gauge if you can handle an abnormality. the story is fantastic and i haven't even finished it yet. so many twists and turns and mysteries to solve. on another topic god does this game drag down sometimes. the first day you get a new aleph or even a waw prepare to reset 3-4 times just to learn the basics about it and eventually get it right. some abnormalities need specific levels to work and some are fucking bullshit like alriune and the silent orchestra. fuck those two in particular i want to get good results not normal! anyways if you really need help with an abnormality the wiki has everything you need and the subreddit is always welcoming. finally let's talk about ego. the weapons and armor you make from the boxes of the abnormalities are insanely useful. just getting one of the higher rank means taking way less damage from everything below. a teth armor with 0.8 on white will take more damage than a waw with 1.2 despite 1.2 being weak to white and 0.8 being resistant. weapons work the same way but in reverse. you'll deal a lot more damage to breaching abnormalities of lower levels with a higher level weapon. the weapon's damage also matters but you'll figure that out as you play... this was less a spoiler-y area and more of a here's some tips from a guy who's put in 50 hours to this game. sort of thing. btw there's a sequel called library of ruina that you shouldn't play until getting the true ending here. [/spoiler]

probably the closest (and best) you can get to an scp managing game out here (ofc with it setting in it own universe there are slight difference on naming stuff but the basic like classification containment procedure data log all that fancy stuff you know and love still exist just with it own twist) you get hella complicated manual book that explain kinda everything but you understand basically nothing and you will forget everything and realized you fucked up stuff (kinda like paper please) puzzle like strategy because containment placement do in matter of fact matter (a lot) a rouge-lite element (because boi you gonna fail a lot and need to grind the hell-out stuff to even stand a chance for endgame content) rts (because mid-to-endgame content actually need you to micro bunch of your unit going into battle) and bunch of other stuff because each abnormalities give unique mechanic to manage properly.  proly you also need decent system to run the game because boi the insanity of endgame chaos is amazing and fps drop right to the ground too just like the facility i manage after bullshit abnormalities breka loose.  the story is pretty ok enjoy the world building but i mostly here for the anomalies so i able to sit through most of the narrative stuff  the artstyle definitely not for everyone but it not really distracting and in my case it actually grow on me slowly (or you can push it by saying that the artstyle relate to the lore of the actual story)  though i quite worry when you already experience most of the anomalies the game has to offers becuase while it has quiite a lot you will not able to re-experience the initial wonder that the game offer and just became another pick your best gear for the run kind of game while it still have a lot of replayability thank to it randomly picked anomalies to be able to choose each time it can get old after many reset.  so yeah if you got interest on any of that aspect definitely a worthy game to pick up (and hey it's pretty cheap too (and the sequel also planed to launch from it early access next april or so))

highly recommend this game of course it has it's pros and cons but every game does. in case you're on the fence or just want to know other people's experiences then here's my list of pros and cons!   pros: -the game plays very well i have never experienced lag or a crash other than when the game closing out was scripted. i can have all of my employees doing things at once and it still runs smoothly -game play itself is very smooth a little hard to get the trick of which can cause some frustration but when you do get it the game becomes much easier  -all of the abnormalities are amazing and fun even the ones based off existing stories like wizard of oz or fairy tales  -the soundtrack is absolutely amazing. in the game you get warnings called trumpets to set the mood for when something goes wrong and you'd think that a blaring alarm would be horrible on the ears but i even listen to them outside of when i play the games  -the translations are really good i haven't really spotted any errors in the structure of the sentences or spelling errors    cons: -this game is abysmally long. i've put over 64 hours into this as of this review and i haven't even gotten 10% of the story not to mention the sheer amount of different abnormalities prevents me from being able to glide through different loops easily  -speaking of loops this is a game where you'll have to start over constantly. when you start over you get to keep most of the objects and information you got from the previous time but you have to work your way back up and hope you don't end up with bad abnormalities that will seriously damage your run -the difficulty curve is kind of confusing. i had to have other people explain to me that you have to start over every time things get difficult to get better gear so you can pass that bump the game only explains the basics  -even if you do have what you need one little slip up can destroy an entire day it's a game that requires a lot of attention and no errors

galaxy brain? in my me? it‚Äôs more likely than you‚Äôd think  [b]begin management:[/b] review time babiezzzzzzz i‚Äôm going to try to avoid spoilers at all costs because i went into this thing completely blind & i think you should too! i have never experienced anything that is anywhere as ambitious interesting or intense as this game is or can be at its peak difficulty levels.  you are the manager of a grand facility in charge of producing energy. how? by performing what appears in the game to be benign research experiments on various types of monsters! some v cute some absolutely terrifying with each having its own unique backstory. your research will unlock valuable information as to how to work with each individual monster for maximum :) :/ or :( results depending on their specific needs and qliphoth counters as well as armour & weapons (ego) to deal with the various ordeals or emergency type situations that might arise amongst your staff and abnormalities should you not meet the specified stat requirements. the mechanical systems in this game go bananas. pay attention to everything.   [b]employee assignment needed:[/b] you may think ‚Äúah yes... rogue-lite monsters this will be a silly little procedurally generated game. surely i won‚Äôt become attached to these characters or care about their silly little tasks ^-^‚Äù listen... the way in which you are completely wrong..... oof. these tiny round-headed bug-eyed sad sweet characters got to me. *you see someone you know and they ask you how you are and you just have to say you‚Äôre fine when you‚Äôre not really fine but you just can‚Äôt get into it because they would never understand* don‚Äôt talk to me about hod don‚Äôt talk to me about netzach don‚Äôt even mention tiphereth. trust me the missions the department heads give you are worth it. terrifying. but 100% worth it. regular hireable employees v cute. mostly v dopey. my partner calls them babies. rest in peace to all the little ones you will lose.  [b]end management:[/b] persevere.  this game will not hold your hand but it does give you exactly the tools you need to excel. should you run into difficulty lose extracted ego that was especially hard to aquire or simply have a monster that you don‚Äôt feel you can adequately handle the game allows you to restart from a save state called the memory repository (every 5 days game time). this is a valuable tool if you extract a monster who only seeks to wreak havoc on your facility or maybe you want to spend more time assigning your employees to specific work types to level up those specific stats before going further.  additionally you are always able to restart from day one. in fact! utilizing the memory repository or beginning anew from day one are quite encouraged! should you choose to rewind or restart you will keep all research done on the abnormalities you have worked with as well as unlocked ego. this makes the beginning of the game much more manageable and (imho) more fun! my only advice would be if you fail a day early on (with all employees dying) do not immediately rewind to memory repository as all of the gear that your employees had equipped at time of death is now gone with them.  lobotomy corp does not want you to fail and thus there are no true fail states if you use all of the tools provided.  as they say ‚Äúface the fear build the future‚Äù proceed to next day? yes  1000000% would recommend to the homies

i've lost track how many times i've had to start from day 1.... 10/10 would see my entire facility get massacred again.  in all seriousness the game is a very interesting scp-esque management sim that has a very solid narrative and method of storytelling that sort of reminds me of nier/drakengard. you will make progress you will approach the end... you will fail. and then you will start from the beginning with more knowledge and tools at your disposal... you will approach the end and likely fail again but this time you make more progress... and the cycle repeats until you are strong enough to overcome your next challenge and it is so satisfying each time. all the while you will unlock more of the story each time you do this. the characters will even mention this may not be your first time talking to them.  i will not lie however this is a tough game if you want to actually reach the end of it even tougher if you want the true ending. but i must say you'll get plenty of hours out of this one for the price and if you like management sims and dark fantasy stories this is right up your alley.

do you like the scp foundation? so do i! do you think it would be fun to try to manage the scp foundation? i thought so turns out its tedious mind bending work and oh so delightful!  this game is a lot of trial and error (mostly error) your workers (who if we're still going with this scp comparison serve as d class scientists and guards) are meant to be thrown into the lions den for the sake of progress. you're supposed to let them die for the greater good so don't be like me and accidentally get emotionally attached to a few of them (yum-yum miho i'll be taking you two to the end! hopefully) it also doesn't help that a few ais get passive aggressive flavor text when someone dies under their domain. [spoiler]fuck of yesod i'm trying my best here![/spoiler]  a nice feature of this game is that every level you do counts as a day and every few days you get a checkpoint if you progress a few days and really realize you are in a bad place with abnormalities you picked or how you built your employees you can rewind back to the last checkpoint (you can also retry your current day as well). the research you did on abnormalities will remain and you have any employee who died after the checkpoint return and lose any you added. there are missions in this and when you complete a mission and rewind the mission is still completed. do not be afraid to do this it's quite handy at least for me. also try to do your missions as soon as you can because completing a mission provides you with a nice upgrade that you can choose.  okay this part is going to be entirely in spoiler tags because i am going to tell you about two abnormalities i would not recommend picking. one because it is something that you need to be later in game to handle and the other which is just tedious and i reset when i realized how it worked. here's the one that i got way too early in game: [spoiler]there is an abnormality called magical girl or queen of hatred she can actually be pretty helpful but if three employees or clerks (ai controlled employees) don't die within a certain amount of time she goes on a rampage and can decimate your entire facility. eventually you can get an item called execution bullets so i would recommend avoiding getting her till then. her teaser line is in the name of love and justice~ here comes magical girl! so if you see that don't grab it till you're ready.[/spoiler] here's the other that is just tedious imo. [spoiler]it's called express train to hell and is actually a tool type abnormality that when used can heal or buff your agents. the thing is every two minutes or so if you don't interact with it a train will run through your facility slaughtering everything in its path. it's easy to get focused on something else in the facility and only realize you forgot about the train until it's too late. happened to me until i reset to a previous checkpoint. the teaser line for this one is when the time comes the train will chug down the tracks and sound its mighty horn.[/spoiler]

bought this game and finally beat it after roughly 230 hours.  in short: this game is well worth the base price and has a long runtime especially worth the asking price if you have a thing for management sims or rts games.  the game seems deceptively simple at first and builds upon itself in clever ways. many times the game has made me smile thinking i didn't think the game was capable of this. very good game if you have a soft spot for games that defy expectations.  cons: -very long runtime (200+ hours if not looking up wiki information) -faux-deep/profound writing on most characters that was personally quite grating after a while -gameplay can be considered trial and error in many instances. -somewhat outdated micromanagement control scheme (have to send units to different rooms/abnormalities to get them to move cannot select individual units when stacked on top of eachother via hud etc.) -there is tons of stuff to remember as you get to later days. your ability to multi task and your memorization ability will surely be tested as you progress. it is possible to be forced to retry days in this manner as one minor thing can set an abnormality off causing a chain reaction.  pros: -very good writing adequate reward for passing challenges and unlocking parts of the story -money spent to time played ratio is off the charts very good value if on a budget as the game frequently goes on sale -as mentioned before the game is very good at surprising you or making you think just what is this game? -gameplay is relatively simple and easy to get into.  i do have more cons listed than pros as you can see but some of them are much more nit-picky than others. overall the game was well worth the price tag. please give the game a shot if strategy games are anywhere on your radar.

i absolutely adore this game. even from the time i didn't have it i would spend hours watching others playing through it and reading up on the creatures that lurk inside the containment units. and yet even after being spoiled most of the time from videos and researching it never stopped me from actually playing the game. and i do not regret it.  if you're a person who loves in depth worlds with interesting characters and plenty of creativity to unpack as well as stories that are rather grim and horror-based than this is a perfect fit. the amount of detail put into every abnormality the uniqueness they all have each character being lovable in their own way and the ability to customize your own employees to help shape your own idea of their story it's very inspiring.  it's a challenging game but extremely fun. however it can be seen as a bit repetitive but with new abnormalities to explore and even if you have uncovered them all it never ceases to be entertaining. it takes a lot of careful attention to details as you learn more about the creatures your employees are caring for to prevent them from escaping and each little quirk they have to them. but the more you play the better you get at remembering. it is fairly slow paced though so if you're someone who prefers fast combat or game play over story it might not be what you're looking for.  overall if you're an artist writer creative person or anything really who loves unique otherworldly creatures and lots of lore this is the right choice for you. i can't express enough how much inspiration this game has given me and it saddens me that it isn't as popular as it should be.

i love lobotomy corp i have nothing bad to say about it. it has an interesting story line fun game play with interesting mechanics and boss battles adorable art and most importantly many abnormalities with unique lore and backstories. it even has multiple endings but if you don't want to stop there you can keep playing and going on with the days. you may wish to avoid restarting days so you can learn about each abnormality in which case i recommend the amazingly polished and very informative wiki. if you're concerned about the translations they did a full english translation rework after someone google translated it and ran off with their money so now you wouldn't even know it was a korean game.

lovely stressful pseudo-rts permadeath scp manager game.  it's one of those games like papers please where the game tells you to do something then keeps adding new instructions to remember. except instead of just giving you new instructions you have to learn them through experimentation and trial and error.  you unlock the instructions by interacting with an abnormality long enough to be able to buy small chunks of information about it. the game forces you to interact with randomly chosen abnormalities in the facility meaning if you don't guess new abnormalities' gimmicks in time you could easily end up with a containment breach [strike]or worse[/strike]  when an abnormality escapes containment the gameplay style shifts from a papers please memory game to permadeath rts until you recontain or figure out how to reliably plan around the abnormality. some of the really messed up abnormalities will willingly recontain themselves after they finish their objective. oftentimes the wrong abnormality escaping can turn a normal day into a bum rush for meeting the quota to finish the day as the state of the facility gradually escalates in danger.  unfortunately sometimes the transition between music is jarring especially during boss fights which use the same over the top actiony theme only for the first phase of every boss when the first phase usually includes 3 minutes of careful setup while the game is paused.  the visual novel story is also very good but there are a few times where a good story beat is ruined by the translation being a little crusty even after the retranslation. without spoiling anything a lot of the characters have developed some of their more wacky personality traits as a reponse to the high employee turnover rate or from negative experiences with other members of the company.      this game has a memory leak but there's a mod that fixes it. install basemod first so you can mod your game. https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/2 then opimization mod for memory leak fix. https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/57  about 9 hours into playing i installed some qol mods. consider holding off on automatic work macro until you've played for a decent bit. https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/47     more detailed info https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/52     weapon info https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/39     free change appearance https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/109  agent control mod https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/107  automatic work macro

i have torn opinions about this game. i will say this is a good game under some conditions which can be tough to fulfill. i will skip the obvious stuff and go through some more important points (for me).  1. this is a very~ long~ game~ the game has 50 in-game days but if you actually want to finish the game in the correct way (without bad endings) you will need to go through far more days. lc is one of the few games that by design encourages you to reset the game (probably for multiple times). (the reset here is different from what you may understand but digger deeper will spoil the game so take your own risk.) this can be converted to at least 100 hrs (very bare minimum) real playtime. so only jump into it if you want to invest such long time here.  2. you'll need to do research you know nothing about the abnormalities and the lc universe itself. when you start the game a whole new world is open to you and this could quickly overwhelm you and worsen your game experience if you insist on trial-and-error. first piece of advice is to take your time and read carefully the manual the game throws at you at the start. you will refer to it constantly during the first few days anyway. second piece of advice is to do research on wiki and guides and such for the immediately upcoming abnormalities and challenges while trying not to spoil yourself further. trust me. doing research for this game won't ruin your game experience by making the game much easier. you will still fail a lot due to your carelessness and such.  3. you need strong skills of control and management into the late game the game will put you through mountains of challenges sometimes to the point that you will feel unfair. if you want to challenge your limit of concentration and management skills this game is perfect. otherwise take your chance. (of course you can choose to bypass some of the challenges but you'll get bad endings which i consider not game completion.)  4. you're up for a brain exercise. let me try to talk about this without spoilers. as i said you don't know anything about the abnormalities and lc universe at the start and those sometimes depends on the things that the characters tell you. talking to the characters is like playing a guessing game since they can constantly confuse you in the early game (since you don't know anything) and further confuse you philosophically in the late game (since they think you can dig deeper into the universe by then). even its appearance does not tell you i assure you the story element in this game is heavy. very heavy. just a teaser every abnormality has its own backstory and there are eighty-sth abnormalities.  5. bugs and dev support this is not a new game. there are still bugs and optimization issues that remain unsolved to this date but i don't think the dev will solve them anymore. (for example the game sometimes shuts itself down if you play for too long. this once made me so mad since i just finished doing a difficult task and the game didn't save before crashing.) luckily there're some mods that can solve those problems and you can easily find these mods from internet. nonetheless don't expect dev support since they may just only focus on lor (the sequel to lc) by now.   6. one thing that i hold a grudge as i said the game encourages you to reset. in fact it is still technically possible if you want to finish the game without bad endings in one go (without resets). however to do that you have to avoid doing a specific thing (i won't spoil it here) that the game never even tries to hint at. so if you didn't spoil yourself about a specific thing about the endgame you will probably get to a point where you soft-lock your game progress and have no way but to reset. personally i feel that's a bad and unfair game design since it potentially gives you the freedom to finish the game in one go but screws it up afterwards (unintentionally?). i used multiple mods and commands to cheese that but that's still frustrating.  7. after all these... still a positive review after all the technical problems i still give a positive review because i believe the dev has put a lot of effort into this game. the stories of the abnormalities and the universe are rich and amazing. the challenges though beyond tough are well-thought and make you feel rewarding if you actually complete them. i can't ignore the effort and creativity here. to me this is a game with excellent insight and idea yet may be technically unsatisfying if you're unlucky or unprepared.  i'm writing this review two weeks after 100% completing the game so maybe i miss sth that i will add to this review in the future. but for now i hope my review helps some newcomers who're considering buying this game.

where.. where do i even start with this game? do i reccomend it? yes. absolutely. i have reccomended this game to everyone i've had the chance to and for good reason.  there's many many things i could say about lobotomy corporation. as is obvious lobotomy corporation is a monster management game similar to a tycoon game. at the start of each day you're given three serial numbers all of which also have a quote attached to them which you will have to choose from. those numbers and quotes refer to one of the many unique abnormalities the game has to offer which are the main mechanic the game is centered around. your objective as the manager will be to do work with those abnormalities and it's through correctly doing work with them that you'll gather energy which you need a certain ammount of to complete the day and move on to the next one. simple enough right? well if you're familiar with scp- and yes i know some people frown upon comparing the two but it's easiest to explain with a comparison such as this- you'll know that each of these abnormalities will have their own set of needs that they need to have met in order to produce energy. if said needs aren't met they could bring harm to the employee that's currently assigned to harvest energy from them or potentially much much worse things.   this game unlike some people may want to believe is a roguelike. you are going to fail a lot and when that happens you usually restart the day and try again with the knowledge from your previous attempt. however should you find yourself with an abnormality that you simply cannot handle or maybe a handful of different abnormalities that paired together leave you in an extremely difficult situation like for example one that despises being looked at next to another that demands you to look at it the game gives you several options to fix this issue. for example every day that ends with the number 1 or 6 will be a hard-save state which you can return to from any other day. if you do this you'll keep all of the gear and information that you acquired on the days ahead of time but all progress made levelling up and training your employees will be lost. so if you got an abnormality that was way too much to handle but still managed to get some information or maybe even gear about it you'll keep all of that information if you are to ever choose that abnormality again as well as keep any of the gear that you may have harvested from it. of course replacing that gear if lost is an entirely different story.  and if for some reason that isn't enough.. restarting from the very first day of the game is completely okay and honestly intended. i had to do this three or four times before beating the game entirely and that's okay. just like with the save-states i mentioned you'll keep all of the gear and information you learned about the monsters. if you happened to get the basic information of one of them their name will even replace the serial code they get when they show up as an option for a new monster when the day starts allowing you to choose between a familiar face or a new scary but potentially valuable new abnormality.   there's many different levels of abnormality and generally the more dangerous it is the more powerful it's obtainable gear will be and the more energy it will prudce. while having a safe facility can be nice it'll also make your days take much longer. and as the game progresses it will start to punish you for taking too long in each day through a mechanic called ordeals. you'll learn more about them by playing yourself but all i will say is that generally.. once you reach a midnight ordeal it's considered a game-over unless you're already prepared for what's to come.  completing missions and progressing days will reward you with progressing the story. missions will continue a character's individual story while ending a day will progress the overall plot. you need to do both of these to get to the finale but doing so isn't really that difficult. while individual missions are difficult at certain points (looking at you disciplinary team..) but every mission you complete and the upgrade you'll get from it will be permanent even if you restart the game from day 1. so you have as long as you need to get all of the missions done.  take your time with this game. it's okay to try over and over again and sometimes this will be the case. this game isn't for everyone and quite frankly there's a bit of jank with the ui in some situations and it becomes apparent after awhile. but it's all worth it in my opinion because of the absolute gem of a story that's hidden behind this game. everything in the game and i mean *everything* is a part of the story. every game mechanic every seemingly one-off dialogue line the filler it's all building upon a beautiful story that you simply don't expect from a game like this at least not from the first impressions. if you're willing to put up with the many many hours you'll spend retrying (it took me roughly 90 to 100 hours to clear the game for the first time) i think this game is more than worth the time investment. i won't go any deeper into any of the characters or story because i think those are best experienced for yourself.  also the game is particularly good at making you attached to your employees so if you're someone who likes writing original characters.. well this game will give you lot of ammunition for getting attached to your random little employee mason and you may just find it that the game wrote a character arc for him purely through it's gameplay. but if that's not your kind of thing then this point is pretty null.

fallout shelter that tries to be less in the rut at the cost of constant frustration.  the unexpected element is discovering new abnormalities and their quirks most of which have lethal consequences. since the price of failure is high you will abuse retry the day button a lot. this removes the element of surprise. you just develop a routine of taking a new abnormality unlocking its information restarting the day knowing it all. some other emergent qualities of abnormalities can be approached similarly or require resetting to an earlier save checkpoint.  still in the end the game starts to feel repetitive and not that surprising after all. to take the player out of their rut there are story and challenges you need to complete to unlock the full story. it is totally not necessary to follow the story to play the game but it exploits the completionist mind. you need to beat one-time challenges to unlock the story and this makes the regular facility management much more challenging.  still in the end you will need to restart the game completely since you will want to unlock all the abnormalities the game has to offer. luckily by that time the game has supplied you with a variety of permanent cross-save buffs to make the grind faster.  very similar in spirit to darkest dungeon but with much less unpleasant grind or moments when you feel like you are just getting farther away from your goal. still probably too reliant on the restart aspect to the point when you start to suspect play-time spoofing.  a good choice for those who like a challenging game and do not mind failing a lot until they succeed.

lobotomy corporation isn't a particularly happy game but i love it. i got it on sale for cheap and i definitely got my money's worth. it's a very difficult game that rewards you with some pretty cool lore every time you manage to complete a day or a mission. it slowly builds up a world beyond the corporation the more you play and gets you invested in finding out more. the monster designs and concepts are neat and there's more to the characters than meets the eye. the character creator isn't a big system like other games but it's cute and you get to equip the characters with gear based on the monsters you work with. you also get to customize death and panic faces lol  it's not a game i can recommend to everybody but if you like or are okay with horror (scary monsters light gore a little bit of psychological stuff) like management games or really want to challenge yourself definitely give this a try. if the lore gets you interested but you're having difficulties with the game there are mods to help make it more manageable. if you decide to play good luck to you.  10/10 would let angela and binah beat me up

it's a rather meticulous management game that gets rather mindbending after the first few in-game days. luckily i rather like this sort of game. made me think of xcom except the base management is the entire game. i get the feeling that i should be trying to iron man mode the game and not use the built-in option to retry the current day at any time but the loop is rather punishing and trial and error is the name of the game. i should probably try that approach on my second playthrough before i inevitably come to master all the many weird and wonderful creatures the game has to offer.  the game seems to have been designed to do one of two things: put you in a sense of security at the start only to spring something on you; or by choosing the wrong little snippet and putting you forever on edge. once i got to the six abnormality i watched with awe as through no clear fault i could understand the damn thing slaughtered all but three of my poor little agents. i don't know if i'm lucky it took that long or if the game has a guaranteed hell beast waiting for you. so yeah very fun and probably one of those games where you don't look at the wiki. probably good for a few playthroughs' worth of suffering.

lobotomy corporation is a game unlike any other sometimes for better sometimes for worse. it's primarily for this novelty that i overall enjoyed it and recommend it.  the core gameplay loop revolves around assigning a growing number of agents to a growing number of abnormalities to gather a growing amount of energy each day. agents will level up from this work but each abnormality has its own mini-game (of a sort) to learn. sending the wrong agent in (wrong could be due to their stats timing or a variety of creative reasons) can get them killed. this could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.  that's where the roguelite element comes in. you can always reset the day or use a memory repository to revert back to the last fifth day. this usually means you can solve whatever problem though it's possible for some very bad luck to put you in an unwinnable position. as you play through the game the challenge becomes juggling a ton of things at once and dropping the ball on one could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.  but if you find something utterly impossible you can restart from day 1 with almost everything you've earned except for the agents themselves. you'll use this knowledge to build a better laboratory next time and progress a little faster. at key junctures you'll face the equivalent of bosses. saying much about their mechanics would spoil them but suffice to say they're very creative. for me they were the highlight of the gameplay. however bear in mind during these fights that it's pretty easy to make a single mistake that could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.  luckily there's a banging music track to maintain your interest during these ordeals (literally ordeals are another mechanic but they're worth discovering on your own). a good story with fantastic lore on all of the abnormalities rewards you for all of your trials and tribulations (though don't expect it to be clear cut even by the end). like the gameplay the story is fairly unique building on this truly unique experience. the atmosphere is wholly engrossing. even the boss fights have a compelling and unique manner in which they pump atmosphere in the game. these elements help temper frustration from an accidental click which could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.  adding to that frustration in a less fun way is the element of grinding (and the awful ui but we'll get to that. it just deserves to be mentioned in more than one paragraph). this comes in two forms. one is where players can continue gathering energy past the limit each day in order to enhance employees. this is the optimal strategy but it's boring. fortunately it's not necessary to win. with careful management i found going 1 cycle past the cap each day sufficient. the second issue is more bothersome: on subsequent replays (where you start from day 1) it's really tedious to return to where you were. there are some bright sides (like seeing new abnormalities and crafting a safer laboratory) but it's overall a chore further worsened by that time you zone out and make a mistake that could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.  finally both last and least (in terms of what lc does well) is the ui. i can honestly say the ui is in contention for the worst ever in a game. you might think that's hyperbole but i assure you it's not. the game constantly obfuscates information forces you to click quadruple the necessary times and stresses out the wheel of your mouse. you will absolutely lose agents because of things like a pop-up telling you the agent is calm all the while hiding their health bar. hotkeys are lulwut. at best you can see a list of 5 of your agents simultaneously out of a number that's eventually [spoiler]10x that size[/spoiler]. and missing one thing could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.  if you can handle losing all of your beloved workers over and over sometimes due to ignorance sometimes due to difficulty and sometimes due to bad design decisions then lobotomy corporation might just be for you.

i don't even know how to review this game. i feel like anything that i say will just give you pointless expectations.  i am very biased because this is with no exaggeration one of the very best games i have ever experienced. to me this game is right at the peak of what video games as a story telling medium can accomplish standing  next to titans like planescape: torment and silent hill 2.  most reviews already describe the various aspects of the game so i'm not sure i can add much here. you are the new manager of lobotomy corporation and it is your job to extract energy from abnormalities. read the manual(!) plan your workforce and meet your daily goals. deceptively simple. the game slowly reveals more of itself to you as you play. the longer you play the harder the game gets and the more you begin to understand the world the purpose of lobotomy corporation and your place in it. the game marries gameplay with story in such a natural and harmonious way that it can really only work as a video game something that i have very rarely seen.  don't read about the story don't cheat by reading the wiki just go in completely blind. i promise that if you put the effort it will be worth your time. very few games left such a strong impression on me and if i can get at least one more person interested in trying it out then this review is already worth it.  *one thing to note is that as you can probably tell from the game time of most people this game is long. it requires endurance to complete and it took me a long time playing on and off to finish it. if you are looking for a quick 20-30 hour game this is probably not going to be your cup of tea. and i would still recommend you to at least give it a chance.

while appearing to be a casual management game lobotomy corporation in fact presents brutally difficult challenges to its players. thankfully the game spans over 50 days of facility management and allows you to retry each day as many times as you want. under some occasions it even allows you to rewind to earlier days while maintaining certain progress (to undo some grave mistakes you might have encountered). combined with the intriguing plot lobotomy corporation makes the process of trial and error a pleasant experience.  ps: here is a piece of friendly advice for first-time players (mild spoiler): [spoiler]do not pick o-01-45 unless you are ready for it. this abnormality's effects on your agents cannot be undone.[/spoiler]
