‚Äúgoodness why are you making such a face? you're making others feel gloomy too. please be more considerate you don't live in this world alone after all.‚Äù   ‚Äúyou are very poor at expressing your emotions. you must be quite shy.‚Äù   one sunny day just like that day they sincerely dried the laundry they dried their own skin.  everyone was finally satisfied when they showed a bright smile. if they met people who asked what was wrong they would respond: ‚Äúi'm just shy that's all. just shy...‚Äù

lobotomy corporation is a real time strategy game that hinges upon your ever expanding facility that exploits creatures known as ‚Äúabnormalities‚Äù for energy. i haven‚Äôt played much like it so there‚Äôs no easy comparison here. anyhow the gameplay revolves around understanding the quirks of each abnormality and being able to juggle more and more as the game progresses. beyond that the story is shown piece by piece as you clear days and objectives. while it‚Äôs rather long and can be difficult at times i‚Äôve been impressed with just about every aspect of this game. if you‚Äôve got the time it‚Äôs probably worth a try.  and with that out of the way onto all of the details.  [b]gameplay:[/b]  simply put: abnormalities are dangerous but profitable. the more of a threat they pose the more energy they‚Äôll generate in interactions. your job is to dictate who handles which abnormality and how they do it. the trouble is you get these things in black boxes with nothing more than a brief sentence to suggest what it could be. while the text might motivate your choice of which one you get it won‚Äôt tell you how to handle it safely or even give you an accurate depiction of how dangerous it is. figuring that out is a matter of trial and error on your part. in other words send someone in there and see if you can learn anything valuable from it. there are fair odds that they‚Äôll die in the process. most abnormalities can be lethal if you don‚Äôt understand them and that‚Äôs the crux of it all. information is your greatest asset. your job at its core is to find and apply it.  while lobotomy corp. is an rts in the sense that stuff happens in real time you‚Äôve got a pause button and two fast forward settings. what this amounts to is that you need to pay attention to where people need to be and when they need to be there. the time for fast decision making will come when you‚Äôre more prepared for it. as you accumulate more abnormalities the time settings help you to increase the scale of your orders without slowing the game down. even if all hell breaks loose you can always rewind to the start of the day or to the most recent checkpoint. if you make a mistake you can always try again.  while the game eases you in real nicely don‚Äôt expect to see it through from start to finish in your first run. there will come a point where there are too many things that can go wrong and progress will become infeasible. while it‚Äôs important to understand where to accept mistakes and push forward it‚Äôs equally critical to know when to go back and take it from the top. each run is easier than the last though the final days will always be a trial.  overall the gameplay is built upon a simple system of interaction that introduces different rules for each abnormality. the game is paced in such a way that the player will always be handling something new and will eventually be overwhelmed by the later game stages. upon reaching these stages the player is meant to restart with what resources they have and make it further the next time. the core of the game is solid and there‚Äôs easily enough content to fill multiple playthroughs with unique encounters.  aside from all that i really enjoyed the character customization in the game. while you are the manager known as ‚Äúx‚Äù you‚Äôve got full control over who gets hired. in other words you get to customize your employees to look like cartoonish versions of your friends among other things. it‚Äôs the best kind of character customizer in my eyes mainly in that it doesn‚Äôt influence the story. especially because it doesn‚Äôt. your characters are free to develop their own stories and traits without compromising the world they exist in. that‚Äôs the magic of it.  [b]writing:[/b]  the story of this game is generally presented in the visual novel format at the end of each day. while i can‚Äôt say too much about it without spoiling anything the story focuses on giving many trails for the player to follow. as mentioned earlier you won‚Äôt see everything on your first attempt but you‚Äôll certainly tug on different threads with each playthrough. the story is well thought out as the events all work in their own ways to paint a picture of the world its people and their dreams.  the character writing certainly holds its own too. everyone‚Äôs lived a time in the world and has come to work in the facility in one way or another ‚Äúx‚Äù included. the present is founded upon the past and it shows in every interaction you see. everyone‚Äôs haunted by a shadow of sorts and it hides in their words and actions. beyond them every abnormality has a story behind it too some of which relating mechanically to others with similar backstories.  what really made this special in my eyes was the story‚Äôs willingness to get into grey and even dark areas. the road to hell was paved with good intentions and we‚Äôre beyond the point of asking if the ends could ever justify the means. what counts is seeing it through to the end.  [b]conclusion:[/b]  lobotomy corporation is a long game that has a lot of unique systems and is positively bursting with creativity in its story and designs. if you‚Äôve got time to burn all the better. this is a good one for sure. at the very least i can recommend it.

there was an employee in the corporation named frank (not related to me by coincidence)  frank was somewhat of a shut in he didn't prefer to talk to others and instead spent most of his time talking with a bird that was being contained within the corporation instead. it was named the punishing bird but it never really tried to punish anyone from what he saw. they talked about many different subjects including but not limited to philosphy art science maths and more this inspired frank to become a researcher one day however frank was moved from the control team down to the central command team 1 he was a bit sad to have to say goodbye to his bird friend because he wouldn't really be able to visit but there wasn't anything he could do.  frank found solace in talking to an anamoly referred to as the snow queen there their conversations  were also rather insightful but frank never felt like they quite lived up to the conversations he would have with his old fowl friend.  one day however frank was delighted by what he saw punishing bird had escaped from it's containment unit and was down in central command frank tried to spark conversation however the bird seemed to ignore him and instead pecked at him while yelling this is for never calling! it didn't really hurt that much and after a few minutes the bird left presumably to go back to containment.  it was a...strange experience to say the least but frank was still happy to see his old friend...little did he know it wouldn't be the last time.  this started happening every friday.

[h1]while i am recommending this game please note it's not for everyone[/h1]  the music is excellent. while some tracks may get repetitive just off the sheer amount they'll be played (looking at you neutral01 and first warning) not a single one is particularly 'bad' while others make certain moments all that more memorable.  the story is phenomenal doubly so now that it has a proper translation and doesn't devolve into engrish. while it may start out as a pseudo-scp it quickly evolves into something more interesting and compelling. i could go on for paragraphs about the sheer accuracy and detail project moon put into the more esoteric aspects of their story and how they tied it to the compelling characterization but then we'd be here all day.   but while the gameplay is relatively simple and starts out easily enough i can definitely say the end-game is unironically some of the most difficult and challenging gameplay you will experience. the best way i can describe it is: each monster has their own unique mechanics as to what they like/don't like and what happens when you finally make them mad enough to escape. some don't like it when someone with a low stat does a work type. some don't like it when someone with a high stat does a work type. some don't like it when you get a bad work result. some don't like it when you have a good work result. some have a combination of the above. some don't like it when employees die while some don't like it when no employees die. some have extremely specific triggers and god help you if you set them off. the end-game monsters you'll face are especially specific and punishing. it's easy when you only have 5 to juggle but by the end you're juggling ~60 all the while having to face 'mini-bosses' every once and a while whose difficulty ranges from easy to 'just restart the day'. then certain events that will deliberately screw with your core game mechanics but give permanent rewards across your persistent save file if you finish them. the end-game cranks all this up to 11.   i cannot stress how absolutely ball-bustingly hard this game is.  i still cannot recommend it enough.   some aside notes though. the game does suffer from memory leaks. 8gb will save you for a little while but generally the longer the days go the more likely you'll suffer worse and worse from them. one trick that does work a bit is to mute the game music.  [b][i]do not use a wiki[/b][/i] half of the enjoyment of the game is blindly experiencing the chaos of a new monster. spoil yourself at your own peril.  please for the love of skull jesus read the in-game manual. it explains every mechanic in the game phenomenally well even the hidden mechanics the game doesn't explicitly tell you about.

this game is a management simulation but dialed up to eleven. it is in no way shape or form a casual management sim. mistakes are usually severely punished. chaos is routine and death is common place.   the lore and the storyline are very impressive which further adds to the immersion. the story explains about the things you will see as you progress.  the gameplay is quite intense despite being a management sim. as the game progresses you will develop muscle memory and your own tactics in order to advance. at some point micro-management will become crucial in order to overcome certain ... hiccups you will inevitably encounter. the management part is also demanding. the abnormalities that you will manage will have unique and sometimes distinct traits each and everyone of them forcing you to assess and allocate suitable and sufficient attention to each and every one of them. some are relatively passive and harmless and can be left alone without consequences. while some requires constant attention and extensive manpower to manage. [spoiler] frick you whitenight[/spoiler]  overall the game is really well-made and it has earned a special place in my heart.  for new players you can either go in blind or you could prepare yourselves with guideline info and tricks. either way it will still be a fun and immersive gameplay. ( if feeling an intense amount of frustration and despair is your thing go in blind)

this is a fantastic game filled to the brim with unique characters and monsters that can keep you entertained for hundreds of hours. if you enjoy creative monster designs and/or games based around micromanagement of many small assets then this is a perfect game for you.  there is one clear flaw to be noted however. this game is extremely prone to crashing at the worst times due to memory leaks. this has caused over an hour of lost progress for me about 2 times after 75 hours of playtime with a bunch of risky scenarios where it almost crashed. overall it is a large issue on an otherwise perfect product. i wouldn't let this discourage you from purchasing as this game is exceptionally fun despite this but it is something that should be considered.

this game is something to behold tbh. it's a monster management rogue-lite simulation game in which you study things called abnormality's and as you study them you create power for the facility that you work for. i'm not going to lie this game is very hard at the beginning of the game and you will die a lot early on. after a while tho you do learn how to study things better and you learn where to send people  and where to put them. tho the difficulty of the game might make you reconsider rather if this game is for you or not. if you can't accept the fact that your going to need to restart runs because of certain abnormality's being together and just royally screwing you this game might not be for you. there are over 100 different abnormality's in the game and each are ranked in which how hard they are to keep locked up and the amount of death they can cause   zayin- the easiest to keep locked up and are most of the time nice to you but still are capable of death   teth- they can break out if your careless but still not to bad to deal with if you got gear and don't make to many mistakes   he- they are more then capable of killing so many people if not looked aftermight need to hire special people just to keep one of these in locked up. they will put up a fight so be careful   waw- the ones that can end your day in seconds if not looked after and are really hard to keep locked up. they are really hard to study sometimes and will will kill people as soon as they enter there box if there not up for the job and escape. and some are super strong ready up the group if one escapes if you don't have good gear from past runs.  aleph- and then there are these guys if one gets out you might as well just cry and restart your day or even run depending on the one aleph you get these guys are god like and are almost impossible to kill  so why would you pick aleph class abnormality's then? because the stronger the abnormality the more energy it makes also you don't get to pick the abnormality you want because you won't even know what your picking. yep at the start of each new day your given 3 options to pick one and all you get is the abnormality's tag number and a faint description of what it is. after when you learn about it tho you keep it's info for future runs so you will know it's name when you pick from your daily 3.  other then that your given the whole idea for the game there are some other things about the game that are best found by your self when you play like the characters and story also do note this game is not originally translated in english so there might be some mistakes when your reading stuff but it's mostly bin fixed out.also people are saying there is a memory leak problem in the gamei haven't had any issues about game after 70+ hours but i could be wrong plus i have heard there are mods to fix that issue again idk if that's true or not heard it from a bud. would honestly recommend this game if your a fan of the scp foundation and or like creepy creatures.tho for the price i would wait for a sale if your hesitant of buying it. tho this game does have a lot of replayability for the price since you need to study everything to get the best ending.  so to rap things up   -game is very hard in a lot of elements - lots of replayability -all of the abnormality's are unique and original in most ways  -characters are cool and you learn to like them as the story goes on -would wait for a sale if your hesitant of buying it but still not bad for the normal price if your looking for something new to play  also a huge tip for new players if they don't want to die rate away and this is spoilers for one scp [spoiler] do not trust the plague doctor if you run into him he is one of the few scp's that can and will ruin your whole run if you run into him trust me [/spoiler]

if i wrote a review for lobotomy corporation a year or so ago my main issue would be how the story is hard to understand due to the translation issues along with translation issues in the gameplay itself. however now that all the text has been fixed to be clear and understandable i gotta say that i really don't have that many issues with it anymore.  the gameplay is that of a management game where you control different characters to do different things but it takes a whole new approach to this formula by adding in the monster management aspect. your characters are tasked with working on different monsters called abnormalities and you need to figure out what you need to do in order to maximize the output or just to prevent the character from dying.  the game starts out simple but over time you have to deal with more and more abnormalities of increasing difficulty that can be set off by the simplest mistake. even some of the earlier abnormalities can cause significant trouble if you don't pay attention. this can also result in domino effects in which while trying to stop one abnormality another one escapes and so on resulting in you being almost required to restart the day.  while talking about having to restart the game this brings me to how these retry mechanics work. the game rewards you taking what you learned from a failed day and putting it to use when retrying it. the game also lets you load your save from a memory repository which happens every five days. these bring back all of the dead characters and resets the facility to what it had been on that memory repository day with the only exception being that you keep the same gear and information on abnormalities that you had. if this still isn't enough you can reset all the way to the first day but keeping all the gear and info.  another feature carried over by the resets is the boss battles defeated. there is multiple boss battles throughout the game which i won't go into detail but they add plenty of difficulty to your playthrough. and lobotomy corporation has a lot of difficulty. at points the game will just not hold back throwing lots of increasingly hard stuff at you. it feels incredibly satisfying to beat this obstacles.  the story on the other hand is done in a way in which you gain more info about the world in between each day and from completing quests you can get more story focused on specific characters. this helps break up the gameplay and allows you to slowly get more and more information. the world itself is also very interesting but is more heavily built upon in the sequel game library of ruina. even without that you can still be engrossed in the plot.  all in all lobotomy corporation offers a new take on an old genre and is a very enjoyable experience. definitely a favorite of mine at this point even with the issues it can have.

a really unique management sim roguelite although it can be brutally difficult and punishing if you don't check the wiki or have a lot of time on your hands to retry the day and see what works.  overall would recommend to anyone who's tried other management sims like ftl. lots of unique flavour art and story. mind the bugs.

what sells me on this game the most is how amazingly unique and different it is.  so... it turns out that the koreans really love scp stuff. like there's even a korean comic about scps. it's all the rage around artist types and thus this game came to be.  this game is a strategy game visual novel management sim.... a heck of a bunch of genres to deal with and oh goodness does it do them right. at first it seems to be a visual novel mixed with a type of management story and the sim gameplay to go along with that fictional setup but as the game continues it slowly evolves into a real time strategy game with rpg elements within the architecture of a simulation game and a visual novel. this is because you are dealing with more things get tougher and you learn to use strategy to balance your teams to deal with threats which vary and can ruin your day.  i was suggested this game by a guy on the internet. in poor english described it as korean evangelion. if this sounds like the start of a good horror story that is because it is because this is actually inspired by scp stuff rather than evangelion although they both use the same references to some awesome effect. this game is a messed up good time and partial bad time. it is actually far less horror than i thought and am pleased to know such.  how it plays? it is a point and click sim game inspired by scp stuff. you farm monsters and abominations for their energy and stuff. it is kinda crazy and i love it thus far. very point and click and the menus to a bit to get used to but i love this game. however as i said at the beginning this is also much a strategy game with great complexity.  the big problem though is that it is tedious and it drags. the random assortments of creatures you deal with the grind of unlocking things and the forced replays only to get the ending are painful and getting the true ending is even more absurdly difficult only for it to bait you with a sequel.

an amazingly crafted game! this is compared to scp a lot so if you're into that i think you'll like this too! imagine that you're the manager of an scp facility and you oversee your guards (agents) collecting energy by working with the monsters (abnormalities) that you can pick yourself in this game okay? the game has quite a bit of replay value especially if you want to see what all of the abnormalities do (and get the true ending while you're at it!) i won't spoil too much but the sefirot meltdowns have interesting gimmicks that add risk with lots of rewards if you're up for their challenges so prepare for the loss of your poor agents and clerks! talking about agents there's a lot of customization options for them like hair and eyes you can even give them fighting panicked and dead expressions! the abnormalities can also give you great suits weapons and various gifts if your agents are lucky so lobotomy corporation also has great original character making potential! if you don't have the money i recommend watching sinvicta so you can see the chaos this game has to offer! the game also occasionally goes on sale (as of 11/27/2020 it's only $9.99) so you really should purchase it! all in all me and many others are obsessed with this game so you should come and join us in this eternal hell! :)

the game is actually super fun and i'm willing to say there probably isn't anything else out like it. it has a very suprisingly good story. for that alone would totally have this game be a 100% recommendation pick it up but....  i need to stress to anyone who picks up the game. this game is hard probably one of the hardest games i have ever played. that doesn't mean its impossible but if you can't handle that difficulty you most likely wont get to the actual enjoyable part of this game and even that is harder then the normal game. with out spoiling anything i'll tell you what you can expect in the worst case 'you don't look up anything on the game'. constant death is to be expected but when you get to the harder days you'll spend the entire day around 30 minutes to doing everything flawlessly only to accidentally mess up once in a single area that you may have totally forgot about causing that employee to die and if you continue all of his gear. depending on who that is its a restart and another 30 mins...... lets just say the highest length day i have had was a hour and 30 minutes so imagine messing up on that day.  games good but don't expect a easy ride nor a short one. i just completed the game 100%. took this hour count.
if you like the scp universe than i can only recommend this game to you!!

to start with: i absolutely love this game; i haven't been able to stop thinking about it since finishing it a few days ago. i highly recommend it and i also recommend going in as blind as possible.   lobotomy corporation is really something special. it has some rough edges -- the controls are serviceable but lacking employee micromanagement is cumbersome the difficulty spikes are big and there are some technical issues -- but the game is clearly a labor of love and it shows. the worldbuilding is fantastic and the mechanics of the game further the narrative in a really cool way. the characters are all well-written and compelling. the re-translation patched in may of this year is great.  as a disclaimer to finish the game you are expected to reset back to day 1 once or twice (losing employees but keeping all other progress). i researched all of the abnormalities and got a 100% codex and i restarted the game twice. subsequent runs are much much faster and i didn't find resetting to be a big deal but it's something to keep in mind.  if the difficulty is a turn-off there are mods that can make the game easier or even trivialize it. i'm not great at video games and i ended up using mods to adjust the difficulty so i could actually get to the end. you will see some spoilers while looking for mods but if you're going to otherwise drop the game it's worth checking out the nexus mods for this game.  a couple other things i briefly wanted to mention: [list] [*] there's a memory leak. i mostly found this to be an issue in the late-game where my sessions were pretty long but if you find the game's chugging you might need to quit and reopen it. [*] the only volume sliders are master volume and music. i had issues with the sound effects of some weapons and abnormalities being a bit too loud. ymmv here but i had the master volume lower than i would've liked for most of the game. [/list]

this game is not for everyone but do not mistake it for an obtuse grind fest. it is a managerial simulation game that relishes not knowing and rewards reading the manual and patiently investigating the world and its denizens. as a manager of the corporation you are in charge of sending employees to harvest energy from abnormalities. you will absolutely lose employees in horrible accidents but that is okay because you can retry with almost nonexistent penalties. the objective is to gather enough daily energy from possibly surly not scps to meet the quota while keeping your employees sane and alive. doing well will reward you with points you can spend on learning more about the abnormalities and also eventually be used to generate gear that you can give to employees to extend their lifespan. you will eventually soft restart through an in universe mechanic and encounter new creatures to die horribly to as you perfect your facility and learn more about the company.

play lobotomy corporation and its sequel but sweet lord in heaven do not investigate the fandom. don't do it bro. it's not worth it. never in my life have i seen such a prolific concentration of degeneracy. it was if satan himself opened the boiler room of hell and beckoned forth the second coming of sodom. this is a warning. i've had to search so many horrible things on urban dictionary so that you don't have to. i never would have imagined people would fantasize about refrigerators in absolute ecstasy but life is a journey of learning and god as my witness for i have never been so horribly wise in this entire lifetime. every soul that posts their sacrilegious project moon fan works to twitter or pixiv or whatever other blasphemous platform must henceforth be deemed the antichrist for no spiritual place on earth would come to recognize someone so unholy. if someone introduces themselves to me as a fan of the game i will run in the other direction without looking back while i scream for the preferential company of a basement-dwelling jojo fan. while every community has its bad apples this fandom may as well be the stock solution because i haven‚Äôt seen such an abundance of freakish behavior since homestuck and even writing that h-word makes me tremble in fear. i‚Äôm not religious but even i know none of these people are getting into heaven. [hr][/hr] [h1]serious review section;[/h1] listen i adore this game and its story but i'm gonna be completely upfront and say that the gameplay is kind of a nightmare (coming from someone who otherwise loves management and sim games). i cannot sing enough praises to the narrative and characters but unless you're a masochist and enjoy being forced to cheese entire sections for utter lack of any other viable strategy then you probably won't like this game. it is [i]incredibly[/i] difficult sometimes unfairly so with it's reliance on sheer rng for some abnormalities and the micromanagement can become absolute hell later in the game. i've beaten the game twice (once without mods and once with) and i can't say i'd ever want to do it again. you [i]will[/i] be forced to restart this game from day one at least once likely several times to actually get anywhere to the point where it is really going to test your patience and drain your stamina like you're trying to slog through all one-thousand-something episodes of a shit anime in one sitting. yes this is by design and part of the narrative but it begs the question of how much is too much when it comes to torturing the player at the cost of overall enjoyment. those are just my thoughts on it at least- i'm not really much of a video game critic so just take my words with a grain of salt. overall what saves this from being a hard pass from me would be the writing. seriously. it's [i]really[/i] good at what it sets out to do narrative-wise. i'd be hesitant to say it's one of the best stories i've come across in gaming but i think describing it in any other way would be a disservice. as much as i despise the later gameplay it was worth the suffering to see the story and characters unfold. it's [i]really fucking good[/i].

lobotomy corporation. face the fear build the future.  alternative title: oh dear god why has that thing broken out already? this game is good. quality. it's not a legendary product but it's enough for most people. however what really carried me (and probably most people) forward was the amazing story. it's seriously well written and such quality is taken over in the sequel library of ruina.  oh yea did i mention this game has a sequel? if you wanna see what they made from the funds of this game go look at that game. anyways regarding the gameplay- you take over as a manager of l corp also known as lobotomy corporation. your company is in charge of generating power in a very clean way- by interacting with special creatures known as abnormalities and making them happy. this happy energy they produce is then used to keep the city alive with power. the only problem is; most if not all abnormalities enjoy munching on your employees splattering your clerks into paste or just enjoy seeing your entire facility fall into ruin. i fully 100% recommend playing this game with as little to no knowledge about the abnormalities as possible. the game shines best when you're playing it blind and are stumbling through the darkness.  the gameplay itself is fine. initially it's easy but once you reach mid to late game the difficulty starts rising sharply showing itself as a well made management sim (especially if you picked the needy abnormalities). there are a few bugs here and there but overall it works well. just be warned though endgame (the final 4 days) have a massive difficulty spike and the game encourages you to reset until you make the game easier and easier to deal with. and by reset i don't mean the day or the past five days i mean back to square one. i understand that can be a turn off for some people so i thought i'd say as much.  music is all right nothing too special besides the ones used for cutscenes and the last day. i recommend listening to library of ruina music to see what they're capable of in the future.  visually it's simplistic.   storywise it's absolutely amazing and you'll find there is a justification for damn near everything in the game. there are a few hints about it strewn inside abnormality lore as well so it's really cleverly made.  all in all i recommend this game. i'm not a fan of management games but this one caught my attention. 8/10 would recommend beating the game just to play library of ruina which is a masterpiece. (of course the story also makes sense for those who haven't beaten lobotomy corp but it helps you appreciate it more).

75% of the time it's a chill management game where you assign people to do things with off-brand scps such as figure out what exactly their deal is.  25% of the time it's not a chill management game because everything has immediately gone to heck due to having done the wrong thing with a given off-brand scp because you didn't know any better.  these percentages change as you add more stuff. ~  memery aside: it's a fairly straightforward concept. game's divided up into days days have an energy quota to meet you get energy by poking things in a variety of manners (most of which will go wrong until you get more information on a given thing) bigger things give more energy per go. you get some events that kick off to prevent you from just mashing the work button on the easiest abnomality and so on. later things are trickier to work with and will probably kill most of your employees outright.  major upgrades (and plot) are doled out via milestone objectives and typically add new mechanics or information to leverage each new thing added to the facility has a set of equipment you can make for smaller per-employee upgrades (or just outright is something you can use if you know how though a lot of them have drawbacks)  there's some light rpg elements people with the right stats generally makes work go better and you can grind to raise them in a pinch though i'm not sure if that's actually worth it or not.  the plot goes places and some of the stuff that can happen is rather intense in all senses of the word.   the soundtrack ranges from one of the most relaxing general themes i've ever heard to ptsd-inducing when some of the bigger stuff breaks out.  overall: it's a good time if a bit slow-burning until you get to the good stuff. also it can get a bit rough if you're trying to keep all your guys alive.
big boi game.

the golden standard of 'trial and 'error'. 60 hours in and i've barely grazed by day 25.  i've seen my men suffocate pull their eyes out willingly jump into singing meat grinders and watched a fucken censored bar singlehandedly cause everyone i love to commit suicide.  attachment is the root of all suffering.  don't make the same mistake i keep on making. accept that everything (even the homies you spent 1 lob point to deck out) are inevitably going to die at the hands of your mismanagement incompetence or curiosity.  i've played a fuck ton of rouge-lite and this one takes the cake at being the most unforgiving.  definitely not for the feint of heart.  gameplay aside - the story and *scps* themselves are great and well-executed and i've spent a good while flicking through the codex like some crazed researcher.  this game will test you.

i love this game but it hits a very specific part of my brain that makes me want to just try one more thing play one more day to the point where i'm not sure if i'm having fun any more. around day 24-25 i hit a bit of a difficulty plateau (even with restarting from day 1) and i decided to take a step back. it's very fun the new english translation is really good and it's super creative.

i can see why people would like this game but unfortunately it's not for me. it's definetly an interesting experience but i think it also requires a decent time investment to get good at it (which i don't have).  if you want an  interesting management game with a really compelling world this game might be for you.  i would really love if steam allowed people to just put informational reviews as while i don't like this game it doesn't mean it's a bad game. it is just focused on a certain niche of players.

https://youtu.be/cmesratag04 ^^^^^ everytime i play this game and bad thing happen .  7/10 stress/micromanagement simulator. 8/10 cute. 8/10 i like the story. 9/10 the music is [b]fire[/b] when bad things happens.  the game do take some time to get into it but when you get the hang of things . you will enjoy it and appreciate all the thing surrounding it .   if you fail . the game is all about retrying the day and using the knowledge you learned that day (ps: you got button to retry the day). so don't shy away from using it . knowing is power . if you faced some hard abnormalities you didn't know how to deal with . there is nothing wrong about checking the wiki . but i recommend doing that when you get stuck . a lot of fun when playing this game come out from the element of surprise and how you can put the puzzles pieces together to know the right way to handle abnormalities .   the things i feel may need improving but not necessary :-   better micromanagement :  -when your employees attacks  using melee . they normally stay stack up . what make it hard to move injured employees away and send them back to heal up . -it will be useful if you can make group for employees .even if they are from different department so you can put your melee and range employees in different team . it will make handling and micromanagementin different events and bosses easier . make different groups based on attack type what can be useful . instead of remembering who got which type of attack and gathering them manually. you will pick which employees go in which group you like . making thing more strategized .   -add 0.75 and 0.5 speed . it will be nice to have that .  [b]ps[/b]: the game may take 50-100h to complete . so if this not your type of game. of repeating things and having cycle of trial and error . you will not enjoy it .

a great story with a half-decent game attatched. the game is on a slow boil and both the story and difficulty ramps up exponentially people tend to say that the tutorial ends roughly at day 25 which is halfway through the game so make of that what you will. it also isn't for everyone so pirating to try isn't a bad idea but remember that it's from a small korean indie studio so they would probably be realy gratefull if you bought it eventually.  lc is a game about managing monsters to produce energy. you produce this energy by sending agents with unique stats equipment and accesories to interact with them in their containment cell. if you have ever been through the scp wiki then the monsters (called abnormalities or abnos) would feel at home with the better of them. these abnos can breach their containment cells and wreck all kinds of havoc or possibly help your facility the abno called one sin and hundreds of good deeds can for instance instantly kill the most dangerous abno in the game for the small payment of one of your agents. you start the game on day 1 with just one abno (the afformentioned one sin) and a couple of agents all crammed into a single department and you get more of every one of these as the days pass. at the start everything is veeeerry slow but it picks up the pace as you get more abnos with different containment procedures to jugle as well as boss battles that start to appear halfway through that can be realy hectic and fun.  the paragraph above is a lie. the game is actually about the story of x (you) angela and the sephiroth (ai managers) of the different departments as well as the strange workings of the facility and titular lobotomy corporation and the motive of the absent founder of the corporation ayin. the monster management turns into a break/challenge between story sections. some readers might recognize some names there namely sephiroth and maybe even ayin. these are ideas from jewish mysticism specifically the kabbalah. while most games skim the top of weird concepts for a unique aesthetic lc and the story (but not gameplay) sequel library of ruina unlike most games dives deep into their theme and it works oddly well. characters character relations layout names symbols and so on all tie back to jewish mysticism and it is quite facinating. you don't need to know anything about the kabbalah to enjoy the story but it is a rewarding deep-dive to read up on.  tl;dr: came for the gameplay stayed for the story

this is a game similar to getting over it if you are not into being beaten down and then completely restarting the day and having another go save yourself some cash and just go read the lobotomy corporation wonderlab comics and some of the wiki articles if you want just to get to know the lore.  when you make a mistake it is usually a bad one and when there is a change it is usually for the worse. it is not heavily luck based but if you were to say it's entirely skill you'd be clowning yourself as well. there aren't many games like it besides like i said the popular art game getting over it. both games turn relatively monotonus activities and what should be boring gameplay into some dramatic angering sometimes heartbreaking feel. you absolutely will rage quit and not want to come back to this game.  it's entirely about the odds being stacked against you and if you will leave the game or not. now granted most people don't want to play a game that punishes them for playing but there is definitely an audience for that. hell i'm one of them so buy this game if you enjoy games that punish you for playing such as getting over it darksouls etc...

if you like management games like prison architect with a serious flair of occult and hebrew mysticism or just want some scp foundation-type content this is for you.  a bit of warning beforehand the game isn't easy and doesn't give you training wheels. it starts off slow but very quickly the amount of things you have to do gets out of control and the game is designed from the ground up to give you a hard time. between the plethora of things to keep track of later in the game and the specific abnormalities (scps) that seem to be *designed* to ruin a run it can get pretty frustrating at times.  overall a very solid and unique game despite the somewhat messy translation here and there - very long too i have like 50 hours in it as of writing this review and i'm not even sure i'm halfway through let alone the potential for replayability. big recommendation from me.

lobotomy corporation is fun and challenging game. it's a mix of part stimulation management and action rpg  the game has 50 days   start out pretty easy game becomes significantly challenging towards the end   the gameplay is simple has some stimulation. where u try to keep abnormality happy to produce energy to finish the day. other part when there escape and ordeal where is more like a action rpg. where u can control employee to take care of it or leave it automatically. you can do more manuel to ensure survival of your employees. over the game you become attach to your employees. as they will become stronger depending what kind of task you assign them. you will likely restart a lot as you learn of the abnormality and how to manage them. if at some point you find it too difficult you can restart or use memory repository to keep all your current equipment and encyclopedia but go back last check point. something i recommend is to do the mission they will help you get buff to your facility that can make things easier later game. even if they are challenging to do as you progress to the last.    story wise is pretty interesting don't want to spoil much but if you like scp and gameplay and art style is down your alley. give it a try   the game getting a sequel soon so is a pretty good time to play the first game

pros:    + amazing music    + simple concept executed wonderfully    + does not punish you for starting over and in fact encourages it    + game doesn't lose its challenge even when you know what you're doing  cons:    - difficult in the sense that a single mistake can force you to restart the day    - high level abnormalities (monsters) will kill your employees without the right armors and/or levels    - a few boss fights are incredibly easy while others are insanely difficult  this is a game where i want to tell people to go in blind because that's kind of the whole point of the game but the game is so rude to you in terms of harshness that i want to tell people to at least watch a video or two first.

it's not perfect by any means but if you're intrigued by the concept of being a site manager at the scp foundation you should at least try the game. also the sephirahs are some of the most interesting characters i've seen in a video game. strong recommend.  updating this review after (more or less) beating the game i think i can be more specific. the act of discovering what an abnormality does is extremely fun and you shouldn't use a wiki if you can get away with it. on the other hand some abnormalities are extremely hard to deal with with powers that are difficult to guess at just from what they do so sometimes you'll *need* a wiki to progress.  game's a pretty rough gem but it's still a gem. as of this writing the game's on sale and it will be until december 1st 2020. it's safe to say it won't go on sale again anytime soon and $10 is an incredibly generous price for it. if it's no longer on sale by the time you read this it's still a pretty damn good game for the price though unfortunately this is a game you have to play for more than 2 hours to appreciate so it's impossible to give it a fair shot and then refund it if you didn't like it. all i can say is that you should play until day 20 or so to get a good idea of what the game's like.

i'm over a hundred hours in and still haven't beaten it yet. i find it very satisfying just exploring different combinations of abnormalities in one facility trying different approaches to different scenarios and when i feel i've reached my limit on how much i can deal with at once i just reset my facility and try to push a little bit further. (or sometimes i try and build the most chaotic facility ever and let everything breach at once that's fun too) the game requires a certain level of patience and dedication to get through it definitely but if you like management simulators where all hell can break loose at a moment's notice i'd highly recommend this game.   oh and also the only thing i would have complained about in the past was the shoddy translation from korean to english (which i realise was not project moon's fault) but that has been fixed so now my complaints are zero!! all in all good game!!

this has to be one of the best management games i have played i will admit that going in this blind is brutal the abnormalities keep you on your toes from a point on you can't afford to be carefree and may have to multi-micro manage problems as they come up. the customisable employs make it fun for playing with friends in the room and the random draws make this seem like a xcom or a rogue-like. the game is good it has some bugs but that's to be expected from a game made by small team. the only downside i came across are some translation errors (i heard that only one person is working on the so be nice).

no this isn't that scp game you want. yes you heard it all before. the game has a nice simple story that drives some mechanics the abnormalities come in so many flavors and you will gradually get tools that are useful enough to allow you to keep up with the chaos. attention to detail is the name of the game and you can bring some rts skills on certain occasions to great effect but good management will get you out of trouble rather than sick apm. only on rare cases does a new abnormality damage your facility bad enough that not even restarting a day will fix. very rare cases. it's a fun game that can get tiresome nearing the endgame. hopefully the story will motivate you to go further.

alright based off from my experience i just want to put some things here to say that this game is rather interesting and fun to play. first off all the concept on its own is similar to an scp management game with a pretty interesting story makes the game a get since i have not seen any games relating to scp management as this one. second of all it steers away from making itself be the foundation rather a separate genre of things which shows originality from project moon. third of all you will not get bored this game as a lot of abnormalities for you to handle with there own quirks and hell fire this also allows the game to have a replay ability due to the fact there is stuff happening all the time each in-game day. ordeals abnormalities breaching abnormalities blowing up your employees core suppressions with in-game mechanic changes objectives and a challenge mode so its a lot to handle. the only complaint i would have about this game is its lack of confirmed achievements like some of the stuff in this game is extremely tough and i believe there should be some achievements for those who had to suffer terrible breaches such as wk and ap. otherwise great game as people still play it today and its generally fun.

this is quite easily the hardest game i've ever played and beaten in my life. granted i haven't played a ton of difficult games and preferred to stick with games where i can choose a difficulty setting but lobotomy corporation does not have a difficulty setting. as many people have said before this game is ridiculously hard. you will not go into this game without resetting the whole game again. when you do it will feel frustrating. hopeless even. i've had a point where i had the ideal facility and was ready to take on the endgame but i made a grievous error in my completion and had to start all over from scratch.   this game is all about clawing your way to the top despite all of the adversities. but as you claw your way to the top you'll experience something truly amazing‚Äî monster designs that range from cool to absolutely terrifying a soundtrack that just keeps on giving characters that manage to be lovable even if they have no redeeming qualities whatsoever and a story that you will just absolutely want to see the end of. this game is amazing however i would not recommend it to those who aren't ready to experience pain unlike any other. when you are ready to experience pain though come give this game a shot. it'll be worth all of it.

this is an overall beautiful story and interesting game i suggest playing it completely blind if you want the full experience. it brought a tear to my eye. the characters are all unique and lovable in their own ways.

this is quite possibly one of the most fun yet grindy and hard games i have played ever.  the story especially when paired with this game's sequel library of ruina is phenominal. the characters are all well written with each of them getting their own story arc. at the start everything is shrouded in mysteries which are revealed bit by bit ending in a phenominal finale. the gameplay is unique and unlike anything i have played before. you need to command employees to work with monsters to produce a certain amount of energy each day. every monster dubbed abnormalities will do horrible things if you mess up. you ll learn how to manage each and every one of them in order to exploit them get better gear upgrade employees and then get the next monster to add to the collection.  this game is a 9/10 for me. it has some flaws but they dont bother me too much so i definitely recommend you to buy this game!

it's been a few years so i wanted to change my review out of boredom.  lob corp is a roguelike monsters inc scp rts windows 12 on dvd toaster management game.  you play as the manager of a perfectly normal and humane power company and your goal is to manage the facility to make sure your workers are able to efficiently meet the energy quota each day. at the end of each day you get to choose a friendly creature to put in your facility which you cannot ignore :] and have to work with and discover more by spending points that you get by working with it. what's that? you don't want to touch the weird slime creature after discovering it will infect your entire facility with love and kindness after working with it? too bad! after certain amount of works some containments will get a ticking time bomb to force you to work with them lest you wish for the friend to escape and turn the clerks and agents into raspberry jelly across the halls of the facility.   the game also has a really good story which slowly reveals to you what is actually going on in this corp and the backstories of each character you meet.  in the beginning and right at the end the game is definitely tough and you will encounter situations that you are unprepared for very often so reset day is a button you will get acquainted with very well. also don't play this without optimisation mod that's one of the flaws this game has with a few more but i don't think it's a good enough reason to just say it makes the game not worth playing. it's definitely a niche game and it's not for everyone but i recommend at least giving it a shot. story itself is worth reading so.. and it has a very good soundtrack which is also different than your normal ost.

imagine having a strict bitter father. this man looked down at you at your birth and said one sentence the only sentence you have ever heard from him.  you are a failure and you always will be.  that father is lobotomy corporation and as you read this review right now you have a choice to make. you can if you wish accept that this man is in his heart a cruel and evil individual whom you have nothing to prove to and no desire to pretend you seek his praise. if that is your opinion then please disregard this game it is not for you.  if however you are insulted by this man's lack of faith in you or feel you can prove to him you are more then he sees you as with nothing but the chance only a chance he will one day gift you with a pat on the back and a firm nod then you have a difficult road to follow.  you will fail. you will fail again. you will fail so many times it looks hopeless. you will fail over and over and over. but each failure you will look up at this man and see he has not noticed. he already thinks of you as a lost cause. to him it is no surprise you are in your natural state. he ignores you. lobotomy corporation does not judge you for your failures it has no need to heap insults on you or question your determination. it has decided to let you do as you will and expects nothing from you.  i like you fought against that indifference. i worked and worked and did all i could to earn the recognition of my worth. but  just as was expected of me i failed. i am 90% through this game but i can't go one step further. 150 hours and i just can't do it. my father was right.  maybe you're better then me. maybe you can make it to the end and see what i couldn't. maybe you can finish what i'm choosing to leave behind. i don't know. but it will be hard and you will fail before you make it there. so how determined are you to prove this man wrong?

the game is incredibly fun. if anyone wants to try it out however i suggest to keep in mind that while you'd want to try to keep any and all employees alive especially for the first few playthroughs that will be almost if not completely impossible. although you can plan for things and set things up nearly perfectly rng can always appear to ruin that plan. it's best to always be lenient and allow one or two employees to die as you near later days. however this won't let you stay safe and chances are due to some of the abnormalities you'll end up with you'll have to start a new game. but that's why you'd want to sacrifice employees... everything you learned about those past abnormalities and all the equipment you got from them is still with you. you'll know when they show up and be able to plan things out even better thanks to having more knowledge than you would've ever had before and even be able to take on stronger abnormalities without any casualties.  so if you're into the idea of managing a bunch of mysterious maybe-deadly-maybe-safe creatures not bound by the laws of reality like you're in charge of the scp facility this is definitely the game for you. just remember you most likely will have to restart your first playthrough.

ignore the time here. i have played and finished the game and want to sing its well deserve praises. lobotomy corp is what happens when you take a management game mix in scp style monsters if you filed the id numbers off them and put them in a universe that is deeply rich with lore twists dark humour and a utterly beautiful story that wouldn't be far off in a game like smt.  you play the new manager who is tasked with gaining enough power from the abnormailites to help the world keep power. these come in randomised scps that you don't know anything about till you gain information on them by looking after them. this isn't so much in the way you look after a pet though. some have exact tells you need to watch for. some need constant attention. some require hugs. some are ...censored....either way you will be looking after an expanding team of x-com like name your friends and murder them employees that will help you tackle the daily life in this utterly safe not dangerous at all murder box of sin and depression.   give this game a chance. if you like roguelike ideas mixed in with a story that will keep you compelled. you will adore this.

this game is immensely frustrating to begin.  i have tried to start playing and subsequently quit trying three separate times since i bought this game years ago.  now on try four i finally have enough of a grasp on the gameplay to allow myself to get hooked.  so why did i come back time and time again?  the story the presentation and the concept of the world do a fantastic job of drawing me in.  something nutty is evidently going on and i can't wait to find out what.  fans of thinking about the moral implications of authority technology and servitude (as well as people that like scp) need look no farther.  do not skip the tutorial.  the tutorial has three parts before referring you to an optional but highly recommended manual.  do not play without reading the manual.  it will probably take you about half an hour to work through the tutorials and manuals but if you are anything like me you will burn out long before you learn the game through osmosis otherwise.  if you get to the point where you understand how to manage the gameplay this game has magical things to show you.  edited after i finished the game:  a hundred hours later i still love this game.   i'd never played a management game before but i enjoyed myself and eagerly await the upcoming sequels.  that said the gameplay in particular has some imperfections that lead to tedium and unnecessary player punishment (days take a long time to complete even at 2x speed and starting from day 1 [which you'll do at least once to finish the game] takes away all of your employees you've spent literal days training).  free mods fix these problems.  they don't even have to make the game easier or harm the vanilla experience.  take a look at the popular ones and give this amazing game a go.

this is a very dubious recommendation. i wish steam had a neutral review setting.  this game's design is hearts of iron 4 levels of convoluted. but now at least the translation is comprehensible and makes sense. everything is properly translated so it is easier to understand. there is a lot of mechanics to weigh and understand. it's promising so i'm going to continue to play it more after this review and if my opinion changes i'll update this.  the justification for the entire game premise is 100% an excuse plot and the presentation is very much anime-esque not just in visual but in the tonality of how things are presented which is to say very weak. this is very disappointing... but the game quickly glosses over it and moves onto the scp/rpc material so you can handwave the nonsense story away and just get to playing an rpc like game.  my biggest grievance with lobco so far is the game has only one theme which plays on repeat ad-nausium i muted the music and just put on some iron cthulhu apocalypse which very seriously changed the atmosphere and theme of the game from something relatively light hearted in its handling of heavy subject matter into something dark and menacing. which was much more enjoyable. this game's music is its biggest weakness. the tonal shift in the theme from the subject matter is cognitive dissonance and not only is the song annoying but it really distracts from the game's narrative.  once you get around the incredibly heavy handed mechanics of the game it has a lot of potential. i like the risk of exploration that's involved. this is totally how the rpc/scp groups would handle their entities. it's all about the danger of trying to understand something that is outside conventional understanding. things will go wrong stuff won't make sense. you will have to risk staff and they will die as you try to figure out what it is you're dealing with. some of these entities get so weird and unknowable that there's a real challenge in disassembling their nature. i wish this was better explored however where you'd spend more time understanding something than what the game has. the system in place i feel makes it a little too easy to comprehend something over time. i'd like it more if it was i guess more rogue like and the anomalies were more difficult to understand with a much more involved process to debunk them with the risk being your entire game. that would add much more tension to the experience.  so far so good.

day 49 is a hell but here's some tip(+ this game is great): 1st step. before level 4 qlipoth put 3 employees that is just okay to be dead in binah's team so they can manage abnormalies when binah put meltdowns on them.  2nd step. press space hoping that none of your employees panic or die (if they panic try to break them from panic if you can) and send them to abnnormalies to weaken binah while calling rabbit protocal   3rd step. when rabbit protocal skipped binah's first phase (or skipped 2nd phase if you're lucky) try to use employees to surpress binah dodging her pattern (when she says something move.)  good luck manager!

lobotomy corporation is a curious thing. it's a very upsetting game that expects you to do things over and over again. it's a game i have not completed and will only play once ever as going through everything is a long and someone exhausting process...so it's odd to say that this is one of my favorite games ever.  lobotomy corporation is at its base a game where you manage a miniature scp corporation doing terrible things for the sake of getting power for the outside world or so it seems. as the game progresses you discover fascinating things about the outside world you're doing this for the sephirot's that run the teams i feel like the thing that is most interesting is that as the game progresses it gives reasons as to why there are certain gameplay mechanics why things happen this particular way even the art style of the game is explained with a lore reason. this certainly isn't a game for everyone in fact i think most will find it long and frustrating but that isn't the way i see it i suppose.
this is legitimately a good game. why don't more people play this?

while i haven't played a whole lot of the game (only day 20) i can say that it seems very very promising. the terrible translation is fixed which makes this game a whole lot more fun now. if you like s.c.p or any management game this will probably be pretty good for you. just note that this game does little hand-holding and is pretty complex and hard to understand at first. the only problem i have is that you gotta have some good rng. for example i unfortunately got the plague doctor on day 11 which later turned into whitenight and killed almost all of my facility. i also had to deal with express train to hell which caused so many restarts.   tldr : good game overall the art is nice and is good as a monster simulation game but you gotta get a bit lucky

it's kinda hard to write about the story which is really the main focus of the game without spoilers all i can say is that it's not one i will soon forget. it can get really dark and uncomfortable but it's not at all edgy. while i think reaching the ending can take too long i haven't lost interest in what's happening for over 120 hours which i consider really impressive. i love the themes and characters it's a story i don't think will age badly if anything it's the opposite. i honestly wonder how library of ruina can top this. it's sad the game was badly translated for so long you can't just google translate a visual novel.  okay so here's the part about the gameplay and the management part is really not that hard lol one monster likes white work other one will kill your agent if you try it. trial and error is the name of the game do it right and you will unlock info that tells you how to work on an abnormality without ever losing employees. ordeals are different but you can always retry to do it again or get a new one. people are just really forgetful and not willing to admit their mistakes they make this out to be eve online level of micromanagement or something when it's really not. yes there are hard parts i didn't mention but there's not that many of them.  some tips: get a few mods to lessen the grind(full-time employees is one i heavily reccomend). don't listen to angela and take care of your agents(guys you control) you need them to progress and while i don't encourage trying to be jesus if they keep dying every day you will not have a good time. abnormalities are really cool and creative but try to keep them in their boxes the first time an abnormality escapes is really fun the second time is a sign of your failure. want to finish the game legitimately? prepare for a heavy grind and like 100 hours of box clicking.  check out the soundtrack there are some amazing tracks in there. i have listened to no warning for over 100 hours and i still like it. if that doesn't convince you the soundtrack is a 10/10 i don't know what will.

i have played this game start to finish multiple times with and without mods. with every day and challenge you complete you gain more personnel equipment abilities and responsibilities giving a wonderful sense of progression. the game is tedious and niche.

this game is super challenging if you're not used to these types of mechanics. but i don't think i'd call it unfair; rather it's as heartless as it presents itself to be.  when they say you're acting as the manager they mean it. you have to send the right employee to perform the right task at the right time. if you don't the consequences can range from mostly simple to catastrophic. in addition you also have to be prepared for unpredictable events; if your teams aren't balanced in stats in equipment they're as good as dead.  and yet these challenges are what make this game so interesting. i especially appreciate that you can restart days in the instance of achieving total failure or unsatisfactory results. you can also go back a few days if you want the chance to make different choices.

you purchase desperate people off the dystopian streets and force them into little rooms to touch scps in your underground bunker. you collect new scps every day for the people to touch. touching scps generates [redacted] which we need for [redacted]. everything is fine and dandy for a very few precious days. slowly you come to the realization that certain scps do not like to be touched and will in fact rip and tear when given the slightest opportunity. we do not talk about [censored]. still we must complete our noble charge of generating [redacted] so some of the little people will just have to be forced to touch the dangerous ones. repeatedly. as [censored] inevitably envelops the fragile flesh of even your most steadfast and valiant operatives and continues to spread across the underground bunker utterly out of control you slowly pull your eyes away from the glass viewport and inject the [redacted] directly into your bloodstream with your main man netzach. brooo that's the way. sometimes you just need to chill out.  the days turn into weeks and the underground bunker turns into an unrecognizable hellscape ruby goldberg machine that triggers the instant somebody passes gas in the wrong direction. you spend your precious moments before dawn ruthlessly executing every single civilian lab worker who had the audacity to show up to work today and disposing of the corpse lest they become meat fodder for the rapturous scps which now populate the bunker and may become alerted to the slapping of thicc employee thighs at any moment. that's enough slaughter for now time to touch the accursed bull[redacted]. why do i hear trumpets? oh frick oh heck everybody get out of there. looks like safety team wasn't very safe after all. well so be it the rabbits shall graze upon this filthy grass once more. safety team hasn't evacuated yet? necessary casualties as excessive as they may be. we must seal off the breach. secure. contain. protecc. ok somebody stop the screaming baby before it causes the apocalypse again. ok clearly what we need are some anti air guns. you then proceed to stuff the big seven into an elevator shaft and utterly buttblast the invading scps before they can buttblast you.  and then it gets harder. why is this one so difficult to buttblast? what in the secured contained protected heck are they doing on the other side of the plexiglass? excessive casualties are a regular occurrence now. many many of you will die but a few may make it through this time. was the game always like this? the past month feels like a blur. where is my cute little scp management game where nothing bad happens? truth is the game was rigged from the start. it's a buttblast or be buttblasted world which is extremely easy for me to appreciate. the music's pretty good as well. wait a second there's another one?

this is probably one of my favorite management sims. apparently there used to be an issue with translation but they re-translated it in english and that's all i've seen and it's very good.  this is a fairly decent management game with a fairly simple management idae you get one new thing to manage every day you pick 1 of 4 ways to manage it and you learn how it reacts. your people get stronger based on the ways they help manage your new monsters and can equip things to help deal with escapes.  where this game shines is that the monsters that you manage all have their own very specific intricacies/guidelines that you need to both learn and follow and these make them all feel like their own interesting scp's to manage. the extremely different ways that these may require handling beyond the 4 ways of management and the ways they can react make them all interesting to learn. as the game progresses you learn more about how to deal with your new abnormalities whether naturally or unlocking information about them.   that said this game is definitely not meant to be completed your first time in. mismanagement of the abnormalities will kill your worker which may lead to escapes and further deaths. challenges you are required to beat may lead to over half your staff dying. if you have too many people die you won't be able to manage some of the abnormalities correctly which will lead to further deaths. information of the specifics of how to handle your abnormalities can be unlocked by managing them at any degree of success and sometimes it can be hard to understand what you're doing wrong until its directly told to you.  that being the case this game has a wonderful reset feature where you can either reset to the last 5 day increment or from the very beginning with all the information you have unlocked and equipment you've gained. you also have the option of resetting the day completely as if it hadn't happened yet. this resetting is key to the game and you're going to want to do it at least once if not more even from the beginning. the challenges you complete give you permanent upgrades that make resets far easier to start out on.  as you get through the game the story will slowly be told to you from various perspectives all leading up to a larger picture. i thoroughly enjoyed reading this story but because it is based on your progression through challenges (which only need to be completed once) it will come in very uneven chunks based on how well you are doing. the abnormalities all have their own descriptions as well that are fantastic to read and give the guidelines of how to handle the abnormalities more context.  i fully recommend this game to anyone who likes management games or the concept of scp-like things.  but turn off kickstarter abnormalities starting out. they are significantly harder to deal than the rest which when starting out can be incredibly awful to deal with.

i saw one (1) picture of netzach on twitter and having just come from fire emblem my brain went well i liked another green haired man what's to say i won't love this one?  cut to almost 100 hours of screaming crying and begging my employees to just please stay alive over and over i can wholeheartedly say this game is definitely the most enjoyable thing i've ever come across.   it starts out overwhelming - the machanics are a lot of things thrown at you at once but thankfully the tutorial makes a fun way to get to grips with things and you are always gifted an easy abnormality first time around to help you get the hang of things. then it quickly starts to ramp up the action with the trial-and-error nature of learning about each abnormality and how to best get energy from them to progress your game. even if it's grindy and requires restarts - you'll come across new abnormalities each time around and there's lots to think of and consider in how you need to build your facility to better suit your objective for the run. (eg: i need alephs for gebura or i want non-breaching abnormalities for the suppressions).  the characters are full of twists and genuine emotion and all lovingly designed. must say getting the art book absolutely added to the enjoyment as i can see all the details and sketches that have gone into the facility and the abnormalities themselves. each creation has its own story and it's a genuine pleasure to discover each one. it's also neat that one can customise the employees themselves so adding in your friends/family/ocs/self to see how long you/they survive before something eats (or worse) them!   all in all the fact that it took me almost 60 hours to unlock 10% towards the true ending (and now 100 hours in i'm only at 40%) shows it was absolutely worth the ¬£20 i spent on it and then some! i've even gifted it to friends so that they might share this glorious hell with me.

i've come to revise my original joke review into an actual one.   upon reflection i think project moon have made a game that scratches a lot of my particular itches. i've fallen in love with the artstyle music world story and gameplay. it has very little to offer in the gameplay department of your typical conventional management game tropes. the dialogue and worldbuilding after having been re-translated of course is actually quite well-written. it lends itself to crafting a world outside of the small one of that the player character sees yet is still entirely believable and interesting.       unfortunately however the game's control methods and odd quirks lend it to being unable to hook new players and keep it from gaining the mass-appeal that it more than certainly has the potential for. it's control methods for your agents themselves are odd at best and frustrating at worst and are more of a suggestion than order. it has a lot of things about it that one definitely needs to spend more than a few hours past steams refund limit of playing to really begin to get the full gist of or get used to as a player.      i love this game through and through but i don't think it's something that everyone will give a fair chance but i can't really necessarily say that i could blame them given the above reasoning. if this game wasn't your thing but the characters and world still interest you then please by all means give the sequel library of ruina a shot. it's an entirely different genre of game while still making many callbacks to this game and recounts the key plot elements from lobotomy corporation.
it's pretty fun i guess

lobotomy corporation is one of those games that might not be for everyone but for those who enjoy these kinds of games it's pretty great.  basically you are hired to be the manager of a facility for studying different things called abnormalities. these things range from weird doodads that can turn back time or make you completely bald to horrifying monsters that will either eat you or do some other horrid thing to you.  you're tasked with sending your employees to study these abnormalities in 4 different ways with each having their own results. some may be more effective than others but until you actually fill out the information page of the abnormality it's basically up to chance. (that is if you don't just have the wiki up in the background)  it gets harder over time as you deal with more abnormalities at a time which could end up working together to cause maximum chaos if you're not careful. however if anything were to escape from their rooms you can send your employees to suppress them. studying these abnormalities can grant your employees interesting equipment for combat and protection. there are also missions you can work on throughout your average day these are linked to progression in the story so do that.  the story is...interesting and not really something i can go over in this review. everything's not as simple as it may seem and you might even have to bend the rules a bit and turn back time to have more than the default amount of days you have until reaching the neutral ending.  whilst the gameplay might not be too amazing for those who enjoy action focused games the lore and world building this game provides is fucking great. you will grow to love the many different horrible and wonderful things you'll encounter.
