this game has drilled a hole into my skull and now lives rent free inside it.  you may mistake this game by it's steam page with a visual novel it's not. in the review section players care so much about story and are ready to pick apart single dialogue for hours - but it's not because there's all there is to the game - story dialogues are just a reward a few lines of story for going through the daily grind and near impossible challenges.   the game starts pretty slowly and controls might be awkward at first but they're actually very very simple. it's just there probably isn't a game you've played before that's similar to lobotomy corp and therefore it doesn't feel intuitive it's not something you've done before. but you get used to it.  figuring out with abnormalities and meeting energy quota isn't all there is - you can actually continue the day after meeting energy quota and you absolutely should - because you can train your employees that way. you can use lob points for that but you will eventually run out of those that way. so the grind is the optimal way. i'd complain if it weren't the part of the story.  the abnormalities themselves have each their own rules - some apply facility-wide some apply during working with the abnormality and some - during suppression. breaking them usually ends up in abnormality escaping or killing employees. some abnormalities could look similar in behaviour but there are ones that start breaking the 4th wall and ones that do something you would never expect. there's an abnormality that has a progress bar (it looks like a clock you'll know when you see it) and it fills up each time an employee works with it. i decided that i don't want to see what happens when it fills up so i started the day over to reset it. when you see that it did not reset after starting a day over or starting a week or the game over you will shit bricks. and you just wait until the clock goes to 12.  the music might sound odd but lobotomy corp absolutely o w n s it (even though not in a legal sense). there isn't a single time in the game where any other soundtrack would seem more appropriate. everything just fits  there are also sephirot missions. they are the story they unlock new upgrades that make the game easier and you should prioritise doing them first.  some missions might look truly (but not the grinding kind) impossible. you might even think that something isn't translated correctly or it's mistyped [spoiler]or the sephira giving the mission has gone mad[/spoiler] but every mission requires of you exactly what it says.  but when you actually manage to pull the stunts required of you you will feel fucking invincible.  it's as though you are able to do anything now... until you see the next mission.  and it goes like that until the very end.  and it feels totally awesome.  there will be boss fights too... just not in a sense they usually are in other games. let's say that there are gameplay features that you really shouldn't be taking for granted and it's those features that give you an edge against whatever comes your way.  but could you manage without them? boss fights hold a lot of surprises and some really good design. [spoiler]for example you literally cannot win against malkuth - girl with a notepad without having a physical notepad yourself. mind == blown. [/spoiler] they managed to surprise me every time right to the last day.  and the plot did so even a bit after the last day.   speaking of plot the game manages expectations very very well. expectations getting flipped upside down is the most satisfying part. can't talk about it without getting into spoilers though. i warned you:  you might think that the game is about monsters and that it's the part we have to uncover.  [spoiler]but it's actually everything else. the story the characters the city above and it's troubles.[/spoiler]  you probably think that abnormalities are some alien creatures that ended up here somehow and we need to contain them.  [spoiler]they're actually more human than anybody in your facility. and we are making them to exploit them later![/spoiler]  [spoiler]you probably think that angela is plotting something against you or the corporation after playing a few days  it's much more complicated than that. i don't know what to tell you. play the game.[/spoiler]  after playing for some time you will start to think that restarting the day and the memory repository is an awkward implementation of a save game feature.  [spoiler]you couldn't be more wrong. it's actually an essential part of both the gameplay and the story by design. it brings another layer to the gameplay and explains a lot story wise when you find it out.[/spoiler]  you might think you're a manager clueless and fresh to the company and you should do what sephirot and angela tell you like what malkuth instructs you to do on day 1.  [spoiler]you're actually a the founder of the company. and the sephirot including angela are here against against their will just because you willed it. and they're waiting expectantly for you to pull them out of their misery and lead them somewhere. [/spoiler]  [spoiler]the facility literally turns upside down on day 50. it actually looks like a tree that way. then it sprouts from the surface and emits light.  it just all makes sense in the end - the tree of light the seed the goddamn cactus on a desk eventually bearing a flower. and it's only one example of many.[/spoiler]  buy and play lobotomy corporation. and i'm not giving you a fucking choice.

i was gifted this game by a friend and i can say i've had a great time with it! (if my hours have anything to say for that haha).   while the text and ui can be really troublesome to read due to really poor colour choices (i have astigmatism and really struggled reading the tutorial i had to get a friend to help me) the game itself is overall very unique and intriguing. i was obsessed after only a few short days of playing and even now i'm about halfway through i can't stop playing.  the art style is very cute but fits the aesthetic very well. the character designs are superb their development was fun to watch and i had a genuinely good time discovering all the different abnormalities (creatures) in the game! though i wasn't able to read their stories in the game due to the text size and colours i was able to look them up elsewhere and i absolutely love the depth behind each one.  the gameplay does tend to get pretty grindy later on especially when you have to restart multiple times but the game compensates for that by allowing you to unlock bonuses that will help significantly more with each run!   i definitely recommend this game tbh! very fun and it's an enjoyable experience once you understand it.

summary:  this game will not be suitable to people that lack determination and the ability to endure pain and frustration over and over again (unless you've beaten a dark souls-like game). it is a korean game which theme is based off the scp universe with fallout shelter-like management mechanics and anime-like design. as of recently the revised english translation has been added which improved the dialogue (i only recently bought it after it came out so i don't know how bad it was before) and for the most part not many complaints coming from me.  story: (no spoliers just very basic run down.) you are the manager for this facility. the facility is divided into different departments with a different sephirah (essentially the head of the department) that report to you. you command employees (essentially d-class but not criminals just people who needed work) who directly follow your orders. there are abnormalities which you must work on using employees and gain energy boxes from them until you reach your daily quota. overtime you unlock more difficult abnormalities and more departments which allow you to gain more equipment and special abilities to maintain order. there are three different endings to achieve and a number of varying abnormalities you may or may not meet (depending how many playthroughs you do to unlock them all).  mechanics: as explained above essentially it is similar to fallout shelter. you can create and customize employees to hearts desire (or as much as you can compensate if you are trying to create a certain replica of a character). hairstyles are kinda of limited to asian hairstyles and you can't change skin colour. overtime if they still live (gets hard to keep them alive) they will level up their stats which for the most part will make them better prepared to deal with the abnormalities. you can also stack points you earn from how well you do the other day to either upgrade an employee or create a new one. abnormalities not only provide you with energy but with equipment weapons and gifts. these can be acquired after you research the abnormality enough times and bank up enough spare energy to create them (gifts are earned by probability when working with them). as you pass more days and unlock and complete more missions/tasks from the sephirahs you can respectively expand/open more departments and unlock new abilities as mention above that can be used to help maintain the peace. moreover as days pass you unlock new abnormalities. you generally get to choose one of three per day with their serial number and a quote of theirs which give you a small sense of what they might be.  difficulty: this game is designed to be frustrating. there is a reason why you can restart a day or rewind to a memory repository (didn't mention this but every 5 days it saves it in the repository [for example: day 1 6 11 16...]. it basically reverts you back to that day as the same but with knowledge kept of the abnormalities you unlocked after the memory day. it gives you a way to avoid a certain abnormality and a potential to choose a new one). it is possible to keep all you employees you have alive throughout the game (which i am currently doing) but from personal experience it can be really difficult and time consuming. overall if you can't handle this or would prefer to keep your sanity then go ahead and avoid the game. but if you want something challenging and interesting then this game might be for you.  price: the price of this game is $28.99 cdn which may seem a lot. for someone who likes the scp universe anime and management/strategy games it is worth. you can get a couple of different games with the different endings which makes it playable for hours to come. however eventually you will unlock everything and the sandbox mode doesnt add much to it (from what i heard). you could also wait for a sale if you need to save money but for the most part this game is worth what you get (especially with all these bad aaa games trend going on thanks 2019 2020). overall if you believe you will play the game to the end then it is worth.  in conclusion this game of interesting and diverse cast of characters and abnormalities makes the story intriguing. frustration can arise as you encounter more difficult circumstances but as you play you can retry multiple times and devise new strategies or plans that allow you to be creative on how you personally will run the facility. their lives are in your hands. good luck.

welcome sir/ma'am/miss/mr if you've received this congratulations!! we have reviewed your cv and determined you are the one to take on the position of manager at our corporation you fulfil all the criteria and skills that we feel will be your most challenging task.   as you are aware we at l corp are the largest energy companies in fact the only company appointed to power the world we live in. we strive for excellent delivery of energy to our homes and humanity due to this purpose and our founder a has placed high expectations on us to achieve this every day. but before we continue please examine the l-pad we provided that details the contract's terms and conditions that you must accept. if not press 'refuse' and step away from the l-pad's blast radius of one kilometre.  ....  thank you for accepting your contract's terms and conditions. level manager clearance acquired.  to continue we must first address the rumours surrounding the corporation. aside from the two prominent rumours that states our employees engage in after hour orgies and that we are a greedy soulless corporation sucking the lifestream out of the planet to power humanity all rumours are true. our energy source come from monsters we call abnormalities who either come to us or have been captured for their threat to the world at large and we interact with them to acquire the positive enkephelin boxes which stores the power siphoned from them.   your duty as acting manager is to take care of these abnormalities we secure contain them in our facility then siphon the energy. simple right? however we should not forget to mention that we've gone through 35 managers in the past month before coming to you and that's not including employee casualties from things such as:   possession and the urge to wear red shoes insanity from looking at incomprehensible beings sacrifice lottery draws mental breakdown suicides testing tools and machines participating in blasphemy and heresy of other kinds  as you can see from the above your new job provides the appropriate challenge you crave. to survive we will give you the first steps:  work is divided into four categories: instinct insight temperance and justice which enhances your employees' health mental fortitude success at work and work speed. abnormalities that are new bring unknowns so it is recommended you send your employees to prod and determine their threat level and what they respond to the best. don't be afraid if they die your subordinates are paving the way to discovery.  we classify our creatures from least to most dangerous: zayin teth he waw and finally aleph who are contained securely in their cells for you. as we bring in each abnormality at the end of each day we give no indication of their threat level but only brief quotes and numbers to keep you guessing. why? in the spirit of exploration and setting your own challenge against creatures unknown the next day for the most energy of course! note that the more dangerous they are the more energy you can afford.  if the creatures do get out our staff are equipped with the most basic riot gear though with research time and energy our welfare team can create ego weapons and suits to defend against these monsters but only through sacrificing pe boxes to unlock abnormality information fully so we can get a full profile of what they do. trust me you don't want to see what happened when we used incomplete information to make a suit the employee's remains had to be torn from the parasitic suit. angela will explain more.  with this advice given we again extend our welcome to you the new manager of lobotomy corporation!! with the threat of death everyday out there...what do you have to lose with us?

due to the devs getting scammed by a shitty translation service this game used to have an awful translation however as of may 2020 the game has a excellently reworked translation. i'd advise all to immediately ditch the scp/fallout shelter comparisons because if you go in wanting either you are not going to get it and that is really a good thing.  +++++ a game that actually deserves it's age rating it's dark no it's quite frankly fucked up. but it's not trying to be edgy for the sake of it or doing it merely for shock value. there's a deep and dark story here that is well worth the hundred+ hours you'll need to see it through. ++++ complex and unique gameplay if i were to give it a genre i'd call it anxiety management +++ a wonderful blend of gameplay and narrative your actions are informing your perspective on the game. the game wants you to become heartless to let that one employee die so you can progress. and are you going to restart and try that boss again just for that one easily replaceable employee? i hope so you monster. +++/--- this game is long you've been warned. this is either a good or bad thing depending on what you want from a game. but this game uses a time rollback mechanic that encourages you to restart the day/week/whole playthrough while retaining everything you learnt like a modern roguelike. getting the true ending requires multiple rollbacks. you can do it in one playthrough but only if you consistently rollback every week in order to get access to all the encyclopedia. ++ this game is brutal and it doesn't care about your feelings on the matter. it consistently defines your limitations and then like a good game should pushes the goalpost a little past them and out of your reach.  ------- game has a memory leak playing for long periods of time will consume memory until your pc crashes. check task manager occasionally to see when it breaches 4gb and restart the game to surpress it's urge to take over your entire computer. ------ in my game i only encountered one bug... but that bug was nasty undoing the win i made against one of the games hardest bosses and killing all of my team and losing me their gear. this would have been bearable but it was on day 43 on my final run to the end. -‚àû binah you weirdos who like this psychopath all need help.

my feelings for this game are kinda complicated. if you want a tl;dr just read the last paragraph. if you want to know my personal thoughts as someone who 100% this game then give the rest of it a read.  this game is unfair. there are many different mechanics that you have to juggle involving the abnormalities to avoid disaster each unique and most of the time incredibly difficult to keep track of. on top of that there are some cases in which you end up getting abnormalities that have rules that contradict another so you end up having to either put up with the horrible things that entitles or reset a few days to hope you get a better roll. by the way resetting is also an integral part of the game. you'll most likely be forced to sacrifice progress to go back and grind better employees or equipment to have a fighting chance meaning having to redo hours of work in some cases. then after that the game has boss fights that make trying to get through a normal day into a nightmare by instilling even more rules. this game is rigged against you. it will beat you up. it wont forgive you for missing even a single beat. it will get you no matter how well you think you know the game and it'll expect you to either persevere or try again for the 10th time. to be brutally honest it's massively unbalanced and the devs know it because that's exactly what they want while at the same time expecting you to get through it. it's stressful and infuriating  ...but even after countless retries over 100 hours of trial and error and chipping away at this game on and off for over a year and only finishing it today i can't say i hate it. even though the devs didn't pull their punches when designing this game they don't necessarily insult you for your failures either. it's a hard game and they know it but they also know that with enough time and patience they know you can win. it's reflected with the themes in the story and the dialog written; no matter how bad things are it's still possible to get through it. that's why i like this game so much. it doesn't patronize you by making things do less damage it doesn't make gear cost less when you lose too many employees it doesn't do any of that. it gives you a difficult challenge and you try to conquer it. this ties incredibly well with the story too but i'd rather not spoil anything. personally i don't really care too much for stories in games but this game has so many layers and a lot of thought put into it's world that i couldn't help but get invested. the more you learn the more you realize just how deep the rabbit hole goes. there really isn't anything quite like this game.  it's honestly hit or miss. it's incredibly difficult and it doesn't get easy. the best way to gauge if you'd like it or not is by watching a video on the first few days and see if it interests you at all. probably to like up to day 10. you might not like it and that's okay; just pass on this game but if you do end up liking what you see then you'll no doubt enjoy what this game has to offer.

by the way before this review starts you don't need to put nearly as many hours into this game as i have. great game overall. not perfect of course but still good and difficult. the concept is that you are the manager of a company that contains and harvests energy from abnormalities. you manage your agents and their work as well as try to keep the abnormalities from causing chaos. the best part of the game is just encountering new abnormalities and learning about their quirks as you have no knowledge of them upon your first encounter. sometimes nothing horrible will happen and you will be relieved about the danger you avoided. sometimes something unknown and horrible happens and it's your job to deal with the situation. you also have to figure out how to go about your day to day stuff collecting energy with the new threat inside the facility. the game also has plenty of quests optional challenges and surprisingly fun boss fights to spice things up. this game is not easy and lots of chaos will ensue as you play through but if you can get past some of the frustrating moments this is a game i recommend.

[h1]welcome to lobotomy corporation![/h1] get comfortable and prepare to face the fear and build the future [b]at great great cost.[/b]  lobotomy corporation also subtitled monster management simulation is a weird and wonderful roguelike strategy management simulator. drawing inspiration from the works of the scp foundation and numerous sources in scifi sci-fantasy folklore horror gaming and more lobocorp initially presents a very simple premise to the player : manage a facility focused on research of abnormal entities and translate that work into energy. more successful work more energy produced.  simple in theory fascinatingly touchy in practice - you're applying a very loose version of the scientific method here and spoilers! lobocorp has very [i]very[/i] loose definitions on employee safety protocol.  the entire game is rendered in a fun cutesy bubblehead [i]'moe'[/i] aesthetic; very charming no eyesore to look at for long periods.  you won't feel a thing when the staff dies! look how cute they are when they scream! of note is the english translation which used to be much choppier (being translated from native korean); the recent (as of writing) update has since cleaned it up dramatically. (i'll note i don't entirely approve of the translation cleanup as some of the engrish actually helped accentuate how strange and esoteric the game is).  the music is superb though you'll be hearing two or three tracks far more often than the others; the inclusion of a diegetic music system rating you based on current panic level really does help you keep solid tabs of how well you're keeping the facility under tabs -- and conversely how boned you really are when things truly hit the fan.   of special note is the [i]second trumpet[/i] theme. you'll know it when it happens - and you'll learn to love/hate the level of chaos that provokes it.  being a roguelike game built on a 'days' system lobocorp does a lot to try and balance the level of stress it ekes out of the player with some nice quality of life features both built-in and unlockable. it is mechanically rich and thematically saturated with subtle and not-so-subtle hints to hebrew scripture and kabbalah teachings alongside its varied references to exterior sources.  [h1]a few tips for the prospective player![/h1] the wiki exists but please refrain from using it until necessary. this game thrives on uncertainty and study. never be afraid to fail as you learn more from failure than success. never be afraid to restart; unlockables stay unlocked through playthroughs even equipment (until death!) if it sounds bad it's probably bad. if it sounds good it's [b]definitely[/b] bad. do look over the provided manual and attempt to parse the four-color-coded stats system as the terminology used is a little intentionally esoteric. red is physical stats white is mental stats purple is workspeed and success and blue/pale governs speed. trust the manual. but don't trust it too much.  spread the love with equipment and avoid the urge to overspecialize departments.   among the many things the lobocorp offers you'll get to :  [list]   [*]hang out with the skull!   [*]read the provided manual!   [*]learn the manual is kind of useless!   [*]kill your first employee (complete with champagne)!   [*]don't touch the button!   [*]learn the color-coded danger levels!   [*]learn the color-coded danger levels are meaningless!   [*]give someone the notepad!   [*]don't blink!   [*]experience new and fascinating forms of anxiety!   [*]hang out with grandma until she gives you the thing you want!   [*]neglect grandma after that!   [*]hang out with the skull!   [*]appreciate the fine arts!   [*]suffer for your art!   [*]make [i]others[/i] suffer for your art!   [*]don't touch the button!   [*]play with strange devices!   [*]play with strange creatures!   [*]kill more employees as you do so!   [*]kill [b]many[/b] more employees as you try to figure stuff out!   [*]try to bond with reddit!   [*]figure out why that's a terrible idea!   [*]discover fascinating new uses for a bathtub!   [*]find out why nature is horrible!   [*]hang out with the skull!   [*]ask where the shoes are!   [*]ask what the tree is doing!   [*]ask what the **** is the safe's problem!   [*]ask what that screeching noise is!   [*]try to keep everything together!   [*]fail!   [*]forget your train ticket!   [*]try something stupid!   [*]be surprised when it works!   [*]hang out with the skull!   [*]do it all again the next day! [/list]

scp management game it's a bit rough towards the end i'd suggest completing as many of the bosses and missions as quick as possible because otherwise the game pacing slows to a crawl towards the end. do not be afraid to revert back to day 1 or the checkpoints it's kinda part of the game loop a large part of the game is about trial and error.  pick it up if you like management games or stories with the same sort of themes as scp

let me begin by saying: i love this game but this game hates me. this game has been a source of anxiety since the day i began playing it. not only that but there's a sequel to this game called library of ruina which i've heard is pretty fun however library of ruina spoils the events of lobotomy corporation so if you give a damn about the lore you'll want to finish lobotomy corporation before you play library of ruina.  imagine buying a game that you think looks interesting you then realize that it is the sequel to another game and so you decide to play that first - then you learn that not only is the lore incredibly mysterious dark and interesting as all hell but it is also so soul-crushingly difficult that i honestly have a feeling akin to mental claustrophobia whenever i pass day 15. every time i pass a day i've spent my real life sanity trying to survive this game and every day you're expected to do what you just did but a little bit harder. every time. trying to describe my current work-day in lobotomy corporation is like listening to the ramblings of a madman i will actually just give you my [i]average shift schedule below[/i] and if you think that your brain will like this kind of game then i warmly recommend partaking in this buffet of pulled pork expensive wine and barbed wire.  [h1]shift 25 starts![/h1] [spoiler]-in the beginning of the game adam has to babysit the [i]child of the galaxy.[/i] adam isn't allowed to do anything else but to sit outside the [i]child of the galaxy's[/i] testing chamber. should adam be possessed to walk into the [i]cherry blossom funeral's[/i] testing chamber the entire security department will be deployed to kill adam. it's better that the [i]child of the galaxy[/i] is sad over the passing of a friend than it being jealous of adam's [i]more friends.[/i]  -eden needs to be stationed outside the [i]express ticket to hell's[/i] testing let me be frank this game is great but incredibly flawed. the world building and creatures are fantastic however it will take you an absurd amount of tedium and micromanaging to complete the story.  i am not a fan of sims like this but i still enjoy the work put into it. the same way i hate turn based battle games but still love persona.  my honest opinion if you don't like this type of game like me buy it and support the devs give it a good honest try and if it gets too tedious look up the story because it is actually super interesting.

tedium corporation: amazing music interesting story  cool artstyle horid lategame and at times mind-numbing gameplay.  you should just stop playing once you reach the boss fights. a single day can take literally an hour. it gets so incredibly tedious to just play this game that i had stopped playing it for months and only just came back to cheat my way to the end cause i wanna know the story for the sequel.  this game wants you to try new things and experiment to find out what works but you get punished so hard for failing its not even funny. spaming the same group of easy monsters 24/7 every single day to get your boxes up just to restart cause the new thing killed half your dudes is the opposite of fun. there are some monsters you could accidentally pick as a new players that are so incredibly annoying that you might as well roll back a few days. you are better off deleting a few hours of progress than try to deal with those for the rest of your playthrough.  also the combat isnt fun or engaging at all. you barely do anything aside from maybe giving a guy a shield or doing minimal kiting. you cant even really fight the strongest monsters. a handful of them is just straight up not beatable your only choice is to restart the day (wow so fun guys thank you).  you'll have a few hours of fun till you reach that point though so i'll still recommend it.

this is the most stressful game i have ever played. it is also one of the best games i have ever played. it is a waking nightmare that thinks you are too chickenshit to try to seriously beat it and has already boldly (and correctly) incorporated the gratuitous despair it will inflict upon you in the future as a core part of the narrative as doing so was a necessary part of brute forcing you into empathizing with the endless suffering you endlessly inflict on others. you should buy it if you are insane. the artbook is cool too. do not pick the train.

the game in its current state is absolutely fantastic. you are your worst enemy in this game. (90% of the time) the abnormalities have decent stories behind them and definitely give you the scp feel as you initially observe their documents and attempt further research. a day in the game can go from 0 to 100 very fast depending if you fail to follow managerial tips or send inadequate staff to tend to the ungodly creatures and tools you have trapped in your containment units. try to avoid guides initially as half the fun is figuring out what caused sudden chaos throughout the facility. the game can be very difficult and punishes the hell out of you for rushing things and losing focus. certain abno's have timed effects that if you fail to tend to them can cause catastrophic damage to the facility. there are also helpful abnormalities that while can still cause damage if used incorrectly generally benefit the facility. these helpful abno's can range from almost no draw backs to absolute carnage if used improperly. the music is great from calming almost elevator like chimes in times of peaceful work to some of the best combat osts in a moments notice when you screw something up.  while there are a few annoy things here or there like when you give agents an order it deselects them making it harder to micro some of the harder breaches/ordeals this can be fixed with a mod thankfully. additionally some of the later game abnos can be quite annoying such as [spoiler] a certain railway driven abno or a certain crying creature and dont get me started on the button. (it can wipe out a huge chunk of progress permanently so for the love of god dont click it) [/spoiler]  all in all a fantastic game and well worth the price tag in its current state.  9/10 from me.

it's hard it's challenging and it's the anime portrayal of scps from around the world- lobotomy corporation is the definition of farming and keeping your prized employees safe and sound. let them die you'll end up with such eradicating results to force a restart on the day- but don't take my word for it look up arcangela on this game via youtube. enjoy.

okay so yes this is a neat game. however. however. worst. tutorial. i. have. ever. seen.  jesus christ. 30 years of gaming. most obtuse confusing mess i have ever seen ever.  the game's themes are heavily based on kabbalah: i have studied kabbalah. kabbalah is easier to understand than the feking tutorial.  and this is *after* the updated improved translation. i can't imagine how bad it must have been for earlier players. holy. *crap!*  ....so yeah it is a genuinely really interesting game and i think i'll get a lot of fun out of it. but good god this is a master class on how not to do a tutorial or teach playing.  examples? randomly pausing and unpausing time telling me i can do that at any time and then disabling that function during the tutorial. so some long paragraphs went by in 5 seconds before i had a chance to read them. redid the same tutorial 4 times: still couldn't read it even with foreknowledge and speed reading. and then when i was trying to follow directions suddenly time would stop and i'd have to pan around the screen searching for what the hell it wanted me to look at now because it doesn't move the camera for you when it wants you to see something. in a tutorial. oy vey.  ...i could go on ranting for hours about how mind-bogglingly terrible the tutorial is but i won't. i will say:  cool theme obvious scp etc influences interesting to have the kabbalah stuff in there too nice art style overall it seems pretty cool it really does.  but whomever made the tutorial should be put in a pilory in the public square and have rotten vegetables thrown at them for the rest of their lives *oh my god it's the worst i've ever seen* o__o  so beware it doesn't have a learning curve it has a learning wall. a wall that is electrified and covered in razor wire and that has a personal grudge against you.   but other than that: neato! i look forward to fully enjoying this game once i understand what they flying fek is going on.

there's a lot to like here but if i had to pick something without giving any spoilers it's the take on horror. the game is very candid that something is up but you get to spend the rest of the game figuring out exactly what that is. the game is extremely unforgiving (but not unfair to be clear) which takes a lot of ongoing getting used to but that works well with the atmosphere of the game. just don't                 don't                          don't                                   spoil anything for yourself.  everything will be fine as always. enjoy your time.

decent game i recommend it if you are looking for a scp-management-ish game. one thing to note is that the game has distinct levels unlike a true sim so you finish your quota for the day and the game goes to a level-select menu. something else to keep in mind is that on each level making one mistake usually snowballs into ruining that day requiring a restart. if you're not a fan of somewhat grindy mechanics like that you have been warned. i was expecting something a little different when i bought it but it's still worth grabbing when on sale.

let me first start off this review by saying that i have yet to complete this game though i believe i have played enough to formulate an opinion on it. also this is a [b][u]spoiler free[/u][/b] review.  lobotomy corporation is [u]not easy[/u] it starts off deceptively simple but then the difficulty ramps up exponentially as it continuously introduces new abnormalities for you to extract energy from and manage all the while you also have to keep in mind the various ordeals (these ordeals usually spawn monsters and whatever else) that make themselves known as your qliphoth counter increases from extracting said energy from abnormalities.  even though this game is extremely difficult i wouldn't outright call it unfair it's possible to pass each day as long as [b][u]you[/u][/b] haven't messed up massively e.g. you haven't hired enough people to cover a particular section of the facility and then you struggle to handle the meltdowns because of it. i feel as though the large level of difficulty in this game makes it feel much more rewarding when you end up beating one of the days with no employees killed this isn't purely a psychological thing as the game itself also rewards you with lob points to spend on hiring employees and upgrading existing ones.  the fact that it's so difficult to reach the next day (at least with no casualties) makes you much more invested in the story at least that's what i found as i felt that i had earnt the progression in the story. this is amplified by the fact that some of the things you do and see in the facility have an impact on the story or are tied into it which i won't talk about any further due to potential spoilers.  in terms of gameplay it can get quite tedious later on like day 25+ and it normally requires you to play the game at normal speed due to the sheer amount of abnormalities you have to manage but earlier on you can get away with playing at 2x speed. the gameplay (sort of) loop can get repetitive as i've mentioned but i always found myself coming back and playing again regardless the standard day normally involves you consistently dishing out work to employees to go and do a specific type of work on an abnormality this can be instinct insight attachment and repression though with some abnormalities one of these types of work may be replaced with a special type.  abnormalities respond to certain types of work better than others so this is where information gathering comes into play you need to spend the special p.e boxes you get from working on a particular abnormality to get access to information regarding how well it responds to certain types of work + any other actions the abnormality may take and under what conditions e.g. what happens when it's individual qliphoth counter reaches 0?  if you find that a certain abnormality responds better to instinct work then you would send in an employee with a high level of instinct.  in terms of music it can get very repetitive after an hour of playing so it would probably be better to turn it off at this point though the changes in music give critical information like if a abnormality has escaped containment or not so there's a trade off with this.  overall i greatly enjoy this game the great story and interesting mechanics paired with the fair difficulty of the game keep me coming back to it.

i got this a year or two ago and i played it for a few hours maybe. i‚Äôm a huge fan of management games and horror (in particular scp which this game is unashamedly inspired by). i can‚Äôt remember exactly why i found it so hard to get into but my guess is it was the incomprehensible english translation. so i shelved it as a game that i wanted to like and just couldn‚Äôt.   a few weeks ago the game was entirely retranslated so i reinstalled it. in those two weeks i played something obscene like 50 hours of it. i am so hooked.   don‚Äôt get me wrong the writing still isn‚Äôt anything outstanding but now that the game doesn‚Äôt have an impenetrable fog of truly abysmal localization the gem in there shines through. the game is about managing a prison full of nightmares monsters and anomalous artifacts - it‚Äôs really the ‚Äúscp tycoon‚Äù i had always hoped it was. when you get an abnormality for the first time you‚Äôll have no idea how to manage it and your employees will die - a lot. slowly you‚Äôll earn a series of entries which explain its rules: some abnormalities are simple like it hates a certain kind of work procedure. but some of the rules are fiendishly clever - requiring you to come up with your own real world procedures to stop you from making mistakes (my desk has a few index cards with counters and notes for various containment techniques). by the end of a run you‚Äôll have dozens of creatures all with different demands - one wrong move and you can start a chain reaction of breaches which will end your game.   the structure of the game is really unique as well. it‚Äôs kind of a rogue like in that you are encouraged to start over but with persistent upgrades which make each run easier but there‚Äôs no permadeath you can try any day over. it‚Äôs sort of real time but kind of turn based - explaining what i mean would rob you of the fun of figuring it out but it reminds me of dungeon of the endless. it has the fun xcom feeling of growing attached to your little guys whose humanity is eroded as they work in your facility but they die so frequently you have to get over that. besides it‚Äôs the abnormalities who are the real cast of characters. and even though the writing never grabbed me the plot did start to get compelling. and i just could not stop digging deeper into the earth and growing my prison full of horrors.   the experience is playing wack a mole while memorizing and internalizing an ever growing set of rules to follow. if that sounds stressful well it absolutely is. but it‚Äôs actually really satisfying to throw up your hands and watch your ant farm get devoured by eldritch abominations. and there is so much to discover - this is a huge really generous game which takes a long time to show you everything it has for you. not for everyone but if it sounds like it‚Äôs for you you have to give it a try.

monster management simulator that was inspired by stuff like scp.  goods; 1. story is awesome 2. amazing soundtrack 3. beautiful game 4. hard  bads; 1. hard. sometimes the game can feel unfairly hard  some things to note; 1. the monsters in this game act like puzzles that you will have to bang your head against the wall to solve 2. the restart day button is not a last resort in this game and is more like a 2nd or 3rd in line response 3. did i mention this game can be hard? and i'm not talking yeah it can be hard for some people the game has a set difficulty and the game takes itself seriously and expects you to pull yourself up to its level. i personally don't mind the challenge i think it makes every encounter you overcome worth more but some people might not like the difficulty.  after its re-translation in 2020 the game is a near-perfect state i've heard some people have memory leaks but i have never had a problem with this. the game also now has a sequel that expands on the story but not the gameplay.  if you're on the fence i'd recommend that you just go for it and give yourself a bit of a new experience and challenge. it's seriously a great game.

the lore and unique monsters are the main draw of this. the game gets really creative and keeps introducing things to keep it interesting.  the random events and pseudo random monsters you get can and will straight up force you to reset and maybe even force to abandon an entire run when you get really unlucky. i don¬¥t mind hard games but this is the bad kind of hard.  you straight up take a 1 in 4 guess whenever you encounter a new monster. sometimes nothing bad happens - other times it straight up instakills you which is highly frustrating.  other times you get punished for using a known good way a 2nd time or some other unforseeable b/s.  yes the lore/writing explains these things but usually when this happens you didn¬¥t have those hints unlocked yet. so you just die and have to restart the day. at least that part is somewhat forgiving. you can just do that and then won¬¥t fall into the same trap again. leaves a sour taste in my mouth though. i¬¥m sorry but when i am supposed to metagame from the get go that is just weird design. it is actually intentional that people die and i understand that.  i really dig the general idea of the game and the lore is really the main draw to this. after several frustrating runs i ended up watching some lets play to get an idea what i maybe doing wrong. that somewhat helped with the experience.  having the wiki open negates a lot of the unfair insta kills but that straight up ruins the experience.  the game is a lot like xcom in that regard. you can customize characters and get attached to them only for the game to take them away from you after a while. personally i handle this really poorly and that will most likely result in me dropping the game really fast but that is just me.  the boss fights i saw in the let¬¥s plays later on are really creative and i can see why people like this game. i can tell a lot of love went into this project and the buisness model is straight forward.   didn¬¥t like the equipment management aspect between the days. that was about the worst part for me next to the cheap instakills. don¬¥t want to give a negative review because of the unfun stuff it is not that bad.

interesting games you can play as a scp officer. you need to observe the behavior of the things you have contained. the game mechanism is near to fallout shelter with scp story line.  ps. (wiki) the scp foundation is a fictional organization documented by the web-based collaborative-fiction project of the same name. within the website's fictional setting the scp foundation is responsible for locating and containing individuals entities locations and objects that violate natural law (referred to as scps). the real-world website is community-based and includes elements of many genres such as horror science fiction and urban fantasy.  on the scp foundation wiki the majority of works consist of special containment procedures: structured internal documentation that describes an scp object and the means of keeping it contained. the website also contains thousands of foundation tales short stories set within the universe of the scp foundation. the series has been praised for its ability to convey horror through its scientific and academic writing style as well as for its high standards of quality.   example : scp-055 is something that causes anyone who examines it to forget its various characteristics thus making it indescribable except in terms of what it is not.  cons - it is very hard to micro management your agents when that things go out of the room.

it's a bit arcane but probably by design.  fortunately the stats are color coded so you don't need to memorize that say an employee's justice stat helps them perform repression work.  and they expect you to fuck up repeatedly as every day ends with a redo day button which is a helpful addition even if it hurts to move onto the next day with a couple corpses that you could have maybe avoided but in several attempts have not managed to.  :p  honestly though i'm kind of digging it even though i have some issues with the core gameplay loop - every day you need to perform a certain amount of successful interactions with abnormalities in order to uh produce energy? but certain abnormalities tick down their qliphoth counter towards escaping just by virtue of you interacting with other abnormalities to the point where the stupid little bird has been escaping nearly every day in my current run.  helpfully - or perhaps as another attack on perfectionists - you do have the option of starting the game again with all your current research still completed (if i'm reading the description right) which probably means you can avoid picking certain abnormalities that are significant pains to house (oh right every time a new abnormality is housed at your facility you're given a choice of three with cryptic descriptions) or singularly useless like the one i chose that *always* kills the employee assigned to interact with it meaning to complete the game in it's entirety you'll probably have to make a few goes of it or check out a guide.  still while it's an imperfect game it's definitely trying some fun shit and it's definitely worth checking out just probably best to grab it on sale.  :p

fantastic game that blends fear of the unknown with mastery and discovery. you'll discover an artifact lose some staff trying to learn what it does then reveal its secrets. some you'll mitigate--others you'll learn to take advantage of. and all the while you'll be creating your own rich cast of agents with their own quirks!  the new translation is great! can't recommend this game enough.

fuck this game. great for people who don't like their genitalia and want a nice solid brick wall to slam them against. unfortunately that's me.  edit: i love this game unironically. the writing the art the systems of the game are all beautiful. it is an orchestra of madness and is unafraid to leave you bewildered by your own incompetence. it respects the player's ability to think for themselves and use the tools they have been given to their maximum effectiveness. the learning curve is a little steep but it all pays off. it just sucks that it takes over a hundred hours to fully learn and appreciate everything the game has to offer.

this game is basically scp with waifus and lots of trial and eroor mechanics. but that is not even bad. this game makes so much fun and after some time you kinda forget that this is not an scp game because this is exactly what i was thinking about how the work in the scp-facilty works. but let me explain the game for you because it is not that easy. there will be alot going on at the same time.  in lobotomy corporation you play as the manager and take control of every worker in the facility. your goal is to harvest energy by working with the various paranormal entities which are called abnomalities. this can be done with ease. there are 4 different methods that every worker is capable of: instict insight attachment and repression.  but not all methods are equally good. every abnormality has a preferred method to be worked with. you can read everything at the information screen of the abnormality. but there is the twist. you need to unlock those things little by little with the energy you gain by working with them. so basically you need to let a worker do his work completely blindfolded. you do not know if the chosen method is the best. the abnormalities will behave different depending on their mood after someone worked with it . if you are unlucky you will have a negative result which can cause various things. from losing energy to killing of your workers or an insane worker who is doing mad stuff.   expect to retry the day after messing up. and you will mess up a lot. after you finished your goal for the day you can retry.   once you get used to the basic mechanics of the game you will have alot of fun. every abnormality has its unique and scary design and story behind it. also they are sort by a ranking system telling the player how dangerous the abnormality is.   the game is super fun not only for scp-fans but for every fan of manager games.

since the game has finally gotten it's highly deserved re-translation. i personally highly recommend the game.  edit: i've played the game through 100% now gotten every ending. the story is phenomenal!  the game's difficulty varies depending a lot on your choices but don't be afraid to restart for a new run if this causes the game to be less enjoyable. the game is rogue-lite indeed all your research mission progression and equipment carries through to new runs so don't be afraid of losing much when you do inevitably have to restart to progress further into the game.   there's very few things that are completely rng-based in my experience making it much more skill and strategy based.  generally i find the game to be fun in all regards especially when it comes to simply goofing around seeing how long you last when you release all your monsters.

i really like this game it reminds me of the scp fandom. it can be hard from time to time its a game that you need to play over and over again to get good at don't be afraid to abandon a run if you have to or just go back a couple of days to pick different  creatures. but if your worried about your progress no worries it saves so long as you finish the day i highly recommend this game.

1 hour in i was wanting to throw in the towel due to how creepy and difficult the game was. despite that deep down i felt like i was lying to myself and went back to play more. soon enough i got over my fears and surprisingly became a huge fan of this scp management theme where we send employees to work studying and trying to contain these abnormalities (while harvesting energy from them). i became unusually addicted to this indie game to the point where i eventually achieved 100% completion a couple days ago after so many hours.  only things that were rough was: - farming for ego and your employee stats could be a bit tedious (not too bad for me since i would usually be doing other things while playing the game). - that one bug that really annoyed me where an employee would become permanently out of control then when you end the day...they would usually instantly die.  other than that i adore this game a ton. if anyone wants to try it they truly should but just know it might be frustrating/challenging in the beginning depending on what abnormality you get. you totally will have to restart all the way to the 1st day later on (a couple times at most) but you keep everything you worked for so it is all uphill. but the most important thing is you really should try to keep people alive in the early run because if they die they can lose that superior gear you worked for until you actually get the better upgrades in the future. but don't sweat it too much you probably get enough to re-acquire the lost goods.  personally i would give this game an 8.5/10 mainly due to still persisting bugs but the game play and challenge is great the art style is lovable the music is absolutely astonishing and the story is pretty rich. it is quite a unique game and very captivating. this game will always have a place in my heart and i look forward to their sequel in the works as well.  updated: slightly changed overall rating and edited out gripes with translations with the complete english re-translation of the game as of may 4th 2020.

do you like supernatural entities? are you a fan of scp foundation lore and/or games but wish you had a game based more on managing these monstrosities? do you enjoy learning from failure and dealing with what can become hectic yet exciting gameplay? then lobotomy corporation should peak your interest.  you are the new manager of lobotomy corporation and you are responsible for utilizing various abnormalities of ranging levels of danger and complication in a newfound attempt to generate energy for a society whose energy needs have skyrocketed compared to what we know today. all the while you learn slowly about the history and origins of the company along with the features gimmicks and dangers of the abnormalities that you slowly add to the facility one-to-two at a time.  you also have to deal with the sephirahs who are basically your assistant managers of each respective department in the facility. command team training team security team information team et cetera. they each have their own personalities and stories which you learn by completing their challenges that range from easy peezy to go fuck yourself! you want me to do what!?  the game is challenging. you will retry things and the game encourages this. the game plays day-by-day and restarting from the beginning of the current day is free (sans resetting the progress you made). that means that while you will still have to unlock the details and entries for new abnormalities again (which you'll want to do as they provide bonuses and allow you to unlock an abnormalities' unique equipment) you will restart a day with the internal knowledge of the new abnormalities weaknesses what they hate how they like their tea and so on. this means that you won't accidentally kill your first worker who you send there by picking the wrong thing and giving them oolong tea when they absolutely fucking demand black tea or so help me i will burn your children!  on top of this the game has two soft-reset functions. first is the hard way; you can reset from day 1. in doing so you keep all entries you've gained and all equipment you've unlocked. however you lose all of your characters and their levels (who you can re-hire if you're attached) and you start from scratch in choosing the abnormalities to add each day. depending on if you got some abnormalities that aren't exactly chill with each other (red hooded nerd and the maybe big bad somehow doggo for example) this may be a blessing but if you've gotten a good set of easy-to-handle abnormalities then this may not be a good idea.  so then you choose the second soft-reset; you just got a really bad abnormality that ruins the nice balance you just got and you've already gotten all of its information? well every few in-game days you get a memory imprint which allows you to reset to that day instead of going all the way back to day 1. the same things apply; you keep info and equipment. you also lose any employees hired in the time between the current day and the imprint day. but you can fix mild issues or prolong a run to get more info on new abnormalities.  combat in the game can actually be quite intricate and interesting. the game is set on multiple floors with elevators to quickly traverse up and down. many abilities (both yours and abnormalities) can effect entire departments entire floors or an entire row or column of the facility. direction you enter a combat scenario from can be the difference between death and victory. you have to think and learn and it's actually sometimes a good idea to let abnormalities run rampant so you learn how to avoid them doing that the next time. it's ingenious in its simplicity.  music is fantastic and varied and tells the mood very well. the art style is cute but easy to read. i absolutely recommend the soundtrack.  in conclusion i absolutely recommend lobotomy corporation but with the following caveat: at the time of this review the english translation is dodgy. this stems from circumstances out of the developer's control (basically they got screwed over by the company who was supposed to be responsible for the english translation) but nonetheless the game does have translation issues which in rare circumstances can actually lead to telling players things that are objectively false when it comes to gameplay.  for example characters in game can have stats leveled 1 - 5. something might say characters with at least 3 of x will be killed while actually meaning more than x so a 1-stat difference that you thought was safe kills one of your better employees and forces you to retry for a reason that isn't because of your own negligence but rather because of exactly the opposite. this is rare but it sucks. just keep it in mind. if you are frustrated with an abnormality use the wiki and find out how to deal with it. there's no harm in it. some of them are frustrating to learn for a lot of people even though it does give you an idea of how to solve it (i'm looking at you schadenfreude!)  if you want to watch some gameplay and hilarity i have 17+ videos of the game on my channel at this time (mostly sh**posts). https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plr4eb3p42g8f0ll4thrsdej9umaggrfmc check it out or don't.

lobotomy corporation starts as a fairly easy management game. while proceeding trough the story the facility will keep growing and you will get abnormalities(monsters) that you have to keep under control. these abnormalities rapidly spike the difficulty of the game by clashing with each other having different skills or conditions that you need to fulfill if you don't want them to escape kill employees or even worse consequences.  lobotomy corporation story is similar to visual novels and adventure games where you have different dialogue options and different endings that depend on certain events. all the main characters have unique designs for each and every one  of them they are likable and interesting in their own way. the abnormalities also have unique designs that come from different types of monsters from various mythos and they all have their own story that you can discover if you research on them enough.  the story is really rich and interesting with some casual moments of your co-workers talking to each other about themselves or stuff happening in the world/facility. the game can be pretty grindy or hard at times specially if you want to achieve all the endings or complete the codex. the art can be a hit or miss depending on who you are but the original soundtrack and the fx sounds are great and completely sell the atmosphere and setting that you'll love if you enjoy things like psychological horror creepypasta/horror stories the scp foundation or movies like cabin in the woods

a novel approach to creating a scp style game lobotomy corporation does a better job of simulation the process of learning and containing these mysterious creatures than any of the official scp projects i've seen to date. while the basic mechanics are relatively simple the layers of complexity that the various abnormalities add results in an interesting and difficult management sim with a lot of spirit. there are definitely some issues i had during my time with it: even after multiple updates the translation is pretty rough (particularly in the lategame scenes) a lot of the ui isn't as intuitive as i would prefer and going for the true ending involves a heavy amount of mindless repetition as you grind out the abnormalities you're missing and prepare for the endgame run. but even with these in mind lobotomy corp is a game worth experiencing for anyone interested in management sims and scp style of horror and storytelling.

extremely fun management sim. if you like monsters creatures and doing testing to discover what makes things tic this is a game for you. my only real complaint is that the game can be unforgiving for tiny mistakes which can lead to resetting a day of work (and the days can be long) but the game does allow you to reset your progress while keeping a lot of your earned bonuses making it easier the second time. even despite this frustrating i've found myself pressing further and further just to find out what happens next and what weird new thing i'll have to deal with.

i recommend this game if you like management simulators like sims or fallout shelter and like scp. this game may not be for everyone. sometimes your employees will die. sometimes you will fail. sometimes you will need to start from day 1 - but don't let that discourage you. starting over is not a complete restart - it saves all of your research your progress and most importantly the items you've created. this game is hard it isn't perfect but it's definitely enjoyable in my experience.  feel free to ask me questions on the game i will answer.

i've only played this game for a few hours and i'm in love with it. the game centers around risk management and this part of the game is handled really well basically the first game i've played were i am constantly weighing the risk and benefits while keeping the quota of the day in mind and my own self-set goals. the game also has a lot of interesting lore and character development. there's also a lot of mods for this game on top of it's normal replay value. there are a few things keeping this game downthe main complaint i hear is about stability issues but i haven't had any problems with this and i'm willing to bet most of it is because of mods. there are also some quality of life issues like the fact that you have to unlock being able to see your employees health and have to go to a different menu for a wile this isn't the biggest issue because seeing employee health doesn't become important till later anyway but this is just one of a few ui improvements that could be made you can fix most of these problems with mods but again stability issues. i have more to say but this review is getting long so i'll just say to summarize this is a really fun management game and you should definitely buy it if you like that kind of game.

my first impression when i played this game for a couple of hours was: holy shit how are these guys so creative with their abnormalities? how can there be this many beings with such different behaviors? typical monsters from rpgs even bosses can't compare to them in the least. i am used to monsters that may look different and have different strengths and weaknesses but can ultimately be clobbered with the right type of attack. with lobotomy corporation's abnormalities there are so many more things to remember. i did not think this was possible. it's so creative!  i haven't gotten past day 21 yet but i can already tell that the trailer gives away only a fraction of what you can expect from the game even if you pause the trailer every few seconds to get a better look at what's happening.  i restarted my first run of the game at day 21 because i made a couple of big mistakes along the way and i was pretty much limping through the last few days. but i regret nothing as everything was part of a wonderfully horrible angsty desperate experience. and the creators must know that because they let you keep your research and items even if you go back to day 1 so it's not a balancing bug it's an intentional feature that you can easily mess up so badly that you have to restart eventually. i consider myself an experienced gamer but i was too engrossed in all the things you could explore to see the red flags in time. and yes i used the word engrossed on purpose. :-) a small down-side is that the side-quests don't get reset so you won't get to see the corresponding sequences again but having all that wonderful research from the get-go is nice too.  and on that note: if you consider playing this game i gotta warn you to get into the right mindset beforehand. i mean: things going horribly wrong again and again is part of the experience. if you never messed up anything this game would be a simple and boring type of tycoon game. so don't get frustrated when you have to replay levels multiple times or when you have to go back even further. you are a manager of a ruthless company which doesn't care for the lives of its employees and which messes with forces they should've killed or left alone instead so you should expect getting punished harder and harder for pushing on.  also don't play the game for 12 hours straight or you will have nightmares about it. ;-)  and as a final note: i think i did get lucky with my first batch of abnormalities. on my second run i chose different ones on purpose and had to restart on day 3 so don't worry if that happens to you as well. the abnormalities i had on day 3 were: [spoiler]punishing bird and 1.76 mhz. and with level i employees this is so bad. on my first run those compartments contained the fairies and the well-cheers one and those are so pleasant to work with. they hardly ever killed any of my people. yes i actually managed to get one killed by the fairies accidentally. t_t ever since then i decided to click-drag on the employee first to assign him/her to the fairies instead of the other way round to avoid picking the wrong one in the heat of the moment.[/spoiler]
i liked the scp theme. the game was complicated (intentionally to fit with that theme). i didn't end up getting far enough into the game to see how it became a rogue-like though.

a fun and yet very challenging game. i never get bored of it and often play it in my offline time. if you want to play a challenging micromanaging game that gives you as much interest as scp related media then this is probably your game. i've been following it since it first entered early access and i have to say it is one of the only early access games i've loved this much after completion. to boot with it's challenging nature the story is also relatively interesting.

i absolutly love it. 10/10 would recommend to someone who craves action on a managment game. a lot of detail easter eggs special synergies with abnormalities a lot of replay potential in fact even needed sometimes. if you like to manage a team and also have a lot of action you will enjoy this game a lot. and the plot thickens... also remember. we don't talk about hod suppression core.

harvest energy from monsters with dubiously-ethical science. learn about new critters so they'll stop breaking out. kill clerks by the dozens so the corpse mountain can't smell them bleed. augment your agents until they're unstoppable forces of nature. forget you left someone in a cursed bunker until half your facility has breached. read the manual. travel back in time to escape your mistakes. confess your sins to a floating jesus skull. meet again as stars.  an amazing game with an excellent lineup of creatures to research and contain a very strong sense of tone and atmosphere enjoyable core gameplay and a really intriguing story with a lot of deep lore to uncover. the early game is rather simple but things quickly develop until you have a fascinating mishmash of monsters whose management conditions you all need to keep in mind and challenges later on will really test your skill as a manager.  now the gameplay itself is fun but where i think lobotomy corporation really shines is in its story - you wouldn't expect much of a narrative from most management/simulation games and its slow start here might make you think lc is the same way but the story is what takes what would otherwise be a neat scp-esque monster containment game and turns it into a masterpiece. i don't want to spoil anything but there's a lot more going on in l corp than morally dubious energy corporation and there are a lot of mysteries and twists you'll uncover along the way. the worldbuilding is also quite intriguing - you may never leave the facility (not until the sequel at any rate) but the writing does a really good job at painting a picture of the world outside and why things in the facility are the way they are.  the soundtrack also slaps. i don't have anything eloquent to say here it's just some real bangers that are great fits for the scenes/days they play in.  probably the best game i played in 2019 and the sequel has so far proven to be a worthy successor. cannot recommend this highly enough if you're a fan of management games or story-driven rpgs. goes on sale fairly often if you're unsure about buying it full price. the early days are a sort of soft tutorial if you're not sure about the game at first i really advise trying to get to at least day 21 or so that's around when things really get going.  if you're thinking of picking this up here's some spoiler-free advice: - read the manual! i'm not joking it tells you almost everything you'll need. - you don't have to end the day immediately as soon as it lets you and it's often beneficial to continue working to train stats and get more gear. just watch out for ordeals. - buy the managerial tips first. usually. - read everything! the floating white flavor text that appears above an abnormality during work can offer useful hints. - don't be afraid to retry the day if something goes wrong.  - try to avoid the wiki - learning things for yourself is part of the fun!  good luck manager!
yes

lobotomy corporation is a 2d management game. you are responsible for managing the supernatural entities sent to your facilities and the employees you hired each day. when it comes to how difficult the level of management can be it depends on how you approach it. there are no constant timers to worry about so you can choose and pick which room to send your employees in for research at your own pace. it's very forgiving even to the point of providing a retry option to reset the day. the only way you can lose progress is if you start a new game from day 1. however you keep all research you've made on the supernatural entities from all your previous runs. as for the research there are four-five main sections for each entity you research. the more sections you complete the more of the entity's story/lore is revealed.  there is a story in this game. naturally it slowly reveals itself after each completion of each day. i've not gotten very far in the story but it gives off a mystery sort of vibe. you are a newcomer to this facility and there have been previous administrators before you. angela the main ai of the facility will converse with you each day. occasionally you'll be given options to choose in order to respond to her questions. there are other characters who will do the same. the only flaw about this is the translation or at least the english. this game was developed in korea (even the default language will start in korean) so some sentences may seem odd to read. overall though the game is quite good with a lot of replay value due to having a choice of what new entity you can accept each day. no two runs are alike.

one of the best management games out there. pretty much every day you need to learn something new and just keep expanding on it until suddenly you have a facility filled with creatures that you know everything about from doing work on it to suppressing it. the game is a wild ride and even the story is pretty intense even though it can be a bit confusing at first. one thing to note is that things will get difficult. if you pick the wrong abnormality or don't prepare for the right challenge you can get steamrolled but don't worry. any of the upgrades and ego you unlock from your run will carry over to the next one (but you will lose gear if the employee dies wearing it). i got invested to the point i wanted to complete the game and my hours are exactly how long it took me to research every abno and complete all the challenges.   you can always ask for help or look stuff up but i highly recommend playing blind. if you are a fan of scp and like management sims then this game will definitely be worth it and there is definitely a lot of action to keep you entertained while managing abnormalities. lobotomy corp brings a lot of uniqueness for each abno which a lot of management sims fail to do you actually feel like you need to handle things differently in order to maintain order. that being said some lower tier abnos can get steamrolled once you get higher tier items but that is understandable.  if i had to give this game some cons i will say it starts off slow. this is of course so you can learn the fundamentals and gradually gain more and more info as things get harder but you won't be doing too much exciting stuff the first few days. if you run the game for too long it gets some pretty bad memory leak. when i was in the late game after an intense day i would restart the game to make sure i wouldn't crash during the next day. this won't really be a problem unless you have been playing the game for a few hours in a row. my final issue is there are no achievements. i love getting all the achievements on games i enjoy. when i picked this game up i was just expected a single playthrough but i loved the game so much i went for full completion anyway.   tldr: read the manual!

i bought this game because i was like yo it's basically scp fallout shelter!. i mean i wasn't exactly wrong by saying that. it's allot more complex with a very interesting mechanic that makes it so every time you play and depending how far you make it the small story elements change along with dialogue and interactions you have with the higher ups in the company. now don't get me wrong games like fallout shelter feel very repetitive which usually result in the player dropping out and losing interest over time because it's meant to be a ongoing thing of progression. this game on the other hand encourages you to keep repeating learning and improving your decision skills as a manager in the game while changing things up along the way (by choosing what abnormalities you have characters and stat division). but enough about mechanics and shit lets hop in that juice: the art style is very nice! along with the soundtrack! woo boy! that menu theme smacks along with the very distinct color pallet of the game is fantastic!  so yeah cool scp management fallout shelter anime the game! 9/10 (i would give it 10/10 but when i first started it took me allot of time to wrap my mind about certain key elements of the game such as sanity and such. but seriously a fantastic game all around.)
