so with 1000+ hours under my belt i can finally say what my opinion is of this game and... well... oh my god i love it! this is one of the best games i've ever played and it's become my favorite game of all time! i'll list a few things a like and dislike about the game below.  what i liked about it: great challenge - the challenge was great and i love replaying it over and over again. fantastic story - the story really interested me and i loved every bit of it. i also love how you can replay story segments! amazing characters - the characters are really unique and stand out (i'm not talking about the abnormalities by the way) and add to the story in a way i never thought they could do. unique monsters - ok look- the abnormalities are my favorite part of this game! there all so unique and none of them felt similar to each other! outstanding graphics - the graphics are amazing! some of the best looking graphics i've seen in a indie game! and i didn't even know the game was made in unity until someone said so! it looks better then unity graphics and is very charming.  but there are some things i didn't like about it.  things i didn't like (spoilers below): difficulty - i like the difficulty but for new players it can be quite challenging. trust me most skip the tutorial and don't even know the manual exists! but this is a minor pick. day 45-49 - ok so the difficulty starts to rise when you get to day 45. starting with giving you a new ordeal. now i like the idea you where going for but these days are a pain! they are way to difficult and even with all max level employees it's still hard and requires a good amount of luck day 49 in particular is one of the most unfair things i've played. speaking of luck. luck - you need to be lucky if you want to beat this game. from getting abnormalities to getting ordeals. you could get nothing above waw level or you can get every single aleph in the game. and the ordeals. some of them are fine. green is fine and amber is fine. but problems happen when crimson and violet show up. so i'll talk about them below. crimson ordeals - i do not like the crimson ordeals unlike the other two dawns and noon's. you can not ignore it when you get later in the game with about 50+ employees and 30+ level 5's. dawn of crimson lowers the qliphoth counter of abnormalities which is fine. but did they really need to explode when they die? they do way to much damage this way. oh and also the dusk of crimson is really annoying. violet ordeals - so violet is the same as crimson but instead it lowers the qliphoth counters of all abnormalities in the department it's in if not killed fast enough. this requires you to stop what your doing and then deal with these. the violet noon punishes new players and i think that's unfair. but. well. the violet midnight is the worst ordeal over. i'd say it's harder then the claw. and the claw is the midnight of the white ordeals and it's supposed to be the hardest ordeal. (sorry for ranting so long in this review i'll shut up now-)  over all i love this game for what it is and i would 100% recommend it! it's a amazing game that deserves more love. so to any one out there reading this review go play this game! all the things i didn't like about the game are just little things i noticed and don't break the game. in fact if you like challenge then play this game! it's one of the greatest games of all time! project moon keep doing your best! and i can't wait to see what your next game has to offer!

a truly maddening game. it starts out deceptively easy with you and your employees tasked to caring for a series of increasingly bizarre otherwordly abberations sealed away in containment cells. you have to interact with them each day - but each creature has particular rules about how your and your employees interact with them. break the rules and someone is probably going to die. but the rules are almost always very simple once you figure them out they're just different for each one - so no problem. until you have 40 employees running around and 25 of these abominations caged in the later stages of the game and an alert has you interacting with 12 of them at once and you forget one of the rules and set of a chain reaction of cascading terror and chaos in your complex and a few minutes later the walls of the entire place are bathed in blood and you're reaching for the 'reset day' button for the 6th time in a row...  ...and that's when you realize that one of the newest aleph class horrors from the abyss has reached back in time to alter your save game. (not kidding)  so yeah. it's that kind of game. micro-management to the nth degree wrapped around all kinds of stranger things style horror and government/corporate conspiracies with cute little chibi people dying horrible deaths due entirely to your own incompetence. it's pretty awesome if teeth gnashingly frustrating at times.

you ever wanted to run the scp foundation? well now you can with all the grisly death that comes along with it.  that being said this game is hard. on my first playthrough i had to restart more times than i can count on two hands at only day three.  this game is not for everyone.  if that sounds like your cup of tea and you can put up with the heat then this is the game for you.

the game while having a not great translation is extremely deep and is very complicated (which is a good thing!). i highly encourage playing blind and not looking at the wiki unless absolutely needed as the game gets a whole extra layer of suspense if you don't know about the abnormality you are working with. word to the wise i got where i've done 4 boss fights at 55 hours of play time because i looked almost everything up which ruined a lot of the surprise the game had and thus made the experience worse but shorter. here's the part where i tell you a few things the game doesn't. every stat is linked to their own work (i.e. fortitude is linked to instinct work and so on and so forth) meaning to level up a stat you have to perform that work with that employee. another thing it doesn't explain well is the panic mechanics. when an employee panics they will go into one of four panic responses depending on their highest stat. ones with fortitude will try to harm others with their ego weapon equipped ones with prudence will stand still for a little while then commit suicide ones with temperance will run around screaming dealing minor white damage to everyone in the room and the ones with justice will make abnormality's escape. the last thing you should know is the leveling mechanic vs abnormality's. lets say we make an employee (level ii) go into the containment room of a he level abnormality (level iii). the employee will get a sign above their heads that says nervous with one explanation point. the employee will then take white damage before even starting the work. this level vs level system works in tiers with aleph abnormality's being level v waw being level iv and so on and so forth. the lesser leveled your employee is to the abnormality the higher the white damage dealt to them (except in cases where it is stated otherwise in the managerial tips section like with censored). this also goes into effect when an employee runs into an escaped abnormality so keep this in mind and don't send under-leveled employees into higher leveled abnormality's rooms!

the tutorial is actually a really bad introduction to the game but it does help you get to grips with the very basics. the fundamentals of the game aren't complicated but the game manages to slowly introduce elements in a way that doesn't overwhelm the player. pretty solid design but you have to push through those first 30 minutes.  the anomalies are pretty interesting and creative definitely recommend it just for the crazier stuff that appears in the higher tiers.

it's a game that requires a lot of patience you'll probably try ending days early when you first try it i suggest that don't end days early unless you're in mid-late game. the story is simple and can be understood by your average human. day 1-15 (early-game) focus on leveling up your employees a lot since the days above this bracket are gonna get more tedious each day.  day 16-35 (mid-game) you'll be getting your alephs around this bracket learn the weaknesses and strengths of each abnormality from he - aleph also do core suppression this early if possible.  day 36-45 (late-game) you'll be encountering more powerful sephiras that can change the balance of the game and give you perks once you have done their missions and core suppression.  day 46-50 (end-game) these days will determine the endings that you will get on the game also everything that you have learned during core suppression will be useful during these days.  summary: perfectly cut screams it's rewind time sacrificing i class agents to be continued micromanaging intensifies.

this recommendation comes with a lot of caveats. now i love the game i think the story is amazing and the characters are great. if you love horror with a little comedy or comedy with a little horror this game hits the spot but...  the caveats: 1) the end of the game ramps up the difficulty by magnitudes. if you're not prepared for the grind or for all the attempts lost to rng or looking away from a critical portion of the facility for a second this may not be the game for you. there are guides for the harder bosses out there on the internet but it can take some searching to find them (i recommend the game reddit for strategies if you need them). and if you're stuck on binah's fight for two months like i was: [spoiler] use the backwards clock once her phase 2 starts. [/spoiler]  2) the translation is rough. the gist of it is there and sometimes there's some clever plays on words but the translator is obviously not a native english speaker. it's better than google translate but be prepared for odd phrasing and typos. for the most part i had no problems but the more surreal the plot and the more metaphysical the topic of discussion the harder the script is to parse.  3) it's long mostly as a result of the difficulty. i got through it by pecking at it slowly over a long period of time but if you want to just play the game and move on to the next one in your library i can't recommend it.  but if those caveats don't deter you and you stick through to the end the emotional payoff is worth it. it's just not a game for everyone.  edit 9/16/2020: the english translation has been entirely reworked since i posted this review originally and is much much better. it is no longer an issue with the game.

murphy's law is a popular adage that states that things will go wrong in any given situation if you give them a chance or more commonly whatever can go wrong will go wrong.  add a little of the butterfly effect and you've got this game.  this is an scp-inspired game which manages to screw you over far more than help you yet still somehow engages you with it's charm. fun looking yet intimidating creatures waifus (myo is best girl.) and fun characters and a quite disturbing stories which support eachother are what make this game. you can make your own waifus too in the shape of employees (even if it costs you a bit more.) but the employees can also die permanently and if your favorite dies you can expect a reset.  i really can recommend this game if you can stand having to reset the same level a bunch of times before you finally manage to beat it just to get the satisfaction of finally surpassing that awful day and seeing your employees grow both ingame and on you.  and my prayers were heard it got retranslated!

by far the simultaneously worst and best day in my hours of playing went like this:  a certain magical abnormality escapes and massacres a large amount of clerks and heavily wounding majority of my employees. this unfortunately upsets a deceptively helpful and 'harmless' abnormality. more dead clerks everywhere. the deaths of so many helpless innocents distresses a certain bird and now he too is rampaging around my facility. i think it cannot possibly get worse but oh it does. with all these bodies around another abnormality escapes and starts chomping down on the endless corpse buffet. i was seconds away from giving up and restarting the day because this was absurd and surely impossible to deal with. out of a morbid sense of curiosity i decided to keep going and just see how far i could get before my *actual* employees began dropping like flies.   the magical abnormality finally goes down but that's only the beginning. everyone jumps into the elevators and the corpse eater gets beaten to a pulp in no time. the bird is surprise greeted by a mob of 30+ people and curb stomped to oblivion. now there's only one problem left. the deceptive 'harmless' one likes to self-destruct for fun. it'll likely one-shot or severely injure most employees on top of another fun side-effect it has. it also isn't alone. there's several of them. one goes down no problem second one likely exploded off-screen while i was busy and the third one... the third one explodes  a fraction of the second before all my employees in the entire facility went in. because of the way i moved my employees they suddenly canceled their movements and doubled back. also to take advantage of the opportunity i purposely set off another extremely difficult one to clear a mission. not a single employee of mine died.   in short: lobotomy corp is not easy. it's stressful and can be overwhelming. sometimes you'll be screwed constantly by one particularly troublesome abnormality. i've come so close to the end only to have to start from the beginning again simply because it was too difficult. but you can have absolutely everything go wrong in a day and still make it through somehow. perseverance is key.

this is the scp management game that never got made and it is exactly what you would expect. you have all your subjects each with different needs and risks being managed by your trusty (and semi-disposable) force of agents who must increase in both number and skill in order to keep pace with the growing number and power of monsters. what makes the game so interesting is the complexity you always have something that needs your attention from the time of day to the effects your agents have on them. failure to notice something as small as a particle effect on an agent may result in them being instakilled. if this sounds harsh it's because it is the ease with which even your most powerful agent can die is part of the feeling of supernatural-zookeeping that makes this so rewarding. the one thing that i will say is not in some way redeemable is the translation into english some dialogue is perfectly fine but then you run into some issues that may vary from a single misspelling to a literal translation from korean that takes a few seconds to process. apart from the translation issues which don't really impact anything other than your immersion the game is a niche masterpiece that will give you one of the most fulfilling experiences in gaming.

undeniably the best scp game out there. whenever you think you've seen the craziest specimen the game has to offer it throws another abomination at you which you'd never have thought of.  graphics are pretty yet simple enough to quickly know what exactly is in front of you. story is altough sometimes weirdly translated at times quite unique and involving. music is definitely one of the strong point of the game. while you'll be hearing the calm theme most of the time basically any other music is a banger that sets the atmosphere perfectly. honestly the only thing this game is truly lacking is more advertisement. it's beyond me how nobody talked about how good the game was when it came out.  but the best part is definitely the specimens you'll have to research in the game. all of them are unique. and i dont just mean that they have different stats. all of them have very different behaviors and ways to ruin your day. which makes the process of researching them never boring. and also never truly safe.
if you get past often broken english this game is amazing. a perfect management sim for me at least. just realize that people will die. a lot. often ones you worked on for hours.

guide on how to get best ending in lobotomy corporation:  step 1: on the abnormality selection screen look out for an abnormality with the description i shall heal you curing you of all disease and injury you possess. and pick it. it's up to chance on whether or not it will show up so it might take a while.  step 2: send in one of your best employees to work with the abnormality until they are blessed. you'll know it worked when it shows a short cutscene of that employee's name appearing on a clock.  step 3: repeat step 2 until 12 employees are blessed.  if you have done all of these steps correctly you should have reached the best ending. make sure to bless your best employees to get the best possible ending.

this game is best described as an scp-like management simulator where if it can go wrong it will go horribly wrong. in fact it is a game that is quite unique but also has one of by far the most fucked up stories i have ever seen in a management simulator. warning the game from what i know starts up in korean so youll have to fiddle with menu's to get it to a language you know be it english french or so on. it can also be really weird and difficult if you have 0 idea on what to do so that tutorial isnt just a click this to learn jack shit hurr hurr! no that thing teaches you what to do and what to avoid this game is wild dark crazy psychologically horrifying and lots of fun.

have depression? obsessive completionist tendencies? have a penchant for managing an ever growing facility that does research on things that shouldn't exist? the ability to fall in love with randomized characters before making them suffer gruesome horrible fates?  and... have you ever wanted to be the one that orders those poor [strike]d-class saps[/strike] employees to perform work on [strike]scp's[/strike] abnormalities?  then this may be the lobotomy for you! [i](actual surgical procedure not included)[/i]  this game is essentially an scp management simulator where you do research on varying abnormalities in order to gain an understanding of them. in an rpg style manner you hire employees and order them to perform one of four kind of works on said abnormalities. while this may sound simplistic in design it is anything back with additional layers of complexity being added in as you progress through the game.   like all games this has its good points and its flaws. do i feel that the good outweighs the bad? [b]absolutely[/b]  [b]pros?[/b] -it has an engaging interesting story on top of being lore rich with every abnormality having its own story.  -rogue-like mechanics so that even when you hit a point of needing to restart you keep your progress and research levels from each previous playthrough.  -the translation can be spotty at times yet oddly endearing in its flaws. do you want expand department??? -hours upon hours of management fun!  [b]cons?[/b] -if reading-heavy games aren't your thing this is probably gonna be a drag. -just as it's a pro the english translation can also be quite bad. at best endearing however at worst it can be misleading and impossible to understand requiring additional research through practical means or by checking the wiki to be done. -there are certain mechanics and concepts that aren't explained well. while this is a management game so you need to learn by trial and error those that are less patient may find themselves struggling and getting easily frustrated by things they don't understand.   i suppose the most important thing to me for enjoying this game is that you need to go into this with a curious inquisitive mind. if you're someone that wants action and adventure or thinks that research is best summarised in a quick manner in order to get straight to the action you may not really enjoy this.   however if you're someone that loves to tinker and experiment to figure things out and overcome challenge after challenge with some grinding along the way. who enjoys in learning the intricacies of a game (while also possibly being obsessive compulsive in your need to know everything) then this may very well be a game that brings you hours upon hours of enjoyment.  take your time have fun. face the future and build the fear.  [strike]...wait[/strike]

alright since this game has gone on sale i feel extremely obligated to write a review for what is now possibly my favourite game even if i'm not versed in making reviews. lobotomy corporation is a monster management simulation and rougelite game. you're the manager of a facility of abnormalities creatures that are strange and must be discovered about by your employees. think of this as scp but with you being the manager of employees who act as d-class scientists and mtf all in one!  the good: the game has many different abnormalities all with their own special abilities. many of these abnormalities can benefit the facility such as one abnormality that heals employees that work on it. sounds great right? it is! but it has a downside: working on something while they're being healed by it's effect will lead to them dying immediately. a trade off you need to remember for a nice benefit. many abnormalities have similar effects that do different things! and managing later parts of the game can feel amazing once everyone is strong enough to deal with anything.your workers can basically become abnormalities at a certain point and it feels good getting them there.  not too long ago the game had a great translation revamp. a lot of negative and even positive reviews mention how spotty the old translation was and it was due to a shady translation team taking the money... or so i heard. whatever the reason a group of fans re-translated the game completely and everything reads much better now!  because i've seen more than one negative review of the looks of the old game i feel it needs to be stated. the game has had a visual revamp at some point and looks far far better now. i don't think it looked awful before but the game definitely looks and feels much better than it did before. some abnormalities got complete visual overhauls that look and feel much better and some stayed the same or got minor touches to look better and it's very noticeable when looking at legacy art.  the bad: the game is rather poorly optimized. i won't fault project moon completely they were an indie dev team and it's honestly amazing they got the game this well done. but a big issue is long sessions causing memory leaks and crashes. this problem is a lot more noticeable if you're on an older system. it's really unfortunate that it happens but playing in shorter bursts can help mitigate this!  another bad thing about the game is just how simply grindy it as. you need to send employees to work on abnormalities to gain stats as for myself i don't mind the gameplay loop or grinding because i like the feeling of finally getting my employees powerful enough to deal with high-level threats however i understand how boring and not fun grinding can be for people. it also really sucks when you have a lapse of judgement or just plain mess up and lose an employee on grind days and can suck the fun out of doing so.  conclusion: all in all for lobotomy corporation's faults i think it's a wonderful game. the story is engaging the characters are wonderful and the gameplay is fun if not a bit repetitive in your 3rd or 4th playthrough. that being said it is extremely replayable. i recommend this game to anyone who enjoys management sims scp or lore rich games. i wouldn't have over 120 hours in the game if it wasn't something enjoyable to play and experience.

one of the most creative and challenging games i have ever played. it begins as a comfy management game that you can play at your own pace but as you progress the game begins to feel like an rts game with the type of stressful situations it puts you in. if you're willing to accept the high difficulty unique gameplay and somewhat jank english translation you'll have an amazing time with this game.  also make sure you have a somewhat decent processor or you'll experience low performance during the later parts of the game.

[h1]mÃ∏ÃîÃûaÃµÕòÕìsÃµÕäÕâsÃµÕÑÃ® Ã∑ÃÄÃûsÃµÃãÃ¶yÃ∏ÃáÃüsÃµÃàÕötÃ∂ÃΩÃ≥eÃ¥ÃäÃümÃ∏ÕõÃ≤ ÃµÕêÃ†fÃ∂ÃâÃπaÃ¥ÕÇÕÖiÃµÕêÕçlÃ∂ÕäÕçuÃ∑ÃíÃ∫rÃ∏ÕÑÃÆeÃ∑ÃêÕö.ÃµÃåÃ≠ Ã∂ÃäÃó Ã∂ÕóÕécÃ∑ÃÄÃªaÃ¥ÕêÃ•sÃ¥ÃÑÃüuÃ∑ÃÑÕÖaÃµÕÄÃ©lÃµÕùÕçtÃ∑Õ†ÕéiÃ∂ÃøÕáeÃ¥ÕäÃ†sÃ¥ÃÄÕÖ:ÃµÃäÕô Ã¥ÕíÕÖ1Ã∏ÃåÃß8Ã¥ÃêÃ©.Ã¥ÕåÃ≠ Ã∑ÃöÃ† Ã∑ÕÉÃ•aÃ∏ÃÅÕábÃ∂ÃâÕánÃ¥ÃÉÃ≤oÃ∏ÃàÕörÃµÃèÃñmÃ¥Õ†Ã°aÃ∏ÕêÃ≤lÃ∑ÃΩÃñiÃµÃÖÃ¨tÃ∂ÃãÃóiÃ∂ÕÄÃ©eÃ∏ÃÇÃºsÃ¥ÃõÕî:Ã¥ÕÉÕú ÃµÃÉÕéuÃ∏ÕÜÃònÃµÃçÃ∞sÃ∂ÃÜÕÖuÃ¥ÃöÃ∫pÃ¥ÕÜÃ•eÃ∑ÃïÃûrÃ∑ÕÇÕïvÃ∂ÃÄÃ£iÃ∂ÃàÃ™sÃ∑ÃïÃ≠eÃ∏ÕêÕîdÃµÃéÃû.Ã∑ÃîÕé Ã∏ÃÉÃ∞tÃµÕÄÃ≠hÃ∏ÃõÃ≥rÃ∑ÕÇÃ≠eÃ∑ÃêÕéaÃ∑ÃíÕátÃ∂ÕãÕç:Ã∏ÃäÃ´ Ã∏ÃêÕîtÃµÃÄÃ∞hÃµÃÉÃúiÃ¥ÃÑÕârÃ∏ÃÇÃ§dÃ∏ÕùÕÖ Ã¥ÕõÕàtÃ∂Õ†Ã∞rÃµÕùÃ™uÃµÃÉÃûmÃ∑ÕóÃòpÃµÃæÃ†eÃµÃíÕôtÃ∑ÃåÃß Ã∑ÃàÃ±cÃ∏ÃâÃ±oÃ¥ÕíÕômÃ∑ÕÑÃ¨mÃ∂ÃèÃ≠eÃ∂ÕÉÃ©nÃ∂ÕäÃ¨cÃ¥ÃøÕîeÃ∏ÃÖÃ† Ã∏ÃÜÕérÃ∑ÕùÃ†eÃµÃÜÕîbÃ¥ÃΩÕïoÃ∂ÃâÃ≠oÃ¥ÃøÕîtÃ∏ÃæÃ†?Ã∏ÕëÃ≤[/h1]   lobotomy inc is a rougelike management simulator held back by it's less than great translation (english). you will suffer many a times due to dramatic translation errors and it will force you to resort to the wiki. thankfully this is only true on some of the dozens of anomalies present in the game (or this review probably wouldn't be a recommend). also helps that there is a very strong fanbase for this game and as a result the wiki is extremely well written and managed. discord peeps are nice too.  [h1] gameplay [/h1] lobotomy inc is a relatively peaceful management sim early in the game but as the steps grow longer and more and more difficult anomalies enter the fray you'll find yourself bouncing several of your hired employees to reach the daily energy quota while doing enough research to prevent the facility and/or the world from ending from said anomalies. all in a good days work.  really playing the game is it's own tutorial. with the help and successes of your research on anomalies you'll uncover management tidbits as well as devise your own strategies specialize or bolster your workers/agents/employees to handle said anomalies. the hardest part is beginning said research. because you know next to nothing when you first get a new anomaly. and it's satisfyingly nerve racking. did i mention that everytime you get a new anomaly you pick one from a selection of three (and all you know to differentiate them is a vague quote about them). yup satisfyingly chilly and atmospheric af too. very cool mechanic. especially for your first few campaigns.  when you first get an anomaly you'll know next to nothing about it and it's up to your guessing skills and agents you've built up to start the research and then energy gaining process. the game is quite forgiving in this state as anomalies that are triggered from one bad move tend to not be wholly catastrophic. and you can sort of guess what a blood powered bath tub can and can't do. sort of.  the tension is still there however and as the game goes on you're given so many options such as the use of anomalies and special forces to help manage the facility and/or accidents. really the best times happen when you accidentally forgot to check on an anomaly that sends a interdimensional train ramming all your agents in the facility. it's thus very very helpful that you're given a reset button in the escape menu if things go too wrong. and things will most certainly go wrong. and you will be amazed just how bad it can get. and you'll panic and try to fix it all before finally relenting that you should probably have pressed that reset button 20 minutes ago. but if you fix it all then you'll feel like you just saved the entire world (which you probably did).   there are two phases to each game day. you keep the ego (special equipment earned from doing detailed research on anomalies) and codex entries on the anomalies that you've done on your playthroughs. allowing for a sense of accomplishment and progress. those ego equipment is pretty important in the prep phase before a day as you'll definitely want to create both specialists and generalists among your agents as more and more dangerous anomalies present themselves. who knows? you might come across an anomaly that may actually help you ... provided you know what you're doing. it's a viable strat to leave a certain anomaly alone if you feel incapable of managing it (that said some anomalies literally have a time clock to doom so be careful).  as the game progressed you'll unlock more and more tools to directly influence as well as upgrade the various departments as the facility grows and expands. use these to your upmost advantage (or survival). subtle maneuvers such as moving your agents/employees to different rooms in preperation to a breach can really make a difference. they also help with ordeals which are random progressively more difficult events that occur the longer you work on each anomaly during a single day. prepare to accept losses.  overall if not for the lacklustre translation on a few anomalies and their unlockable management entries the gameplay is a very solid [b]9/10[/b]. a very hands on approach to a management sim with a surprising level of tension surprise and sometimes sheer panic and horror. best leave that multi appendaged abomination for another day aye.  however a key [b]flaw[/b] is the downtime when a mistake doesn't happen. this is inadevertently the majority of the early game which can be quite laborious and boring due to it's generally weaker threat level. thankfully the story makes passing this stage quite bearable to the mid game where the game really opens out and gives you a lot of options as well as challenges to upgrade your various departments.   [h1]story[/h1] contrary to a lot of management sims these days. lobotomy has a fairly long and immersive campaign that functions similar to a traditional visual novel style game. the campaign lasts for a very good few months with a good play session of 2 or so hours summing up to 1-3 days. that is a lot of story and gameplay to unpack for a game that's $20 usd. i won't spoil the story but if you guys like something to top off your [strike]scps[/strike] anomalies lobotomy does not disappoint. evidently i'm not good at rating stories but it's above average so hmmm [b] 8.5/10[/b] sounds good. did i mention taht every anomaly has it's own background story too (unfortunately also suffering from some translation flaws)  [h1]music and art [/h1] each anomaly has it's own bells and chimes that you can hear when zoomed in on their appropriate holding cells. some range from barely audible to very audible [insertlovecraftianhorrortrackhere]. they definitely work the treat to provide that uncanny experience as you manage them. these are further bolstered by short dialogue clips that show up while working with the anomalies that aren't written down in the in-game codex/encyclopedia. subtle features like this makes the game all the better. offcourse there is just general facility music and [b] danger [/b] music. i won't spoil that last one cuz it's a whole different treat when you've reached each of the three stages of 'you fucked up'.   each anomaly main characters and agents you control are wonderfully cartoonish and juxtapose the whole paranormal stuff that goes on in the facility. this quickly dissolves as things go awry however and your once amicable and harmless looking employees can quick devolve into panic fueled messes as trumpets roar your first danger step. it has a slight but signficant urge of dread and subtle realism that sinks in these moments.  a straight [b]10/10[/b] for how much i enjoyed it all.   [h1] overall [/h1] apart from some bugs with a very specific anomaly i'd say lobotomy corp is quite the underrated marvel of a game. if you're looking for some added spice to your management sims and can handle some xcom levels of difficulty/rng lobotomy is a perfect time sink. oh offcourse give it a go if you love the scp foundation as well.   [b]9/10[/b] held back by translation flaws but a very good and one of a kind game. worth full price if you're willing to steel yourself and wiki some of the anomalies when you have trouble. will suffer from my mistakes again (and again). also made by a korean team btw.

this game is really good. for the amount of budget it had i'm surprised at the very high level of quality this game has. i'll try my best in this review to avoid spoilers but disclaimer right from the start do not look up anything about this game or some of the cool mystery will be taken away from you.  lobotomy corporation is a game where you manage a joint scp containment facility and power company. i think it perfectly captures the feel of just how dangerous and weird working in such an environment is while maintaining that amoral corporation feel. while the game is difficult and involves some trial and error it never feels tedious since you can immediately retry the day if you don't like the outcome. or if you feel like you've fallen too far behind you can go to the last 5 day milestone you've hit to try and come up with a different gameplan for the week.  although there are some legitimate complaints to be had about this game i think they can be excused for the most part. -the english translation is passable and does its job but there are a few immersion breaking flaws here and there along with the occasional unnatural-sounding sentence.  -the nature of dealing with new abnormalities and the fact you are very likely to do something wrong and kill one of your employees until you learn more about it could be frustrating. however i do think this can be excused due to the fact you can restart the day whenever you want and the nature of the game. -customization something purely cosmetic that doesn't give you any gameplay advantage at all costs currency. granted it's only one lob which is nothing later on in the game but the fact it costs something at all is a bad choice imo. just let me customize my people. -you will not beat this game on your first run. the odds are just far too stacked against you to possibly beat the game on your first try due to lacking ego gear and likely not having optimized employees. but there is the upside that there are enough abnormalities so you will be seeing new ones very often on a restart. also you keep all ego gear and abnormality information you unlocked on restart. -some stuff that should be in the game by default like a fast-forward button has to be researched as well as the ability to see health bars. this is like the only big complaint i have though besides customization.  i'm not good with ratings but i seriously love this game. i would easily give it an 8/10. if and when the english translation has only a few flaws i'll easily bump this rating to an 8.5/10. very good job project moon! i only wish i knew of this game when the kickstarter was active.  edit: the game was re-translated on may 4th and the translation is good. i'd easily give this game an 8.5/10 now it's absolutely worth your time to check out.

lobotomy corporation despite it being one of my favorite works of media in terms of story and setting is a mixed bag in term of an overall game. it's something that isn't for everyone but something i would nonetheless recommend to those who might fit it (hell i've written lengthy fanfictions regarding it so that's something to note).  [b] the good: [/b] the experience of working with strange creatures and slowly discovering how to use them and work around them feels wonderfully evocative of scp foundation-like stories; this is a game you really really want to go into unspoiled.   the character designs are nice the music despite mostly being not made for the game is incredibly well chosen and most of all; the story and setting designs have so much thought clearly put into them that it feels like an incredibly well plotted out dystopian setting a fact that i'm sure the seuqel library of ruina will only flesh out more when it's released.  [b] the bad: [/b] the gameplay while fun at first can become repetitive later; especially when you're managing several abnormalities you're used to and going through days that can take upwards of 15 minutes at times and especially if you're restarting a day repeatedly for a specific option or trying to deal with a specific boss battle. it can get grindy so be prepared for that. it's also quite difficult at points and will often require you to rewind and try things again if you fucked up too many times or didn't do well enough. if you give up easily this game probably isn't for you!  [b] the elephant in the room: [/b] a notable fact and a fact that will likely be remedied soon is that for several years this game has had an infamously bad translation as a result of the dev team being essentially scammed. however a retranslation by a dedicated fan group that'll be added officially to the game is in the works to fix this. despite that for the best experience i'd personally recommend waiting until the translation is complete to play the game - the lore in this thing is t h i c c and you'd be really cheating yourself by experiencing it through an indecipherable and confusing lens.   overall if you like intricate stories management simulators and watching everything go to hell as you try to protect your precious agents from entities that have no right to exist buy lobotomy corporation. it's not for everyone and it has its flaws but it's one of my favorite games of all time off pure story alone. despite that i'm only giving it a 8/10 due to the aforementioned details.

[/olist]

allow me to explain the craft the beautiful artistry that went into a single man within this game.  first of all yesod is so fucking cute. the adorable nature so strong so evidently clear can only be contained so much in one small snake man. his preciousness is extremely hard to contain in his person which i can understand makes it easy to miss because such preciousness is all around you. it is impossible to compare the cuteness of this ai to any known being. let us elaborate.   first and foremost yesod is the sephirah of the information team but secondly he is a small baby snake you should very much protect from any pain. his turtleneck is made of the softest cotton and his gloves contain the gentlest warmth known to humankind. when i purchased this product i was not aware of my new beautiful baby boy it would contain. at first you may be deterred by the viper's tsundere nature but please do not be alarmed he is truly very soft and tender like mashed potato.  to understand yesod you must first understand the hard shell that hides his buttery soft interior.   yesod is an ai who takes his work very seriously and at times may be a bit prickly with you the manager because of it. please do not feel angered by this he simply cares as much as you do about your precious employees. you can tell by looking at his soft eyes that he is a sweet soul hidden behind a sweet little turtleneck that keeps us from developing diabetes from his sugary sweet face. you should not be enthused by this to hug the viper yet however remember he is a tsundere.  if you were to be given the luxury of holding the viper's hands however you would be able to feel the warmth behind those cotton gloves. i do not mean just body warmth i mean the warmth of your soul from touching something so adorable it melts into your skin your bones and warms your very being. what happens if you kiss his cheek you ask? i definitely enjoy this game and can recommend it to others though with a couple of points to make.  the things lobotomy corporation does well: an interestingly cutesy art-style for a horror game that ultimately works out in its favor. it's basically scp: the anime while being able to stand as its own thing rather than be a self-aware cash-in. interesting anomalies good character design and a heaping helping of roguelike on top of my management simulation simply work well and keep me on the hook for long periods of time*.  the things lobotomy corporation does not do well: first let's get this out of the way. the english translation is terrible providing unintentional comedy at best and making it incredibly hard to understand basic game mechanics at worst. you're probably going to need the wiki more than once even if you are trying to play blind. now discovery failure and restarting are all core aspects of the game. you should not look at this as a game that you beat in one run. rather each run is more a way to collect new gear experience knowledge and equipment to make your next run that much better. you will be restarting. multiple times in fact.  if you go into it expecting that it can be a lot less soul-crushing when you accidentally pick an anomaly you absolutely cannot deal with during the last day before a checkpoint. still sucks but know ahead of time what you're getting into.  final verdict: if you can look past its flaws and want something that will provide a consistent challenge for quite some time this is the game for you. the number of anomalies appears to be few but even with multiple resets the roster feels sufficient enough at least as far in as i've gone. i would warn new players that the game's difficulty curve is worst at the very beginning as the game very rapidly stops holding your hand after the first department or two. expect resets. expect so many resets.  and for the love of god don't take the magical gir-

lobotomy corporation is a mixed bag kept alive mostly by the allure and fun of scps.  the goal of the game is to run a program that extracts energy from scps (called anomalies in this game) to reach your daily quota all the while managing an increasingly complex facility which teeters closer and closer to complete collapse with every level you beat.  the biggest strike against this game is the poor translation.  the devs are korean and whoever did the english translation is obviously not a native speaker.  it's incredibly difficult to follow at times and in a game where you need to understand each creature's complex rule set to survive that's a huge issue.  luckily the lobotomy corporation wiki is very well written otherwise i don't think i could even hit level 10.  but if you can't stand alt-tabbing and pulling up a wiki page then you should not get this game.  pulling back towards some positives though the game is incredibly unique.  the anomalies are all very interesting and fun to figure out (if you can read their descriptions anyway) and the art style reminds me a lot of the persona 5 menus.  it's pretty sleek and the artist for the game can make some very nice character designs.  and the soundtrack while not the best i've ever heard does pull it's weight.  as for gameplay it's rather basic.  it's a rock-paper-scissors system at it's core with several layers on top of it.  it leaves a bit to be desired but hey it's not terrible.  and the real meat is of course the anomalies.  if you like scp then i'd recommend this game.  but otherwise unless you're a diehard fan then i'd say pass on this game.

i know technically... they're not scp's but..... they're scp's.. so i'm gonna call them scp's.  lobotomy corp is a tumblr management simulator. in where you manage a community in which each individual has very specific demands in which they are not catered to will cause an emotional meltdown and as a result go on a rampage. often causing a chain reaction of triggered individuals as one will trigger others causing even more chaos. (it's a joke chill.)  lobotomy corp is a management game in which you hold and research scp's. each attention or the lack there of in very specific ways in order to keep them under control. as more and more are added to your management every day your skills are pushed further and further. as more demands grow as well as the possibility of those demands overlapping with other scp's in conflicting ways. learning how to manage each one effectively to reduce possible risks.  learning and managing how these things work is a strange and engaging experience each scp being a puzzle to be mentally constructed as you observe behaviour. making sure you research it in the correct way and observe every little action it does in response. i've had an insane amount of fun just trying to work out why and what causes them to behave the way they do.  at the same time the game is held back by a number of extremely frustrating issues. the ui is outright awful confusing unresponsive at times and can often get your staff killed. as you try to micromanage specific abilities of scp's but finding the ui failing to do what you want it to do such as trying to move staff away from the doom approaching from the other side of the hallway. an alert system that warns you but fails to tell you anything else in which every so often you need to manually scan every room in the base instead of just listing affected rooms. missing a single one can lead to a game over as even a single death requires the day to be restarted.  the tutorial and translation are pretty bad. i'd outright suggest just going to the games wikipedia game and reading up on the mechanics than trying to understand the tutorial.  this is my biggest issue with the game deaths. at the end of every day you're given points to increase staff attributes or to hire new staff and increase their attributes. unfortunately if a staff members dies the number of points given is drastically reduced. so not only did you lose someone very well trained but you also lose points needed to replace them. a single loss requires you to restart the day or you just end up in a downwards spiral of losing staff but no points to replace them! please redesign this!  my last issue while most scp's are strange but fun to explore some can be utterly rage inducing. often requiring you to go back multiple days to simply make sure you never pick them again! spoilers incoming but it's to give you an idea of the biggest offenders. [spoiler] 1) a scarecrow that requires intelligence research to not break free but breaks free if someone too intelligent does the research. often the staff member assigned for this will level up their intelligence by working on it. so you need a new staff member for that spc every day! 2) an scp that can wipe most the base if not clicked on every 2min 3) worst of all... an scp that will kill the entire base if you take your camera off of it. holy damn whyyy?! if you get this guy all your hours need to make sure this asshole is always on screen. why?! it's awful![/spoiler]  while i have many complaints lobotomy corporation is a diamond in the rough. it's many issues while frustrating are pushed aside by how unique and interesting the gameplay is. i know i complained a lot but that's because i absolutely adore this game! it's just so rough around the edges. if you're into scp stuff at all pick this game up and even if you're not it's a great management game on its own.

commendable move by projectmoon.  i never expected the re-translation considering the fact that players already seemed content to play lobotomy corporation as-is even with the then-poor translation.  although this new one still isn't the greatest it is at least somewhat comprehensible.

this is one of my top five games. of all time. lobotomy corporation is a game where you get to play as the manager of a company that extracts energy from monsters called abnormalities. i found this game randomly while looking through the steam upcoming releases and upon watching the trailer i was intrigued. i had never played management simulators before and i quickly realized that this was not like normal management simulators. the games story takes place like a visual novel where you click to move on to the next bit of text with abit more of the story being revealed as you get through the games fifty odd levels. and by god is it a good story the actual meat of the gameplay takes place with you managing a few workers and monsters that gradually increases as you open up more departments. eventually giving you access to more dangerous monsters. the working day ends when you have collected your energy quota. including any side missions you want to complete. as you can imagine not all these monsters are happy about being locked up and if managed incorrectly will kill employees and escape if the latter happens you will need to rally your workers (who can also be upgraded with special equipment) to try and recontain the escapees. complicating this are monsters that occasionally appear in the facility to wreak whatever havoc they can. and then there are boss battles. boss battles in a management simulator. i won‚Äôt lie this game can get pretty hardcore. it can be frustrating  and exhilarating. making me genuinely feel like i am the manager at a monster factory. if this game takes your interest (like it did with me) then i highly recommend you try it.

there are some reviews on this page which will tell you that lobotomy corporation is a monster management simulation. i am here to tell you that this is in fact a blatant falsehood and having reached an ascended state of being can now reveal the truth:  [b]lobotomy corporation is a monster dating simulator game.[/b]  with almost every day you can pick an additional monster's route to unlock. there are four options to do stuff with them but the only important one for waifu purposes is attachment. there are so many different options to romance from cute ais and robots to slime girlfriend the [censored] which also features nsfw scenes (still have not figured out how to bypass this filter but i am sure this is an option somewhere) a tsundere bloodborne girl and also a bishonen sparkly enough to rival edward cullen amongst many others. if you have a foot/leg fetish or hand fetish or happen to like dogs that's also covered! also birds. there are so many birds in this game it's untrue i counted at least six.  many monsters are a bit tsun-tsun and will try and smack you around little before admitting any kind of affection. however they may also like to give you presents as a token of affection. just be warned that too much waifu will ruin your laifu and if you try and pursue too many different routes at once then they may follow you out of the containment and fight over you and if there's one thing that nobody wants it's multiple prospective monster gfs/bfs duking it out in the facility. or maybe you do it's kind of entertaining to watch. also sometimes these random jackasses will show up out of nowhere and try to ruin everything but you can ask ms. bloodborne to beat them all up so it's ok. 11/10 would date again.  (on a more serious note this game does have an excellent and meaningful story line and is a great monster management simulator. that being said go into it fully accepting the facts that a) you are most likely going to have to restart from day 1 if you want to 100% and b) a lot of stuff is going to blow up in your face the first time you deal with it so don't expect a oneshot run or anything. the translation errors have since been fixed thanks to the many efforts of the fanbase too. only remaining issue is the occasional tendency for memory leak to build up on long days; you can usually help avoid this by closing the game and booting it up again on failed attempts and letting it run until it resolves the end-of-day section. there are also mods which should help with this issue available on the nexusmod website.)

video review at bottom:  	lobotomy corporation felt like a weird combination of several games while still being an incredibly unique experience. if i were forced to explain it in a nutshell i‚Äôd say it was fallout shelter but you had to care for scp‚Äôs while training your employees in their 4 different skills. that tl;dr however doesn‚Äôt even come close to doing the game justice in my opinion. 	when you first fire up the tutorial you are greeted by your cute little ai helper named ‚Äúangela‚Äù. she guides you through 3 tutorials then sets you on your way. while it wasn‚Äôt the worst tutorial in gaming history i definitely felt like i learned more from reading the in game manual and experimenting. yet given that the game draws heavily from the scp foundation. so much so that they even straight up admit this on the steam store page i feel like the lack luster tutorial forcing me to throw my none the wiser employees at potentially dangerous abnormalities to even begin figuring out what i was doing added significantly to the experience. after i got over the initial learning curve i was glad they did things the way they did. 	so what did i learn? the game is broken up into days. over the course of each day you are tasked with collecting an ever increasing amount of enkephalin that will be packaged into pe boxes and used to create energy to meet the ever growing needs of humanity! you do this by taking care of the abnormalities. you have 4 options to use in this endeavor. instinct which applies to the base physiological needs. insight aimed at improving their cell. attachment to satisfy their social needs. and lastly repression to suppress the existential entity and it‚Äôs spiritual desires. while those descriptions sound intense and varied on the surface it basically boiled down to finding out which one a specific abnormality prefered and more or less spamming it. at least at first... you could deduce this through trial and error or increase your observation level of the abnormality. as you work with the creatures and gain pe boxes you would accrue another resource creatively named unique pe boxes. you could then spend these to learn about that specific entity. such as its name. how it responds to the various interactions. what it‚Äôs attack and defense is like. insight into its unique characteristics and once those were finished you could spend all the leftover on unique equipment to gear up your employees. my favorite was a magic gun from an old lady that could shoot insane workers back to peak mental health. which leads me to your employees. 	in between days you would earn lob points. these would be spent on hiring customizing and raising the stats of your workforce. outside of spending your lob points to do so your workers could also improve their stats overtime by performing work on the abnormalities and once enough stats were gained they‚Äôd also receive a promotion. i didn‚Äôt really notice their promotion level having any impact outside of being a representation of an individual‚Äôs overall abilities. there were 4 stats one for each of the four interactions that we talked about before but beyond improving their proficiency in a specific interaction they also improved the various aspects of that individual. fortitude was for instinct work and would increase their maximum health pool. prudence was for insight work and would increase their maximum sanity. temperance was linked to attachment work and increased the overall work speed and success rate and lastly justice was tied to repression work and their movement speed. 	in between days each employee could be assigned and freely reassigned to various departments you would unlock and level up by assigning the 1 new abnormality you would receive to that division. as employees spend days working for a specific department they would gain a permanent bonus like increasing their movement speed from the control department or temperance for working in the information department. the department heads would also give you missions and completing them would reward you with a new perk they called research you could unlock at the end of the day. some of the earliest ones you would get would be the ability to increase the speed to 2x or 3x or the ability to send employees to work on abnormalities in other divisions. 	now as i said earlier. at the start of the game it‚Äôs pretty straightforward to attend to your abnormalities and most of the starting ones that i encountered could be summed up as find the type of work they prefer and spam it. pushing into the end of the control department and beginning of the information department the first and second departments respectively. the abnormalities start to become quite dangerous if the employee doesn‚Äôt perform the work well. then going into the 3rd and 4th departments information and training the scps begin to become incredibly unique.one stood out the most to me was ‚Äúbeauty and the beast‚Äù. beauty and the beast was the first unique abnormality i encountered. it gives the most boxes from repression work but this would lower it‚Äôs invisible health bar. if beauty and the beast died they would also kill the employee then respawn. other works would increase this invisible health bar. so it was part guessing game and part balancing act to acquire energy from beauty and the beast. 	 lobotomy corporation is a rogue lite game. it is an incredibly lite rogue lite though. you are given the ability to revert to the start of the day where you assign and equip employees. you also get a ‚Äúmemory imprint‚Äù every 5 days that you can revert to and then of course in rogue lite fashion you can go all the way back to the start but keep certain things. all observations are carried over. along with any unspent unique pe boxes and all the equipment you still had at the end of your last run. 	now i‚Äôve mentioned equipment a few times without touching on it. ‚Äúwhat does it do?‚Äù you may be wondering. once again it‚Äôs divided into 4 categories. red is for health damage. white is for sanity damage. black is health and sanity damage and lastly pale is a percentage of hp. as of writing this i didn‚Äôt make it far enough to encounter pale damage. the abnormalities and defensive equipment would have strengths and weaknesses to these elements then each abnormality and worker based on their weapon would deal one of these damages. unless it was white damage and they were attacking a co-worker it would fill up their sanity. which was kind of silly to behold but very useful. 	overall i had a ton of fun with this game and expect it to be a regular in my gaming library. i'd say the game was worth full price. even more worth it if it goes on sale. after experiencing the entirity of this game and reading the ocean of positive reviews i must conclude that the game wasn't even close to be a bad choice of purchase nor am i able to write a more convincing review for this game. all i can say is that i never enjoyed a game as much as this one. playing this game feels like eating your favorite cereal filled with caramel and onions only to find out it was a bizarre foreign soup made by a chef who is actually your tsundere crush from 4th grade and tries to improve this dish with random ingredients chosen by a roulette and you later help making this dish appeal to you because you thought your crush was trying to poison you. and in the end you were just eating your greens your parents told you to eat and you refused the entire time without their supervision on 3 am which tastes as lame as it sounds and suddenly gaining the ability to taste each and every vitamin you taste and tell just like handling the same abnormalities after restarting at day 1 with all your facility upgrades making the game easier than before in exchange of losing your beautiful children who survived throughout your time in this facility known as your employeesm making the new run feel less thrilling as the very 1st but at least you're then able to proceed through the days further into the end than before. but at what cost? was it for you? was it for the employees the sephirahs and angela? or did you just want to observe those cool new abnormalities who really spooked and excited you when you first saw them? what makes you think this game can't be used as your own personal sandbox with all your employees against all the breaching abnormalities in a battle royale? perhaps this game was trying to teach you how to become rl managers developing steady and flawless multitasking performance and make you treat your adorable employees like expendable toilet paper this game makes enemies towards any humanists and this is exactly why i was starting to lose touch into this game like i used to at around day 49 making it seem impossible because i had easily breachable high tier abnormalities who stand in the way of actually finishing the day but in the end... i just wanted to mess around my facility that's all. no challenge mode was needed i just wanted to play with my abnormalities as they were my little pets tearing my employees appart like wet paper. not because im some sort of monster i can just restart and everything would just seem like nothing happened or made that what i said in vice versa. but i must say im glad i got this out of my chest and i really really enjoyed the time i got into it midway before i unlocked every single facility upgrades which made this whole scenario seem like a cakewalk. but i really missed the time i got actually intimidated by any new scary abnormalities and getting excited afterwards of crafting it's e.g.o. equipment of it.  tl;dr: if i had a wish i would delete my save file of this game and erase my memory just to experience the story and lore of this game the characters and their unique design

this game is not for everyone. the english translation is kinda akward and the game doesn't explain the mechanics of it very well but i think this makes the game better. during the first half of the game i was put into a position of power where the lifes of all my employees rested in my hands where if i didn't do my job properly then horrible creatures from beyond human comprehension would escape their cells and start cutting off heads and i had no idea what to do or how to do it. it legitimaly made the game feel like a horror game and it is a really unique horror experience that i have never seen another game have.  something that does not work in favor of the game is the fact that it can be somewhat tedious. days can drag on for very long and you need a lot of patience sometimes. the game also pretty much requires you to restart the day if it goes wrong otherwise you wont be properly prepared for the latter days. heck during my first playthrough i had to restart from the very beginning once i got to the very end. and yet i still went back and played it all the way through.  if you can tolerate or appreciate everything that i have told you so far and you like the way the game sounds in the storeoage description then you absolutely need to buy it. the atmosphere is great most of the creatures and monsters are very creative and despite the fact that your secretary tells you not to i found myself getting really attached to my employees. it's a very unique game and if you can look past some of its flaws it is a game i can recomend.

lobotomy corporation is what it says on the tin: a monster management simulation. you direct agents to perform work on abnormalities and gather information to meet daily quotas. simple in theory but the game gets more complex as you go on. each abnormality requires a specific approach and experimentation is how you find out what this approach is. the game punishes mistakes frequently but it's fair even if you don't know it yet. the cast of characters that you meet are engaging and the story is easy to get invested in. lobotomy corporation is easily worth the full price and it's even better when you get it on sale. just be careful when you talk about it with friends who've played it since spoiling abnormalities or the story is easy to do by accident.
good waifus.

mistakes easily snowball into nearly unsalvageable situations and things can go from 0-100 in very short order depending on what abnormalities you have. after you get all the boss bonuses and immunize yourself to meltdowns the early game it can be kind of boring unless you grab wn 'your-ticket-sir' and all the other toxic abnormalities. that said the last 5 days are still one of the best experiences i had in gaming and it really makes you feel the sacrifices of agents you spent time training.  story is kind of anime at times but has a serious and 'deep' side to it depending on how much you are willing to read into the subtext of the lore and how much you are willing to read. difficulty can pretty low if you spend a lot of time training everyone into giga-chads and cheat by looking at the wiki but hopefully you don't do this. gameplay is fine and there's a lot of variety to your agents. interface and trying to select specific agents is sometimes frustrating but nothing game-breaking just need to sometimes think of ways to separate agents since they can all stack up on one spot making choosing the specific guy being targetted for a near-instant-death-with-aoe attack kind of hard.  going in blind probably isn't for everyone since not everyone would appreciate having to restart a lot and get their balls broken when they lose half their a-team but it honestly is the best way to experience the game.  also forget the other people who complain about day 49 sure i lost the most agents in that single day but it is the best day in the game.

the game is a little clunky sometimes and there isn't any real save function. just a very irregular autosave and progress that you keep in new games. all in all it's a pretty interesting game though if you like management simulation horror and such. i'd definitely recommend it to anyone who likes scp and stuff too
my old review didn't make sense so here's a new one;  this game will turn a child into a man. and turning a man into a crying mess. have fun.

this game feels like an scp management game. you send your underlings to do your bidding and try to keep the creatures contained while doing so. you research ways to improve conditions for your employees and keep them even safer. i enjoyed playing this and enjoyed watching all hell break loose because i wanted to watch the world burn. there are many different abnormalities to capture and observe (you can choose from three every day) they have their own stories and there's even an actual storyline as you play through as a manager. if you happen to make a wrong turn on a day and choose to start over any observations of any creatures are saved and the game will let you know if a creature you have already captured pops up as a choice. there are multiple departments that you can construct (a long process you can only work on one a day) and each holds four abnormalities.   just watch out for the plague doctor. i mean of course unless you want all hell to break loose.

bought at full price and not disappointed. simple concept with good mechanic progression that ties into the story. slow start but can get very crazy very fast. if you like management games where things can go from perfect to horribly wrong in the blink of an eye this is for you.

management game in which you must assign your workers jobs with the stuff of nightmares in the hopes the results will be good and they won't die or trigger a containment breach. you work for a company that harvests energy from anormalities.  you have an energy goal per day which you acquire by achieving good outcomes in your jobs. good outcomes will also grant you boxes (not lootboxes just plain boxes per anormality) which you can use to 'purchase' information on an anormality as well as gear for your employees (weapons and armor) the information can be things such as chance of success of each job type lore management tips and so on.   every job performed also ticks away on a 'meltdown' countdown which will cause one of your anormalities to try to escape. some anormalities do not escape. others require special suppression methods.  your workers have 4 stats and each governs a job type. stats have 5-levels. each of these levels may have a different success rate for a specific job/anormality even when it's the same stat. you can upgrade them by performing specific types of jobs or by spending lob points awarded at the end of a mission for completion. these points are also used for hiring new personnel should yours meet horrible fates.  the gear is also affected by the 4 stats so an armor might do well against certain anomaly attack types and have others vaporize you. weapons have a damage 'type' that also affects damage done to anomalies for better or worse.   missions are segmented in days after each of which you must select a new anormality to house in your facility which you will develop into quite a handful later on. you can replay days (resets day progress) or travel back to previous days some things go 'back' with you (i think gear does) and others don't (your anormality choice will be redone but you will have the same 3 anormalities to pick from). this will only change when you start a new game.  it sounds like a lot to wrap your head around as much as it is to try and put all that's going on in the game in these words (and i'm pretty sure i missed a lot) but it's all pretty clear once you follow the tutorial and try your first day.   it's really fun the workers could look a little better but that's just a personal taste the rest of the graphics look clean and neat the music is nice and i found it pretty fitting for the setting the gameplay is thrilling discovering new anormalities is super fun and nerve-wracking when they go wild.  it's pokemon but with all sorts of eldritch horrors and you gotta contain 'em all!

[i] slow breathing [/i]  okay i've got this. everything is fine.  ~ 5 minutes later ~  at least 30 employees brutally murdered sprinkle on 10 executed by the manager 1/4 of the facility transformed into bees and 1/4 of the facility breaking down and getting sucked into a black hole.  manager is everything alright?  [i] sips vodka [/i]  [b]everything is fine![/b]   i've really fallen in love with this vastly underappreciated game as of late. one of the most panic-inducing and fun management games in recent years where however much you might think that everything is fine [i]nothing is ever fine![/i] there is always an element of mystery and problem-solving layered underneath the brutal manslaughter from which the game gets it's charm. you never know what the gigantic black bird with fifty eyes will do to the poor schmuck you shove into it's containment unit until you give it a try.

pros: interesting premise pleasant art style great soundtrack. monsters are memorable and workable as you progress through the game and gain knowledge. interesting story. rewards savescumming and requires multiple playthroughs.  cons: late game balance ranges from completely bearable to ridiculously difficult. some monsters are so annoying to work around that you're better off reloading the save than keeping them around (looking at you goddamn train). story is told through vn-style exposition dumps that make it difficult to care about the characters. quite rng-dependent on what monsters you'll unlock during a playthrough and whether your characters die or not. also some questionable translations including a handful of significant translation errors.  overall 8/10  slime girl best waifu

i've been really enjoying the game so far especially while streaming it with my friends who also show interest! i went into the game with practically zero micromanagement experience yet despite that i've been doing quite well in my first run (currently coming close to day 40)!  the idea of your employees dying and losing the gear you've worked hard to get can be scary at times and handling some of the higher (waw/aleph) class abnormalities seems intimidating but with time you should get used to it. you really have to be careful though - fortunately the retry options and the memory depository make this game a little more forgiving (though i've heard that midnight ordeals and some core suppressions can be very difficult.  if you're interested in getting the game i would suggest watching some kind of gameplay before you get your hands on it just so you know what you're getting yourself into - be warned however as this game can be very difficult at times!

you manage teams that handle subjects called abnormalities that are used as an energy source. these abnormalities must be handled with certain requirements by interacting with them (or by not interacting with them).   learning the specifics of an abnormality is trial and error until you know enough about it. many of these abnormalities will cause devastating troubles for your teams while a few are proven beneficial.  you control the employees and assign them tasks of what to do with abnormalities. abnormalities will have to be suppressed sometimes. the game requires some tactical thinking as more teams and abnormalities arrive. you will learn that some abnormalities will try and mess up your operation.  so if you like oddities and monsters while managing everything then this game is for you!

lobotomy corporation is one of steam hidden gems. gameplay is very unique and well done. game even gives you new mechanic [spoiler]bullets which allows you to effect whats happening in facility in more direct way[/spoiler] in middle of game so you don't get bored with what you have and also introduces sort of boss fight. every abnorm you need to take care of feels unique and you are just starting day thinking what completly new way of bringing death to your employees you just got. characters are memoriable and interesting (netzach is my spirit animal). music is amazing every emergency tier has its own music that describes what is happening in facility. only thing i can complain about is some translation errors and that after this game no other game will give me this much satisfaction as ending day after recontaining some of most dangerous anomalies without having entire department dead. and community. community might be small but its just so amazing. 10/10 maybe best game i ever played.

if you too enjoy the glamorous high-paced world of management tempered with screams of your employees being gruesomely dispatched in the most horrific manner possible by eldritch abominations from beyond this games for you!  take on the role of the manager and help the lobotomy corporation extract energy from terrifying monsters in an attempt to fight global warming.  don't underestimate them though or you risk endangering your employees lives and sanity.  this game is very interesting in that it's one part management simulation and one part survival/horror.  you need to carefully interact with grotesque terrors that each have their own quirks and expectations.  for example some need to be experimented on at specific intervals and if you don't interact with them often enough they'll try to kill your employees.  others need to be interacted with while in a certain state and if you get it wrong they'll get mad and try to kill your employees.  another might not appreciate the particular experiment that you are running and will try to kill your employee.  there's another that will just drive your employee insane for looking at it escape and then drive all your other employees insane looking at it.  the fun is in trying to find the right interaction balance that ensures the specimens won't get mad enough to escape and kill everyone.  you get to see all these crazy looking things and make weapons and equipment from them.  failing isn't game ending either.  you can retry days when everything seems to go wrong and if you want you can start over completely while keeping your research and equipment but reset employees.  the game isn't without it's flaws.  i think the game is originally from korea but offers a translation in english.  the translation can be a bit spotty in places but it's good enough that you can understand most of it.  another pain point is that the ui doesn't seem to give you enough information or at least the information that you actually care about from time to time.  also i wish that there was a way to give better orders to employees.  you're able to select employees and tell them to move from room to room but it's hard to know which employee is actually selected and you can't be sure that you actually told them to go somewhere.  you can also mass select but you don't have an indication of group you have selected.  i think this is biggest pain point because i've lost several employees by accidentally sending the wrong people to suppress some outbreak that would massacre one group but barely hurt another.  it would be nice if the ui took some inspiration from some rts games.  overall it's fun to play.  if i had to compare it to other games i'd say it's kind of like a mix of darkest dungeon (lovecraftian resource management) sim city (base planning and interactions) and a dash of monster hunter (make equipment out of monsters and use the right equipment to help you to make more equipment out of monsters).

this is an scp game where you work in management instead of being a disposable grunt. your goal is to work with these abnormalities to generate p.e boxes (energy) to supply a dying world with power. you do this by managing and sending your personnel to work with the abonormalities. every in-game day gives you a new abonormality to work with which get progressively more dangerous. the charm of the game is trying to find out what makes these abnormalities tick and trying to manage the chaos once you're getting a larger and larger facility.   the first couple are days are pretty tame but once you get to around day 10 the story starts to pick up. the story is the best part of the game for me as it gets progressively more serious and is very good at teasing you about it's history and it's world. this along with the peronal stories of the different department leaders is what will most likely keep you playing.  the game is very lenient on restarting as you will almost certainly make use of it because this game does not mess around when everything goes wrong. you will keep any equipement and research you did on abnormalities when you restart and any unlocks you gained from working with the departments will be yours to keep. there will also be a save point every 5 days in case you got something you can't work with yet.  [h1]the good[/h1] fantastic story very good music fun but somewhat tedious gameplay once you reach the later stages of the game very unique and creative abnormalities great lore on the abnormalities   [h1]the bad[/h1] translations are iffy in places but it's good 97% of the time it's simply not for everyone day 49  [i]when you are close to the star you can hear the welcoming cheers and singing. if we all return back to this place only the blue star will remain. we will meet again as stars.[/i]
