probably one of my favorite things about the game is the discovery. there are so many abnormalities all with different features and even special mechanics. it's a micro-management/grinding kind of game with a twist of horror from all the backstories and the plot of the game.  for as much as there is in the game it's absolutely worth the purchase price.  my only criticism is on the translation issues but i know they are working on fixing this. if broken english is deal breaker for some people i would suggest waiting until it is fixed before buying. also because it is a trial and error style game you'll be restarting a lot. believe me the game gets increasingly difficult so losing people is something you want to avoid because it makes progressing much more difficult.

[i]note[/i]: if you hate trial-and-error or even just anything that involves resorting to your last save and repeating a level to advance you're gonna hate this game period.  [h1]summary[/h1] [b]content[/b]: a lot of things will take more than one try to get so jam-packed [b]controls[/b]: click-based mainly. there's keyboard shortcuts but you can generally play this with one hand. [b]gameplay[/b]: simple management-based; logic-driven. [b]strongly[/b] trial-and-error based. suppression is strategy-based.  [b]graphics[/b]: simple to sophisticated polygons [b]replay value[/b]: definitely. [b]soundtrack[/b]: reminds me of a futuristic office? really simple definitely fits the game [b]story[/b]: a little lacking especially at the beginning but it gets there [b]worth the price[/b]: yes. final answer.  [h1]about the game[/h1] lobotomy corporation | monster management simulation or as i knew it when it first got released and will be referred to as such in the future lobotomy corporation is a monster management simulator with rougue-like rpg-like elements added. a lot about the game is already defined in the description so i'm going to skip what's already been covered and get to the more indepth details.  [h1]abnormalities[/h1] like its inspirations lobotomy corporation has monsters they call abnormalities. these are your subjects that you research on to provide energy towards your facility. each of these guys comes with a story of some sort and perameters on how to utilize/research it. some can benefit your facility in the sense of advanced weaponry or defense while others can quite literally destroy everything you've built up until that point. it's up to you to figure that out however. if you actually take the time to read the lore it's got a good bunch of it. maybe not as much as scp considering that's full of fanmade ones as well but it's got a lot and interesting ones at that.  [h1]suppression[/h1] here's where the rougue/rpg elements begin. suppression is a feature of the game where when certain perameters are achieved [spoiler]whether it be the abnormality acting on its own accord escaping due to frustration or the wrong type of research applied to it[/spoiler] the abnormality escapes. lobotomy corporation shows no mercy when it comes to this as many will quite literally destroy your entire facility if you're not careful. not to worry though! when you do the correct research towards an abnormality it will allow you to purchase gear for your employees (most of the time). not all gear is equipped to deal with all abnormalities however so you will have to be smart about which ones you buy and who you equip them to. i still haven't mastered this myself and find myself getting overrun often.  [h1]why the price?[/h1] okay so in the early access version things were basically completely different. they had a game structured but it was not what they wanted and it took a lot of funds and time to revamp it into the version you see here today. i think they've come a long way and with how much gameplay you can get out of this it's worth $25.  [h1]comparisons to the early access/complaints[/h1] okay first off let me note that the original user interface was 1000x easier to read and use. [url=https://youtu.be/zlrhdbxe878]you can see glimpses of it in this video provided.[/url] it had 5 different things you could do vs the 4 you can only do now and was soooo much friendlier to the one now which i think was provided to cater more towards the korean fanbase as this [i]is[/i] a korean game by a korean-based company. i also find that while it's useful to have staff that can do everything essentially it was a lot more of a fun difficult when you were given only one or two staff members that could do a task and you had to forcibly manage your staff around this.  the early access version also had a different style of equipping as there was really just three categories: longrange melee and defense weaponry. i much prefer the release's version where they are catered to specific entities adding to the gameplay itself. especially since each individual abnormality can have a different type of attack it adds more to have to cater to specific departments. it also added a layer of difficulty that was otherwise not present in the ea version.  the story. there was really a lack of story in ea as all you did was really talk to an ai on what looked like a text simulation similar to zork. not to say that was a bad thing but it was a little...bland. i'm not sure anthropomorphing the ai and the deparments was the right answer but it was a step in the right direction. it kind of made the action choices they gave you make a little more sense than before however when you were just essentially talking to a terminal.  upgrades!!! holy smokes a lot of the features that are given as upgrades were a given in ea but now you have to earn the right not to sit there aimlessly for a few minutes while you wait for your first few abnormalities to act up. i was so upset when they came out with the release and the fact they revamped it to make you [i]earn[/i] these features that are normally given to you. but that's just the spoiled part of me speaking. it's definitely unique.   [h1]overall[/h1] just a generally good game. lots of replay value (especially since it's built in that way) and makes you earn its affection like a nice ale or a woman.
it's like the scp game i had always wanted!

on a more serious note: -the employees are extremely adorable -the abnormalities are very interesting highly detailed and well thought of -the game mechanics are also quite detailed and fun with all the damage types work types and etc. -the soundtrack is great -the dialogue with the characters especially angela is interesting and entertaining if you are interested in things like scps and such i would say give this game a try. the unique attributes and backstories of the abnormalities will definitely interest you.  on a more sincere note: -the employees are so cuuuuteeeeee -who the hell comes up with the names? creativity is going through the roof with these developers i like it -10/10 would pause game and micro-manage all employees again

i love this game. the fact that you can learn about each abnormality on a different playthrough makes subsequent playthroughs much easier and adds an incentive to experiment with all of them. i wish the soundtrack was available i quite enjoy the warnong songs specifically the first trumpet.
good game. get ready to restart alot for a 100% ending but great nonetheless.

not exactly what i expected; the cycle runs as this.  get a monster - send some poor soul in first to it likely to have them go insane or be murdered - restart the day - repeat untill you get a scrap of information on the monster - after gaining that info try to farm that monster for recources - get a new monster - was rince repeat*  *exept when your last monster goes on a rampage whenever it smells blood in the air; someone ignores it for too long; someone gets unhappy; or you breathe air wrong.  7/10 solid monster managment sim ^-^

really cool game with a nice mixture of horror story-telling and roguelike simulation in one! i enjoyed playing this game very much. i'm still not yet half way through so i'm not sure how more difficult this game will get but i'd definitely recommend purchasing as it is well worth the money in my honest opinion. i don't really know much about the scp foundation but the design and the stories behind the abnormalities are very interesting yet creepy at the same time. however there are few things i'd like to point out: 1. language problems i heard it was localized well in other languages like chinese but english translation is mediocre at best. which is why i only playd in korean. i'm not sure if i'd recommend this game to an english speaker which is a big bummer since it'd be nice to make my friends play this and watch their reactions.  2. complicated ui tbh i am not your best video game player. i suck at games that require a lot of control but that is partly because i am also a control freak with a perfectionist streak. this game gave me a lot of anxiety because i hate it when the employees die or when the abnormalitie escape. it is the literal worst if there is an abnormality loose and a panicking employee at the same time (i just redo at this point). for me the stop button was my best friend but the ui in general is a bit clunky and very different from most other games which did not help with my anxiety. it's almost as if you are playing a trpg but on computer. for me it took about five days (in game) to get used to it but expect a lot of confusion in the beginning since there's a lot to remember in order to play this game smoothly.

it's buggy the localization is still pretty bad even after several improvements the micromanagement can get annoying and the ui can be a nightmare to navigate at times.  that being said there's a lot of love put into this game the abnormalities have a vast array of design writing and behaviors and there's not really any other games that capture the essence that lobotomy corporation manages to. and there's nothing quite like the panic you feel when your abnormalities start to escape your employees all start to be eviscerated or driven insane and everything falls to heck; very few games manage to make you feel as genuinely distressed at a situation devolving as lobotomy corporation does.   don't get it for more than $20 and you should be able to get your money's worth.
game can be tedious and if you go in blind it will rape you harshly but other than that its a good game the monsters are cool and the story is cool too (a wiki exists for it by the by)
the game is quite challenging and enjoyable. monster managment permadeath risk taking makes you try new things and overall 1 of a kind. 9.5/10

this game is one of the few that legit spooks me. this game is like you're managing the facility in cabin in the woods but there's nothing silly or fun about this game. this game is next level spooky. i'm spooked.

warning those who dislike save scumming (which they even built into the game for us) will not like this game as it is highly trial/error based.  ***spoilers for two anomolies.***  day 3: my new toy is a cool piece of armor (sends employee) work completed employee decapitated.  (sends another) work completed decapitated again...   oook so much for my 100% safety rate (day ends).  day 4: my armor likes repression therapy (sends employee wearing body armor for repression) worked completed decapitated. ok i feel like a bad boss now... whats perky iron maiden like toy they gave me (sends employee).  well go figure that hurts (hits cancel button and it ignores cancel) employee dies 30 seconds later.  @#%# (loads save)  day 4 again (sacrifices two employees to perky iron maiden to get intel).  intel #2 notes anybody i send will die the end @%@! (loads save)  day 4 yet again (sacrifices 4 employees to the currently renamed decapitating armor for intel).  intel #1 anybody w/ 1 fortitute (which is my entire staff bc i just started the game) will be decapitated upon completion of work.  @#%!@$^!#$^@#%@  i'm at day 4 and already half my anomolies feel like trolls out to torture me and these are still mid/weak class anomolies.  unlike my employees (which are dead) my sanity rating has decreased to critical levels so i must heal up before attempting to battle a game again.   despite not even lasting 1 hour before needing break i'll still recommend it because the game is very good at what it was designed to do.  they wanted to make a punishing management game where everything is stacked against us and my employee death toll clearly says they succeeded.
decent story good - gameplay meh.
with my infinite hatred i recommend this game dont touch it

you get to run and manage the equivelant of an scp facility where some of the anomalies can even alter the more litteral properties of the game. the translation from korean is alright but its slowly being improved on and the game is really fun.  if you're a fan of scp or the idea of something otherworldly being out there then this is the game for you!
dark souls iv

lobotomy corporation is simultaneously a creepy game a relaxing game and an intense game with an intriguing world and criminally low sales. you definitely should buy it if your dream is to manage an occult research facility while facing fears and overlooking casualties.   you can call this game a ‚Äúnightmare research manager‚Äù: it‚Äôs all about researching scary unspeakable things entertaining scary unspeakable things to keep them inside their chambers and harvesting energy from scary unspeakable things all to get through another day. no worries about your fate though you are the chief executive of this research facility so you won‚Äôt have to get your hands dirty and your life shorter ‚Äî you have employees for that. don‚Äôt get too attached to someone: sooner or later they will all die horrible deaths either because of your mistakes or the circumstances or just out of cruel necessity.    so how exactly do you manage occult research facility? basic procedure goes something like this: you choose a chamber to research then the type of research (instinct insight attachment repression) then assign an employee to do it and then... hope for the best. remember inside that chamber waits a strange abnormal [i]thing[/i] and no one knows what it can do. if your research ends up well (or at least comes to an end) you'll extract some energy (there is a quota to move on to the next in-game day) and most importantly you'll get unique pe-boxes which you can spend to unlock information about researched abnormality (we are doing research here you know) or invest in equipment like hazard-suits and weapons.    when all is well life at the facility goes on nice and easy it's almost a routine ‚Äî drink your coffee assign tasks to your employees wait for timeout read in-game wiki... until you mess something up (or an emergency happens). why would you mess up? well every couple of days you receive a new abnormality to work with and your facility keeps expanding this increases the chance of a critical mistake dramatically. but you shouldn't worry about that as from that mistake begins the best part of the game: managing a containment breach. imagine you send a wrong employee to the wrong chamber you look at the thing you must not look you mess up a research procedure and a disappointed abnormality breaks out from its chamber and begins rampaging in the hall. then it kills somebody. suddenly this death upsets another abnormality and it also breaks free. then it hacks up other chambers releasing all other abnormalities. and then the train pulls in. and then the static creeps in. you try your best to overcome containment breach but [b] eÕÇÃΩÃÉÕ•aÕÑtÕ§ÕÉÕ¶Ã±Ã≤ÕôÃù ÕóÕõÕ´Ã∞ÃÆÃûÃºtÃäÃàÃÑÕäÃªhÃÇÕíÃìÕ£Õ´ÃªÃ¨ÃØÕñÃ´ÕáeÕìÃóÃ¨ÃûiÕ´ÃøÃçÃÑÃéÃàÃ≠ÃºÕñrÕ• ÕëÃöÃ≠ÕáÃºÃ≥ÃÆÕïÕáeÃ•ÕöÕéÕÖÕñyÃÉÃçÕõÃäÕñeÃÅÕêÃúsÕÉÕ¶ÕØÕåÃ∫ÃùÃ£Ã∞Ã≥ ‚Äî then i saw when the lab member broke one of the seven seals and i heard ‚Äî emergency in the third hallway ‚Äî you cannot escape it in the past there is no past ‚Äî error. human is dead mismatch. [/b] in a split second your peaceful lab turns into a war-zone; another split second and there are no survivors only piles of corpses and mad apostles of the new god.   gameplay: it‚Äôs your management game. you check the in-game wiki (i don‚Äôt recommend using community wiki on the net it kills the fun) you send your employees to attend their tasks you observe get new data unlock new pages in wiki learn about abnormalities quirks create schedules react to emergencies.   story: you start working as a manager at the research facility with a cute ai as your assistant. as the game progresses you meet other ais and people. everything else is a heavy spoiler so i‚Äôll be a gentleman and finish this section right now. [i] *cough*-*cough* 4 endings [/i]    characters: [i] note to myself from the future: don‚Äôt look under the spoiler. [/i] [spoiler]sad to inform you but all your employees are bald. and you are bald. but no one is dead. [/spoiler] which is nice.    p.s. for more awesome hidden gems follow the steam [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10722089/]criminally low sales[/url] curator.
a fun game with a experimental feel to it plus with a sudden increase in difficulty in later stages of the game though it's fun if your into management and keeping your people alive and well.

this is an amaging game i love it! there is such a veriety of characters and monsters and the most interaction you see is when everything goes to heck. most epic music playing your worst nightmares escaping agents getting squashed workers going insane and then there is just that one clerk in the middle of the apocalipce (probably with a cup of tea or coffee) looking with zero care at all the monsters dueling in the hall in front of him like in the arena and igoring him. just another bright day at the lobotomy!

closest we got to an scp management simulator. starts off a bit slow mainly so you can get used to what you're doing. and then shite starts to hit the fan. so you start again with that knowledge in mind.  interesting mix of time\resource management coupled with a story given in the style of a visual novel it's worth a look if you are a fan of either. although the animation is a bit sparse and some... interesting translations pop up every now and again so keep that in mind.  7\10 would mute music and play kyoto connection over the top again.

the first time i played lobotomy corporation i didn't rely on wiki so starting from day 5 due to my lack of knowledge i captured a few alphe and other extremely dangerous abnormalities. the condition of the facility became so bad i couldn't proceed in my game and i have to throw away virtually all my checkpoints. the second time i played smart and carefully reviewed the wiki before choosing abnormalities. this time none of my employees died and the game went very smooth. but then i played every day in the game basically the same way and most importantly i lost the thrill and excitement of venturing upon completely unknown abnormalities.   to regain the excitement i tried not to rely on wiki too much yet playing this game without wiki is so difiicult i have to grind multiple times before scoring a day. in addition to that the rougue-like feature of the game means that once you select an abnormality you cannot undo the process (unless you rewind to a very distant checkpoint) so selecting the wrong abnormality would cause tremendous amount of trouble in the early-mid game. i think the developers should definitely make the game more tolerant to mistakes so that players wont need to rely on wiki.  despite the criticisms lobotomy corporation is really a great game and i think it has done a extremely good job in capturing the essense of scp foundation series. i enjoyed the game a lot and would recommend this game to everyone.

ok first thing: is this a horror game?  yes but in a different kind of feel. the game puts you on edge especially near the beggining of the game when you dont know that many abnormalities (aka scps). one false move and you could loose a lot of employees. of course you could reset the day and more or less remove this fear (but thats not cool).   do you like management games?  yes: then this game does a great job at keeping you busy creating routines and strategizing workflow for your employees.  no: then prepare for what could be a nightmare of trial and error figuring out strategies for dealing with abnormalities.   do you enjoy juicy lore?  yes: good there is a lot of lore to go around for each abnormality (some more than others in my opinion).  no: well you don't have to read the lore.  do you enjoy the idea of starting over? yes: this game will run you into walls sometimes. no: this game will run you into walls.  are you prepared to nonstop think about a game? yes: good this game will make you think  no: get ready for at least one restless night of thinking about the game.  are you that kind of person that like cute anime-style females/males? yes: are you ready to protect your waifus?                    yes: protect the waifus                    no: you may not be ready no: no

do you like scps? no? do you like giving up 30 mins of work because of 1 misclick like a damn masochist? no? do you like beating up abnormalities like a damn sadist? no? well do you like ai waifus? do you like slime waifu who can kill the whole company in minutes? well just shut up stop thinking  and start managing.10/10

if you like management/hotel games with strange and dangerous creatures well this game was made for you. all the abnomality are really creative and well designed they all have interesting ability and temper. if i could give an advice to newcomer it's to not hesitate to restart games and use the checkpoint at your advantage since you keep your progress even if you roll back a few and or restart a new game.

i always seem to find myself consumed with games like this in a good way. lobotomy corporation isn't the kind of game where i could just namedrop another and say this is a lot like game x except y and z are different. it plays like a management/tycoon-like game but the depth (and intensity) of the gameplay gets really high up there the longer you go. this is not an easy game. expect employees to die resets to be done and day 1 restarts to be made (which are pretty much necessary for the true ending). the art style music and the story are phenomenal. i want to say so much about the story but it'd be spoilers galore so i'll just say the story goes from 0 to 10 to 100 to 100000 to 10000000 the longer you play. [strike]the translation is passable at times good most of the time but haltingly bad at others especially later on in the game. it isn't enough to detract from the ending though in my opinion.[/strike] (edit 5/4/20: they redid the entire english translation. it's beautiful now.) the intense difficulty spikes (especially near the end) are something i love in a video game but it felt almost cheap at some points and almost like glitches until i realized the game was supposed to work that way.  overall definite 9/10. i can see this game becoming somewhat of a cult classic because of its unique design and difficulty. after beating the game twice however i can confidently say that i want in on that lobotomy corp cult. you should give this cult a try too. also fuck you hod

10 hours in:  i got this~ none of my employee's are dying and i finally figured out how to play this game  *thomas the death engine shows up* choo choo motherfucker *half the facility becomes chunky salsa all over the walls*  well shit....   that's essentially the game in a nutshell. its definetly a game for specific types of gamers as you cannot really play this game casually if you want to do well in the mid-late stage of the game it becomes a memory game as its typically when you forget things your employee's die. while the game can be brutal at times its honestly a fairly forgiving game compared to other micromanaging nightmare games considering its actually very possible to recover if things go slightly pear shaped. you can just retry the day if half yer team gets wiped and if yer really boned jump back a few days keeping all the stuff you gained (besides employee's/experience) to try again maybe don't pick that abnormality that just keeps ruining your day.  it gets even better when you get the abilities to rapidly hire/train new meat-i mean employee's as at that point a few deaths are just to be expected and accepted (as it should be.) this is however a few hours into the game. while somewhat related thats the name of the game when it comes to features most have come to expect just not being there. most of them are locked until you research them like fast-forwarding. the only one i do have a gripe with is showing hp/sp as even when you research it to be visible its absurdly inefficient especially when they bundle up. pro tip: if your having a group of your employee's suppressing something and you want to make sure they run before they become paste or mad left click the entity and pause on the right it will display all your employee's hp/sp via scrolling in numeric values. play pause a few times and just watch their numbers like a hawk and you should be fine for the most part.  as for the abnormalities puzzle solving it is fairly basic to understand difficult to master the more the game progresses. you get 4 options for your employee's (or abilities which represent different aspects like hp and etc) to try and the higher the result the more boxes you get as energy and to buy tips or equipment once to learn everything about the abnormality. sometimes its a crap shoot as sometimes one of the 4 options often creates a bad result and depending on the abnormality that can range from no rewards/damage to instadeath and alot of abnormalities have conditions that lead to employee's deaths. thats why i said its a memory game as while the information may be learned and easily accessible i'm guilty of loosing a few employee's to forgetting something about an abnormality and sending them in to their deaths. if you are really stressed about not knowing what to do there is a wiki. i typically use it to double check how a abnormality works because translation problems (which suprisenly is not that bad) or not clear enough. but the main drive of this game is not knowing what to do and figuring it out.  unfortunetly i don't think this is a game one can truley grasp in 2-3 hours. most issues i had with the game devolved the more i played and rushing through the days will leave you under-equiped and under-skilled where the rng can screw you over much easier. the rng is only a problem when you don't have the skills/pattern down to take care of most problems. besides that most of my employee deaths have been forgeting something or sending employee's in under-skilled and watching timmy proceed to rip his own head off. i typically spend 20-30 minutes a day doing a little grinding as employee's improve their abilities by using them before moving on so that i can handle most things. this is a game intended to be played for 30+ hours easily i can tell. i'm still in the first of 3 sections. so if your looking to buy this game expect to sink alot of time into it~

after playing some scp related survival horror games having a game that plays from the other prospective is a really fun. the fact that you have to figure out anything about the abnormalities is really challanging but not impossible.  i really enjoy playing this game and would deffinetly recommend it.

good gameplay theme and style.  the translations are pretty terrible though which does make some parts of the game very difficult so be prepared for a few frustrating errors here and there (more an issue for gameplay than story as the story doesn't seem too important).  tends to encourage replaying each day of gametime to get a good result so probably not really rogue-lite. if you're into that style of playing it can be good fun striving for the perfect day only to have your favourite employee get decapitated by an anomaly at the end of it.

it's a super enjoyable game. there's a sense of enjoyment that comes with learning and adapting to each new abnormality that comes into my management. it has some serious scp vibes which i really like. also the weapon and armor system is badass. plus having abnormalities that bestow gifts makes your employees feel unique/ special. the art style also adds makes this game feel cute while still implementing that  element of horror.   the only issues i've come across is some minor issues with syntax. i am very pleased with this purchase.
neat little game love the idea of contain secure and protect so i;m a fan.

honestly i dont know where to start with this game. it's probably my favorite one right now and i can't stop focusing on it. everything from plot to gameplay to design to art; is extremely unique to me. i adore all of it so much and thats commendable from such a small scale first time (to my knowledge) team of makers. i don't know if i can provide an unbiased review really but i just wanted to say that i love this game with all my heart and that it's absolutely worth it if you find quirky strange scary complicated creatures endearing characters with a degree of tragedy and love to suffer in all the right ways. it's hard. but it's a good kind of hard.   a good comparison i can draw here about the difficulty is with dwarf fortress. dwarf fortress players have a term called 'fun'. you have 'fun.' it's hard as hell and the fact of the matter is you're going to die. you'll lose. you'll have rough days damn ballistic days. you'll lose employees you love you'll have days where you'll want to open-palm-slam don't touch me. but it's also a game that can be really satisfying. it's fair in it's difficulty imho. don't be afraid to pull up the wiki you'll need it. but i can't personally reccomend it if you can't stand that kind of gameplay.  beyond that and in a more personal note; this is a game that's done good for me. i bought it on a whim while it was still in beta several months back. i got it when i was dealing with some bad life stuff. i won't go into it but i wasn't doing great. that being said as i played more of this dug into it talked to people who also were fans got friends into it so on... it's helped me a lot. the game itself is great but the fans are even better. there's language barriers sure but you can tell everyone's so passionate. and damn that's a nice thing to see in a game community. it's probably irrelevant to the review but i feel like it ought to be said.   it's a lovely quirky fun and often emotional game that i adore and hope others give a good chance. it's worth it at least to me. but enough chat i suppose. i've got a bunch of monster-bees i gotta go wrestle back into containment. thanks for reading.
this game is excellent. if you have time to think for it you will be able to set your own lobotomy company~

very hard very good game 10/10 would recommend buying

an absolute masterpiece when it comes to any sort of game that centers around research and management with you actually doing the work of figuring out how things work and how to avoid disaster (although it's still up to you to make the calls whether to listen to your notes or not). you quickly go from a stable small and simple facility to a massive complex filled with employees specialized just for certain anomalies some people hired just for suppression of breached entities and a quadrillion things you must keep track of or else everything will come crashing down hard. though said quadrillion things aren't too complex; it's not like you have to keep track of inventory (save for which boxes you got from certain anomalies which can make armour and weapons for your agents and the number of these things you have on hand for them to use).  it well demonstrates the inspiration of the game namely scp in terms of how it is represented. though unlike the foundation you don't have death row inmates doing the science but rather your agents interacting right with the potentially game ending beings that may or may not take a few lives should things turn out for the worst.  it combines elements of horror quite well and each of the abnormalities are original in almost every aspect save those inspired by something (which even if they are they always have an original twist to their stories [spoiler]such as the warm-hearted woodsman who is a twisted vile version of the tin man from the wizard of oz[/spoiler])! if you enjoy scp you will love this game!  the only major critique i have for it is the english translation seeing that project moon self-translates these instead of going through a professional translation team. however as i have observed the game's english translation is actually higher quality that other games and media that have been self-translated from eastern asian languages. the use of pseudoscience terms is also a bit difficult for newbies to get a grasp of though it will click with the player at some point what these mean if anything at all.  8.1/10!  edit: thanks to the work of cool kids club a translation team who is chill and good i'm bumping my score up to a solid 9.6. their translation is excellent and even makes a few callbacks to some mis-translations from the old version that have become beloved community memes e.g. the bear-themed beer. while the pseudoscience terms may still throw new players in a loop i feel they've justified it. i'm bumping up the score a little more as after playing it i did some research and discovered a lot of the symbolism that ties this game together in both religion and philosophy. it's grown into a proper indie franchise given lots of care by a team with so much ambition that they released a webnovel a comic series a sequel and even a restaurant around their game.

this. this is probably the closest you will get to a scp/supernaturalanomoly management game. its also a damn well executed one at that.  for those new to any scp related topics...   you are basically a manager of a facility that aims to contain and exploit seamingly harmless but at times lethal abnormalities. like all facilities related to the supernatural the facility that hired you also have some shady business going on behind the scenes. as you spend your coming employment days you will first love it and then start to hate and question your very choice of applying for a job at lobotomy corporations.  now with the basic overview of the game out of the way.  is this worth your time and money? yes. yes it is!  buy it. buy it now!!  don't let the reviews about inaccurate translations scare you away. you are missing out on a brilliant experience!! and to be honest the translation is not that bad. of course it helps to know korean but its not chinese visual novel on steam level bad. you'll have no trouble understanding major story events and what lacks in language proficency it makes up for it with brilliant art style gameplay and atmosphere.  really just try it. this game is full of surprises and it will have you go into a panic attack when you least expect it.(until you remeber there is a pause button.)   now here are some things to keep in mind which will make your life easier.  (if you fail to resist the temptation of clicking purchase that is.)  -there is a wiki. it is now your best friend. it is your only friend. -don't trust the ai so much. remeber the wiki is your only friend. -there is a pause button. -don't get too attached to your staff...you don't want to be friends with them for various reasons. -and gat damit try not to name your employees... i know its hard... but it helps to see them as pieces of meat not ppl... -energy is all that matters. seriously if you met your daily qutoa go home asap. -did i mention there is a pause button?  hopefully some of the tips will help you through tough times at lobotomy corporations both physically and mentally.  if you still miraculously did not click the purchase button. then.. buy it. experience it. and you will be greatful that you spent money because some stranger on the internet told you to.

so far i really like the game. i dont know what all the hate about the game is about the translation is much better then what im used to working with i do know however that is has already been updated.   im really liking the scp cabin in the woods feel from it a lot and the ability to perma unlock things for future trys is what i like most.

so what is this game about? it's about a lab. it's about monsters. it's about running a lab with monsters. the monsters are scary. the monsters eat your people. when the monsters eat your people the friendly ai folks get unhappy. do not let the monsters eat your people. you should buy and play this game. it is a very good game.

another rare occasion that i have loved a game so much (and the community behind it has been phenomenal) that i feel i have to share my experience for you to judge for yourself.  first this game does not hold back. it's hard. but there in lies the fun so much chaos breaks out in different ways. just when you think you have it in the bag one little thing sets off the whole facility. each day passed feels like such a great success and the further you get the more gratifying it is that hard abnormalities in the beginning tend to ease back. there are checkpoint days so you don't have to fully restart if it gets too much and a tutorial they added upon full release. i've loved (almost) every minute of this game and if you like unique and violent micro managment games then check this out.  p.s. there are translation errors occasionally but nothing that has been over the top or unreadable.

i'm really really enjoying this game. every new anomaly (which you choose out of 3 given just one line of flavor text for each) is a new little puzzle to work out which tends to end in deaths as you try poking and prodding it in various ways literally testing how it reacts. key to this for me in the ability to pause freely at any time to issue orders and the completely unpenalized ability to restart each day now armed with the little bits of extra knowledge you gleaned from sending in your best employees to poke at that mysterious meat grinder's 'on switch'. restarting that day means all your employees are alive again and that you don't technically have that knowledge in the ever-unlocking encyclopedia but /you/ have learned it and i find that learning pretty compelling.  the little puzzles of each individual anomaly become part of the greater puzzle of managing your whole growing facility and new challenges arise from how they interact with each other. like i had a very dangerous one which would do bad things in no one had died by each 'meltdown' and i had another super easy to deal with anomaly which was pretty certain to escape after being worked on. so i'd let the easy monster escape and wait until it had killed enough disposable office workers to keep the more dangerous creature happy before sending my agents to easily suppress it.  the translation isn't ideal but the odd english it results in actually added to the atmosphere to me. it helped the sort of uncomfortable creepiness that i think works well for the game and to do a better job in english would probably need some really talented writers to get even something close to that same feeling across.  discovery is absolutely the best (and most rewarding) way to learn in this game which is extra suitable given the whole studying-super-dangerous-monsters setting of the game. while a better and more understandable translation for the tutorial would help a lot i was able to understand enough that i could learn through playing. even the managment notes for each anomaly's encyclopedia entry end up giving hints a lot of the time instead of foolproof instructions partly from the translation and partly (i assume) from design. i was learning new things about how some old piece of crumbling armor worked even 20+hours after i'd filled out it's encyclopedia entry to completion.  lobotomy corp really lets me scratch a perfectionist/min-maxing itch as i kit out each of my agents in the armor and weapons crafted from anomaly research and try to send them on specific monster research tasks to improve their various stats to max them out. there's an x-com feel to growing attached to certain agents which allows for fun spontaneous narratives you come up with yourself. like i ended up with a punch-girl and a magical-girl who became the backbone of my anomaly defense force. similar to how i play x-com though i would rather reset a day than let someone die which ends up in quite a lot of resetting given how dangerous things can be. however you really don't have to play that way.   losses can and do happen and it is absolutely not hard to recover from. if things do get too bad you could reset the day. if that's not enough you can reset to a 'memory imprint' checkpoint that happens every 5 days which takes you back to where you where for the checkpoint but you [keep all the research progress you did including weapons/armor made /since/ the checkpoint was made as well]. so even when things go bad you can try again and have more advantages going in maybe picking different anomalies this time while having the gear from the anomalies you picked before the reset to help you or pick the same ones again while starting with the bonuses to success rate that your previous research has given you.  you can even go all the way back to day 1 and you keep all that research and encyclopedia progress which i did myself after making the first 'run' basically a learning experience for the game and its mechanics. again like x-com restarting a 'campaign' after having learned about the game during the first (not very successful) one is super helpful and in lobotomy corp you even keep that useful encyclopedia progress!  after completing certain challenging encounters (i was /not/ expecting this game to essentially have boss fights!) you unlock helpful lasting advantages and one of the first makes the new agents you recruit come in at a much more experienced level which makes replacing even a veteran agent much much easier. so even if you're like me and are super tempted to reset when an agent (or soldier in x-com) dies there are things in the game to help that temptation relax.  it's not all good of course. there are some ui things i really wish the game had like an always visible list of agents with their hp/sp shown which would really help make sure no one's taking way more damage than i expected during an anomaly breach or a lab-wide 'ordeal' encounter. a list of each department's agents pops up when you select a thing they can interact with but it'd be really helpful to see that list all the time. that's probably my biggest complaint. the later days can take a long time but that's because /i/ take my time and feel compelled to squeeze as much leveling up as i possibly can in often specific stats on specific agents into each day as possible. ordering agents around during dangerous situations is not super precise which could be frustrating but is also something i've been able to work around.  i'm having a lot of fun with this game especially the ongoing discovery aspects and would recommend it if you are interested in the above and in a uniquely flavored management sim with plenty of capacity for micromanagement (and the ability to pause at any time with a tap of the spacebar to keep things from ever being overwhelming!). just know that if you play like me the game can be very time consuming.

a lot of fun if you're into the whole scp foundation thing and are a fan of strategy games with a shitload of micromanagement. starts off fairly simple (and bit slow) but quickly becomes what i'd consider a very deep strategy simulation game (aka a total clusterfuck).  it's extremely satisfying interacting with some big scary aleph-class scp (the highest threat level scps) that was slaughtering your employees and trashing your facility constantly at first like just another part of your routine after hours of cautiously testing out different interactions to see what you can safely do and what causes it to instead teleport to the center of the department and start playing classical music that makes everyone's heads explode all at once for (a frighteningly real) example.  my biggest complaints with the game are as follows: -several scps (not even necessarily high threat-level ones) are so absurdly powerful when they breach that they've either caused irreparable damage by the time you even get to them (see blue star) or are literally designed to be unfightable (see nothing there mad props to arcangela for doing it anyway tho). it really hurts a game focused around experimenting with spooky creatures and finding out how they work when said spooky creature forces you to restart the entire day if you fuck up interacting with it. this leads directly into my second gripe: -employees are way way too hard to hire train and gear up for a game where half the fun is watching big spooky monsters murder your staff in new and exciting ways. the game has a reset day mechanic which allows you to cut any losses you may have suffered and try the same day again for free but having to use that and lose like half an hour of progress because one of your high-level employees ate shit on accident absolutely trashes the pacing of the game at later stages.  other than that the game actually is a shitload of fun and certainly worth a buy if it looks at all interesting to you. if you are starting to get too frustrated with it there's a small-ish modding community that have come up with some balance changes to help with some of the aforementioned issues.

now that this game's english has been properly translated i recommend this game to anyone who enjoys management and multi-task games.  the general experience of the game is getting new monsters and objects and learning how they work. some trial and  error is required often resulting in the deaths of employees. once a monster is understood its threat is greatly reduced and it becomes manageable. the more dangerous monsters will enact a greater toll before this occurs. while inherently not a bad system it does have a few glaring flaws. the penalty for losing important employees is quite severe often game-ending. the more dangerous monsters are likely to simple devour crappy employees so you have to use your more experienced ones. since you can restart any round as many times as you want learning different monsters becomes a tedious process of feeding them your best employees until you understand them and then retrying the level with this knowledge. in other words this game starts to break down when you try to meta-game it. this would normally be okay but since losing a couple important employees can end a run there's almost no incentive to play the game the way it is meant to be played.  the longer the game goes the more you have to manage. some monsters will kill any employee who worked on them if that employee goes to work on another monster. so while you're dealing with a problem and assign such an employee without thinking about it you can kill them. some monsters can only be worked on by employees with very specific stats. this can be fun but it can also be overwhelming. this is made worse by the intentionally clunky interface and lack of basic commands to make controlling your employees easy. the interface is intended to be basic to force the player to use more focus increasing the danger of monsters that require focus in order to prevent disaster.  in order to win a round you have to generate enough resources. so in the backround while you're managing disasters you still need to generate that base income. it feels like macro play in an rts in a lot of ways (which isn't that surprising considering the korean origins of this game.)  you will probably enjoy the game if the following applies to you: 1. you like scp 2. you like games that force you to multitask 3. you like trial and error 4. you like starcraft or similar games where player focus is a resource  you probably won't like it if any of these apply to you: 1. you like to metagame meaning you like to figure out how a game works and use that against it. this game is not good for this at all 2. you expect a polished experience 3. you want an interface that makes controlling everything easy
insanely good and addicting. recommend it wholeheartidly.

another review was written so well i agree with her ( having about the same amount of game time so far) 100%   so i'll quote hers  if you're like me and wondering why the reviews seem 50/50 when the store front shows very positive.. it's because the majority of the negative reviews stem from the language disparity in this game. i speak korean and english fluently and i noticed a lot of grammatical errors in the localized (us) version. despite this it doesn't make the game unplayable. the errors are few and spread apart nothing critical.   gameplay is fun so far it's like you're the ceo of a monster babysitting company. you don't build anything but you earn resources/money by successfully watching over the monsters and cryptids. you slowly hire more 'employees' as you play and can upgrade them with items researched off the monsters/cryptids. these employees serve as your fighting force and monster nannies.   the graphics aren't the best but the artstyle is charming and cute. besides that this game is worth the $20 or cheaper if on sale. the developers patch often and make an effort to be vocal with the community. you can tell they're passionate for their baby of a game.   overall i give it an 8/10

all the security team is dead the resource team is panicing and the reserch team has gone mad. another job well done.  lobotomy corporation is a simple game to play but a hard game to master you are the manager of an energy corporation that had the bright idea of using literal monsters demons and eldric abomonations as a power source. your job is simple meet the energy quota for the day. the problem you only get energy from happy monsters and it is really easy to piss them off. the game is a balencing act of sending the right agents to the right cages and try to not let anyone die. notice i say try people will die...a lot. character creation is wonky since you use a skill point to change the character's looks but not their name (their might be a way to change an agents name i just could not find it) it reminds me of xcom's character creator but penilizes you for changing what your character looks like. the story is interesting and has a lot of subtext in it but half of the references i feel just went over my head. without a doubt this game feels like a passion project with constant updates and bug fixes good job project moon keep up the good work.  pros: really good at causing the player to panic. great monster designs. engaging gameplay. good music (mainly during breach). great art style. constant updates.  cons: monster choices can be the death of a playthru. difficulty spikes. the game sometimes crashes (usualy at the worst time). character creation is not the best. the tutorial is not the best at explaining things.  for your consideration: if you like scp but you want a game that instead of you escaping from a facility you are the manager of the facility then this game is for you. if you are looking for a horror game that is foucused on stradigy then this game is for you.    p.s. it is really sad when you trust a sentient pile of bodies more then sailor moon.

oh man so good.  very rich and deep strategy game.  rough-around-the-edges in the asian indie way.  also some very interesting rpg elements.  if you like strategy rpgs and you like the abnormality theme you will definitely love this game.  i've played for 100+ hours and the game is still surprising me every time i play.  edit:  having beaten the game and gotten the true ending i did want to add one more thing.  once you know what you are doing and your employees are beefed up (on ng+) days 1-45 are a breeze and days 46-49 are far too hard.  the difference is extreme.  it does follow a pattern of asian games ramping way up in difficulty at the end (actually it's usually after the end) of the game so that's the only explanation i can think of.  but seriously even knowing exactly what i am doing i have no interest in going through days 46-49 again.  i still recommend this game highly because i had such a great time almost the entire game and am very glad i played it.

a fun yet challenging game for both scp fans and random people alike. while it is very difficult at times and the tutorials can be lacking help from friends or the wiki definitely helps. especially the wiki. trust me you'll be having that thing on hand for some of the abnormalities.  this game is also heavy on micromanagement and domino effects can ruin a day. for example panicking employees alone can cause a chain reaction if unchecked and don't get me started on what happens if you forget about someone in the shelter... both these scenarios are avoidable but require a sharp eye and mind. so keep this in mind when purchasing.  overall it's a solid pick although the nature of this game might not be best for everyone.

lets see. if you like managing things or running little city simulators. then you'll probably like this game. its fun exploring the first few monsters and seeing what sticks. its entertaining to watch your little worker ants running everything in this ant farm.  however. the game needs a whole lot of polish before its actually accessible to all players.  i'll list the things that need to be addressed here. warning huge wall of text incoming.  1. needs a tutorial. i sat there for a few minutes trying to figure out how to the hell to do anything. no one really wants to flip through pages of a manual to figure out just how to get started.  2. tool abnormalities. some of them are timer based. usually 10-30 seconds of use will trigger an effect. (usually instant death) no one wants to die a lot just because there wasn't a built in timer ui in the game to tell you time is almost up.  3. instant death mechanics. usually this comes hand in hand with rng. you get bad rng. a lot of people end up dying. and you get frustrated. because its not because of failure of leadership. its because you rolled the dice and lost. one of the monsters will teleport and blast damage around it on impact. fine. i'll make sure they can survive one teleport. however it will teleport twice onto the same location therfor instant killing them. diminishing returns on effects would reduce the severity of bad rng. (two of the melt down missions adds rng on top of rng quadrupaling the frustration)  4. some things are too situational or useless in general. one tool kills your employees. but the energy output is kinda worthless for the trade off. some monsters exist only to annoy you. *cough meat lantern* one of the later abilities you get is a defense task force. it locks down the entire department. however most monsters in the late game will simply  teleport  into another department. making this ability very very very niche and almost pointless most of the time. the list goes on. so a lot of these pointless things will have to be rebalanced to give them a purpose later.   5. combat is kinda. well its clunky. your employees aren't intelligent enough to make real time decisions. so you have to tell them what to do. frankly its kinda akward to make them  dodge  a couple of macro buttons built into the ui should remedy this. example one. a monster that wrecks everything in melee range. so you want to send ranged attackers to deal with it. so you end up having to akwardly round them all up into one small room and then send them. i don't know what direction the developer is going with this game. cause you're a manager not a commander.  6. couple more user interface options would be nice. here's a few things they can add. (manager creates advanced ai. can't even develop a simple ui that could save employees?) a red box showing what abnormalities are breaching. a tab to show which employees are suppressing which or working with what monster. when you sending employees to suppress a monster it'd be nice if it would reccomend an employee with the appropriate armor or weapon to send. usually you end up having to remember exactly which employee is and what gear they have before you send them. maybe an indicator tab telling you who is about to die? put in a button to press to tell near death employees to run?  7. few extra things that'd be nice. being able to purchase armor or weapons at the beginning of the day. not the occuring day. sometimes you'll forget to purchase the ego gear before the day ends. which can really set you back. some of the clerks are kinda dumb.. slightly smarter self preservation ai would be nice. some hotkeys? so far mostly everything is controlled via mouse. (imagine playing starcraft with only your mouse.. i know right? what are we cave men?)  so is it worth playing or buying even? yeah but the game is so unpolished that newcomers that start playing literally will put it down from all the frustration and annoying things adding up. its still in early access so there's still hope yet. if the finished product as a nice ui reduce the severity of rng rebalance a few things to make them useful and most of the annoying traits are gone then you got yourself a pretty nice game.

pretty damn fun needs a lot of work but some cool core ideas that need expanding. if your a horror or dark sci-fi fan its worth a look but please pay attention to the not a sim warning its more like a puzzle game than anything just with blood like seriously sooo much blood. sorry devs blood does not equal horror it equals blood and that is fine if thats what your going for but might be a bit over the top same with the wifu thing or whatever its a bit over the top so if either of those things rub you the wrong way steer clear.

awesome game concepts cool abnormality designs quite interesting gameplay. a total thumbs up.

through its current development the game continues to impress me the more updates are added to it. fixes and new additions added in intervals as it is still an early access. the hesitation of losing your valued staff as you encounter new and dangerous abnormalities revolving around a gamble and tactic approach as the only way to maintain it better is to experiment with it. with recent updates brings returning old concept abnormalities and alpha gameplay features while making sure your better staff members stay alive from the uknown  the graphics and animation details of the game are nice too look at regarding a plot as to why it looks like that. the ui looking somewhat unique as your staff which you can customize have different actions which can be shown from a little worrisome to seeing your facility going into complete chaos to seeing a few cute actions from your staff which have a cute visual about them.  this game shows alot of potential and await for new implements and features as it continues through it's development.  ps. to have the true intended experience i recommend not searching through wikis about the game. this game is meant to be a roguelike as more dangerous abnormalies will want to destroy your facility. you keep what you learned as you start over.

the game is really good and i like it a lot. think of this game as scp facility manager simulator but with anime art style and a lot of plot. though i can't force you to follow and enjoy the plot but the game is a lot more fun with it imo. other than that the game has a lot of mechanics to learn and fun(and not so fun) abnormalities to discover learn contain and suppress. also a little warning but the game gets pretty difficult by the end but if you're willing to go through it then its totally worth it.
this game is hard to start but it gets easier over time. don't avoid it just because it's difficult

don't let the early access or the slightly stilted translation put you off. this game is an excellent resource simulator with a depth of different systems and a good variety of the monsters you need to contain and they all feel unique. the game could do with a tutorial but there's a manual (available in game from a link near the top of the screen while playing) that should give you everything you need to know.  this game is an absolute diamond in the rough don't pass over it like i initially did due to the rough-around-the-edges appearance. the studio is very open and honest about the development of their game and what they've made absolutely deserves the entry price for the game.

lobotomy corporation is a game where you manage monster's happiness worker's sanity and your time  because sometime you forgot to eat or sleep.  the game inspired by the scp idea of a secret organization containing monsters/object/entities. however this game have its own unique identity where all its monsters/object/entities (abnormalities they called it in this game) are unique and the corporation handling them have dark secrets. the game have lore and stories for each abnormalities which is quite diligent for the developers of this game.  even though this game is still in its 'earlier access' there are a lot of content in it and will still worth your time. the game does have some bugs translation error and grammar mistakes. but the developer keep updating it which is very good.  it is also a very hard game and punishable for someone who is a perfectionist like me. so prepare to be stress a lot. if you like mangement game that include bizarre abnormalities that could make you stress out till your head get bald i recommend this game.

quite honestly this is one of the funnest small title games that i've manage to stumble on. it's like a blend of foster's home for imaginary friends meets scp containment breach meets men in black (take that interpretation as you will). i‚Äôll try not to spoil anything here and the game is well worth it in my opinion.  - the art style is awesome good ui (minus one or two issues that can be seen during the pause menu but i‚Äôll get to that in a bit) good design for the characters and agents and interesting use of theming in each different department.  - sound wise the music is pretty good though it could use some diversity in the tracks during non-hostile moments instead of one looping song but it's a good song regardless.  - gameplay is mostly solid as you discover and unlock information of each creature you acquire in the facility. there is quite a bit of challenge to it as well as you must approach each and every breach carefully and it different ways to preserve agents and reduce as many casualties as possible if you‚Äôre looking for perfect runs. there is also a good use of the restart mechanic which is fair so far in how it works. buff and debuff whether they‚Äôre from the creatures equipment or the department is pretty explanatory. the only complaint i can find is responsiveness of the agents when directing them to disengage or engage a target. moving them manually doesn‚Äôt have much of an issue but clicking on their icon on the side to switch between suppressing and non-hostile is quite finicky. might i suggest buttons next to their icons to set to aggressive or passive modes when a breach occurs maybe?  -story‚Ä¶ i haven‚Äôt gotten too far into it (trying for a really perfect playthrough so a lot of restarting but it‚Äôs still going well). i‚Äôm on day 16. however the concept and premise behind it is well crafted though there are still some minor grammar issues and some possible mistranslations but i‚Äôm sure the devs will get to it eventually. there is also the issue of some dialogue and one or two menu buttons that go off screen out of their text box go behind or are block by other icons in the game. this is pretty major for the ui part that i mentioned where the text for the major reset isn‚Äôt visible. (i‚Äôm playing on max settings with a 1920x1080 monitor)  -controls: solid for the most part minus somethings mentioned from the gameplay section. pretty responsive and simple.  for a small indie title this has a lot of potential and promise in my humble opinion. i look forward to what the devs plan on doing next both in this game and future projects they have planned.
should given me some kinda warning about the ordeals first time encountering doubt made me shit myself.  p.s.: the music is fucking amazing.
i bought this game. i didnt get off of it till my computer shut off because i didnt realize the charger came loose 14 hours later. need i say more?

full review when the game is finished.   as of right now lobotomy corporation is a management/puzzle game with some interesting lore.  you manage abnomalities: who should interact with it how they should do it and when. send the wrong person and horrible things can happen. do the wrong interaction and horrible things can happen. meet certain prerequisites and horrible things can happen.  this is where the puzzle part comes in. each abnomality is effectively a puzzle you need to figure out. how do they work? do you need a specific action to trigger something good or bad? how they respond to certain interactions? once you figure out how they function you will either be much more in control of the situation or terrified of the thing you now must contain.  combat exists but it's very simple. select an abnomality that is breaching and then tell who should go deal with it. some kiting is possible and sometimes required.   but this is the game right now. hire employees give them weapon and suits to help them deal with abnomalities learn how to handle them and try to finish a day without someone important dying. don't worry too much. someone will always die. lots of people will die everyday. just make sure your best agents aren't among the casualty list.   extra credit for the music. it's pretty good. also the fact this is a management game with boss fights. they aren't related to combat no. these are boss fights that will test how well you can manage and contain abnomalities and they can be pretty intense.

i bought this on sale and knowing how good it is now i totally would've bought it full price. i normally hate management games so thats saying something about this. don't worry about terrible gameplay mechanics or lack of content (there are currently 85 abnormalities :0) because this game has it all figured out.

a fantastic horror game lobotomy corporation puts you in the shoes of an overseer in one of its many facilities. you will have to reset alot. you will have to die alot. the game is ment to be hard but that reset button is always there and its easy to regain progress if you know what your doing.

a story-focused scp management simulation. considering its art and play style it's not a game for everyone. but if you are into the story setting/deal with monster that kind of thing you might love it.  pros: + main story and the monster settings are intriguing it's pretty dark too despite the cartoon art style. + the bgms are great especailly the alert bgm is awesome + the game is pretty challenging but certain progress can be kept after each run so it gets easier as you play. + the game is pretty deep in both story and its content so far i have 27 hours in but there's still a lot of things for me to discover. + this game received continous update and support since last year its release and there are a few hardcore fans in different regions devoting to this game. (e.g. the chinese and japanese localization were done by its fans)   cons: - cartoon art style (although it's actually a part of story setting the cognition filter) - it's kind of difficult in the early runs takes some trial and errors if played blindly. - it can be a bit grinding if you want to play in power gaming mode. - also yes the alert bgm is great but most of time you won't be happy to hear it (lol  overall the game although being early-access is already a pretty good game as it is now. i would recommend this game at 8.8/10.

this game has aspects of a management simulator visual novel and rogue-lite. the feel of the game is cheerful at first as the first one you get is always 'one sin and one hundred good deeds' which will never kill you or go berserk. after the first day though it's mostly trial and error. with tons of possible beings to run into you have to spend your points into learning all you can about them through the management sections such as their names strengths weaknesses how they behave with different aspected employees stuff like that.   the developers are consistantly updating this game which is great as every update adds something that is worth playing.  as a note this game is very challenging. you will have to restart from day 1 several times but you get to keep all your  observational data from previous playthroughs and this includes any equipment that you unlock which is a great way to play.  each playthrough you will get more and more days through the game. this is not for the faint of heart.

it definitely looks like it could be a great game with a bit more work. a smarter person than i would probably get more enjoyment out of this than i do currently just because it's so damn difficult to know what you're supposed to be doing at any given moment. this game would really benefit from a tutorial or at least a hints/tips window every now and again. the art is lovely and there are some really interesting ideas and descriptions - however the writing or translation can be a bit poor sometimes so you don't really know what it all is supposed to mean.  i don't regret giving this game a go and i'll probably keep coming back to it to try it as it develops but at the moment i would say it's not worth the price tag in its current state. if this game gets a tutorial or a less steep learning curve that would be the thing that makes me recommend this more wholeheartedly. it is still worth checking it at the moment though.

so i normally don't review games while they are in early access but this game seems to be for some reason really obscure even though its really interesting game. i guess because its korean developer team so their english is bit stiff they don't have much of marketing or let's player coverage and because name of the game sounds bit weird. i mean what kind of company would name themselves lobotomy? vicisection & autopy inc? :p  anyway yeah its scp style game about managing monsters. goal is to gather energy by interacting with monsters until energy quota for the day is reached. its not a tycoon game you don't build facilities or anything though you do select which departments you upgrade next. game is trial & error in fun way before you interact with abnormality you don't know how they react to one of four different methods until you try it out so there is chance for some abnormalities to just kill your employeers if you picked wrong option but since you can retry each day as much as you want its on softer end of rogue-lites meaning you aren't punished harshly. real difficulty of game comes when you have gathered up enough abnormalities for their different rules and effects start to combo in really horrific ways making management harder. i also think that strongest class of abnormalities disable pausing option meaning you have to be really fast thinker if they breach the containment. on first playthrough its possible you end up gathering really hard to deal with abnormalities and thats fine if you start game over you keep encyclopedia entries and e.g.o. equipment so you know which abnormalities to avoid picking next playthrough.  that said game mechanics can be bit of obscure and i think there is severe need of tooltips. like i had no idea that white damage type can be used to heal panicked agents <_<

purchased during autumn sale. early access. 7 hours 0 bugs. played on mobile amd a10-9600p.*  no spoilers.   the game is fun. art is good. story is engaging. characters are appealing. music is appropriate-i hope for more.  didn't have a hard time playing. they released an explanation along with pictures.   +i liked the writing. it feels balanced. +tame abnormalities to gain access to better equipment.  =soundtrack is small.  -people who panic are considered dead. i hope this is ironed out.  -initial contact with many abnormalities instantly kills employees upon failure. i hope this is improved. -certain stressed abnormalities instantly kill employees. pointless to attempt improvement.   frequent improvements.  7 hours no bugs. ui could use improvement. studio seems to have fun and be passionate about their work and progress.   +frequent improvements. =recruitment screen was a learning experience. =does not seem to support touchpad for mobile users at this point in time.*  liked the game. hope to support project moon.  keep up the good work.   *detrimental to my experience as visuals were obscured. therefore stopped at 7 hours. example was able to determine how to handle abnormalities by reading or appearance.  after facility growth camera panned out. could not control camera.  no longer able to read or make judgement upon appearance and had to learn through  death of employees.  tried windows magnifying glass. also googled unity engine tools to zoom in for developers.  did not rectify. i do not own an extra mouse.  hope this helps mobile users considering the game. touchpad not supported at this time.

lobotomy corporation is the first offering of korean studio project moon (not to be confused with type moon) and it has to be said if they can consistently keep up this kind of quality they have a bright future ahead of them.  lobotomy corporation is a resource-management game with your chief resource being employees. failure to keep your employees in good health both physical and mental results in death panic and general nastiness but the best way to ensure that you complete the goal of each day (achieving at least a certain number of p.e. boxes) is to put your employees into situations likely to result in damage physical or mental or both. as a result after a certain point without proper management your facility is likely to end up having all its employees dying all manner of horrifying monsters invading and/or breaking loose and general chaos occuring which as anyone who's played dwarf fortress knows is immense fun for all involved (except possibly the employees).  the reason that your employees are going to be put into dangerous situations is the central concept of the game - abnormalities. abnormalities are monstrous entities some of which seem to have humanity's destruction as a priority. most of the captive ones seem content to stay in their cells - or at least they do provided that they aren't messed around with. unfortunately this messing around with them is essential to completing the goal for the day as many abnomalities when interacted with generate enkephalin - a possibly magical substance which according to in-game lore can be processed to generate enormous quantities of energy.  the sheer complexity of handling the numerous different abnormalities all of which have differing effects and restrictions upon interactions should make this a good pick for anyone who's played and enjoyed other resource- and time-management games.  while project moon are still actively building the game and i strongly suspect will continue to do so for a considerable length of time i feel like their attention to detail and clear desire to release a quality product make them a team to watch.
